prompt: Abir Al-Sahlani, a 47-year-old female, born on May 18, 1976, in Basra, Iraq, to a middle-class family with a father who was a leading opposition politician and a member of the Communist Party. She fled Iraq with her mother at the age of 15 and settled in Sweden, where she began her political career. Al-Sahlani holds a master's degree from Stockholm University and has worked as an information engineer and politician. She is a member of the Centre Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament since July 2019, serving on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Al-Sahlani has been a member of the Swedish Parliament from 2010 to 2014 and has been involved in various intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, LGBT Rights, and Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas. She has three children and is a Swedish citizen. Al-Sahlani has been recognized for her support of Iranian women and the Mahsa Amini protests, and in 2024, she won the "Best Speech" award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards.

Achille Variati is an Italian male politician born on January 19, 1953, in Vicenza, Italy. He is a graduate of the University of Padua. Variati has been affiliated with the following parties: Christian Democracy (till 1994), Italian People's Party (1994-2002), The Daisy (2002-2007), and the Democratic Party (since 2007). He was a member of the municipal council of Vicenza (1980-1995) and served as Mayor of Vicenza in two non-consecutive terms (July 12, 1990 - May 8, 1995, and April 29, 2008 - June 13, 2018). He was also a member of the Regional Council of Veneto (1995-2007) and President of the Democratic Party group (2007). Variati was elected as a Member of the European Parliament on October 13, 2022, representing North-East Italy.

Adam Bielan, a Polish politician, born on 12 September 1974 in Gdańsk, Poland, educated at the Warsaw School of Economics. He is a member of The Republicans party, having previously been affiliated with Solidarity Electoral Action (1997-1998), Conservative People's Party (1999-2001), Right Alliance (2001-2002), Law and Justice (2002-2010), Poland Comes First (2010-2011), Poland Together (2013-2017), and Agreement (2017-2021). He has held various offices, including Member of the European Parliament (2004-2014, 2019-present), Vice-Chair of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group (2009), Member of the Sejm (1997-2004), Deputy Marshal of the Senate (2015-2019), and Member of the Senate (2015-2019). He has represented the constituencies of Lesser Poland and Świętokrzyskie (2004-2009), Masovian (2009-2014, 2019-present), and Chrzanów (2001-2004).

Adam Sebastian Jarubas, a Polish politician, was born on 17 December 1974 in Busko-Zdrój, Poland. He served as the Marshal of Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship from 27 November 2006 to 22 November 2018, and was a member of the Polish People's Party. He was the party's vice-president from December 2012 and the official candidate for the office of President of Poland in the 2015 Polish presidential elections, receiving 1.60% of votes in the first round. He is an alumnus of Jan Kochanowski University.

Adina-Ioana Vălean is a Romanian politician born on 16 February 1968, in Băicoi, Prahova County, Romania. She is married to Crin Antonescu and has one child. Vălean has a master's degree in European Integration and Security Studies, postgraduate studies in National Security and Defence Management, and a bachelor's degree in Mathematics from the University of Bucharest. She is a member of the National Liberal Party and the European People's Party. Vălean was a Member of the Chamber of Deputies from 2004 to 2007 and a Member of the European Parliament from 2007 to 2019 and again from 2024. She served as the Chair of the European Parliament Committee on Industry, Research and Energy from 2019, as the Sixth Vice President of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2017, and as the European Commissioner for Transport from 2019 to 2024 under the leadership of President Ursula von der Leyen.

Adriana Maldonado López, a Spanish politician, born on January 9, 1990, in Pamplona, Spain. She is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 2, 2019, representing Spain. She served on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and joined the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic in 2022. She is part of the parliament's delegation for relations with the Pan-African Parliament since 2021. She is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital and the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises. Her term as a Member of the European Parliament ended on August 16, 2023. She was elected to the 15th Congress of Deputies in the 2023 Spanish general election from Navarre, starting her term on August 17, 2023.

Adrián Vázquez Lázara, a Spanish politician, born May 5, 1982, in Madrid, Spain. He has a degree in Law from the Complutense University of Madrid, a diploma in Japanese Language and Culture Studies from the International Studies Institute in Tokyo, an MA in International Relations from the University of Warwick, and a Degree in International Relations from Lindenwood University. Vázquez worked for the OSCE, NATO, the Korea Trade-Investment Promotion Agency, and as an advisor to former minister for foreign affairs Ana Palacio. He was chief of staff of the Citizens delegation to the European Parliament from 2015 to 2020. Vázquez was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 for Ciudadanos and re-elected in 2024 for the People's Party. He served as Chair of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs, spokesperson for Ciudadanos at the European Parliament, and Secretary-General of Ciudadanos.

Agnes Jongerius, a Dutch Catholic and Labour Party member, born on 4 November 1960 in De Meern, Netherlands, studied social-economic history at Utrecht University, graduating cum laude in 1988. She worked for the Federatie Nederlandse Vakbeweging from 1987 to 2012, serving as chair from 2005 to 2012. Jongerius has been a Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands since 1 July 2014, focusing on decreasing flexible employment contracts and promoting fixed ones. She is vice-chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and a member of the Delegation for relations with Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Jongerius is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, the URBAN Intergroup, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. She has served as a supervisory board member of PostNL and the Atria Institute, which specializes in gender equality and women's history, and was chairwoman of the latter. Jongerius is in a relationship with VPRO journalist Ger Jochems and lives in Utrecht.

Agnès Evren, a French politician of The Republicans (LR), born on 27 December 1970 in Paris, France, of Turkish origin, educated at Pantheon-Sorbonne University. Served as Valérie Pécresse's spokesperson in the 2015 regional elections and vice president of the Regional Council of Île-de-France in charge of education and culture. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, serving on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Petitions, as well as delegations for relations to Afghanistan, Palestine, and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development and the URBAN Intergroup. Served as spokesperson for Pécresse's Soyons libres movement in 2018, then chaired the Paris chapter of LR. Member of the Council of Paris, representing the city's 15th arrondissement since the 2020 elections, endorsed by Rachida Dati. Served as one of the spokespersons of Pécresse's campaign team in the 2022 French presidential election, and as one of the spokespeople of LR. Left the European Parliament in 2023, replaced by Laurence Sailliet.

Aileen McLeod, born 24 August 1971 in East Kilbride, Scotland. Education: University of Edinburgh (1993, German and European Community studies), University of Central Lancashire (2004, PhD). Politician of the Scottish National Party. Former Member of the European Parliament for Scotland (2 July 2019 - 31 January 2020). Former Member of the Scottish Parliament for South Scotland (5 May 2011 - 23 March 2016). Former Minister for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform (21 November 2014 - 18 May 2016).

Aldo Patriciello, male, born 27 September 1957 in Venafro, Italy. Former Vice President of Molise. Member of the European Parliament since 8 May 2006. Party affiliations: Christian Democracy (1979-1994), Italian People's Party, European Democracy, Union of the Centre, Forza Italia, The People of Freedom, new Forza Italia (until January 2024), Lega (since January 2024). Convicted to four months for illegal financing, not jailed.

Alessandra Basso, born 14 March 1967 in Treviso, Italy, is a member of the European Parliament representing North-East Italy, affiliated with the League party, serving from 2 July 2019 to 9 June 2024, and is a lawyer by profession, educated at the University of Bologna.

Alessandra Moretti, Italian politician, born 24 June 1973 in Vicenza, Italy, nationality Italian, profession Politician, Lawyer, educated at University of Urbino, member of Democratic Party, served as Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019 and previously from 1 July 2014 to 15 January 2015, representing North-East Italy, Member of the Italian Chamber of Deputies from 19 March 2013 to 25 June 2014, representing VII (Veneto 1), Deputy Mayor of Vicenza with delegation for education and youth, spokeswoman for Pier Luigi Bersani's campaign for the centre-left primary election in 2012, candidate for President of Veneto in 2015, member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Special Committee on Beating Cancer, Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and Parliament's delegation for relations with Japan, also part of the Spinelli Group and the European Parliament Intergroup on Children’s Rights.

Alessandra Mussolini, born December 30, 1962, in Rome, Italy. Occupation: Politician, actress (1970-2006). Education: Master of Science in medicine and surgery from Sapienza University of Rome. Party affiliations: MSI (1992-1995), AN (1995-2003), AS (2003-2009), AS (2004-2006), PdL (2009-2013), FI (2013-2018, 2019-present). Offices held: Member of the European Parliament (2004-2008, 2014-2019, 2022-2024), Member of the Senate (2013-2014), Member of the Chamber of Deputies (2008-2013, 1992-2004). Relatives: Granddaughter of Benito Mussolini, daughter of Romano Mussolini, half-sister of Rachele Mussolini, niece of Sophia Loren. Views: Initially opposed to LGBTQ+ rights, later became supportive, feminist, and advocate for women's rights.

Italian politician, Alessandro Panza, born 15 May 1982 in Domodossola, Italy, Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy constituency since 2 July 2019, term ending 9 June 2024, affiliated with the League party.

Alex Agius Saliba is a Maltese politician from the Labour Party, born on 31 January 1988 in Pietà, Malta. He studied at the University of Malta and worked as a journalist for One Productions from 2008 to 2013. Agius Saliba advised several Labour ministers from 2013 to 2017, headed the EU Secretariat from 2017 to 2018, and was a member of the Labour Party's National Executive for 10 years. He is a lawyer by profession. In 2018, he married Sarah Agius, former mayor of Żebbuġ, and they reside in Siġġiewi. Agius Saliba was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Malta in 2019, serving as rapporteur of the Digital Services Act and vice-president of the S&D group since 2021. He received a "Rising Star" award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2024.

Alexander Bernhuber, an Austrian politician, born on May 18, 1992, in St. Pölten, Austria, is a member of the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP). He attended the Federal Institute of Education and Research Francisco Josephinum and studied at the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences (BOKU) in Vienna. Bernhuber is a farmer, running a farm with crops and beef cattle in Lower Austria, and worked as an agricultural policy consultant in the Lower Austrian Farmers' Union. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing Austria, and serves on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Petitions, and the Committee on Culture and Education. He is part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs) and has published a booklet called the Austrian Green Deal, focusing on the implementation of the European Green Deal in Austria. His main objectives include protecting rural livelihoods, strengthening regional and high-quality food and food supply, and making rural areas more attractive. He is the youngest member of the European People's Party in the European Parliament.

Alexander Yordanov is a Bulgarian literary critic and politician, born on 13 February 1952 in Varna, Bulgaria, and is of Bulgarian nationality. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the constituency of Bulgaria, with a term starting on 2 July 2019 and ending on 15 July 2024.

Alexandr Vondra, Czech politician and diplomat, born 17 August 1961 in Prague, Czech Republic, married with four children, graduated in geography from Charles University in Prague in 1984, Doctor in Natural Sciences degree in 1985, dissident and Charter 77 signatory in the mid-1980s, imprisoned for two months in 1989, co-founder of the Civic Forum in November 1989, foreign policy advisor to President Václav Havel from 1990 to 1992, First Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs from August 1992, Czech Ambassador to the United States from 1997 to 2001, Government Commissioner for the preparation of the 2002 Prague summit of NATO from 2001 to 2003, Deputy Foreign Minister from January to July 2003, member of the Civic Democratic Party since 2006, Senator from Litoměřice from 2006 to 2012, Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2006 to 2007, Deputy Prime Minister for European Affairs from 2007 to 2009, Minister of Defence from 2010 to 2012, Member of the European Parliament since 2019, director of the Prague Centre for Transatlantic Relations at the CEVRO Institute in Prague from 2012 to 2019, instructor at the CEVRO Institute, pro-United States and wary of European integration.

Alexandra Geese, a German politician and member of the European Parliament for the Alliance 90/The Greens party since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Germany. Born on 1 July 1968 in Lippstadt, West Germany, and educated at Cologne University of Applied Sciences. Prior to her political career, she worked as an interpreter in Italy from 1987 to 2010 and at the European Parliament from 2015 to 2019. She has served on the Committee on Budgets, Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age. She is also part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with Iraq and Latin America, and a member of the European Internet Forum, European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, and European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights. She has been involved in coalition negotiations in Germany, including the 2021 traffic light coalition and the 2022 North Rhine-Westphalia state elections. She has three daughters and lives in Bonn's Kessenich district.

Alex Phillips, a British Green Party politician, born 9 July 1985 in Liverpool, England, UK, of Jewish heritage, with a degree in French Studies from the University of London Institute in Paris and a PGCE from the UCL Institute of Education. She was a Labour Party activist from 2001-2003, then joined the Green Party in 2003 due to Labour's decision to invade Iraq. She was a Brighton and Hove City councillor from 2009-2023, representing the Goldsmid ward from 2009-2015 and the Regency ward from 2015-2023. Phillips was Mayor of Brighton and Hove from 22 May 2019 to 15 May 2020, and a Member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. She worked as a French and German language secondary school teacher, and as the policy lead at the HIV and sexual health charity, Terrence Higgins Trust. Phillips is married to Tom Druitt, a fellow Green Party councillor and managing director of The Big Lemon, with whom she has two children.

Alexandra Phillips, a journalist, broadcaster, and former politician, was born on 26 December 1983 in Gloucester, England. She studied English literature and philosophy at Durham University and broadcast journalism at Cardiff University. Phillips worked as a local journalist for ITV and BBC Wales before joining the UK Independence Party (UKIP) as head of media. She left UKIP in 2016 and joined the Conservative Party, then the Brexit Party in 2019, and Reform UK in 2023. Phillips served as a Brexit Party member of the European Parliament for the South East England constituency from 2019 to 2020. She was a member of the Committee on Development and the delegation for relations with South Africa. Phillips has also worked as a presenter on GB News and talkRADIO, and has contributed to The Daily Telegraph. Her notable works include "McCoy & Phillips", "The Great British Breakfast", "The Afternoon Agenda", and "We Need To Talk About...".

Alexis Georgoulis, a Greek actor and politician, born on 6 October 1974 in Larissa, Greece. His father worked for OPAP and his mother taught kindergarten. Georgoulis served in the Hellenic Army and studied civil engineering at the National Technical University of Athens. He began acting in 1996 and gained fame with his co-starring role in 2001's Eisai to Tairi mou. He is a member of Syriza and was elected to the European Parliament on 26 May 2019 for a four-year term, with a platform that included promoting Greek cinema. He was expelled from Syriza and The Left in the European Parliament – GUE/NGL in 2023 due to an alleged case of sexual harassment. His term in the European Parliament started on 2 July 2019 and is set to end on 16 July 2024.

Alfred Sant, a Maltese politician and novelist, born on February 28, 1948, in Pietà, Malta. Education: University of Malta (BSc, MSc), École nationale d'administration (MPA), Boston University (MBA), Harvard University (DBA). Leader of the Labour Party from 1992 to 2008. Prime Minister of Malta from 1996 to 1998. Leader of the Opposition from 1992 to 1996 and 1998 to 2008. Member of the European Parliament for Malta from 2014 to 2024. Published several books, including novels, plays, and non-fiction works. Awarded Companion of Honour of the National Order of Merit in 1996.

Alice Bah Kuhnke, a Swedish politician, born on 21 December 1971 in Malmö, Sweden, to a Gambian father and a Swedish mother. She was raised in Horda, Jönköping, and attended a track-and-field-oriented high school in Växjö. Bah Kuhnke is a former television presenter, hosting shows such as "Disney Club" and "Kalla fakta." She has been married twice, first to Henrik Johnsson from 1998 to 2002, and then to Johannes Kuhnke from 2003 to 2023, with whom she has three daughters. Bah Kuhnke was the Director General for the Swedish Agency for Youth and Civil Society from 2013 to 2014 and worked as General Secretary for Fairtraide Sweden from 2004 to 2007. She served as Minister of Culture and Democracy in the Löfven Cabinet from 2014 to 2019 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing the Green Party. She is currently the Vice-Chair of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance and serves on several committees, including the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality.

Alícia Homs Ginel, a Spanish politician, born 15 October 1993 in Palma de Mallorca, Spain, obtained a degree in Political Science and Public Management at the Autonomous University of Barcelona, worked as technical advisor to the Regional Ministry of Labor of the Balearic Islands, elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019, served on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas and the Spinelli Group, member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party.

Alin Mituța is a Romanian politician, born on May 24, 1984, in Novaci, Gorj County, Romania. He holds a master's degree in European affairs from Sciences Po Paris, a BA in political science from Paris Nanterre University, and a BA in international relations and European studies from the National University of Political Studies and Public Administration. He is a member of the REPER party since 2022 and is affiliated with the Renew Europe Group in the European Parliament. Mituța has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since December 28, 2020, and is part of several committees, including the Committee on Budgetary Control, Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and the Special Committee on Beating Cancer. He has proposed and negotiated the abolition of extra-fees for intra-EU communication and has called for the European Commission to stop the United Kingdom from holding EU nationals in immigration removal centers.

Alviina Alametsä, a Finnish politician of the Green League, born on 29 September 1992 in Tampere, educated at Jokela High School and the University of Helsinki with a specialization in world politics, worked as a project leader at Mental Health Partnership Finland, assistant of Pekka Haavisto in the Finnish Parliament, and city councillor of Helsinki, chairs its equality committee, served as a Member of the European Parliament from 1 February 2020 to 15 July 2024, and as a Member of the Finnish Parliament for Helsinki since 16 July 2024.

Alyn Smith, born 15 September 1973 in Glasgow, Scotland, is a Scottish politician and member of the Scottish National Party (SNP). He studied law and European law at the University of Leeds, spent a year on the Erasmus Programme at the University of Heidelberg, gained a master's degree in European studies from the College of Europe, and received a Diploma in Legal Practice from Nottingham Law School. He qualified as a lawyer with Clifford Chance and worked with Anderson Strathern. Smith was a director of Turning Point Scotland and a trustee of LGBT Youth Scotland. He is Honorary Vice President of the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (SSPCA). He was elected as an MEP for Scotland in 2004 and served until 2019, then as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Stirling from 2019 to 2024. He has been serving as SNP Spokesperson for Europe and EU Accession since December 2022. He is openly gay and married his long-time partner Jonathon Ramsay in 2023.

Ana Collado Jiménez, a Spanish politician from the People's Party, born on 8 February 1984 in Ávila, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 6 September 2023, representing Spain, replacing Esteban González Pons.

Ana Miguel Marques Neves dos Santos, born 12 September 1981 in Coimbra, Portugal, is a Portuguese politician and lawyer who is a member of the Social Democratic Party. She served as a member of the Assembly of the Republic for Aveiro from 25 October 2019 to 28 March 2022. She became a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal on 2 April 2024, succeeding Paulo Rangel, and served until 15 July 2024.

Ana Maria Miranda Paz, a Spanish politician from Galicia, was born on 2 May 1971 in Cuntis, Galicia, Spain. She is a member of the Galician Nationalist Bloc and has served in the European Parliament three times. Miranda Paz holds a degree from the University of Santiago de Compostela and works as a lawyer and politician. She was first elected to the European Parliament in 2012 as a member of the Europe of the Peoples–Greens electoral alliance, replacing Oriol Junqueras. Miranda Paz served until 2013. In the 2014 European elections, she stood on the list of The Peoples Decide alliance and took over the seat in February 2018, joining the parliamentary group of the Greens/European Free Alliance in March. In the 2019 election, the Galician nationalists were allied with the electoral coalition Ahora Repúblicas, and Miranda Paz replaced Pernando Barrena in September 2022.

Anabela Lopes Rodrigues, a Portuguese politician from the Left Bloc, born 18 October 1976, member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 26 March 2024, replacing Marisa Matias, first black MEP from Portugal.

Anders Primdahl Vistisen, born 12 November 1987 in Vridsted, Central Denmark Region, Denmark, is a Danish politician and Member of the European Parliament. He is a member of the Danish People's Party and has been affiliated with the European Conservatives and Reformists and the Identity and Democracy Party. Vistisen was the national chairman of the youth section of the Danish People's Party from 2012 to 2015. He studied at the University of Berlin. Vistisen was a member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2014 to 1 July 2019 and was re-elected on 22 November 2022, representing the constituency of Denmark.

Andor Deli, born 2 May 1977 in Bečej, Serbia, is a Hungarian politician from Vojvodina, Serbia. He is a member of the European People's Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Hungary's Fidesz since 1 July 2014, representing the Hungary constituency. Deli was educated at the University of Novi Sad Faculty of Law, where he earned a degree of jurist in 2000, passed a judicial examination in 2004, and earned a master's degree in 2008. He worked for the Provincial Secretariat for Education, Administration and National Community in the Autonomous Province of Vojvodina from 2002 to 2014 and was appointed head of the secretariat and Vice President of the Government of Vojvodina in 2012. Deli is a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the Delegation to the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee, and a substitute member of the Committee on Regional Development and the Delegation to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. He is affiliated with the Alliance of Vojvodina Hungarians and Fidesz parties. Deli has two daughters and can be found online at https://deli.fidesz-eu.hu/hu/.

Andrea Bocskor is a Hungarian politician and Member of the European Parliament from Hungary, born on 11 August 1978 in Berehove, Ukrainian SSR, Soviet Union. She is a member of Fidesz, has Hungarian and Ukrainian citizenship, and lives in Berehove, Ukraine. Her educational background includes a degree in English-History from the Trascarpathian Hungarian Teachers' Training College and a PhD from ELTE-BTK in Budapest in 2010, as well as the title of Candidate of Historical Sciences from the Institute of Ukrainian History-National Academy of Science in Kiev in 2013. Before becoming an MEP in 2014, she worked as a docent at the Ferenc Rákóczi II Transcarpathian Hungarian Institute and Director of the Lehoczky Tivadar Institute. Her main political aims include representing the Transcarpathian Hungarian minority in the EU, promoting the rights of national minorities, European cultural and linguistic diversity, and ensuring the use of minority languages at the European level, as well as supporting European integration and the political and economic stability of Ukraine.

Andrea Caroppo, born 26 June 1979 in Minervino di Lecce, Italian nationality, lawyer by profession, educated at Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore, member of the South Ahead party, elected to the European Parliament representing Southern Italy since 2 July 2019.

Andrea Cozzolino, Italian politician, born 3 August 1962 in Naples, Italy, married to Anna Normale with three children. Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2009, representing the Southern Italy constituency. Party affiliations: Italian Communist Party (PCI) until 1991, Democratic Party of the Left (PDS) from 1991 to 1998, Democrats of the Left (DS) from 1998 to 2007, Democratic Party (PD) since 2007, Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) since 2009, and European Socialist Party (PES) since 2014. Served on various committees including Committee on Regional Development, Committee on Budgetary Control, Committee on Budgets, Committee on Petitions, and Subcommittee on Human Rights. Vice-president of the Committee on Regional Development and rapporteur for the European Parliament on the proposal for a Regulation on the Regional Development Fund for 2021–2027 and on the Cohesion Fund. Involved in the Qatargate scandal, charged with bribery, membership of a criminal organisation, and money laundering, currently conditionally released from house arrest.

Andreas Glück, a German politician, born on March 8, 1975, in Münsingen, West Germany. He is a member of the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. He studied human medicine at the University of Tübingen. Glück worked as a surgeon and was a member of the Landtag of Baden-Württemberg from 2011 to 2018. Since 2019, he has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament, representing Germany. He is part of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Freedom of Religion or Belief and Religious Tolerance, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Andreas Schieder, born 16 April 1969 in Vienna, Austria, is a male politician from the Social Democratic Party of Austria. He has one son. He graduated with a master's degree in economics from the University of Vienna. He was a member of the National Council from 2006 to 2019. He served as state secretary in the Ministry of Finance from 2008 to 2013 under Chancellor Werner Faymann. He was the parliamentary leader of the Social Democratic Party in the National Council from 2013 to 2017. Since 2019, he has been a Member of the European Parliament, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs. He has been a deputy chairman of the Social Democratic Party of Austria since 2016. He is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the URBAN Intergroup. He was awarded the Grand Decoration of Honour in Silver with Sash in 2011.

Andreas Schwab, born 9 April 1973 in Rottweil, Baden-Württemberg, Germany, is a German politician and member of the European Parliament for Germany, representing the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2004, serving on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, where he deals with network and information security. He is the European People's Party Group's coordinator on the committee. He has also served as rapporteur on the ECN+ Directive and the Digital Markets Act. Schwab is a member of the European Parliament's Sky and Space Intergroup and the European Parliament Intergroup on Biodiversity, Countryside, Hunting and Recreational Fisheries. He holds memberships in various organizations, including the University of Freiburg's Advisory Board, the Franco-German Institute's Board, and the European Council on Foreign Relations. Schwab has received awards such as the "Young European of the Year" in 1998 and the Federal Cross of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany in 2018. He is Of Counsel with CMS Hasche Sigle since 2009 and has studied at the University of Freiburg, Sciences Po, and the University of Wales.

Andrei Petrov Slabakov, a Bulgarian politician, was born on 13 August 1960 in Sofia, Bulgaria. He is a member of the VMRO – Bulgarian National Movement party and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Bulgaria constituency, with his term set to end on 15 July 2024.

Andrew England Kerr is a British politician born on 23 September 1958 in Birmingham, Warwickshire, England. He is married to Sally Annaliese England Kerr. He qualified as a solicitor in 1985, specialising in property law, and has worked as a director of England Kerr Hands & Co, Englands Estate Agents, and England Safety Ltd. He voted for Brexit in the 2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum and supports Brexit due to concerns about the European Union's corruption and undemocratic nature. He was elected as a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands constituency in the 2019 European parliamentary election but became an independent MEP on 29 September 2019 after the Brexit Party withdrew the whip due to a likely conflict of interest. He served as a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and was part of the delegation to the EU-Kazakhstan, EU-Kyrgyzstan, EU-Uzbekistan and EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees and for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020.

Andrey Kovatchev is a Bulgarian politician, born on 13 December 1967 in Sofia, Bulgaria. He holds a degree in Biology from Saarland University, Germany, where he also obtained his PhD. Kovatchev is a member of the European People's Party (EPP) and the Bulgarian party GERB. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the Bulgaria constituency. Kovatchev has held various positions, including Quaestor of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2019, vice-chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and chairman of the Union of European Federalists in Bulgaria. He is a strong supporter of European integration, federalism, and the single currency. Kovatchev has expressed concerns about discrimination in North Macedonia, especially towards citizens who declare their Bulgarian identity, and has advocated for the preservation of cultural heritage and the opening of communist archives. He supports a visa-free regime between the EU and Western Balkan countries and has proposed merging the positions of President of the European Council and the European Commission into one President of the European Union, elected directly by European citizens.

Andrey Grishev Novakov, a Bulgarian politician and member of the European Parliament, representing the GERB party and affiliated with the European People's Party. Born on July 7, 1988, in Pazardzhik, Bulgaria, and grew up in Mominia Klisura. He studied at Southwest University "Neofit Rilski" in Blagoevgrad, acquiring a bachelor's degree in Public Administration in 2011 and a master's degree in Law in 2014. He specialized in the United States within a program for young leaders in 2014. Novakov was President of the Student Parliament at Southwest University, chief editor of the student newspaper "Vestnikat", and deputy chairman of European Democrat Students. He worked as a public relations expert in the municipality of Blagoevgrad and held positions as regional coordinator of Youth GERB, International Secretary of Youth GERB, and candidate for member of the Bulgarian parliament. Novakov is a member of the Committee on Regional Development, substitute-member of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on budgetary control. He is a laureate of the Forbes magazine ranking "30 under 30" for most successful young people in section "Politics". He was elected co-chair of the Commission on Sustainable Development in EUROLAT in 2015. He is married to Tatyana Novakova from 2017 to 2023 and has one child.

Andris Ameriks, born March 5, 1961, in Jūrmala, Latvian SSR, is a Latvian politician and economist who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He is a former deputy mayor of Riga. He was a member of the Communist Youth organization of the Latvian SSR during his youth. He has been a member of the Riga City Council since 2001, serving as the Deputy Chairman of Riga City Council from 2010 to 2018. He was a member of the Saeima from 1993 to 1998, representing the National Harmony Party and later, Democratic Party "Saimnieks". He is known for receiving significant income from investments in payday loan companies. In 2017, he reported an income of 616,386 EUR and 35,250 USD. He resigned as deputy mayor of Riga City Council in 2018 amid corruption allegations. He has been serving on the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Petitions in the European Parliament. He is part of the Parliament’s delegation to the EU-Kazakhstan, EU-Kyrgyzstan, EU-Uzbekistan and EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees and for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia. He is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. He is a member of the "Honor to serve Riga" party since 2012 and is married to Ginta Amerika.

Andrius Kubilius, a Lithuanian politician, born on December 8, 1956, in Vilnius, Lithuania. He is a physical engineer and politician by occupation. Kubilius is married to Rasa Kubilienė, a violinist in the Lithuanian National Symphony Orchestra, with whom he has two sons and three grandchildren. He speaks Lithuanian, English, and Russian. Kubilius studied at Vilnius University, graduating from the Faculty of Physics in 1979 and completing postgraduate studies from 1981 to 1984. He became a member of the pro-independence Sąjūdis movement and later the Executive Secretary of the Sąjūdis Council. Kubilius joined the Homeland Union – Lithuanian Christian Democrats in 1993. He served as Deputy Speaker of Seimas from 1996 to 1999, Prime Minister of Lithuania from 1999 to 2000 and again from 2008 to 2012, Leader of the Opposition from 2012 to 2016, and Chairman of the Homeland Union from 2003 to 2015. Since 2019, Kubilius has been a Member of the European Parliament, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy.

Andrus Ansip, born 1 October 1956 in Tartu, Estonia, is a member of the Estonian Reform Party. He studied chemistry at the University of Tartu, graduating in 1979. Ansip worked in various roles including as an engineer, instructor, and head of the organisational department of the Tartu District Committee of the Estonian Communist Party. He also held positions in banking and investment ventures, serving as a member of the board of directors of the People's Bank of Tartu, chairman of the board of Livonia Privatisation IF, and CEO of Investment Fund Broker Ltd.

Ansip entered politics in 1998, serving as Mayor of Tartu until 2004. He then became Chairman of the Estonian Reform Party and Minister of Economic Affairs and Communications. In 2005, he was appointed Prime Minister of Estonia, a position he held until 2014. During his tenure, he oversaw the relocation of the Bronze Soldier of Tallinn, which led to mass protests and rioting.

Ansip was elected to the European Parliament in 2014 and served as Vice-President of the European Commission and European Commissioner for the Digital Single Market from 2014 to 2019. He was re-elected to the European Parliament in 2019 and has since served on various committees, including the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age.

Ansip is married to gynecologist Anu Ansip and has three daughters. He has received several awards, including recognition for his service in the fight for Estonian freedom and national idea. Ansip has also been a member of the Estonian voluntary home guard organisation Kaitseliit since 2009.

Andrzej Halicki, a Polish politician, born on 26 November 1961, educated at SGH Warsaw School of Economics, member of the Civic Platform party. He served as Minister of Administration and Digitization from 22 September 2014 to 16 November 2015. He was a member of the Sejm, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and was chairman from 24 June 2009 to 2012. He was also the spokesman of the Civic Platform parliamentary group from October 2009 to 2010. He was Vice-President of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe from 2012 to 2014. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Foreign Affairs. He is the Vice-Chair of the European People's Party in the European Parliament, serving alongside multiple others, since 19 June 2024.

András Gyürk, Hungarian politician, born 2 December 1972 in Budapest, Hungary. Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2004, representing Hungary. Member of Fidesz and Patriots for Europe. Served as Deputy leader of Fidesz's parliamentary faction, Vice chairman of the Hungarian Parliament's Committee on Youth and Sport, and Chairman of Fidelitas, the youth organization of Fidesz. Member of the Hungarian Parliament from 1998 to 2004, and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe from 1998 to 1999. Member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Delegation to the EU-Armenia, EU-Azerbaijan and the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Cooperation Committees, and substitute for the Delegation for relations with the Arab Peninsula and the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. Married with two children. Educated at Franciscan Secondary School, College of Finance and Accountancy, and Eötvös Loránd University, Faculty of Humanities.

André Jorge Dionísio Bradford, a Portuguese journalist and politician, was a member of the Socialist Party. He served as a Member of European Parliament for Portugal from 2 July 2019 until his death on 18 July 2019. Born on 30 November 1970 in Ponta Delgada, Azores, Portugal, to an Azorean mother and an American father, Bradford graduated in Social and Cultural Communication and obtained a master's degree in Political Science and Theory. He worked as a journalist at Açoriano Oriental and Diário de Notícias before starting his political career in 2000. Bradford held various political offices in the Azores and was appointed to the agriculture committee and the delegation for EU-U.S. relations during his term as MEP. He died from cardiac arrest on 18 July 2019, at the age of 48, in Ponta Delgada, Azores, Portugal.

André Rougé, a French politician, was born on 23 December 1961 in Paris, France. He studied law at Paris-Panthéon-Assas University and received military training at the Ecole spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr. He served as a soldier in the 6th Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment and later worked as a journalist-reporter, covering the Sandinista rebellion in Nicaragua. Rougé held various positions, including director of external relations at the Bouygues group and consultant for companies. He is the founder and chairman of the think tank Les Horaces. Rougé is a member of the National Rally and has held several political positions, including parliamentary assistant, chief of staff, and special adviser. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, serving on the Committee on Regional Development and the Delegation for relations with the Federative Republic of Brazil. Rougé is married to Florence Goulet, an MP for the Meuse, and they have a son. He is a national delegate for overseas France and a member of the National Rally's national bureau.
Andżelika Możdżanowska, a Polish politician, is a Member of the European Parliament representing the constituency of Poland for the Law and Justice party.

Angel Dzhambazki, a Bulgarian nationalist politician, was born on 21 March 1979 in Sofia, Bulgaria. He is a graduate of Sofia University, where he specialized in international studies. Dzhambazki is a member of the VMRO - Bulgarian National Movement and the European Conservatives and Reformists Group. He served as a Member of the Sofia City Council from 19 November 2007 to 29 May 2014 and as a Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024, representing the Bulgaria constituency. Dzhambazki has been involved in several controversies, including making racist, xenophobic, and homophobic comments, and has been accused of abusing his influence and forensic manipulation. He has also been detained at Sofia Airport for attempting to bring a Makarov pistol onto a flight and was caught driving under the influence of alcohol. Dzhambazki has a daughter named Bilyana and has volunteered at the COVID ward in the Military Medical Academy during the COVID-19 pandemic. He is fluent in Bulgarian, English, German, and Russian, and enjoys mountaineering. Dzhambazki has expressed strong views against multiculturalism, eurobureaucracy, and the Istanbul Convention against domestic violence, and has been a vocal supporter of traditional Christian values.

Angelika Niebler is a German lawyer and politician born on 18 February 1963, in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. She is a member of the Christian Social Union in Bavaria, part of the European People's Party. Niebler has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1999 and has been her party's deputy chairwoman since 2015. She has a Doctor of Law degree, with a dissertation on "The use of expert systems in legislative procedure." Niebler has practiced law with various firms, including Lovells, Beiten Burkhardt, Bird & Bird, and Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. She has also been a visiting lecturer on Intellectual/Industrial Property Rights at the Munich University of Applied Sciences since 2016. Niebler is married to Michael Niebler and has been a member of several corporate boards, non-profit organizations, and has received various awards, including the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany in 2017.

Angelika Winzig, born 9 May 1963 in Attnang-Puchheim, Austria, is an Austrian politician and member of the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP). She holds a degree from the Wirtschaftsuniversität Wien. Winzig served as a member of the Austrian National Council from 2013 to 2019, where she was part of the Committee on Economic Affairs, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defense Committee, Budget Committee, and Finance Committee. Since 2 July 2019, she has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing Austria. In the European Parliament, she serves on the Committee on Budgets, Committee on Budgetary Control, and is a substitute member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Winzig is also part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs).

Angelo Ciocca, born 28 June 1975 in Pavia, Italy, is a member of the League party and served as a Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy from 7 July 2016. He was involved in controversies including suspected ties to the 'Ndrangheta organization in 2009 and was sentenced to 1 year and 6 months for his role in the Lombardy Region reimbursement scandal in 2019.

Anja Haga, born 25 December 1976 in Drachten, Netherlands, is a Dutch politician of the Christian Union party. She studied at the University of Groningen, obtaining a degree in linguistics and a postgraduate degree in European policy making from the Vrije Universiteit Brussel. She started her career as a clinical linguist and later worked in the private sector. She joined the Christian Union party in the early 2000s and served as a member of the Provincial Council of Friesland from 2010 to 2015, focusing on issues of public transport, sustainability, and healthcare. She was re-elected in 2011 and 2015, and served as parliamentary leader from 2011 to 2015. In 2015, she joined the municipal executive of Arnhem as alderperson, focusing on sustainability, migration, and healthcare. She resigned in 2017 due to disagreements over a street prostitution zone. She worked for forestry management organization Staatsbosbeheer from 2017 to 2023 and joined the board of A Rocha Netherlands, a Christian nature conservation organization, in 2020. She was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2023, succeeding Peter van Dalen, and served until 2024. Her committee memberships include the Committee on Fisheries, Subcommittee on Human Rights, and Delegation for relations with the countries of South Asia.

Anja Hazekamp, a Dutch politician and Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands, representing the Party for the Animals and the European United Left–Nordic Green Left. Born on 21 January 1968 in Vlagtwedde, Netherlands. Graduated in biology from the University of Groningen in 1995. Worked for various animal welfare organizations, including the Dutch Society for the Protection of Animals and the Seal Rehabilitation and Research Centre. Served in the States of Groningen from 2007 to 2014 and the House of Representatives of the Netherlands in 2012. Member of the European Parliament since 2014, re-elected in 2019 and 2024. Sits on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Delegation for relations with Japan. Advocates for animal welfare, environmental protection, and sustainable development.

Ann Widdecombe, a British politician, has the following characteristics and background: 

Born on 4 October 1947 in Bath, Somerset, England. 
Graduated from the University of Birmingham with a degree in Latin and from Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford, with a degree in philosophy, politics, and economics. 
Converted from Anglicanism to Roman Catholicism in 1993. 
Member of the Conservative Party from 1976 to 2019, the Brexit Party from 2019 to 2021, and Reform UK since 2023. 
Member of Parliament for Maidstone (1987-1997) and Maidstone and The Weald (1997-2010). 
Member of the European Parliament for South West England (2019-2020). 
Minister of State for Employment (1993-1995), Minister of State for Prisons (1995-1997), Shadow Secretary of State for Health (1998-1999), and Shadow Home Secretary (1999-2001). 
Appointed to the Privy Council in 1997 and made a Dame of the Order of St. Gregory the Great in 2013. 

Holds socially conservative views, including opposition to abortion, same-sex marriage, and assisted dying. 
Supports reintroduction of the death penalty for murder and is opposed to all forms of euthanasia. 
Favors rigorous laws on animal protection and is against fox hunting. 
Expressed skepticism about climate change and voted against the Climate Change Act 2008. 
Has appeared in various television shows, including Celebrity Fit Club, The Widdecombe Project, and Strictly Come Dancing. 
Has written several novels and non-fiction books, including The Clematis Tree and The Mass is a Mess.

Anna Cinzia Bonfrisco, Italian politician, born 12 October 1962 in Riva del Garda, Italy, university professor, company manager, Italian nationality, member of the Senate of the Republic from 28 April 2006 to 1 July 2019, member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 9 June 2024, representing Central Italy, affiliated with PSI until 1994, FI from 1994 to 2009, PdL from 2009 to 2013, FI from 2013 to 2015, CoR from 2015 to 2016, DLI from 2016 to present, and Lega from 2018 to present.

Anna Katrin Cavazzini is a German politician of the Alliance 90/The Greens who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. Born on December 12, 1982, in Schlüchtern, West Germany, she studied European Studies at the Chemnitz University of Technology and later completed a Master's degree in International Relations at the Free University of Berlin and the Humboldt University of Berlin in 2009. Cavazzini worked as an advisor to Ska Keller from 2009 to 2014 and later as a consultant on development financing issues at the Federal Foreign Office in Berlin from 2014 to 2016, with a secondment to the United Nations in New York. She also worked as an advisor on trade policy at Campact from 2016 to 2017 and on human rights at Brot für die Welt in Berlin from 2017 to 2019. Cavazzini is considered part of the left wing of the Green Party. She serves on the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which she chairs, and is part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with Brazil and to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly. She is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption and the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group.

Anna Deparnay-Grunenberg, a German politician of Alliance 90/The Greens and member of the European Green Party, born on 5 June 1976 in West Berlin, West Germany. She studied forestry and environmental sciences at the University of Freiburg and the University of British Columbia in Vancouver. From 2 July 2019 to 2024, she served as a Member of the European Parliament representing Germany. Her parliamentary committee assignments included the Committee on Transport and Tourism, where she was the shadow rapporteur on rail passenger rights legislation, and the Committee's Tourism Task Force. Additionally, she was part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with Mercosur and the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals.

Anna Donáth, a Hungarian politician, born on 6 April 1987 in Budapest, Hungary, to László Donáth and Ildikó Muntag. She is the youngest of three siblings, with her father being a former pastor and former member of parliament for the Hungarian Socialist Party, and her paternal grandfather, Ferenc Donáth, being of Jewish descent. Donáth studied sociology at the Eötvös Loránd University in Budapest and migration and ethnic studies at the University of Amsterdam. She joined the Momentum Movement in 2016, became its vice president in June 2018, and was elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in the 2019 European Parliament election. Donáth was the leader of the Momentum Movement from 21 November 2021 to 29 May 2022, and again from 28 January 2024 to 7 July 2024. She has one child.

Anna Fotyga, a Polish politician, born 12 January 1957, in Lębork, Poland. Married to Ryszard Fotyga, with two children. Graduate of the University of Gdańsk and the Danish School of Public Administration, with postgraduate internships at the Department of Labor of the United States, Cornell University in New York, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. 

Member of the Law and Justice party and the European Conservatives and Reformists Group. Served as Minister of Foreign Affairs of Poland from 9 May 2006 to 15 November 2007, under Prime Ministers Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz and Jarosław Kaczyński. Chief of the Chancellery of the President from 29 November 2007 to 20 August 2008, under President Lech Kaczyński. Member of the European Parliament since 13 June 2004, representing Poland, and Chair of the European Parliament Subcommittee on Security and Defence from 7 July 2014 to 2019.

Anna Elżbieta Zalewska, née Gąsior, born 6 July 1965 in Świebodzice, Poland, is a Polish politician who served as Minister of National Education from 16 November 2015 to 4 June 2019 under Prime Ministers Beata Szydło and Mateusz Morawiecki. She graduated from the Polish Philology Department of the University of Wrocław in 1989. Zalewska is a member of the Law and Justice party and has been a Member of the Sejm since 2007, representing the Wałbrzych electoral district.

Anna-Misel Asimakopoulou is a Greek-American politician. She was born on March 27, 1967, in New York City. Asimakopoulou is a member of the New Democracy party. She studied Economics at Bryn Mawr College and Law at Cornell University. Asimakopoulou served as a Member of the European Parliament, representing Greece from July 2, 2019, until July 16, 2024. She was involved in several controversies, including a GDPR breach scandal in 2024, where she used the Ministry of the Interior's database to target eligible Greek voters residing abroad. Asimakopoulou was ordered to destroy the voters' data and pay a fine of €40,000. She also testified as a defense witness in the 2019 trial of former New Democracy MP Nikos Georgiadis, who was sentenced to 28 months with suspension for sexual assault against minors. Asimakopoulou is a member of the New York Bar Association and has worked as a lawyer specializing in financial transactions and international banking law. She has been a member of the European Internet Forum, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. Asimakopoulou announced that she would no longer be running as an MEP in 2024 following the email leak scandal.

Annalisa Tardino, Italian politician, born 30 April 1979 in Licata, Italy, nationality: Italian, educated at University of Palermo, profession: Lawyer, member of League party, elected as Member of the European Parliament on 2 July 2019, representing Italian Islands constituency, serving as LIBE rapporteur on the European Commission’s proposal for a European Health Data Space.

Anne Sander, French economist and politician, born on 1 October 1973 in Haguenau, France, nationality: French, party affiliation: The Republicans, educated at University of Strasbourg, father: Jean-Marie Sander, served as Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024, representing France, and as Quaestor of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, committee assignments: Employment and Social Affairs (2014-2017), Economic and Monetary Affairs (2017-2019), Agriculture and Rural Development (since 2019), delegation for relations with the EEA countries and Switzerland, European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, URBAN Intergroup, endorsed Bruno Le Maire in the 2016 presidential primaries and Laurent Wauquiez in the 2017 leadership election.

Anne-Sophie Pelletier, born on 5 February 1976 in Besançon, France, is a French politician and member of La France Insoumise party. She was elected as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the constituency of France, starting her term on 2 July 2019 and set to end on 15 July 2024.

Annie Schreijer-Pierik, a female politician from the Netherlands, born on 17 February 1953 in Diepenheim. She is a member of the Christian Democratic Appeal and the European People's Party. Schreijer-Pierik is a pig farmer and a member of the Roman Catholic Church. She is married to Jan Schreijer and has three children. Her political career started at age 17 with the Katholieke Plattelands Jongeren. She was a member of the municipal council of Ambt Delden from 1991, the council of the province Overijssel from 1995, and the Dutch national parliament from 1998 to 2010. As a Member of Parliament, she chaired the Agriculture committee from 2004 to 2008. Schreijer-Pierik was a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, serving on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and the Committee on Fisheries. She was part of the Parliament's delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Annika Bruna, a French politician, born 26 November 1956 in Versailles, France. She is a member of the National Rally party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for the France constituency since 2 July 2019, with her term set to end on 15 July 2024. Bruna previously served on the regional council of Île-de-France from 1998 to 2010 and was a parliamentary assistant to Jean-Marie Le Pen. In the European Parliament, she is part of the Identity and Democracy group, serving on the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality and the delegation for relations with Belarus.

Annunziata Rees-Mogg, The Honourable, born 25 March 1979 in Bath, Somerset, England, British politician and journalist, educated at Godolphin and Latymer School, married to Matthew Glanville with three children, daughter of William Rees-Mogg and Gillian Morris, sister of Jacob Rees-Mogg, member of the Conservative Party from 1984 to 2019 and 2020 to present, also a member of the Brexit Party in 2019 and an independent from 2019 to 2020, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the East Midlands region from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, previously a prospective parliamentary candidate for the Conservative Party in the 2005 and 2010 general elections, and a leader writer for The Daily Telegraph, deputy editor of MoneyWeek, and editor of the European Journal.

Ansis Pūpols, MEP, is a Latvian politician born on 24 March 1975 in Riga, Latvia. He is a member of the National Alliance party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Latvia since 14 May 2024, replacing Dace Melbārde.

Anthea McIntyre, born 29 June 1954, London, England, to David Scott McIntyre and Joy Irma Stratford McIntyre. Educated at Claremont School, Esher, and Queen's College, London. Businesswoman, partner in Wythall Estate since 1976, consultant with MCP Management Consultants 1985-1991, partner 1991-2011. Married to Frank Myers, MBE, in 1999, resides in Walford, Ross-on-Wye. Member of the European Parliament for West Midlands 1 December 2011 - 31 January 2020, Deputy Chairman of the Conservative Party 17 July 2016 - 22 September 2016, under Theresa May's leadership. Served on the European Parliament's Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Delegation for Relations with South Africa. Appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire in the 2022 New Year Honours for political and public service.

Antoni Comín i Oliveres, PhD, MEP, born March 7, 1971, in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Nationality: Spanish. Alma mater: Autonomous University of Barcelona. Profession: Professor and politician. Party affiliation: Junts (2020–present), previously affiliated with Citizens for Change (2003–2011), Socialists' Party of Catalonia (2003–2014), and Republican Left of Catalonia (2015–2017). Family: Son of Alfonso Carlos Comín, grandson of Jesús Comín Sagüés, partner of Sergi Corbera, and father of one child. Minister of Health of Catalonia from January 14, 2016, to October 27, 2017. Member of the Parliament of Catalonia from October 26, 2015, to July 30, 2018, and from June 28, 2004, to October 5, 2010. Vice President of the Council for the Republic since December 8, 2018. Member of the European Parliament for Spain since July 2, 2019.

Antonio López-Istúriz White, a male, born on April 1, 1970, in Pamplona, Spain, to a Spanish father and an American mother, educated at CEU San Pablo University and University of Navarra, fluent in Spanish, English, French, and Italian, married with 2 children, member of the People's Party and the European People's Party, served as Secretary General of the European People's Party from March 2002 to May 2022, Member of the European Parliament since 2004, representing Spain, served on various committees including Legal Affairs, Foreign Affairs, Transport, and Internal Market and Consumer Protection, rapporteur on several reports including EU-China relations and Cyber Defense, advocate for children's rights, disabled and elderly rights, and self-employed workers, received several awards including Commander of the Order of the Star, Parliamentarian Prize, and Officer of the Order of Bernardo O'Higgins, has been involved in Transatlantic relations and has met with several politicians from the United States, including Senator Marco Rubio and Congressmen Paul Ryan, has been vocal in his support for Cuban dissidents and Venezuelan opposition.

Antonio Maria Rinaldi is a 69-year-old Italian economist, university professor, and politician, born on 27 February 1955 in Rome, Italy, to a banker father and a noblewoman mother. He graduated in economics from LUISS University in 1979 and has worked at various credit institutions and companies, including Banco di Roma, American Service Bank, Fideuram, CONSOB, Eni, and ENAV. Rinaldi has been a university professor, teaching political economy and corporate finance at Link Campus University of Rome, University of Molise, and D'Annunzio University of Pescara. He is a post-Keynesian economist and has expressed critical positions towards the euro as a single European currency, identifying as a Eurosceptic. Rinaldi was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing the League party in the Central Italy constituency. He has two children and is married.

Antonio Tajani, male, born 4 August 1953 in Rome, Italy, married to Brunella Orecchio since 1988, with two children, graduated in law from Sapienza University of Rome, reserve officer of the Italian Air Force, professional journalist since 1980, speaks Italian, English, French, and Spanish. 

Politician with the following experience: 
- Deputy Prime Minister of Italy and Minister of Foreign Affairs since 22 October 2022, 
- President of the European Parliament from 2017 to 2019, 
- European Commissioner from 2008 to 2014, 
- Member of the European Parliament from 1994 to 2008 and again from 2014 to 2022, 
- Member of the Chamber of Deputies since 13 October 2022, 
- Secretary of Forza Italia since 15 July 2023.

Party affiliations: 
- Italian Monarchist Union (UMI) in the 1970s, 
- Forza Italia (FI) from 1994 to 2009, 
- The People of Freedom (PdL) from 2009 to 2013, 
- Forza Italia (FI) since 2013, 
- European People's Party Group (EPP Group).

Antony Hook, a British Liberal Democrats politician, was born on 10 April 1980, in Faversham, Kent. He studied history at University College London and law at City University. He is a barrister and was a member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2019 to 2020. He is a member of Kent County Council for the Faversham Division since 2017 and Leader of the Liberal Democrats in Kent since 2021. He is married with two daughters. His key actions and views include: representing the claimant in R (on the application of Costello) v North East Essex Justices, a judicial review of a decision by Magistrates; calling for Council Tax to be abolished; proposing a motion against racism in Kent County Council; supporting a written constitution in the UK; and advocating for action to reduce the Gender Pay Gap.

Arba Kokalari, MEP, born 27 November 1986 in Tirana, Albania, is a Swedish politician of the Moderate Party and the European People's Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Sweden constituency since 2 July 2019. Kokalari serves on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. She is also a member of the delegation for relations with the United States and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and has been her parliamentary group's shadow rapporteur on the Digital Services Act since 2021. Kokalari is an alumna of Stockholm University.

Arnaud Danjean, a French politician, born 11 February 1971 in Louhans, France. Graduated from Sciences Po with a degree in communication, research and human resource in 1992, and completed his curriculum with a postgraduate diploma in political science and international relations at Sciences Po in 1993. Served as a reserve officer at the submarine base of Toulon, and later joined the French DGSE as a civil servant, carrying out numerous missions in Sarajevo in 1995 and 1996. Worked as a Balkans specialist for the Ministry of Defence and took part in the negotiations of the Rambouillet Agreement in February and March 1999. Joined the Mission of France to the United Nations in Geneva in 2002, and performed a new mission in Kosovo for Javier Solana in 2004. Member of the staff of Minister of Foreign Affairs Michel Barnier from 2005 to 2007. Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, representing East France constituency until 2019, and then the nationwide constituency. Chaired the European Parliament Subcommittee on Security and Defence from 2009 to 2014. Member of the European People's Party Group and the centre-right party The Republicans. Served as a member of the Regional Council of Burgundy from 2010 to 2015, and the Regional Council of Bourgogne-Franche-Comté from 2015 to 2017. Appointed special adviser to Prime Minister Michel Barnier in 2024. Decorated Chevalier de l'Ordre national du Mérite in 2000.

Asger Christensen, a Danish politician, born 8 January 1958, in Tarm, Denmark, is a member of the European Parliament representing Denmark, affiliated with the Venstre party and part of the Renew Europe parliamentary group, serving since 2 July 2019, and is a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport, as well as part of the delegation for relations with China and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and has been a farmer and owner of a farm since 1982.

Asim Ahmed Ademov, a Bulgarian politician, born on 3 December 1968 in Dabnitsa, Bulgaria, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Bulgaria constituency since 14 September 2017, re-elected in 2019, with a term set to end on 15 July 2024, affiliated with the GERB party, having served on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs from 2017-2019 and the Committee on Culture and Education since 2019.

Assita Adoua Kanko, a Burkinabè-born Belgian journalist, human rights activist, author, and politician, born on July 14, 1980, in Godyr, Burkina Faso, to a Muslim family. She was subjected to female genital mutilation as a child and has since campaigned for the practice to be banned. Kanko holds dual citizenship of Belgium and Burkina Faso and has been a member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing the New Flemish Alliance. She serves as a vice-chairwoman of the European Conservatives and Reformists group. Kanko has been a strong advocate for women's rights, human rights, and has spoken out against antisemitism, radical Islam, and multiculturalism. She has also been critical of the EU's response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine and has supported Ukraine in the conflict. Kanko has written several books, including "Omdat je een meisje bent. Verhaal van een besneden leven" and "Leading ladies: maak je ambities waar". She is married with one daughter and lives in Brussels. Kanko has been a member of the think tank Liberales, worked as a parliamentary aid to the Flemish Open VLD party, and has been an advisor to companies on implementing Sustainable Development Goals. She has also been a columnist for De Standaard and has received the Ebony Spur award from the N-VA in 2017.

Athanasios Konstantinou, Greek MEP, born 18 July 1959 in Athens, Greece, physician, retired Hellenic Air Force officer with rank of taxiarchos, graduate of Hellenic Army Corps Officers Military Academy and Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, speaks English and German, formerly member of Golden Dawn, now independent, serving term from 2 July 2019 to 16 June 2024, voted against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for human rights violations on 15 September 2022.

Atidzhe Alieva-Veli, a Bulgarian politician, born on 18 September 1981 in Devin, Bulgaria, grew up in Borino, and holds Bulgarian nationality. She has a bachelor's degree in biotechnology, a master's degree in industrial biotechnology from Sofia University, and a second master's degree in Public Administration from the University of National and World Economy in Sofia. Alieva-Veli started her professional career at Danone's Bulgarian branch and later worked at the State Agricultural Fund, becoming one of the deputy directors in 2013. As a member of the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, she has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2019, representing the Bulgaria constituency. Her committee assignments include the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development since 2020 and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs from 2019 to 2020. She is also part of the Parliament's delegations to the EU-Kazakhstan, EU-Kyrgyzstan, EU-Uzbekistan, EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees, and for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia. Her term is set to end on 15 July 2024.

Attila Ara-Kovács, born 14 January 1953 in Oradea, Romania, is a Hungarian politician, philosopher, and journalist, educated at Babeș-Bolyai University, representing the Democratic Coalition party as a Member of the European Parliament for Hungary, elected on 2 July 2019, serving the Hungary constituency.

Aurore Lalucq, French economist and politician, born 17 April 1979 in Longjumeau, France. Member of the European Parliament for France since 2019, initially representing Génération.s (2017-2019) and later Place Publique (since 2019). Served on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Subcommittee on Tax Matters, Committee on International Trade (2019-2021), and Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (since 2021). Member of the Parliament's delegation for relations with the United States, European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group. Re-elected as an MEP in 2024. Member of the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) since 2023. Urged leaders to not support Arctic LNG 2 due to climate change concerns in 2021 and called for review of Binance cryptocurrency exchange registration in 2022. Educated at Paris Dauphine University and Panthéon-Sorbonne University.

Aurélia Beigneux, a French politician born on 2 June 1980, director of Epinorpa, former Assistant for Social Affairs at the Town Hall of Hénin-Beaumont, elected to the European Parliament in 2019 as a member of the National Rally, involved in a litigation case due to a discrepancy between her income and declaration of resources.

Aušra Seibutytė-Maldeikienė, a Lithuanian politician, born on June 4, 1958, in Palanga, Lithuanian SSR, Soviet Union. She is a member of the European Parliament since July 2, 2019, representing the Lithuania constituency. Prior to this, she served as a member of the Seimas from November 14, 2016, to June 30, 2019, and as a Vilnius City Councilor from April 22, 2015, to November 13, 2016. She is affiliated with the European People's Party group in the European Parliament and has been a member of the Homeland Union since 2023, previously being an independent politician. She has also been briefly associated with the Liberal Democratic Party in 2004. Maldeikienė holds a degree in economics from the Lomonosov Moscow State University and has worked as a lecturer and economist. She is married to Eugenijus Maldeikis, a Lithuanian economist and politician, from 1979 to 2017, and has two sons, Matas and Mykolas. Maldeikienė has written several books on economics and has been a columnist and analyst for various publications. She has also been a spokesperson and head of the Public Relations Unit in Vilnius bank and has worked as a teacher of economics in Vilnius Jesuit High School.

Balázs Hidvéghi, a Hungarian politician, was born on 28 November 1970 in Budapest, Hungary. He graduated from Petőfi Sándor High School in Budapest in 1989 and from the Eötvös Loránd University in Budapest in 1995, majoring in English and Hungarian. He obtained a Certificate in Diplomacy at the Institute for International Studies at the University of Leeds, England in 1991, and a DEA master's degree at the Institute of European Studies from the Robert Schuman University of Strasbourg, France in 2005. He has been a member of Fidesz since 1989 and has held various positions, including Deputy State Secretary for International Affairs and External Economic Relations at the Ministry for National Economy, Deputy Director responsible for Hungarian communities in the Carpathian basin and the Hungarian diaspora, Member of the Hungarian Parliament, Vice-Chairman of the Committee on National Cohesion, and Member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. He was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 and is a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, including Disinformation. He is married to Brigitta Hidvéghiné Pulay, a lawyer and specialist in environmental protection and sustainable development, and they have four children.

Barbara Gibson, born 25 August 1962 in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, United States, is a British politician and academic. She holds a PhD in Intercultural Communication from Birkbeck, University of London, and has lectured on this topic at various universities and business schools in the UK and Europe. Gibson has over 25 years of experience as a business communication professional and has worked with companies worldwide. She is a past international chair of the International Association of Business Communicators, past-president of SIETAR UK, and a past International Group Chair of the Chartered Institute of Public Relations. Gibson was a Liberal Democrat Member of the European Parliament for the East of England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. She was also a councillor for Haldens on Hertfordshire County Council from 4 May 2017 to 6 May 2021. Gibson was elected to the European Parliament at the 2019 European Parliamentary election and was a member of the Committee on International Trade, the Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and a substitute on several other EU Parliamentary bodies. She is currently divorced and used to live in Welwyn, Hertfordshire, with her husband and two dogs.

Barbara Thaler is an Austrian politician of the Tyrolean People's Party (TVP), born on 16 February 1982. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Austria. In parliament, she serves on the Committee on Transport and Tourism and is part of the Tourism Task Force, the Parliament's delegation for relations with India, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises.

Barry Andrews is a male Irish politician born on 16 May 1967 in Dublin, Ireland. He is a member of Fianna Fáil and Renew Europe. Andrews was educated at Blackrock College and University College Dublin. He worked as a secondary school teacher from 1991 to 1997 and later as a barrister from 1997 to 2003. Andrews is married with two sons and a daughter. His family has strong connections to Fianna Fáil, including his grandfather Todd Andrews, a founder-member of the party, and his father David Andrews, a former Foreign Minister. Andrews's brother is comedian David McSavage, and he is a cousin of former RTÉ presenter Ryan Tubridy and Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews. Andrews was first elected to public office in 1999 as a Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown County Councillor. He served as a Teachta Dála for the Dún Laoghaire constituency from 2002 to 2011 and as Minister of State for Children from 2008 to 2011. Andrews was CEO of GOAL from 2012 to 2016 and Director-General of the Institute of International and European Affairs since 2017. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for the Dublin constituency in 2019 and re-elected in 2024. Andrews is a member of several committees, including the Committee on International Development, Committee on International Trade, and Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality.
