Bart Groothuis, born 1 January 1981, is a Dutch politician and Member of the European Parliament since 1 February 2020, representing the Netherlands for the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party within the Renew Europe group. He was educated at Radboud University, studying economics and history, and the Netherlands Institute of International Relations Clingendael, studying international relations. Before his parliamentary career, Groothuis worked as a personal assistant to Henk Kamp, and as a cybersecurity expert at the Ministry of Defence, where he served as the director of the cybersecurity bureau. He is the spokesperson for defense, technology, geopolitics, energy, industry, digitization, and cyber within his party. Groothuis has been a strong advocate for European defense cooperation, cybersecurity, and digitization, and has voiced concerns about European dependence on countries like China. He has been a member of several committees and delegations, including the Delegation for relations with Iran, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence. Groothuis is married with two daughters and resides in Voorburg.

Bartosz Adam Arłukowicz, born 31 December 1971 in Resko, Poland, is a pediatrician and politician who served as the Minister of Health from 18 November 2011 to 10 June 2015 under Prime Ministers Donald Tusk and Ewa Kopacz. He was a member of the Sejm from 2007 and the European Parliament from 2019 to 2023. His party affiliations include the Democratic Left Alliance (2001-2004), Social Democracy of Poland (2004-2009), Civic Platform (since 2011), Left and Democrats (2007-2009), and Civic Coalition (since 2019).

Bas Eickhout is a Dutch politician and a Member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the GreenLeft party and the European Green Party. He was born on 8 October 1976 in Groesbeek, Netherlands. Eickhout studied chemistry and environmental science at Radboud University in Nijmegen from 1994 to 2000. Before entering politics, he worked as a researcher at the Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment, focusing on transnational environmental problems, including climate change. He has been a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and substitute for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Eickhout has also served as the Parliament's rapporteur on various environmental topics and is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals. He has been the co-president of the Greens-European Free Alliance since 2024, alongside Terry Reintke. Eickhout is the author of two books, "Klimaatmores: Radicaal naar een andere norm" (2016) and "Groen realisme: Strijdbaar voor een groene economie" (2024). He has received the Environment award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020. Eickhout resides in both Utrecht and Brussels, has a partner, and a daughter from a previous relationship.

Beata Agnieszka Kempa, born on 11 February 1966 in Syców, Poland, is a Polish politician who has served as a Member of the European Parliament for Lower Silesian and Opole since 2 July 2019. Kempa was initially a member of the Law and Justice party from 2001 to 2011, then joined United Poland in 2012. She was elected to the Sejm on 25 September 2005, representing the 3 Wrocław district, and served until 1 July 2019. Kempa held the position of Chief of the Chancellery of the Prime Minister from 16 November 2015 to 18 December 2017, under Prime Ministers Beata Szydło and Mateusz Morawiecki.

Beata Mazurek, a Polish politician from the Law and Justice party, born on 19 October 1967 in Ostrów Mazowiecka, Poland, educated at the John Paul II Catholic University of Lublin and the Pułtusk Academy of Humanities, with two sons, served as a Member of the European Parliament since 4 June 2019, previously as Deputy Marshal of the Sejm from 9 January 2018 to 4 June 2019, first elected to the Sejm on 25 September 2005 with 7,012 votes in the 7 Chełm district, and became a spokeswoman in December 2015.

Beata Szydło is a Polish politician, born on 15 April 1963 in Oświęcim, Poland. She is a member of the Law and Justice party and has been the Prime Minister of Poland from 2015 to 2017. She was the third woman to hold the office. Szydło is married to Edward Szydło and has two sons, Tymoteusz and Błażej. She is a devout Catholic and declares her adherence to conservative Christian values. 

Szydło was educated at Jagiellonian University in Kraków, graduating in 1989, and later completed post-graduate studies at Warsaw School of Economics and Kraków University of Economics. She was elected Mayor of Gmina Brzeszcze at the age of 35 and held this position for seven years. In 2005, she was elected to the Sejm, the lower house of the Parliament of the Republic of Poland. 

Szydło led the presidential campaign of Andrzej Duda, Law and Justice's nominee for President of Poland, to victory. She was appointed Prime Minister on 16 November 2015, after Law and Justice won a decisive victory in the parliamentary election. During her time in office, she was a vocal critic of numerous European Union policies, particularly on immigration. She introduced the 500+ programme, supplying families with 500PLN for every child, starting from the second child. 

Szydło was forced to resign as prime minister in December 2017, after Jarosław Kaczyński, the Chairman of Law and Justice, withdrew confidence from her to continue as the party's lead election candidate within the Sejm. She was subsequently appointed Deputy Prime Minister by her former deputy, Mateusz Morawiecki. 

In 2019, Szydło was elected to the European Parliament, representing the constituency of Lesser Poland and Świętokrzyskie. She received the highest number of individual votes of any European Parliamentary candidate in Poland's history. She resigned as deputy prime minister to take her seat in the European Parliament. 

Szydło is currently a vice-chair of the European Conservatives and Reformists group in the European Parliament. She has been ranked 31st in Forbes magazine's ranking of the world's 100 most powerful women and the 10th among the most influential female political leaders.

Beatrice Covassi, Italian politician, born 1 December 1968 in Florence, Italy, Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy constituency since 6 December 2022, affiliated with the Democratic Party and Solidary Democracy, successor of Simona Bonafé.

Belinda de Lucy, born 15 October 1976 in Sheffield, South Yorkshire, England, married to Raymond McKeeve with 4 children, occupation politician, member of Reform UK, previously Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and part of the delegation to the EU–Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, Reform UK's Education and Families spokesperson since 2023.

Benyamin Naeem Habib, Pakistani-British politician, born June 7, 1965, in Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan, to a Pakistani Punjabi father and English mother. Emigrated to the UK in 1979, educated at Rugby School and Robinson College, Cambridge, studying natural sciences. Worked as an analyst at Lehman Brothers, finance director at PWS Holdings, and managing director of JKL Property before starting his own property fund company, First Property Group plc. Initially a Conservative Party voter and donor, he supported Brexit in the 2016 referendum. Elected as a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament in 2019, serving until the UK's withdrawal from the EU. Became Co-Deputy Leader of Reform UK in March 2023, alongside David Bull, and the party's Brexit and the Union spokesman. Candidate for the Wellingborough by-election in February 2024 and the Wellingborough and Rushden constituency at the 2024 General Election. Removed as Co-Deputy Leader of Reform UK in July 2024.

Benoît Biteau, a French farmer, agronomist, and politician, born on 7 April 1967, in Royan, France. He is a resident of Sablonceaux. Biteau initially held membership in the Radical Party of the Left from 1985 to 2017, later becoming an independent politician. He was a Member of the European Parliament for France from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024. He also served as a member and vice-president of the Regional Council of Poitou-Charentes from 2010 to 2015 and as a member of the Regional Council of Nouvelle-Aquitaine from 2016 to 2021. Biteau was elected as the deputy for the 2nd constituency of Charente-Maritime in the National Assembly in the 2024 legislative election, running under The Ecologists banner, part of the New Popular Front alliance, and took office on 8 July 2024, succeeding Anne-Laure Babault.

Benoît Lutgen, born 10 March 1970 in Bastogne, Belgium, is a Belgian politician. He is a member of the Centre démocrate humaniste party and served as its head from 2011 to 2019. His father is Guy Lutgen. Lutgen was Secretary-General of the Centre démocrate humaniste from 2001 to 2002 and National Campaign Director in 2004. He held various ministerial positions in the Walloon government, including Minister for Public Works, Agriculture, Rural Affairs, Nature, Forests and Heritage, and Minister for Agriculture, Rural Affairs, the Environment and Tourism from 2004 to 2009. Lutgen has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Transport and Tourism and as a substitute member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. He is also part of the Parliament's delegation with the United States and a member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Disability and the Welfare and Conservation of Animals. As of 2024, he is a member of the Belgian Chamber of Representatives.

Bergur Løkke Rasmussen, a Danish politician and Member of the European Parliament for Moderates, born on 4 March 1990 in Gilleleje, Denmark, son of Lars Løkke Rasmussen, married to Simone Spånberg with 1 child, switched from Venstre to Moderates in March 2023, and has been in office since 14 November 2022, representing the Denmark constituency.

Bernard Guetta is a French politician and journalist. He was born on January 28, 1951, in Boulogne-Billancourt, France. Guetta is the half-brother of DJ and record producer David Guetta. He is married to Catherine Sayegh and has 2 children. Guetta graduated from the Centre de formation des journalistes in Paris. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, representing the constituency of France. Guetta is an independent politician and a member of Renew Europe. He has written several books on politics and geopolitics. Guetta is part of the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Bernd Lange, a German politician, born on 14 November 1955 in Oldenburg, West Germany, is a member of the Social Democratic Party and the Party of European Socialists. He studied Protestant theology and political sciences at the University of Göttingen. Lange was a teacher at a high school in Burgdorf from 1983 to 1994 and later worked as the head of the department for "Economy, Environment and Europe" at the German Trade Union Federation from 2004 to 2009. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 1994, with a break from 2004 to 2009, and is currently the chairman of the INTA committee and rapporteur for TTIP. Lange is a member of several intergroups, including the Interparliamentary Delegation for relations with South Africa, the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. He has received several awards, including the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany and the MEP Award in the category "Trade". Lange is married, has one daughter and an adult adopted son, and lives in Burgdorf, Germany. He is a member of the Business Forum of the Social Democratic Party of Germany, the Deutsche Umweltstiftung, IG Metall, and the German Life Saving Association. Lange has been a member of the Social Democratic Party since 1974 and has held various positions within the party.

Bernhard Zimniok, a German politician and former Bundeswehr lieutenant colonel, born 21 June 1953, served in the airborne division for 15 years, and as part of the diplomatic protection unit at the German embassies in Damascus and Islamabad, and as a security advisor in Africa and the Middle East. He is a member of the Alternative for Germany party, which he joined in 2015 in response to the refugee crisis. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Germany and sitting as part of the Identity and Democracy group, and also serves on the Committee of Foreign Affairs.

Bert-Jan Ruissen, a Dutch politician and Member of the European Parliament from the Netherlands, born on 22 March 1972 in Kruiningen, Netherlands, studied at Wageningen University and Research, is a member of the Reformed Political Party and the European Conservatives and Reformists, served as assistant to MEP Leen van der Waal and advisor for EU Agriculture Policy at the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, was a member of the local council of Krimpen aan den IJssel from 2006 until 2019, has been a full Member of the European Parliament Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, substitute Member of the European Parliament Committee on Fisheries and European Parliament Committee on Foreign Affairs, and first vice chair of the European Parliament delegation for the relations with Israel, voted against the new European Commission of president Ursula von der Leyen, the resolution to denounce the LGBT-free zones in Poland, and the European Green Deal, signed a declaration against surrogacy, expressed support for Taiwan, is married with four children, and was re-elected in the June 2024 European Parliament election.

Bettina Vollath, Austrian politician, born 29 October 1962 in Graz, Austria, educated at University of Graz, member of Social Democratic Party of Austria, served as Member of European Parliament for Austria constituency from 2 July 2019 to 9 October 2022, committee assignments include Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and working group on Frontex, delegation to EU-Albania Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee, succeeded by Theresa Muigg.

Biljana Borzan is a Croatian politician and physician, born on November 29, 1971, in Osijek, Croatia, to a Croatian Serb family. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Croatia and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Borzan has been a Member of the European Parliament for Croatia since July 1, 2013, and has served as the Vice President of the Socialists & Democrats Parliamentary Group since June 19, 2019. She is a physician by profession, specializing in occupational and sports medicine. Borzan is married to Vladimir Borzan, a gastroenterologist, and they have two sons, Andrej and Matej. She is fluent in English, German, and Russian, in addition to her native Croatian. Borzan's portfolio includes Internal Market and Consumer Protection, Economic and Monetary Affairs, and Committee on International Trade. She is part of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, Disability, Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. Borzan was awarded the Women's Rights and Gender Equality Award in 2018.

Bill Newton Dunn, born 3 October 1941 in Greywell, Hampshire, England, is a British politician. He is a member of the Liberal Democrats, having previously been a member of the Conservative Party until 2000. He was educated at Marlborough College, Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, and INSEAD. Newton Dunn is married to Anna Terez Árki and has two children, Tom Newton Dunn and Daisy Newton Dunn. He has served as a Member of the European Parliament for the East Midlands and Lincolnshire constituencies. Newton Dunn was first elected as a Conservative MEP in 1979 and served until 1994. He was re-elected in 1999 and crossed the floor to the Liberal Democrats in 2000. He was re-elected in 2004 and 2009, but lost his seat in 2014. Newton Dunn was re-elected in 2019 and served until the UK's withdrawal from the EU in 2020.

William Kelleher, an Irish politician, born 20 January 1968 in Cork, Ireland, married to Liza Davis with 3 children, educated at Sacred Heart College and Pallaskenry Agricultural College, a member of Fianna Fáil and Renew Europe, served as a Senator from 1993 to 1997, a Teachta Dála for Cork North-Central from 1997 to 2019, Minister of State for Labour Affairs from 2007 to 2009 and for Trade and Commerce from 2009 to 2011, and a Member of the European Parliament for the South constituency since July 2019.

Birgit Sippel, born 29 January 1960 in Bochum, Germany, is a German politician serving as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 1 July 2009, representing the constituency of Germany. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Prior to her European Parliament career, Sippel was involved in local politics, serving on the city council of Arnsberg from 1994 to 2004, and held various positions within the SPD, including membership in the party's National Council and council in the federal state of North Rhine-Westphalia. In the European Parliament, Sippel is a full member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and a substitute member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. She has been involved in various topics, including privacy and data protection, EU asylum policy, migration, and police and judicial cooperation. Sippel is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. Outside of politics, she is a patron of Fair Trials International, a member of the Board of Trustees of St. Maria zur Wiese, and a member of IG Metall.

Bogdan Rzońca, born 1 June 1961 in Zarzecze, Jasło County, Poland, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019 for the Subcarpathian constituency, representing the Law and Justice party, previously affiliated with Christian National Union and Solidarity Electoral Action. His prior offices include Member of the Sejm from 2011 to 2019 for the Krosno constituency, 1st Marshal of Subcarpathian Voivodeship from 1 January 1999 to 22 November 2002, and Voivode of Krosno from 1997 to 1998.

Bogusław Marian Liberadzki, born 12 September 1948 in Sochaczew, Poland, is a Polish economist and politician. He is a professor of economics, educated at the Main School of Planning and Statistics (now Warsaw School of Economics) and the University of Illinois. He holds the Chair of Transportation at the Warsaw School of Economics and is also a professor at the Maritime University of Szczecin. He was an under secretary (vice minister) in the Ministry of Transportation and Maritime Economy from 1989 to 1993 and minister from 1993 to 1997. He was a member of the Sejm (lower house of Polish parliament) from 1997 to 2003, representing the Democratic Left Alliance, and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004. He is currently vice president of the European Parliament and a member of the Budgetary Control and Transport and Tourism committees. He is married to Grażyna and has two sons, Kamil (MA) and Marcin (PhD), both working at the Department of Banking of the Warsaw School of Economics.

Brando Benifei, Italian MEP from North-West Italy, born 1 January 1986 in La Spezia, educated at University of Bologna, member of the Democratic Party since 2007 and previously a member of the Democrats of the Left from 2002 to 2007, serving in the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, with committee assignments including Employment and Social Affairs, Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age, and member of various intergroups including Anti-Corruption, Digital Agenda, and Disability, supporter of Laicism and LGBTQIA+ rights.

Brian Monteith, born 8 January 1958 in Edinburgh, Scotland, educated at Portobello High School and Heriot-Watt University. Former member of the Federation of Conservative Students and organiser of a successful campaign to take Heriot-Watt out of the National Union of Students. Worked as a researcher for the Centre for Policy Studies, in public relations for Michael Forsyth Associates, and set up Leith Communications public relations company. Elected as a Member of the Scottish Parliament for the Mid Scotland and Fife region from 1999 to 2007 as a Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party list member. Held positions as Education, Arts, Culture & Sport spokesperson and Finance Spokesperson. Resigned as Finance Spokesperson in 2005 and had the whip withdrawn by the Scottish Conservative Party. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament for North East England from 2019 to 2020 as a member of the Brexit Party. Former chairman of English-Speaking Union Scotland, worked for the Botswanan government, and is an acquaintance of indicted American lobbyist Jack Abramoff. Current editor of ThinkScotland.org and communications director of the lobbyists Global Britain.

Brice Hortefeux, a conservative French politician, born 11 May 1958 in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France. Raised in Auvergne. Married to Valérie Dazzan since 2000, with three children. Education: Lycée Saint-Jean de Passy, degree in private law from Paris Nanterre University (1982), master's degree in public law (1984), and studied at Sciences Po. Profession: Lawyer. 

Member of The Republicans (since 2015), previously part of the Union for a Popular Movement (2002-2015) and Rally for the Republic (before 2002). 

Held various positions: Local authority administrator (1986-1994), Regional councillor of Auvergne (since 1992), Prefect (1995), Special adviser in the office of the President of the Senate (1998-1999), Head of office of the Minister for the Budget and Communications and government spokesman (1993-1995), Minister of the Interior, Overseas, Local Authorities and Immigration (2010-2011), Minister of the Interior, Overseas and Local authorities (2009-2010), Minister of Labor, Family and Social Affairs, Solidarity and the City (January-June 2009), Minister for Immigration, Integration, National Identity and Development Solidarity (2007-2009), Minister of Territorial collectivities (2005-2007), and Member of the European Parliament (1999-2005, 2011-2024). 

Supports immigrant repatriation from France and has incentivised voluntary return. Favors controls on immigration and believes France has the right to expel or welcome immigrants on a discretionary basis. Was found guilty of a racial insult in 2010 and fined 750 euros with an order to donate 2,000 euros to an anti-racism group.

Bronis Ropė, a male Lithuanian politician, born on 14 April 1955 in Degutėliai, Ignalina District Municipality, Lithuania. He studied at the Kaunas University of Technology between 1974-1979 and was the chairman of the faculty trade union from 1976 to 1978. He was the mayor of Ignalina from 1995 to 2014. He is a member of the Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union and the first vice chairman of the party. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the Lithuania constituency. He is married to Danutė Šileikytė-Ropienė since 1985 and they have two sons.

Camilla Laureti, born on 20 May 1975 in Rome, Italy, is a journalist and politician who has been a Member of the European Parliament since 11 January 2022, representing the Central Italy constituency. She is affiliated with the Democratic Party and graduated in contemporary history from Sapienza University of Rome. Laureti's background includes working as a radio journalist at ANSA and Radio Città Futura, becoming a professional journalist in 2006. Her political experience encompasses serving as a press officer for the Presidency of the Lazio Region and Luca Cordero di Montezemolo's Italia Futura association. She was also the municipal councilor for culture and tourism in Spoleto from 2014 to 2017 and provincial secretary of the Democratic Party in the province of Perugia since June 2021.

Carina Ohlsson, Swedish Social Democratic politician, born 14 June 1957 in Lidköping, Sweden. Member of the European Parliament since 26 September 2022, replacing Jytte Guteland. Served as member of the Riksdag from 5 October 1998 to 26 September 2022, representing Västra Götaland County East. Held position of Alderman of the House from 26 September 2022, succeeding Tuve Skånberg and preceding Karin Enström. Chairperson of the Social Democratic Women in Sweden from 2013 to 2021.

Carles Puigdemont i Casamajó is a Spanish politician and journalist from Catalonia. He was born on December 29, 1962, in Amer, Catalonia, Spain. He is a member of the Together for Catalonia party and has been associated with the pro-independence faction of the Democratic Convergence of Catalonia party. He served as the 130th President of the Government of Catalonia from 2016 to 2017, when he was removed from office by the Spanish Government following the unilateral Catalan declaration of independence. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He is married to Romanian journalist Marcela Topor and has two daughters. He is a supporter of Girona FC and FC Barcelona and plays rock guitar and the electric piano. 

Puigdemont's political ideology is centered around Catalan independence and self-determination. He has been a strong advocate for the right of Catalonia to hold a referendum on independence and has been critical of the Spanish government's actions to suppress the movement. He has also been critical of the European Union's handling of the Catalan crisis and has called for reforms to the EU to make it more democratic and responsive to the needs of its citizens.

Puigdemont has been involved in several controversies throughout his career, including his role in the 2017 Catalan independence referendum and his subsequent removal from office. He has also been accused of misusing public funds and has been the subject of several investigations and lawsuits. Despite these challenges, he remains a prominent figure in Catalan politics and continues to advocate for the region's right to self-determination.

 Puigdemont was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, but was initially unable to take his seat due to a Spanish court ruling. He eventually took his seat in January 2020 and has been an active member of the parliament, advocating for Catalan interests and pushing for reforms to the EU.

 Puigdemont has been living in exile in Belgium since 2017, but has continued to be involved in Catalan politics. He has been a vocal critic of the Spanish government's actions in Catalonia and has called for the EU to take a more active role in resolving the crisis. He has also been a strong advocate for the rights of Catalan citizens and has worked to promote the region's culture and interests.

In 2021, Puigdemont was arrested in Italy on a European arrest warrant issued by Spain, but was released without charge. He has also been the subject of several other investigations and lawsuits, including a Spanish Supreme Court investigation into his role in the 2017 Catalan independence referendum.

 Puigdemont has been a strong advocate for the rights of Catalan citizens and has worked to promote the region's culture and interests. He has been a vocal critic of the Spanish government's actions in Catalonia and has called for the EU to take a more active role in resolving the crisis. Despite the challenges he has faced, he remains a prominent figure in Catalan politics and continues to advocate for the region's right to self-determination.

 Puigdemont has pointed out the fact that Spain has decided to recognize Palestine but not Kosovo, "a country with which the European Union has diplomatic relations". He also accused Spain of helping Turkey "to suppress the Kurds". Puigdemont said that "Above all, Spain is the country that suppressed the democratic referendum of Catalonia" on 1 October 2017.

On 8 August 2024, Puigdemont made a return to Spain after seven years in self-imposed exile in Belgium, delivering a defiant speech at the Arc de Triomf in Barcelona advocating for Catalonia's right to self-determination before quickly disappearing, sparking a large-scale police operation.

Carlo Calenda is an Italian business executive and politician born on 9 April 1973 in Rome, Italy. He is the son of Fabio Calenda, a journalist, and Cristina Comencini, a film director and screenwriter, and the grandson of Luigi Comencini, a popular director of Italian comedy movies. Calenda was educated at the La Sapienza University in Rome, where he graduated with a B.A. in law without Laude. He has been married to Violante Guidotti Bentivoglio and has four children. 

Calenda started his career in finance companies and later became a manager of Ferrari under the presidency of Luca Cordero di Montezemolo. He then served as the marketing manager of Sky Italia and as an assistant to the then president of Confindustria, Luca Cordero di Montezemolo. 

Calenda joined the youth of the Italian Communist Party (PCI) at 14 and later became a member of the Italian Communist Youth Federation (FGCI). In 2009, he was appointed political coordinator of Future Italy, a liberal centrist think tank founded by Montezemolo. In 2012, he joined Civic Choice, the liberal political party of incumbent Prime Minister Mario Monti. 

Calenda was appointed Deputy Minister of Economic Development in the government of Enrico Letta in 2013 and later confirmed in that post in the cabinet of Letta's successor, Matteo Renzi. In 2016, Renzi appointed him Italy's Permanent Representative to the European Union, a position he held until May 2016. 

Calenda was appointed Minister of Economic Development on 10 May 2016, following the resignation of the incumbent minister Federica Guidi. He continued as minister in the government of Paolo Gentiloni, who succeeded Renzi when he resigned as Prime Minister in December 2016. 

Calenda joined the Democratic Party (PD) in 2018 but exited from the party in 2019 to found his new movement, Action (Azione). He served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022 and was a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) from 2019 to 2021. 

Calenda was a strong supporter of free market and globalization but later became critical of the Third Way policies promoted by Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, and Matteo Renzi. He expressed his pessimistic view about globalization and centre-left politics, which according to him, have failed in protecting workers from offshoring and unemployment. 

Calenda ran in the 2021 municipal election for Mayor of Rome but lost against Roberto Gualtieri. In the 2022 general election, his party Action signed an alliance with Enrico Letta's PD but later broke the alliance and formed a centrist alliance named Action – Italia Viva (A–IV) with Matteo Renzi's Italia Viva. The list ran a pro-nuclear power and pro-regasification campaign as solutions for the ongoing energy crisis. 

Calenda has written three books: "Orizzonti selvaggi" (2018), "I mostri" (2020), and "La libertà che non libera" (2022).

Carlo Fidanza, Italian politician, born 21 September 1976 in San Benedetto del Tronto, Italy, residing in Milan. He is a member of Brothers of Italy (FdI) and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2019, previously holding a seat from 2009 to 2014. Fidanza was a member of the Italian Social Movement (MSI) until 1995, then joined National Alliance (AN) until 2009, and The People of Freedom (PdL) until 2012. He served in various positions, including group leader of Alleanza Nazionale in the Council of Zone 5 in Milan, municipal councilor in Milan, and president of the Multidisciplinary Cynological Observatory (O.Ci.M.). Fidanza was a full member of the Transport and Tourism Commission and alternate member of the Agriculture Commission in the European Parliament. He is currently a member of the Transport, Post and Telecommunications Commission and has been involved in several controversies, including a corruption investigation and allegations of illegal financing and money laundering. Fidanza has been elected co-president of the Parliamentary Intergroup on Religious Freedom (FORB).

Carlos Coelho, Portuguese politician, born 20 May 1960, in Lisbon, Portugal. He is a member of the Social Democratic Party, affiliated with the European People's Party (EPP). Coelho studied at the University of Lisbon. He has been a member of the European Parliament for Portugal, serving from 1998 to 2019 and again since 2023. He has held various positions, including chairman of the Temporary Committee on the ECHELON Interception System and the Temporary Committee on the alleged use of European countries by the CIA for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights and the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability. In Portugal, he has served as Undersecretary of State Adjunct to the Minister of Education, and as President of the Social Democratic Youth.

Carlos Zorrinho, Portuguese politician and university professor, born 28 May 1959 in Óbidos, Portugal, graduated in Business Management at the University of Évora, Doctorate Degree in Information Management, Full Professor of the Department of Business Administration at the University of Évora, Member of the National Council of the Socialist Party since 1990, Member of the National Parliament 1995-2000, Vice-President of the Socialist Party’s Parliamentary Group 1999, coordinated the ProAlentejo 1997-1999, Member of the National Council for Education 2000, Secretary of State Deputy to the Minister for Home Office 2000-2002, National Coordinator of the Lisbon Strategy and the Technological Plan 2005, Secretary of State for Energy and Innovation 2009-2011, Leader of the Socialist Party’s Parliamentary Group 2011, Member of the European Parliament 2014-present, Head of the Portuguese Delegation, Vice-chair of the Delegation for the External Relations of the European Parliament to Brazil, Member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, EUROLAT, ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, substitute member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Parliament's delegation for relations to the MERCOSUR, member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, and the European Internet Forum, Co-President of the Parliamentary Assembly of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Organization-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly 2023, affiliated with the Socialist Party and the S&D group.

Carmen Gabriela Avram, a Romanian journalist and politician, born on 8 May 1966 in Vișeu de Sus, Maramureș County, Romania, with a father who was a Romanian language professor and a mother who worked as a chemical laboratory analyst. She attended the local German-language school, graduated from Garabet Ibrăileanu High School in Iași in 1984, and the Faculty of Construction and Engineering at the Gheorghe Asachi Polytechnic Institute in 1989. She also undertook postgraduate studies at the National University of Political Studies and Public Administration, specializing in International Relations, graduating in 2004. 

She worked as a civil engineer, a substitute mathematics teacher, and a journalist for leading Romanian broadcasters ProTV and Antena 3. She was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in May 2019 on behalf of the Social Democratic Party and is a full member of the Party of European Socialists and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. She is a member of several parliamentary committees, including the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport, and Delegation to the EURONEST Parliamentary Assembly. She is also a substitute member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and Committee on Fisheries.

She has received numerous awards and distinctions for her journalistic work, including the APTR "Human Condition Award", Association for International Broadcastings Jury Commendations, and Emmy International Television Awards nominations. She speaks Romanian, German, French, English, Spanish, and Hebrew, and is a member of the Romanian Orthodox Church.

Caroline Nagtegaal, a Dutch politician from the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD), served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 14 November 2017 to 15 July 2024, representing the Netherlands constituency. Born on 1 June 1980 in Utrecht, Netherlands, Nagtegaal held committee assignments including the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (2017-2019) and the Committee on Transport and Tourism (2019-2024). She co-authored a 2019 resolution on cybersecurity risks posed by trade with China and was shadow rapporteur for a regulation on charging stations along European highways. Nagtegaal was part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the Arab Peninsula, Mercosur, and the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, and a member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas and LGBT Rights.

Caroline Roose, a Belgian politician active in France, born on 10 November 1968 in Ostend, Belgium, and residing in Villeneuve-Loubet since childhood. She is a member of Europe Ecology – The Greens (EELV) and served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, representing the constituency of France. Her committee assignments include the Committee on Regional Development (2019-present) and the Committee on Fisheries (2020-present), as well as the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport (2020). She is also part of the Parliament's delegations to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and a member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Welfare and Conservation of Animals and Western Sahara, and the MEP Alliance for Mental Health. She endorsed Yannick Jadot as the Green movement's candidate for the French presidential election in 2022.

Caroline Voaden, a British politician and journalist, born on 22 November 1968, in Wantage, Berkshire, England. She studied French and Economics at the University of Sheffield. Voaden worked for Reuters from 1991 to 2000, covering assignments in Amsterdam, Dublin, Bonn, Belgrade, and Zagreb. She was the youngest female bureau chief at Reuters while covering the Yugoslav Wars in Zagreb. After being widowed in 2007, she moved to Devon and founded her own modern craft brand in 2012. Voaden was the operations manager at a resettlement charity and the chair of the national WAY Foundation from 2009 to 2011. She served as the online editor for JustGiving from 2000 to 2007 and as the chief executive of Devon Rape Crisis & Sexual Abuse Services from November 2021 to May 2023. Voaden joined the Liberal Democrats in 2016 and was elected as Member of the European Parliament for the South West of England constituency in 2019. She was the leader of the Liberal Democrats in the European Parliament from 12 November 2019 to 31 January 2020. In the 2024 general election, Voaden was elected as the Member of Parliament for the South Devon constituency, with 22,540 votes (46.0%) and a majority of 7,127.

Caterina Chinnici, born 5 November 1954 in Palermo, Italy, daughter of judge Rocco Chinnici, killed by the Sicilian Mafia in 1983. Graduated in law at 21 years old from the University of Palermo. Served as Prosecutor General of the Court of Appeal of Caltanissetta and Public Prosecutor at the juvenile court in Caltanissetta and Palermo. Regional councillor for family and local governments from 2009 to 2012 and regional councillor for the civil service until July 2012. Member of the European Parliament for Italian Islands since 25 May 2014. Initially a member of the Democratic Party, switched to Forza Italia in 2023. Married to Manlio Averna with 2 children. Member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, vice-chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control since 2019, and member of the Special Committee on Terrorism from 2017 to 2018. Co-chairwoman of the European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights, and member of the intergroups on Fighting against Poverty, Integrity, and Cancer. Released the autobiographical book È così lieve il tuo bacio sulla fronte in 2014. Ran as the centre-left coalition candidate in the 2022 Sicilian regional election, placing third.

Create politician profile for Henriëtte Catharina Rinzema: 
Born: 4 July 1985, 
Party: People's Party for Freedom and Democracy, 
Office: Member of the European Parliament, 
Term Start: January 2022,
