Catherine Zena Bearder, a British Liberal Democrat politician, born on January 14, 1949, in Hertfordshire, UK, married to Professor Simon Bearder with three sons. She was educated at Hawthorne's School and St Christopher School, and worked as a development officer for national charities before entering politics. Bearder served as a councillor in Cherwell and Oxfordshire County Council, and was a parliamentary candidate for Banbury and Henley. She was a Member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2009 to 2020, and held various leadership positions including Leader of the Liberal Democrats in the European Parliament, Quaestor of the European Parliament, and Liberal Democrat Europe Spokesperson. Her key focus areas include environmental issues, wildlife conservation, biodiversity, human trafficking, and gender equality.

Catherine Chabaud, a French politician, born 29 November 1962 in Bron, France, is a member of the Democratic Movement and the European Democratic Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019, with her term ending on 15 July 2024. Prior to her political career, Chabaud was a navigator and journalist, notable for being the first woman to complete the Vendee Globe yacht race in 1997 and the only female to have skippered the winning entry on corrected time in the Fastnet Race in 1999. As a Member of the European Parliament, Chabaud serves on the Committee on Development and is part of the European Parliament Intergroups on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. She authored a 2021 report on marine plastic.

Catherine Griset, a French politician and Member of the European Parliament representing the National Rally party, elected to serve the constituency of France, first taking office on 2 July 2019 and re-elected in 2024.

Catherine Joanna Rowett, born 29 December 1956 in Yeovil, England, is a British academic and politician. She is a member of the Green Party of England and Wales and has been a councillor on Norfolk County Council for the West Depwade division since 13 July 2023. She previously served as a Member of the European Parliament for the East of England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. Rowett was a lecturer in philosophy at Swansea University from 1990 to 2000, Reader in Greek Culture at the University of Liverpool from 2000 to 2003, and has been a lecturer, Reader, and Professor of Philosophy at the University of East Anglia since 2003. She was awarded a Leverhulme Trust Research Fellowship from 2007 to 2009 and has published several books on Greek philosophy, including "Rethinking Early Greek Philosophy: Hippolytus of Rome and the Presocratics" and "Knowledge and Truth in Plato: Stepping Past the Shadow of Socrates". Rowett stood as a Green Party candidate for the constituency of South Norfolk in the 2015 and 2017 general elections.

Charles Goerens, a Luxembourgish politician, was born on 6 February 1952 in Ettelbruck, Luxembourg. He studied agricultural science and was first elected as a member of the Democratic Party in 1979. He served as chairman of the party from 1989 to 1994. Goerens has been a member of the European Parliament since 2009, previously serving from 1982 to 1984 and 1994 to 1999. He was Minister for Cooperation, Humanitarian Action, and Defence from 1999 to 2004 and briefly served as Minister for Foreign Affairs in 2004. He is a member of the Committee on Development, Subcommittee on Human Rights, Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and various intergroups. He advocates for associate membership of the United Kingdom to the European Union and fights against racism, xenophobia, and antisemitism. He is a member of the Democratic Party, Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, and Renew Europe.

Charlie Weimers, a Swedish politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2019, re-elected in 2024, representing the Sweden Democrats party. Born on 12 November 1982 in Karlstad, Sweden, and currently residing in Hammarö. 

Weimers was previously a member of the Christian Democrats (1998-2018) and briefly affiliated with the Moderate Party (1996-1998). He served as chairman of the Swedish Young Christian Democrats (2008-2011), vice president of the Youth of the European People's Party (2007), and district chairman of KDU-Värmland (2000-2001, 2003-2004). Weimers was elected to the Hammarö Municipal Council (2002, 2006) and the Värmland Regional Council (2006). He was Deputy Mayor of Hammarö (2010-2011).

Weimers is a member of the European Parliament Committee on Foreign Affairs, Delegation to Iraq, and substitute member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and Delegation to the U.S. He co-chairs the European Conservatives and Reformists Migration Working Group.

Policy positions: 
- Supports building a wall on the EU-Turkey border and adopting an Australian-style migration policy.
- Advocates for EU-financing of physical border barriers and reducing asylum reception.
- Opposes joint EU-debts and EU-taxes, questioning the legality of Next Generation EU.
- Proposes a referendum lock to limit transfers of power to the EU and enable Swedish EU-exit.
- Supports enhanced EU-Taiwan relations, including a bilateral investment agreement.
- Called for an investigation into China's handling of COVID-19 and supports a Special Committee to examine the origins of COVID-19.
- Condemns Russian invasion of Ukraine, supporting Ukraine and opposing peace negotiations with Russia.

Sanctioned by the Islamic Republic of Iran in 2022, which Weimers considers "a badge of honor."

Chiara Maria Gemma, an Italian politician, was born on 20 September 1968 in Brindisi, Italy. She holds a degree from the University of Bari and has worked as a university professor and politician. Gemma has been a member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Southern Italy. Her party affiliations include the Five Star Movement (M5S) from 2019 to 2022, Together for the Future (IpF) in 2022, and Brothers of Italy (FdI) since 2023.

Chris Davies, a British Liberal Democrat politician, was born on July 7, 1954, in Lytham St Annes, Lancashire. He was educated at Cheadle Hulme School, Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, and the University of Kent, Canterbury. Davies served as a councillor for Liverpool City Council from 1980 to 1984 and for Oldham Metropolitan Borough Council from 1994 to 1998. He was a Member of Parliament for Littleborough and Saddleworth from 1995 to 1997 and a Member of the European Parliament for North West England from 1999 to 2014 and again from 2019 to 2020. Davies was the Liberal Democrat spokesman on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee and the ALDE coordinator on the ENVI committee. He was involved in controversies, including being forced to resign as leader of the Liberal Democrats group in the European Parliament in 2006 due to comments made in emails to a Jewish constituent. Davies made comments on an unpublished report in 2008, claiming evidence of "embezzlement and fraud" among EU parliament members, and made a speech at the 2009 Liberal Democrat conference, expressing anger towards those involved in the MP expenses scandal. He won a parliamentarian of the year award in 2014 for his work on sustainable fishing and was a strong advocate for environmental and climate policies.

Chris MacManus, Irish politician, born 13 March 1973 in London, England, to Seán MacManus, a retired Sinn Féin politician, and brother of Joseph MacManus, an IRA volunteer killed in 1992. He moved to Sligo, Ireland in 1976. MacManus is a member of Sinn Féin and The Left in the European Parliament - GUE/NGL. He was a member of Sligo Borough Council from 1999 to 2014 and Sligo County Council from 2017 to 2020. He served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Midlands-North-West constituency from 6 March 2020 to 17 July 2024. He sits on the Agriculture and Rural Development Committee and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and is a member of the EU Delegations for relations with South Africa and Palestine. He was co-opted to replace his father in 2017 and retained the seat in the 2019 Sligo County Council election. He contested the 2016 Irish general election and lost his seat at the 2024 European Parliament election.

Chrysoula Zacharopoulou, a Greek-French gynaecologist and politician, was born on 7 May 1976, in Sparta, Peloponnese, Greece. She is a member of La République En Marche! and holds French nationality. Zacharopoulou received her PhD in endometriosis at the Sapienza University of Rome in Italy. From 2019 to 2022, she was a Member of the European Parliament, serving as a vice-chair of the Committee on Development and the parliament's rapporteur on the Africa-EU partnership. She also co-chaired the Shareholders Council of COVAX from April 2021. Zacharopoulou served as Minister of State for Development, Francophonie and International Partnerships from 20 May 2022 to 21 September 2024, under the governments of Prime Ministers Élisabeth Borne and Gabriel Attal, and President Emmanuel Macron. She has been involved in various groups, including the MEPs Against Cancer group and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. Zacharopoulou publicly criticized Vice-President of the European Commission Dubravka Šuica in 2020 for her past voting record on sexual and reproductive health and rights. She was investigated for rape allegations in 2022, but all investigations were closed by April 2023.

Christel Schaldemose, born 4 August 1967 in Odense, Denmark, is a Danish politician who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2006, representing Denmark. She is a member of the Social Democrats and the Party of European Socialists. Schaldemose has a master's degree in history from the University of Southern Denmark. She is married to Ib Lindstrøm and has three children born between 1996 and 2003. Schaldemose has been a member of the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Culture and Education. She has also been a part of the Committee of Inquiry into Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector and has served as the parliament's rapporteur on the Digital Services Act. Schaldemose is a member of several groups, including the MEP Heart Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals.

Christian Allard, born 31 March 1964 in Dijon, France, is a French citizen and Scottish politician. He is a member of the Scottish National Party. Allard has been a councillor for Aberdeen City Council since 2017. He was a Member of the Scottish Parliament for North East Scotland from 2013 to 2016 and a Member of the European Parliament for Scotland from 2019 to 2020. He has worked in the fishing industry for over 30 years. Allard has three daughters and six grandchildren.

Christian Doleschal is a German politician born on 27 April 1988 in Kemnath, West Germany. He is a member of the Christian Social Union (CSU) and the European People's Party. Doleschal has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Germany. He serves on the Committee on Regional Development and is part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Kazakhstan, EU-Kyrgyzstan, EU-Uzbekistan, and EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees, as well as for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia. He is also a member of the MEPs Against Cancer group and the chairman of the Young Union in Bavaria. Doleschal is a lawyer by profession and holds a degree from the University of Bayreuth.

Jan Christian Ehler, a German politician, born on 17 August 1963 in Munich, Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Ehler studied journalism, political science, and macroeconomics at Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich, and holds a PhD in political science. He has worked in various roles, including managing director of Biotech GmbH and Projektgesellschaft Bahnerprobungs- und Technologiezentrum, and as an assistant to the managing director of ddp/ADN. Ehler was a member of the State Parliament of Brandenburg from 1999 to 2004, serving as spokesperson on industry and technology policies. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004, serving on various committees, including the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence. Ehler is also a member of several delegations, including those for relations with South Asia, India, and the United States, and chairs the European Parliament Intergroup on Creative Industries. He holds memberships in various organizations, including the Atlantik-Brücke, Cyber-Security Council Germany, and the European Security Research and Innovation Forum.

Christian Sagartz, an Austrian politician, born on January 16, 1981, member of the Austrian People's Party and the European People's Party, serving as Member of the European Parliament for Austria since January 23, 2020, previously councillor, vice-mayor, and chairman of the town's party in Pöttsching, chairman of the Burgenland Young People's Party from 2002 to 2008, and chairman of the Mattersburg district chapter since 2010, with a background in political science, having earned a BA from the University of Vienna in 2010 and a master's degree in political consultancy in 2012, currently serving on the Committee on Development, the Subcommittee on Human Rights, and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, as well as being a substitute member of several parliamentary delegations, including those for EU-Albania, EU-Montenegro, ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and relations with South Africa.

Christina Jordan, Brexit Party politician, born 19 June 1962 in Johor Bahru, Federation of Malaya, Malaysian-born British, married with 2 daughters, residing in Salisbury, Wiltshire, England, worked as secretary in Turkish Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, cabin crew member for British Airways, trained as nurse at Royal Hampshire County Hospital, awarded Hampshire High Sheriff Award for Services to the Community, attended Queen's Garden Party at Buckingham Palace in 2015, voted for Brexit in 2016 UK EU membership referendum, served as Member of European Parliament for South West England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, member of Committee on Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety, part of delegation for relations with India.

Christine Anderson, born 29 July 1968 in Eschwege, West Germany, is a German politician and member of the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party since 2013. She completed a commercial apprenticeship and lived in the United States for six years, studying economics and working. Anderson was the AfD group leader in the Limburg-Weilburg district assembly from 2016 to 2018 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing Germany. She is a former activist of the Pegida movement and has expressed anti-immigration views, specifically opposing Islamic migrants. Anderson has also shown support for the Canada convoy protest and has been critical of COVID-19 pandemic measures, including experimental gene therapy treatments. She has been a member of several European Parliament committees, including Culture and Education, Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and Artificial Intelligence in the Digital Age. Anderson has three children and lives in Fulda.

Christine Schneider, a German politician, born 5 June 1972 in Landau, West Germany, is a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the European People's Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Germany constituency since 2 July 2019. Prior to this, Schneider was a member of the Landtag of Rhineland-Palatinate from 1996 to 2019, where she chaired the Committee on Agriculture from 2006 to 2016 and served as deputy chairwoman of her parliamentary group from 2016 to 2019. In the European Parliament, Schneider serves on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and is part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with South Africa. She is also a member of the Supervisory Board of Sparkasse Südliche Weinstraße.

Christophe Clergeau, born 1 September 1968 in Nantes, France, is a French politician from the Socialist Party. He is a member of the European Parliament, representing France since 2 June 2023, replacing Éric Andrieu. He has been a regional councillor for Pays de la Loire since 2004 and has held various positions including 1st vice-president delegated to economic development and innovation of the Pays de la Loire region, vice-president of the Regional Council of Pays de la Loire, and National Secretary for Europe of the Socialist Party since 2019. He is part of the Party of European Socialists and the S&D parliamentary group. His committee assignments include the Committee on Development and substitute positions on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and the Subcommittee on Public Health. He is also part of the parliament's delegations to the OACPS-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the Africa-EU Parliamentary Assembly, and for relations with Mercosur. His mother is Marie-Françoise Clergeau.

Christophe Grudler, a French politician and journalist, born 9 April 1965 in Belfort, France, educated at the University of Strasbourg, historian and journalist by occupation, Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019, re-elected in 2024, affiliated with the Democratic Movement and the European Democratic Party, part of the Renew Europe group, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and various delegations and intergroups including those focused on Artificial Intelligence, Children's Rights, Climate Change, and Animal Welfare.

Christophe Hansen, a Luxembourgish politician, was born on 21 February 1982, in Wiltz, Luxembourg. He is a member of the Christian Social People's Party (CSV) and has been the party's Secretary-General since 2021. Hansen is fluent in Luxembourgish, French, German, English, Spanish, and Dutch. He studied Geosciences, Environmental Sciences, and Risk Management at Louis Pasteur University in Strasbourg. Hansen has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2018, representing the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), and has served on various committees, including the Committee on International Trade (INTA), the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). He has been a quaestor of the European Parliament from 2022 to 2023. Hansen is married with two children and is the cousin of Luxembourg's minister of agriculture, Martine Hansen. He has been nominated by Prime Minister Luc Frieden to be Luxembourg's EU Commissioner in August 2024.

Ciarán Cuffe is a member of the Green Party and the European Green Party, born on 3 April 1963 in Shankill, Dublin, Ireland. He is a grandson of George Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Skakel Kennedy, and a granduncle of Patrick Little. Cuffe attended Gonzaga College, University of Maine, University College Dublin, and University of Venice. He has degrees in architecture and urban planning from University College Dublin and an MSc in cities from the London School of Economics. He was a Teachta Dála for the Dún Laoghaire constituency from 2002 to 2011, Minister of State from 2010 to 2011, and a Member of the European Parliament for the Dublin constituency from 2019 to 2024. He is a member of the TRAN and ITRE committees and has written reports on energy efficiency and the energy performance of buildings. He is the President of the European Forum for Renewable Energy Sources and has advocated for renewable energy, energy efficiency, and climate action. He has also promoted healthy eating, school gardens, local markets, and sustainable travel.

Cindy Franssen, a Belgian politician and Member of the European Parliament, born on 30 January 1976 in Oudenaarde, Belgium, educated at Ghent University, affiliated with the Christian Democratic and Flemish party, serving in the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Dutch-speaking electoral college of Belgium, member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, and the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with India, and member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Fighting against Poverty, Trade Unions, Disability, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, recognized as one of the 100 Influential Women in Oncology.

Claire Regina Fox, Baroness Fox of Buckley, is a British writer, journalist, lecturer, and politician. Born on 5 June 1960 in Barton-upon-Irwell, Lancashire, England, to Irish Catholic parents. She is the elder sister of British writer Fiona Fox and Gemma Fox. Fox was educated at the University of Warwick, graduating with a lower second class degree in English and American Literature, and later gained a Professional Graduate Certificate in Education from the University of Greenwich. She was a mental health social worker from 1981 to 1987 and an English Language and Literature lecturer at Thurrock Technical College and West Herts College from 1987 to 1999. Fox is the director and founder of the think tank the Academy of Ideas, formerly the Institute of Ideas. She was a core activist and organiser of the Revolutionary Communist Party for twenty years and later became a registered supporter of the Brexit Party. Fox was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and served until the UK's withdrawal from the EU in 2020. She was nominated for a life peerage by the Boris Johnson-led Conservative government and was created The Baroness Fox of Buckley on 14 September 2020. Fox sits as a non-affiliated peer in the House of Lords. She has been a vocal advocate for libertarianism, Euroscepticism, and free speech, and has been critical of multiculturalism and identity politics.

Clara Eugenia Aguilera García, a Spanish politician from the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, born on January 3, 1964, in Granada, Andalusia, Spain. She has been a Member of the European Parliament representing Spain since July 1, 2014. Aguilera is part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital and has received the Agriculture, Fisheries and Rural Development Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2023. She has expressed a controversial view on animal welfare, stating she is not interested in the happiness of animals she consumes.

Clara Ponsatí i Obiols, Catalan economist and politician, born 19 March 1957 in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Education: University of Barcelona, University of Minnesota. Occupation: Economist, Politician. Citizenship: Spain. 

 Offices held: 
 Counselor of Education of Catalonia (14 July 2017 - 28 October 2017), 
 Member of the Catalan Parliament (17 January 2018 - 29 January 2018), 
 Member of the European Parliament (1 February 2020 - present). 

Party affiliations: 
 JxCat (2017-2020), 
 Junts (2020-2024), 
 Alhora (2024-present). 

 Constituency: Spain (European Parliament constituency).

Clare Daly, Irish politician, Independents 4 Change, GUE/NGL, born 16 April 1968 in Newbridge, County Kildare, Ireland. Education: Dublin City University. Married to Michael Murphy from 1999, separated, with one daughter. 

Positions held: 
Member of the European Parliament for Dublin constituency (2019-2024), 
Teachta Dála for Dublin Fingal (2016-2019), 
Teachta Dála for Dublin North (2011-2016), 
Fingal County Councillor for Swords area (1999-2011). 

Party membership: 
Independents 4 Change (2016-present), 
United Left (2013-2015), 
Socialist Party (1996-2012), 
Labour Party (until 1989). 

Views and controversies: 
Opposed to EU militarism, 
Supported Russian positions on Ukraine, 
Opposed sanctions against Russia, 
Voted against resolutions condemning Russian invasion of Ukraine, 
Supported Palestinian rights and opposed Israeli actions in Gaza, 
Opposed US military presence in Iraq, 
Visited headquarters of Iraqi state-sponsored paramilitary network Popular Mobilization Forces, 
Supported Venezuelan and Ecuadorian governments, 
Opposed condemnation of Nicaragua, 
Sued RTÉ for defamation. 

Voting record: 
Against resolutions critical of Vladimir Putin's Russia, 
Against providing €1.2 billion in loans to Ukraine, 
Against a resolution condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine, 
Against establishing a tribunal to investigate the Russian leadership for crimes of aggression against Ukraine, 
Against a resolution to declare Russia a state sponsor of terrorism, 
Against condemning Nicaragua for the arrest of Rolando Álvarez.

Claude Gruffat, born 13 September 1957 in Rumilly, Haute-Savoie, France, French nationality, independent candidate on the list of Europe Ecologie Les Verts, Member of the European Parliament for France from 1 February 2020 to 15 July 2024.

Claude Moraes, a British Labour Party politician, was born on 22 October 1965 in Aden, South Arabia (now Yemen), to Indian Catholic parents from Karnataka and Mumbai, and grew up in Scotland. He studied law and international law at the University of Dundee, Birkbeck, University of London, and the London School of Economics and Political Science. Moraes worked as a researcher for MPs John Reid and Paul Boateng, a national officer at the Trades Union Congress, and director of the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants. He was a Commissioner at the Commission for Racial Equality from 1997 to 2002 and an elected council member of Liberty from 1994 to 2002. Moraes was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for London in 1999, serving until the UK's withdrawal from the EU in 2020. He held various positions, including chair of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, deputy leader of the European Parliamentary Labour Party, and vice-president of the Socialists and Democrats Group. Moraes was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in 2020 and awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Greenwich in 2022.

Claudia Angela Gamon is an Austrian politician, born on December 23, 1988, in Feldkirch, Austria. She has a bachelor's degree in International Business Administration from Vienna University of Economics and Business, and pursued her master studies there from 2011 to 2015. Gamon worked in her parents' wine business from 2010 to 2013, and later held various positions at the federal party of NEOS. She was a member of the National Council of Austria from October 2015 to 2019 and served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2024, representing the NEOS – The New Austria party. Gamon was a member of several committees, including Research, Innovation and Technology, Sport, and the Court of Auditors, and was part of the Spinelli Group, the MEPs Against Cancer group, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs) and Disability. She is Austrian by nationality and has been involved in various initiatives, including the initiative against church privileges.

Clotilde Armand, a French-born Romanian politician and businesswoman, born on June 28, 1973, in Pointe-à-Pitre, France. She is married to Sergiu Moroianu, a Romanian mathematician, and has 4 children. Armand holds degrees from École Centrale Paris and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She acquired Romanian citizenship in 2015. Armand worked for Airbus, Distrigaz Sud, and Egis, managing various projects and teams. She co-founded the Save Bucharest Union (USB) party in 2015 and ran for Mayor of Sector 1 in the 2016 Romanian local elections, narrowly losing to Daniel Tudorache. Armand was a Member of the European Parliament from July 2019 to November 2020, serving on the Committee on Budgets. She became the Mayor of Bucharest's Sector 1 in October 2020. Armand's political positions include anti-corruption, advocating for a change in the political class, and re-integrating people who need state help.

Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar, a female politician from Portugal, born on April 8, 1982, in Funchal, Portugal. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party. She has three children and graduated from the University of Minho. She served as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal from July 1, 2014, to April 4, 2024. She was a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Fisheries, where she served as vice-chairwoman. She was also part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with Brazil, South Africa, and the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Additionally, she is a member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and Artificial Intelligence and Digital. Prior to her European Parliament term, she served as a Member of the Assembly of the Republic for Madeira from June 20, 2011, to July 1, 2014. She also served as Secretary of State for Fisheries in the XXIV Constitutional Government of Portugal under Prime Minister Luís Montenegro and Minister José Manuel Fernandes, succeeding Ricardo Morgado.

Colm Markey, born January 3, 1972, in Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland. Member of Fine Gael and the European People's Party. Served as Member of the European Parliament for Midlands–North-West constituency from November 20, 2020, to July 17, 2024. Member of the European Parliament Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, substitute on the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the Committee on Fisheries, the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport, and the Delegation for relations with Mercosur. Former member of Louth County Council from 2009 to 2020 and former president of Macra na Feirme.

Constanze Angela Krehl, born 14 October 1956 in Stuttgart, West Germany. 
German politician and member of the Social Democratic Party, part of the Party of European Socialists. 
Graduated in computer science from the Technische Universität Dresden in 1980. 
Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 1994 to 2 October 2022, representing Germany. 
Held various committee assignments, including Committee on Regional Development, Committee on Budgets, and Delegation for relations with Russia. 
Chairwoman of the Delegation for relations with Russia from 1994 until 1997 and chairwoman of the Delegation to EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee from 1997 to 1999 and 1999–2002. 
Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. 
Part of the working group on European policy in the negotiations to form a coalition government under Chancellor Angela Merkel following the 2017 federal elections. 
Awarded the Federal Cross of Merit in 1998. 
Member of IG Bergbau, Chemie, Energie, and Socialist Youth of Germany – Falcons.

Corina Crețu, born 24 June 1967 in Bucharest, Romania, studied at the Academy of Economic Studies, Faculty of Cybernetics, graduating in 1989. She worked as an economist, journalist, and political commentator before joining the Spokesperson's office of the Cabinet of President Ion Iliescu from 1992-1996. Crețu was a member of the Romanian Social Democratic Party from 1996 to 2019 and joined PRO Romania in March 2019. She served as Presidential Advisor, Presidential Spokesperson, and Head of the Public Communication Department from 2000-2004. Crețu was a Deputy in Romania's Parliament from 2000-2004, a Senator from 2004-2007, and a Member of the European Parliament from 2007-2019, sitting with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. She was Vice-President of the European Parliament from June 2014 to October 2014 and European Commissioner for Cohesion and Reforms from 1 November 2014 to 1 July 2019. Crețu was married to Ovidiu Rogoz in 2012 and has a background in economics and journalism.

Cornelia Ernst, German politician and Member of the European Parliament, born 30 November 1956 in Bad Saarow, East Germany. Education: secondary school (1974), degree/diploma in education science (1979), PhD in 1983 at Leipzig University. Member of The Left Party and European United Left–Nordic Green Left. Parliamentary experience: Member of the Parliament of Saxony (1998-2009), Member of the European Parliament (2009-present). Previous roles: regional chairman of the Left Party in Saxony (2007-2009), parliamentary advisor for the state parliamentary group of the PDS in Saxony (1991-1999), chairman of the PDS in Saxony (2001), chairman of the state association of DIE LINKE in Saxony. Committee memberships: Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Regional Development, Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Industry, Research and Energy. Delegations: relations with Iran, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo. Speaker of the German Delegation of Left party.

Cristian Silviu Bușoi, a Romanian physician and politician, born March 1, 1978, in Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania. He is a member of the National Liberal Party (PNL) and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Romania since 2019, previously serving from 2007 to 2013 and 2014 to 2019. He chairs the European Parliament's Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). Bușoi graduated from the Medicine Faculty of the Carol Davila University of Medicine and Pharmacy in Bucharest in 2003 and has been a lecturer at the Victor Babeș University of Medicine and Pharmacy in Timișoara since 2007. He has been a member of the PNL's central political bureau since 2007 and has held various positions within the party, including vice president of the Timiș County party chapter and president of the Liberal Student Clubs. Bușoi has also been a member of the Romanian Chamber of Deputies for Timiș County from 2004 to 2007 and has worked on legislation related to education and healthcare. He is married to Georgiana and has authored several publications, including "Liberal Reform of Educational Services in Romania" and a guide to the Lisbon Treaty.

Cristian Ghinea, born July 20, 1977, in Bucharest, Romania, is a Romanian publisher, activist, and politician of the Save Romania Union party. He holds a degree from the London School of Economics. Ghinea's professional background includes being a journalist and social activist. He is the founder and director of the organization CRPE. From 2016 to 2019, he served as a Member of the Chamber of Deputies representing Bucharest. Ghinea was the Minister of European Funds in the Romanian government of technocrats under Prime Minister Dacian Cioloș from April 27, 2016, to October 26, 2016. He served as a Member of the European Parliament for Romania from July 2, 2019, to December 22, 2020. Ghinea has been the Minister of Investments and European Projects in the cabinet of Prime Minister Florin Cîțu since 2021 and the vice president of the Save Romania Union party since October 2017.

Cristian-Vasile Terheș, a Romanian politician and journalist, born on December 4, 1978, in Zalău, Romania. He studied theology at Babeș-Bolyai University in Cluj-Napoca, and journalism at Fullerton College in Fullerton, California. Initially a priest of the Romanian Greek Catholic Church, he was consecrated in Oradea and later worked as a clergyman in Irvine, California. Terheș transitioned to politics, initially supporting the Social Democratic Party (PSD), then joining the Christian Democratic National Peasants' Party (PNȚ-CD) in May 2020, and becoming a member of the European Christian Political Movement (ECPM). He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Romania in 2019. In 2023, he became the leader of the Romanian National Conservative Party. Terheș is known for his statements against COVID-19 vaccinations and pandemic-related restrictions, and has been critical of various government measures, including those related to the pandemic and online news regulation. He has also been involved in controversies, such as comparing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to Nicolae Ceaușescu.

Cristina Maestre Martín de Almagro, a Spanish politician from the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Spain. She has been a member of the Committee on Petitions and the Committee on Regional Development, and part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with China and the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs). Prior to her European Parliament tenure, she served as a municipal councillor in Daimiel from 2003 to 2015 and as a member of the Senate from 2004 to 2011.

Csaba Molnár, Hungarian politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from the Democratic Coalition, born 4 December 1975 in Csorna, Hungary, married to Kinga Szűcs with one son, András, former Minister of Transport, Communications and Energy and Minister of the Prime Minister's Office, served in the cabinets of Ferenc Gyurcsány and Gordon Bajnai, participated in a week-long hunger strike in 2012, member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and substitute member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, member of the parliament's delegation for relations with Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), elected to the European Parliament in 2014, representing Hungary, affiliated with the Party of European Socialists.

Cyrus Engerer, a Maltese politician, was born on September 28, 1981, in Tas-Sliema, Malta. He is a member of the Labour Party, having previously been a member of the Nationalist Party from 2003 to 2011. Engerer is a graduate of the University of Malta and the College of Europe, with a background in European Studies and Communications. He has been involved in various roles, including as a project manager at the Office of the Prime Minister, an adviser on EU funds, and a special envoy to the European Union for Prime Minister Joseph Muscat. Engerer has been a strong advocate for civil rights, particularly in the areas of LGBTQ+ rights and divorce legislation. He was a leading spokesperson for the Yes campaign in the 2011 Maltese divorce referendum and has worked to promote LGBTQ+ rights within the Labour Party. Engerer was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in November 2020 and serves on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the Constitutional Affairs Committee. He is the partner of Randolph De Battista, a Member of Parliament for the Labour Party. Engerer has been involved in controversy, including a court case related to the circulation of pornographic images, for which he received a suspended two-year jail term.

César Luena López, Spanish politician, born 29 October 1980 in Logroño, Spain. Education: licentiate degree in Humanities from the University of La Rioja (2003), PhD from the University of La Rioja (2014). Member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) since 2000, previously Secretary General of the Socialist Youth of La Rioja region (2002) and Secretary General of the regional branch of PSOE (2012-2017). Served as municipal councillor in Bobadilla (2003-2007), member of the regional legislature of La Rioja (2007-2008), member of the Congress of Deputies (2008-2019), and Member of the European Parliament (2019-present). Member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) and the Spinelli Group. Former Secretary of Organization of the PSOE (2014-2016).

Dace Melbārde, born 3 April 1971 in Rīga, Latvian SSR, Soviet Union, is a Latvian politician. She is a member of New Unity, having defected from the National Alliance in 2022. Melbārde was educated at Valmiera's 1st Secondary school, University of Latvia, Latvian Academy of Culture, and the University of Latvia's School of Economics and Management. She has a Bachelor's degree in History Sciences, a Master's degree in cultural theory, administration and history, and a Master's degree in company management. Melbārde worked as chief specialist of education and information work at the Latvian War Museum, led a cultural centre at the Latvian Police College, was deputy director of the National Youth Initiative Centre, general secretary at UNESCO's National Commission of Latvia, Chairman of the Council for the Conservation and Development of the Historical Centre of Riga, Member of the Council of Ministers Education for All, and Under-Secretary of State on Cultural Policy Issues of the Latvian Ministry of Culture. She was Director of the State Centre for Arts Education and Intangible Heritage, and Minister for Culture of the Republic of Latvia from 2013 to 2019. In 2019, Melbārde was elected as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the National Alliance and joining the European Conservatives and Reformists group. She has received several awards, including the Order of the Three Stars 4th class, the Spīdola Award, and awards from the Ministry of Education and Science and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Latvia.

Dacian Cioloș, born 27 July 1969, is a Romanian agronomist and politician who served as Prime Minister of Romania from November 2015 to January 2017. He was previously Agriculture Minister under Călin Popescu-Tăriceanu from October 2007 to December 2008 and European Commissioner for Agriculture and Rural Development from February 2010 to November 2014. Cioloș is the founder of the Freedom, Unity and Solidarity Party (PLUS) and was the president of the Save Romania Union (USR) from October 2021 to February 2022. He was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from July 2019 to July 2024 and the leader of the Renew Europe political group from July 2019 to October 2021. Cioloș is married to Valérie Villemin, a French agriculture expert, and has no children. He has a degree in horticultural engineering from the University of Agricultural Sciences and Veterinary Medicine of Cluj-Napoca, a master's degree in the economy of agricultural development from the École nationale supérieure agronomique de Rennes, and a doctorate in the economy of agricultural development from the University of Montpellier 1.

Damian Boeselager, a German business consultant, journalist, and politician of Volt Europa, born on 8 March 1988 in Frankfurt, West Germany, is a member of the European Parliament for Germany since 2 July 2019. He is affiliated with the Greens-European Free Alliance and Volt Germany. Boeselager studied Philosophy and Economics at the University of Bayreuth and Public Administration at the Hertie School of Governance in Berlin. He has worked as a management consultant for McKinsey & Company and initiated a journalistic travel project, Euroskop. Boeselager is the co-founder and Vice President of Volt Europa, advocating for pan-European, pragmatic, and progressive policies. He supports electoral reform, digital currency, improved health policy, better distribution of migrants, a common European asylum system, the European Green Deal, and European federalism. Boeselager has been involved in negotiations for the EU electoral law reform, the European Corona Recovery Plan, and the RePowerEU support programme. He has received the Hertie School’s Alumni Achievement Award in 2020.

Damien Carême, a French politician of La France Insoumise, born on 16 November 1960 in Joeuf, France, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, re-elected in 2024, representing the constituency of France. Formerly a member of the Socialist Party until 2015 and Europe Ecology – The Greens from 2015 to 2023. Served as mayor of Grande-Synthe from 2001 to 2019. Has worked with Médecins Sans Frontières on refugee shelter construction. Endorsed Benoît Hamon in the 2017 French presidential election. Serves on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and is part of the parliament's delegation for relations with South Africa. Divorced with two children.

Dan-Ștefan Drăgălin Montreanu, born 11 September 1970 in Orăștie, Hunedoara County, Socialist Republic of Romania, Romanian politician, former Minister for Agriculture in the first Tăriceanu cabinet from 2006 to 2007, member of the European Parliament for Romania since 2019, affiliated with the PNL and the EPP group.

Dan Nica, born July 2, 1960, in Panciu, Romania. Married with one child. Engineer and politician, member of the Social Democratic Party. Education: Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iași, doctorate in Communication Sciences in 2005. Career: worked at the Galați County Telecommunications Directorate from 1985 to 1996, associate professor at the University of Galați from 1993 to 1996. Elected to the Chamber of Deputies in 1996, re-elected in 2000, 2004, and 2008. Minister of Communications and Information Technology from 2000 to 2004, Vice Prime Minister and Minister of Administration and Interior from 2009, Minister of Communications from 2012 to 2014. Member of the European Parliament since 2014. Awards: Knight of the Order of the Star of Romania since 2002.
Daniel Buda, Romanian politician, born 11 January 1970, member of European Parliament since 2014, affiliated with EPP group, member of PNL (formerly PDL).

Daniel Caspary is a German politician and a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), part of the European People's Party (EPP). He was born on 4 April 1976 in Karlsruhe, Baden-Württemberg, Germany. Caspary has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 1 July 2004, representing Germany. He studied technical economics at the University of Karlsruhe and served in the federal German armed forces as a first lieutenant in the reserve. Caspary is married with five children and lives in Weingarten. He has been the chairman of the German CDU/CSU-delegation in the European Parliament since 2017 and deputy-chairman of the Christian Democratic Union in Baden-Württemberg since 2017. Caspary has been a strong advocate for EU trade policy, supporting the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). He has also been involved in various initiatives to improve working conditions in Bangladesh and ban the import of goods produced in forced-labour camps in China.

Daniel Freund, a German politician, was born on 14 October 1984 in Aachen, Germany. He is a member of the Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party. Freund earned a graduate degree in political science, economics, and law from Leipzig University, a master's degree in public affairs from the Institute of Political Studies in Paris, and studied at the Elliott School of George Washington University. He worked as an intern at Germany's Federal Foreign Office and the EU Delegation in Hong Kong, as a consultant for Deloitte, and in the office of MEP Gerald Häfner in Brussels. Freund was head of advocacy for EU integrity at Transparency International's Brussels office from 2014 to 2019. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, serving on the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and the Special Committee on foreign interference in all democratic processes in the European Union. Freund is also a deputy member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and part of the parliament's delegation to the EU-Montenegro Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee. He co-chairs the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption and is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. Freund has been chairing the Spinelli Group since 2021 and is part of the Centre for European Policy Studies/Heinrich Böll Foundation High-Level Group on Bolstering EU Democracy. He is married with one son and two daughters.

Daniel Hannan, Baron Hannan of Kingsclere: 
 Politician information:

  - Adviser to the UK Board of Trade (4 September 2020 - present)

Daniela Rondinelli, born 19 August 1967, Italian politician, member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Central Italy, affiliated with the Democratic Party (since 2023), previously with the Five Star Movement (until 2022) and Together for the Future (2022).

Danilo Oscar Lancini, Italian politician, born 15 October 1965 in Rovato, Italy. Served as Mayor of Adro from 2004 to 2014. Member of the League party. Became Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy on 17 April 2018, succeeding Matteo Salvini. Re-elected in the 2019 European Parliament election.

Danuta Hübner, a Polish politician, born on 8 April 1948, in Nisko, Poland. She is a member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the Civic Platform and previously affiliated with the Polish United Workers' Party from 1970 to 1987. She is also a member of the European People's Party since 2004 and the Civic Coalition since 2018. 

Hübner received her MSc in Economics from the Warsaw School of Economics in 1971, her PhD in economics in 1974, and a post-doctoral degree in international trade relations in 1980. She was a visiting scholar at the University of Sussex in 1974 and a Fulbright scholar at the University of California, Berkeley, from 1988 to 1990.

Hübner has held various positions, including Minister Head of the Chancellery of the President of the Republic of Poland from 1997 to 1998, Government Plenipotentiary for establishing the Committee for European Integration from 1996 to 1997, and Under-Secretary of State in the Ministry of Industry and Trade from 1994 to 1996. 

She served as European Commissioner for Regional Policy from 2004 to 2009 and as European Commissioner for Trade from 2004. Hübner was a member of the Amato Group from 2006 to 2007 and has been a member of the European Parliament's delegation for relations with the United States since 2009. 

She has been chairing the Committee on Constitutional Affairs since 2014 and previously chaired the Committee on Regional Development from 2009 to 2014. Hübner is a member of the Brexit Steering Group and has been serving on the Parliament's Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members. 

She has expressed her disappointment with the Brexit decision and emphasized the importance of understanding the UK's goals in the negotiations. Hübner voted in favor of a resolution invoking Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union in 2017, which could potentially strip Poland of voting rights in the EU for violating common values.

David Bull is a British television presenter, author, and politician. He was born on May 9, 1969, in Farnborough, London, England. He studied at Imperial College London and worked as a doctor before starting his career in broadcasting in 1995. He has presented numerous shows, including Newsround, Watchdog, and Most Haunted. He has also appeared on American television, including The Rachael Ray Show and Sugar Dome. He is openly gay and has been involved in various charitable work, including supporting the Cystic Fibrosis Trust and the British Red Cross. He was a member of the Conservative Party before joining the Brexit Party in 2019 and later becoming the Deputy Leader of Reform UK from 2021 to 2024. He was a Member of the European Parliament for North West England from 2019 to 2020. He ran as the Reform UK candidate for the West Suffolk constituency in the 2024 UK General election, coming in third with 20.8% of the vote.

David Casa, MEP for Malta since 2004, born 16 November 1968 in Valletta, Malta, member of the Nationalist Party and European People's Party, known for social rights, rule of law and anti-corruption activism, media freedom, Quaestor of the European Parliament, Co-Chair of the Media Working Group, EPP's Head of National Delegation for Malta, Coordinator for the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, substitute for the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee, successfully negotiated the Work-Life Balance Directive, the European Social Fund Plus, the Social Climate Fund, and the EU Disability Card and EU Parking Card, recipient of the Croce dell'Ordine from the Sovereign Military Order of Malta.

David Cormand, a French politician, born on 30 November 1974 in Mont-Saint-Aignan, France, with a degree from the University of Rouen. He is a member of Europe Ecology – The Greens (EELV) and previously of The Greens from 1999 to 2010. Cormand served as the national secretary of EELV from 11 February 2016 to 30 November 2019, succeeding Emmanuelle Cosse and preceding Julien Bayou. He was a regional councillor of Haute-Normandie from 2007 to 2015 and a municipal councillor of Canteleu from 2001 to 2020. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, representing France. He has served on the Committee on Budgets, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age. Additionally, he is part of the European Parliament's delegations with the Korean Peninsula and to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals.

Create a politician profile for David Lega with the following information:

Name: David Lega
Birthdate: 12 October 1973
Birthplace: Gothenburg, Sweden
Party: Christian Democrats
Occupation: Deputy Mayor of Gothenburg, public speaker, entrepreneur
Known for: Paralympic swimming, public speaking
Term as Member of European Parliament: 2 July 2019 - 16 July 2024
Constituency: Sweden
Committees: Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Human Rights, European Parliament Intergroup on Disability
Awards: JCI Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World (2005), Whang Youn Dai Achievement Award (1996)
Sports career: Paralympic swimmer, competed in 1996 and 2000 Paralympic Games, 1994 and 1998 IPC Swimming World Championships, 3 gold medals in 1998 IPC Championships
Business ventures: Lega Wear, companies in personal development and computer technology
Literary work: HANDS FREE - David Lega's Inspiring Journey (2008)
Executive boards: Swedish Sports Confederation, UNICEF Sweden.

David James McAllister, born January 12, 1971, in West Berlin, West Germany, to a Scottish father and a German mother, holds both German and British citizenship, and speaks German and English as native languages. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union, part of the European People's Party. McAllister is a lawyer by profession, studied law at Leibniz University Hannover with a scholarship from the Konrad Adenauer Foundation, and served his compulsory military service in the Bundeswehr from 1989 to 1991. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2014, serving as chairman of the Delegation for Relations with the United States, member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and vice chairman of the International Democrat Union. McAllister was Minister-President of Lower Saxony from 2010 to 2013, and chairman of the Christian Democratic Union of Lower Saxony from 2008 to 2016. He is married to Dunja McAllister, a lawyer, and has two children.

David Sassoli, Italian politician and journalist, served as President of the European Parliament from 3 July 2019 until his death on 11 January 2022. Born on 30 May 1956, in Florence, Italy, to Tuscan parents, his name was chosen in honour of David Maria Turoldo, an Italian presbyter and theologian. Sassoli studied at the Sapienza University of Rome, department of political science. He began his career as a journalist at Il Tempo in Rome, later working with various newspapers and the news agency ASCA. In 1992, he became a reporter for TG3, collaborating with Michele Santoro on programs such as Il rosso e il nero and Tempo reale. Sassoli hosted Cronaca in diretta in 1996 and became anchorman of TG1, where he gained popularity as a journalist. In 2007, he became deputy director of TG1 under Gianni Riotta. Sassoli supported Articolo 21, liberi di..., an Italian association promoting freedom of expression. 

In 2009, Sassoli entered politics, joining the centre-left Democratic Party (PD) and running in the European Parliament election for Central Italy. He was elected with 412,502 personal preferences, becoming the most voted candidate in his constituency. From 2009 to 2014, he served as PD's delegation leader in the Parliament. In 2012, Sassoli announced his candidacy for Mayor of Rome but ended up in second place. He was re-elected to the European Parliament in 2014 with 206,170 preferences. On 1 July 2014, Sassoli was elected Vice-President of the European Parliament. 

In 2019, Sassoli was re-elected to the European Parliament with 128,533 votes. On 2 July 2019, he was proposed as the new President of the European Parliament by the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Sassoli was elected President with 345 votes in favour, succeeding Antonio Tajani. As President, he paid tribute to victims of terrorism in Europe, attended the site of the 2016 Brussels bombings, and asked for the liberation of Oriol Junqueras, imprisoned after the 2017 Spanish constitutional crisis. In 2020, he ordered the cancellation of visits to the European Parliament due to the COVID-19 outbreak and self-isolated in his Brussels residence. 

Sassoli was married to Alessandra Vittorini, with whom he had two children, Giulio and Livia. He was a leftist Catholic influenced by Giorgio La Pira and don Lorenzo Milani. Sassoli was a fan of classical music and ACF Fiorentina, his hometown football team. He died on 11 January 2022, at the age of 65, due to a "serious complication due to a dysfunction of the immune system" complicated by his multiple myeloma.

Deirdre Clune is a member of the European People's Party and Fine Gael, born on 1 June 1959 in Blackrock, Cork, Ireland, to Peter Barry and with a grandfather Anthony Barry who were also politicians. She is married to Conor Clune since 1982 and has 4 children. Clune was educated at Ursuline Convent Cork, University College Cork with a B.E. in Civil Engineering, Trinity College Dublin with a diploma in Management Engineering, and University College Cork with an HDip in Environmental Engineering. She served as a Teachta Dála for the Cork South-Central constituency from 1997 to 2002 and 2007 to 2011, Senator for the Cultural and Educational Panel from 2011 to 2014, Lord Mayor of Cork from 2005 to 2006, and Member of the European Parliament for the South constituency from 2014 to 2019 and 2020 to 2024.

Delara Burkhardt, an Iranian-German politician, was born on November 3, 1992, in Hamburg, Germany, to an Iranian mother and a German father. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party (SPD) and the Party of European Socialists. Burkhardt studied political science at the University of Kiel from 2012 until 2016. Since 2019, she has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament, representing Germany. In parliament, she is a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and part of several intergroups, including the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, the European Parliament Intergroup on Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas.

Denis Nesci, Italian politician, born 25 July 1981 in Italy, member of the Brothers of Italy party, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy since 3 October 2022, succeeding Raffaele Fitto.

Dennis Radtke, a German politician, born 29 April 1979 in Bochum, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. Member of the European Parliament since 24 July 2017, representing Germany, affiliated with the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Previously a member of the Social Democratic Party until 2002. Served as trade union secretary with IG Bergbau, Chemie, Energie from 2008 to 2017. Committee assignments include the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and delegations for relations with the Korean Peninsula and the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions. Chair of the Christian Democratic Employees' Association in North Rhine-Westphalia since 2019, and member of the national leadership of the CDA. Nominated as delegate to the Federal Convention for the purpose of electing the President of Germany in 2022. Member of IG Bergbau, Chemie, Energie since 1998. Publicly endorsed Armin Laschet as the party's chair in the 2021 Christian Democratic Union of Germany leadership election.

Derk Jan Eppink, born 7 November 1958 in Steenderen, Netherlands, Dutch journalist and politician, studied Dutch law at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam and European law and International Politics at the University of Amsterdam. Worked as trainee at the European Commission, assistant to Members of the European Parliament, journalist at NRC Handelsblad and De Standaard, and cabinet secretary for European Commissioners Bolkestein and Kallas. Elected to the European Parliament for List Dedecker in 2009 and for Forum for Democracy in 2019. Member of the Dutch House of Representatives for JA21 from 2021, switched to the Farmer-Citizen Movement in 2023. Signed the Madrid Charter, a document describing left-wing groups as enemies of Ibero-America. Member of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group Executive.

Diana Riba i Giner, a 49-year-old female Catalan politician from Spain, born on 21 February 1975 in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain, with a degree in pedagogy from the University of Barcelona. She is a member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019. She is affiliated with the Republican Left of Catalonia and the Republics Now electoral alliance. She has a partner, Raül Romeva, and two children, Elda and Noah. Her career includes working at the Center for Initiatives and Research Centers in the Mediterranean Foundation, La Caixa Foundation, and running the Pati dels Llibres book shop in Sant Cugat del Vallès. She is a member of the Castellers in Sant Cugat and the Catalan Association for Civil Rights.

Diane Dodds, born 16 August 1958, in Rathfriland, County Down, Northern Ireland, is a Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) politician. She is married to Nigel, Lord Dodds of Duncairn, and they have three children. Dodds was educated at Banbridge Academy and Queen's University Belfast, where she studied to become a teacher. She served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Northern Ireland from 2009 to 2020, and previously sat in the Northern Ireland Assembly from 2003 to 2007 as MLA for West Belfast and from 2020 to present as MLA for Upper Bann. Dodds was also a member of Belfast City Council from 2005 to 2010, representing the Court District Electoral Area. She voted against a motion asserting the "existence of a clear risk of a serious breach by Hungary of the values on which the Union is founded" in 2018. Dodds is the DUP's Spokesperson for Education and Skills.

Dietmar Köster, a male, born on 6 January 1957 in Schwerte, Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany. He is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Köster graduated from the Ruhr University Bochum with a degree in social science in 1983 and obtained a doctorate in 2002. He served as the Director of the Geragogik e.V. Research Institute from 2002 to 2011 and has been a professor at the Dortmund Vocational College since 2012. Köster was a Member of the European Parliament representing Germany from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024. He was a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, Delegation for relations with the United States, and Committee on Legal Affairs. He also served as a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. Additionally, Köster is a member of the German United Services Trade Union (ver.di).

Dimitris Papadakis, Cypriot politician, born 22 August 1966 in Famagusta, Cyprus, serving as Member of the European Parliament for Cyprus since 1 July 2014, representing the Movement for Social Democracy until 2020 and as an Independent politician since 2020, member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee.

Dimitrios Papadimoulis, a Greek politician, born on March 21, 1955, in Athens, Greece. He is a member of the New Left party (2023-present) and previously affiliated with Synaspismos (until 2012) and Syriza (2012-2023). Papadimoulis studied civil engineering at the National Technical University of Athens and worked as an engineer and business executive for 25 years (1980-2004). He is married to Nadia Soubasaki and has two children. Papadimoulis has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2014, with previous terms from 2004-2009, and a member of the Hellenic Parliament from 2009-2014. He has served as Vice-President of the European Parliament since July 1, 2014, and is the head of the Syriza delegation at the European Parliament. Papadimoulis is a full member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and a substitute member of the Committee on Regional Development.

Dinesh Dhamija, a British Indian politician, was born in 1950 in Australia. He is a member of the Liberal Democrats and served as a Member of the European Parliament for the London region from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. He was educated at Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, and holds an MA in law. Prior to his political career, he was a successful entrepreneur, best known as the founder of online travel agency Ebookers, which he sold for £209m in 2005. He has an estimated worth of £100m as of 2004. He joined the Liberal Democrats in 2014 and has held various roles within the party, including Deputy Treasurer.

Dino Giarrusso, born 11 September 1974 in Catania, Italy, is an Italian television personality and politician. He graduated in Communication Sciences from the University of Siena in 1997 and worked as a journalist, collaborating with La Repubblica and L'Unità. Giarrusso was a television author for local Sicilian newspapers and worked on commercials and documentaries, often focusing on his homeland. He was an assistant director for Ettore Scola, Marco Risi, and Ricky Tognazzi, and played minor roles in Italian TV series. From 2014 to 2018, he worked as a correspondent for the TV program Le Iene on Italia 1. Giarrusso was elected as an MEP in the 2019 European Parliament election with 117,211 preference votes, making him the most voted candidate of the Five Star Movement. He represents the Italian Islands constituency in the European Parliament, having taken office on 2 July 2019. Giarrusso was a member of the Five Star Movement from 2018 to 2022, and later joined South calls North in 2022.

Dita Charanzová, a Czech politician, was born on 30 April 1975 in Prague, Czechoslovakia. She holds a doctorate from the University of Economics in Prague and graduated from the Diplomatic School of Spain in Madrid. Charanzová has two daughters and speaks fluent English, French, Spanish, and Russian. She was a member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, representing the Czech Republic, and served as Vice-President of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2024. Charanzová is affiliated with the Renew Europe group and was a member of the ANO 2011 party until 2023. Her areas of focus include digital agenda, consumer protection, internal market, and international trade. She has held various roles, including coordinator for Renew Europe in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and has been involved in child protection online. Charanzová has received several awards, including the MEP Award three times, the New Europe 100, and recognition from European consumer associations. She is a member of the European Council on Foreign Relations, the Aspen Institute, and the World Law Foundation.

Dolors Montserrat i Montserrat, a female politician from Spain, born on 18 September 1973 in Sant Sadurní d'Anoia, Catalonia, Spain. She studied law at Abat Oliva CEU University in Barcelona, and later specialized in urban, real estate, and environmental law. Montserrat is a member of the People's Party and has been involved in politics since 2007. She served as Minister of Health, Social Services and Equality from 2016 to 2018, and as a Member of the Congress of Deputies from 2008 to 2019. Since 2019, she has been a Member of the European Parliament, where she chairs the Committee on Petitions and serves on several other committees. Montserrat is an outspoken opponent of the Catalan independence movement. She has been Vice-Chair of the European People's Party in the European Parliament since June 2024.

Dominik Tarczyński, a Polish politician and journalist, born on March 27, 1979, in Lublin, Poland. He served as a community animator at London's Westminster Cathedral from 2003 to 2008, hosted a radio broadcast of Christian music, and was a lay assistant to a British exorcist. He was the director of TVP3 Kielce from 2009 to 2010 and later worked as the deputy director for operation in the IT and Telecommunications Center of TVP. Tarczyński was a journalist for Gazeta Polska, created documentary films, and founded the Association of Catholics Charismatics. He ran for the Świętokrzyskie Sejm in 2010 but was unsuccessful. He co-founded Solidarna Polska in 2011 but left in 2014. He was elected to the Sejm in 2015 and 2019 as a non-party candidate from the Law and Justice list. Tarczyński was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 and took office on February 1, 2020. He was re-elected to the European Parliament in 2024. His party affiliations include Law and Justice and the European Conservatives and Reformists Group.

Dominique Bilde, born 1 August 1953 in Nancy, France, is a National Rally politician. She was a Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024, initially representing East France from 2014 to 2019. Dominique Bilde is the parent of Bruno Bilde.

Dominique Riquet, a French Radical Party politician and surgeon, born on 18 September 1946 in Valenciennes, France. He served as the Mayor of Valenciennes from 2002 to 2012. As a Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, representing North-West France, he was part of the European People's Party group from 2009 to 2014, then the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe group, and later the Renew Europe group. He held various committee positions, including the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Budgets, and chaired the European Parliament Intergroup on Long Term Investment and Reindustrialisation. Riquet urged the replacement of the European Union's ambassador to Cuba in 2021.

Domènec Ruiz Devesa, a Spanish politician born on 3 March 1978 in Alicante, Spain, is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE). He has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Spain since 2 July 2019. Ruiz Devesa is part of the Committee on Culture and Education, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, and the Spinelli Group. In 2022, he was the parliament's rapporteur on a proposal for an overhaul of European election rules.

Dorien Rookmaker, a Dutch politician born on 30 July 1964 in Petten, Netherlands. She is a member of the More Direct Democracy party and has previously been affiliated with the Otten Group, Forum for Democracy, and Democrats 66. Rookmaker holds a propaedeutic degree in political science from Leiden University and a doctoral degree in Business Economics from the University of Groningen. She worked in the financial sector, including as head of non-financial risk management at NN Group and as a Risk Officer on the Executive Board of Nationale Nederlanden. Rookmaker was a municipal councillor in Groningen and a member of the Senate from 11 June 2019 to 11 February 2020. She served as a Member of the European Parliament from 12 February 2020 to 15 July 2024, initially as a non-attached member and later as part of the European Conservatives and Reformists group. Rookmaker is committed to fighting fraud and supports a European network of high-speed railway lines. She abstained from voting on the removal of Eva Kaili as European Parliament's vice-president due to insufficient information.
Dragoș Benea, a Romanian politician and Member of the European Parliament, representing the Social Democratic Party, from the Romania constituency.

Dragoș Pîslaru is a Romanian economist and politician of REPER who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He was previously a member of USR PLUS/USR. He also held the position of Minister of Labor, Family, Social Protection and the Elderly in the government of Prime Minister Dacian Cioloș from 18 April 2016, until 4 January 2017. 

He is a graduate of the Faculty of International Economic Relations within the Academy of Economic Studies in Bucharest with a bachelor's degree in International Economics. He holds a Master of Science - International Relations from the London School of Economics and Political Science in the United Kingdom and a Diploma of Entrepreneurship - Case Study Centered Learning at Harvard Business School. He holds a doctorate in economic sciences.

Pîslaru taught economics at ASE Bucharest as a university lecturer, at the Faculty of International Economic Relations. He was associate researcher at the Romanian Center for Economic Policies and executive director of the Applied Economics Group. Pîslaru held the position of administrator / general manager in the strategic consulting company, GEA Strategy & Consulting S.A.

In the European Parliament, Pîslaru serves on the Committee on Labor and Social Affairs, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. He is the parliament's rapporteur on the Support Program for Reforms, with a budget of 25 billion euros. He is also part of the working group within the ECON Committee dedicated to joining the euro zone.

Pîslaru is a member of the Competition Council Advisory Board, Romanian Society of Economy, The TCI network, Team Europe, and the Alumni Association in Romania of the London School of Economics. He has been involved in several projects on European policies, in particular regarding economic competitiveness, sustainable development and engines of growth.

He was born on March 23, 1976, in Bucharest, Romania. He is a member of REPER since 2022 and previously a member of USR PLUS/USR until 2022.

Dragoș Tudorache, a Romanian politician, born on January 14, 1975, in Vaslui, Romania. He is a member of USR PLUS/USR and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing the Romania constituency. He holds a position as deputy chair of the Renew Europe parliamentary group and is part of various committees, including the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age, and the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware. He is also a rapporteur on the United States-European Union relations and the Artificial Intelligence Act. Prior to his European Parliament career, he worked at the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), the United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK), the Delegation of the European Commission in Bucharest, and the European Commission's Directorate-General for Migration and Home Affairs. He was the Minister of Internal Affairs in the Cioloș Cabinet from 2016 to 2017. He has expressed political positions on issues such as the treatment of EU nationals in immigration removal centers in the United Kingdom. He is a recipient of the "MEP of the Mandate" award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2024.

Dubravka Šuica, a Croatian politician, was born on May 20, 1957, in Dubrovnik, PR Croatia, FPR Yugoslavia. She graduated from the University of Zagreb's Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences in 1981, majoring in English and literature and German language. Before entering politics, Šuica worked as a high school teacher, university professor, and principal in Dubrovnik for 20 years. She joined the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) in 1990 and became active in politics. Šuica served as the head of HDZ's Dubrovnik branch from 1998 to 2014. She was elected as the first female mayor of Dubrovnik in 2001 and re-elected in 2005, serving until 2009. Šuica was a member of the Croatian Parliament from 2000 to 2011, holding positions in various committees, including Chairwoman of the Family, Youth and Sports committee and vice-chairwoman of the Committee on European Affairs. She was also a member of the European Parliament from 2013 to 2019, serving as one of the deputy chairs of the EP's Delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. Šuica was elected as Vice-President of the European Commission for Democracy and Demography in 2019, a position she still holds. She is a member of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) and the European People's Party (EPP). Šuica is married to Stijepo Šuica and has one child.

Edina Tóth, a Hungarian politician and Member of the European Parliament for Fidesz, born on 11 March 1975, graduated from Pázmány Péter Catholic University in 1998 and Századvég School of Politics in 1999, with a background as vice-president of Fidelitas from 1996 to 2003, vice-president of European Democrat Students from 1999 to 2001, and work experience in the Hungarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as a political advisor to the European People's Party, and as a member of various committees including the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Committee on Industry, Energy and Research, Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and Subcommittee on Public Health.

Eero Olavi Heinäluoma, born 4 July 1955 in Kokkola, Finland, is a Finnish politician and a member of the Social Democratic Party. He studied political science but did not finish his degree. Heinäluoma is married to Satu Siitonen-Heinäluoma and has a daughter, Eveliina Heinäluoma, who is a member of the Finnish parliament. His wife passed away in 2016. He has held various positions, including Minister of Finance from 2005 to 2007, Speaker of the Parliament of Finland from 2011 to 2015, and Member of the European Parliament since 2019. Heinäluoma was the chairman of the Social Democratic Party from 2005 to 2008. He has been a member of the Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions and served as its director from 2000 to 2003.
