Heinäluoma has received several honors, including the Order of the Cross of Liberty, the Order of the White Rose of Finland, the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana, and the Order of Friendship, which he renounced in 2022. He is currently serving as treasurer of the S&D Group in the European Parliament and is a member of several committees and intergroups, including the European Parliament Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development.

Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, a Spanish politician from the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, born on July 12, 1975, in Bilbao, Basque Country, Spain, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 14, 2009, representing Spain, member of the Committee on Budgets, coordinator on the Committee on Budgets for her parliamentary group, rapporteur on the 2015 budget and the COVID-19 pandemic recovery fund in 2020, drafted legislation on cutting EU funds to member states that undermine the rule of law in 2019, member of the delegation to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, part of the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Integrity (Transparency, Anti-Corruption and Organized Crime), with a family background in politics as her mother Lentxu Rubial and grandfather Ramón Rubial were members of the Senate of Spain.

Eija-Riitta Korhola, Finnish politician, born 15 June 1959 in Lahti, Finland. Education: University of Helsinki (Bachelor of Arts in philosophy, 1990; Licentiate in philosophy, 1994; Doctorate in environmental science, 2014). Career: Development educator, Finn Church Aid (1993-1996); Assistant, radio editorial office (1994-1998); Journalist and educator on the radio, television, and press (1996-1999); Publicist, Helsinki Festival (1997); Member of the European Parliament (1999-2014); Party secretary, Finnish Christian Democrats (2003); Vice chairwoman, Finnish National Coalition Party (2006-2010); Chairwoman, First Step Forum (human rights organization) (since 2002). Former member of the European People's Party; served on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, Committee on Budgetary Control, and Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Elena Kountoura, Greek politician, born 2 November 1962 in Athens, Greece, daughter of Alexandros Kountouras, former Hellenic Army officer and monarchist. Graduated from the National Gymnastic Academy of Greece and the Department of Sport Science and Physical Education at the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens. Former international model, director of a women's magazine, and track-and-field athlete. Married to Sarantis Papachristopoulos, with two sons, Alexandros and Marios. Brother Nikos Kountouras is her political adviser. Speaks English, French, and Spanish, in addition to native Greek. 

Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Greece. Served as Minister for Tourism from 23 September 2015 to 3 May 2019 and from 27 January 2015 to 28 August 2015. Member of the Hellenic Parliament for Athens A from 2004 to 2015. Party affiliations: Syriza (from 2019), Independent Greeks (2012-2019), and New Democracy (until 2012).

Elena Lizzi, Italian politician, born 30 October 1967 in San Daniele del Friuli, member of the League party, served as Assessor for Culture and Identity, Education, Equal Opportunities of the Province of Udine from 2008 to 2013, Deputy Mayor of Buja, Assessor for Environment, Production activities, Community projects and Tourism of Buja since 2017, Member of the European Parliament for North-East Italy since 2 July 2019, term ending 9 June 2024.

Elena Nikolova Yoncheva, a Bulgarian freelance journalist and politician, born on 27 May 1964 in Sofia, Bulgaria, to a Bulgarian father, Nikola, and a Russian mother, Larisa. She graduated from Moscow State University. Yoncheva was in a relationship with Sergey Stanishev, former Prime Minister of Bulgaria, from 1994 to 2009. She has reported from various conflict areas, including Kosovo, Algeria, Chechnya, Israel, Somalia, Afghanistan, Iraq, Venezuela, and Colombia. Yoncheva was a correspondent for Bulgarian National Television and has authored over 25 TV documentaries. She was injured by a tear-gas grenade while reporting from Istanbul, Turkey, in 2013. Yoncheva was a participant in bTV's television series Dancing Stars in 2008 and co-anchor of TV7's show "The Original" since 2013. She filmed a documentary denouncing the trafficking of migrants through Bulgaria, allegedly facilitated by Bulgarian authorities. Yoncheva was elected to the European Parliament on the Bulgarian Socialist Party ticket in 2019 and is a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and the Democracy, Rule of Law & Fundamental Rights Monitoring Group. She is also part of the parliament's delegations for relations with Israel and to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean. Yoncheva was the chair of an inter-institutional negotiation group for the EU Migration Pact. She was nominated as a candidate for MEP from the DPS political party in the 2024 European Parliament election.

Eleni Stavrou, a female politician born on 4 July 1975, is a member of the Democratic Rally party, representing the Limassol constituency in the Cyprus House of Representatives. Her educational background includes studying English literature at the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, an MA in War and Mediterranean Studies, and a PhD in war studies from King's College London.

Italian politician Eleonora Evi, born 20 November 1983 in Milan, Italy, studied at Polytechnic University of Milan, working as a designer, Member of the European Parliament from North-West Italy from 1 July 2014 to 12 October 2022, Member of the Chamber of Deputies from Lombardy 1 since 13 October 2022, Spokesperson of Green Europe from 10 July 2021 to 30 November 2023 alongside Angelo Bonelli, previously affiliated with the Five Star Movement from 2013 to 2020 and Green Europe from 2021 to 2023, joined the Democratic Party in April 2024.

Elisabetta De Blasis, Italian politician, born 30 April 1974 in Avezzano, Italy, nationality: Italian, profession: Cardiologist, married to Angelo Cacchio, 3 children, Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy since 2 November 2022, previously affiliated with Forza Italia (2013-2018, 2022), Lega Nord (2018-2020, 2022-2023), currently with Brothers of Italy (2020-2022, 2023-present).

Elisabetta Gualmini is an Italian politician and university professor, born on 17 May 1968 in Modena, Italy. She is a member of the Democratic Party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for North-East Italy since 2 July 2019. Gualmini has committee assignments on the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. She is also part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee and a member of intergroups on Anti-Racism and Diversity, Western Sahara, and Fighting against Poverty. Gualmini holds a degree from the University of Bologna and a PhD from the University of Florence. She is married to Salvatore Vassallo and has two children.

Eliza Vozemberg, a Greek politician, was born on 14 September 1956 in Athens, Greece. She is a member of the New Democracy party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Greece since 1 July 2014. Vozemberg studied law and political sciences at the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens. She serves on the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Committee on Transport and Tourism, which she chairs, and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Vozemberg is also a member of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Ellie Chowns, a British Green Party politician, born on 7 March 1975 in Chertsey, England, with a background in geography, environmental studies, and development studies, holding a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Sussex, a Master of Professional Studies degree in sustainable development from the University of Middlesex, and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in international development from the University of Birmingham. Chowns worked for charities such as Voluntary Service Overseas and Christian Aid, and as a lecturer at the University of Birmingham, specializing in international development. She was a councillor on Herefordshire Council from 2017 to 2024, leader of the Green group, and Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands from 2019 to 2020. Chowns was elected as the Member of Parliament for North Herefordshire in 2024, overturning a significant Conservative majority with a swing of +34.4% compared to the 2019 election. She is a member of Giving What We Can, a community of people who have pledged to give at least 10% of their income to effective charities.

Elsi Katainen is a Finnish politician, a member of the Centre Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. Born on 17 December 1966 in Haapajärvi, Finland. She served as a member of the Finnish Parliament from 21 March 2007 to 28 February 2018, representing Northern Savonia from 2007 to 2015 and Savonia-Karelia from 2015 to 2018. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 March 2018, representing Finland. Her committee assignments include the Committee on International Trade from 2018 to 2019 and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development since 2019. She is also part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Elżbieta Małgorzata Kruk, born 19 November 1959 in Lublin, Poland, is a Polish politician and a member of the national conservative party Law and Justice. She attended the John Paul II Catholic University of Lublin. Elżbieta Kruk was elected as a member of the Sejm on 25 September 2005, representing the 6 – Lublin constituency.

Elżbieta Rafalska, born 22 June 1955 in Wschowa, Poland, is a Polish politician. She has been a Member of the Sejm since 2007 and previously served as a Senator. Rafalska was the Deputy Minister of Labour and Social Policy under Ministers Joanna Kluzik-Rostkowska, Anna Kalata, and Jarosław Duda. She served as Minister of Family, Labour and Social Policy from 16 November 2015 to 4 June 2019 under Prime Ministers Beata Szydło and Mateusz Morawiecki, succeeding Władysław Kosiniak-Kamysz and preceding Bożena Borys-Szopa. Rafalska has been a Member of the European Parliament for Lubusz and West Pomeranian since 2 July 2019. She is a member of the Law and Justice party and holds a degree from the University of Szczecin.

Elżbieta Łukacijewska, born 25 November 1966 in Jasło, Poland, is a Polish politician from the Civic Platform party. She served as a Member of the Sejm from 23 September 2001 to 12 July 2009 and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Poland since 14 July 2009, re-elected in 2014 and 2019. She is part of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and the Parliament's delegation to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.
Emil Radev is a Bulgarian politician serving as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the Citizens for European Development of Bulgaria party, and the constituency of Bulgaria.

Emma Wiesner, a female, born on 11 November 1992 in Västerås, Sweden, is a Centre Party politician and former energy systems engineer. She has been a Member of the European Parliament for Sweden since 4 February 2021, and is a member of the Renew Europe parliamentary group. Wiesner is a full member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Fisheries, and a substitute member of the Industry, Research and Energy committee, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and the Special Committee for the Protection of Animals in Transport. She was educated at Uppsala University.

Emmanouil Fragkos is a Greek politician and veterinarian, born on June 27, 1993, in Chios, Greece. He graduated from the School of Veterinary Medicine of Aristotle University of Thessaloniki in November 2016. Fragkos is a member of the right-wing Greek Solution party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Greece since July 7, 2019. He signed the Madrid Charter, joining the right-wing alliance organized by Spanish political party Vox.

Emmanuel Maurel, a French politician, born on 10 May 1973 in Épinay-sur-Seine, France. He was educated at Sciences Po and Paris-Sorbonne University. Maurel is a member of the New Popular Front and the Republican and Socialist Left. He was a member of the board of the French Socialist Party and a candidate for the leadership of the Socialist Party in 2018, but lost to Harlem Désir. Maurel was a member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, serving on the Committee on International Trade, the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, and the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering. He has been a member of the National Assembly for Val-d'Oise's 3rd constituency since 8 July 2024, and previously served as a member of the delegation for relations with India and chair of the delegation to the Maghreb countries.

Engin Eroglu is a German politician of Turkish descent, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Free Voters party. Born in Germany, he initially joined Bündnis 90/Die Grünen at 15 and left at 29, then joined Freie Wähler Hessen in 2012. He held various offices within the party, including state chairman of Freie Wähler Hessen and deputy federal chairman of the Free Voter Freie Wähler. Eroglu has been a member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Committee on Foreign Affairs, and several delegations. He is a member of the Renew Europe Group and the European Democratic Party. His professional background includes working as a bank clerk and independent branch manager. Eroglu is committed to preserving regional banking structures and has spoken critically of human rights violations under the Chinese regime.

Enikő Győri, a Hungarian conservative politician, born on 17 July 1968 in Budapest, Hungary. She is a member of the Fidesz party. Győri earned her degree at the Corvinus University of Budapest, Faculty of International Relations in 1992, and a PhD in 2000. She also participated in a course at École National d’Administration in 1997. Győri speaks English, Italian, Spanish, and French. She has held various positions including Member of the European Parliament (2009-2010, 2019-present), Ambassador of Hungary to Italy (1999-2003), and Ambassador of Hungary to Spain (2014-2019). Győri was the Minister of State for European Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (2010-2011) and Secretary of State of Foreign Affairs (2010-2014). She has been a lecturer at ELTE University in Budapest and Eszterházy Teachers’ College in Eger. Győri is married with two children.

Erik Bergkvist, a Swedish politician and former Member of the European Parliament for Sweden, born on 1 May 1965, died on 20 February 2024 at the age of 58 due to lung cancer, serving from 2019 until his death, and was succeeded by Linus Glanzelius.

Erik Marquardt, a German politician and Member of the European Parliament, born on 20 October 1987 in Neubrandenburg, Germany, representing the Alliance 90/The Greens party, serving the Germany constituency since 2 July 2019.

Erik Poulsen, a Danish politician and Member of the European Parliament, born on 16 June 1967 in Holstebro, Denmark, representing the Venstre party, serving the Denmark constituency since 14 November 2022.

Ernest Urtasun i Domènech is a Spanish ecosocialist politician and economist. Born on January 27, 1982, in Barcelona, Spain. He holds a licentiate degree in Economics from the Autonomous University of Barcelona and a postgraduate degree in international relations from the University of Barcelona. He is a member of Catalunya en Comú and Green Left. He worked as adviser for MEP Raül Romeva from 2004 to 2008, and later as a diplomat at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation. He was the director of the general secretariat of the Union for the Mediterranean from 2011. He has been a member of the trade union Comisiones Obreras since 2012. He served as Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2023, integrated within the Greens–European Free Alliance (Greens/EFA) political group. He was a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, the Delegation for relations with the countries of Central America, and the Delegation for relations with Iran. He received the Economics & Monetary Affairs, Taxation & Budgets award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020. He was appointed Minister of Culture on November 21, 2023.

Ernő Schaller-Baross, a Hungarian diplomat and politician, born January 30, 1987, in Budapest, Hungary. He is a member of the national-conservative party Fidesz. He studied at the Austrian High School in Budapest and graduated from the Faculty of Law of Károli Gáspár University in Hungary in 2010. He worked as a desk officer at the Ministry of Public Administration and Justice of Hungary from 2010 to 2013 and as the Director of International Affairs of the Foundation for a Civic Hungary from 2013 to 2018. He served as the Deputy State Secretary for International Affairs at the Prime Minister's Office of Hungary from May 2018 to January 2021 and as a Ministerial Commissioner at the Prime Minister's Office of Hungary in 2020. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since January 2021, serving on the Committee on Legal Affairs, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence, and Committee on International Trade. He is also a board member of the Hungarian Golf Federation and a member of the Supervisory Board of the Otto Habsburg Foundation. He participated in the James S. Denton Transatlantic Fellowship and the International Visitor Leadership Program.

Esther Sanz Selva, a Spanish politician, MEP, born on 2 July 1985, in Valencia, Spain, member of Podemos, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 21 December 2023, succeeding Ernest Urtasun.

Esther de Lange, a Dutch politician and member of the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) and European People's Party (EPP), served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 2007 to 2024. Born on 19 February 1975 in Spaubeek, Netherlands, she was educated at Utrecht University and The Hague University of Applied Sciences. De Lange has been a strong advocate for agriculture, food safety, and sustainability, and has held various positions within the European Parliament, including Vice President of the EPP Group and Vice President of the EPP Party. She has been an outspoken critic of right-wing populist movements in the EU and has expressed frustration with the lack of understanding for the situation of parents in the European Parliament. De Lange has been a member of several committees, including the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety, and the Committee on Industry, Research, and Energy. She has also been a part of various delegations, including the delegation for relations with India, the delegation for relations with Iraq, and the delegation for relations with the United States and Russia. De Lange has one child and commutes between the village of Driebruggen and Brussels. She stepped down as MEP in February 2024 to become the head of cabinet of European Commissioner for Climate Action Wopke Hoekstra.

Estrella Durá Ferrandis, a Spanish politician, was born on 22 September 1963 in Puçol, Valencia, Spain. She is a Professor of Psychology at the University of Valencia and a researcher at the Polibienestar Research Institute. Durá Ferrandis is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Spain. Her areas of expertise include social policy programs, unemployment, women's health, functional diversity, chronic illnesses, dependent elderly persons, and migrants. She is a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and a substitute for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Durá Ferrandis is also a member of the Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and a substitute for the Delegation for relations with the countries of Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

Eugen Jurzyca, born 8 February 1958 in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, is a Slovak economist and politician. He holds memberships in the Freedom and Solidarity (SaS) party and the European Conservatives and Reformists Group. His education includes the University of Economics in Bratislava and the Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service. Jurzyca has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Slovakia since 2 July 2019, with a term set to end on 15 July 2024. He also served as a Member of the National Council of the Slovak Republic from 1 July 2014 to 30 June 2019, and as the Minister of Education of Slovakia from 9 July 2010 to 4 April 2012, succeeding Ján Mikolaj and preceding Dušan Čaplovič. He has been a Member of the Bureau of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group since July 2019. Prior to his current party affiliation, he was a member of the Slovak Democratic and Christian Union – Democratic Party (SDKÚ-DS). Jurzyca has promoted public debt reduction, evidence-based policymaking, and a favorable business environment. He has held various positions, including co-founder of Slovak economic think-tank INEKO, Business Alliance of Slovakia (PAS), and Slovak branch of Transparency International, as well as Member of the Bank Board of the Slovak National Bank, Deputy Chairman of the Antimonopoly Office, and a member of the Government Economic Council. He received the Order of Ľudovít Štúr of the second class in 2005. Jurzyca is married with two children.

Eugen Tomac is a Romanian politician, historian, and journalist born on 21 June 1981, in Ozernoe, Ukraine. He studied at the University of Bucharest, graduating with a degree in History in 2003 and a master's degree in 2004. Tomac's professional career includes working as an editor at various newspapers and radio stations, teaching history, and serving as an Expert in the Presidential Administration. He has been a member of the Democratic Liberal Party and the People's Movement Party, which he founded in 2013 and has been leading since 2018. Tomac has held various offices, including Secretary of State for Romanians Abroad, Member of the Chamber of Deputies, and Member of the European Parliament. He has been an advocate for the rights of Romanians living abroad, children's rights, and human rights, and has been critical of Russia's actions in Ukraine and Moldova. Tomac has received several honors, including the Vocația Spiritului Balcanic Award and the Dimitrie Cantemir Commemorative Medal.

Eva Kaili, Greek politician, born 26 October 1978 in Thessaloniki, Greece. Education: Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (architecture and civil engineering), University of Piraeus (Master of Arts in international and European affairs). Profession: Newscaster, politician. Party affiliation: PASOK (1992-2022), Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (2014-2022). Offices held: Member of the Hellenic Parliament (2007-2012), Member of the European Parliament (2014-2024), Vice President of the European Parliament (2022). Committees: Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Interests: Innovation Strategy, ICT, Technology, Foresight, Businesses, ESG, CSR, UN, WTO, OECD, Middle East. Personal life: Partner Francesco Giorgi, daughter born in 2021. Arrested in 2022 on charges of corruption and money laundering, suspended from European Parliament and PASOK. Released from pre-trial detention to house arrest in 2023, later released from house arrest. Under investigation for EU budget scandal charges.

Eva Konstantinova Maydell, born Eva Konstantinova Paunova, is a Bulgarian politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) representing Bulgaria, born on January 26, 1986, in Sofia, People's Republic of Bulgaria. She is a member of the GERB party and the European People's Party. Maydell is married to Niklas Maydell since 2017. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree from John Cabot University in Rome. Maydell was first elected to the European Parliament in 2014 at the age of 28, serving on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). In 2019, she was re-elected and continues to serve on the ECON committee and on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). Maydell is also a member of the Delegation for relations with Japan and the Delegation for relations with the United States. She is the EPP Group Coordinator/Speaker in the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in the Digital Age and co-chair of the European Parliament Digital and AI Intergroup. Maydell has been recognized as the European Parliament's "Best Newcomer" in 2015, featured in Forbes' "30 under 30" Europe selection in 2016, and listed in Politico's 40 most influential MEPs. She was the president of the European Movement International from 2017 to 2023.

Eva-Maria Poptcheva, a Spanish politician, was born on 17 October 1979 in Plovdiv, Bulgaria. She holds citizenship of Bulgaria, Germany, and Spain. Poptcheva studied law at the Albert Ludwig University in Freiburg, Germany, and later earned a PhD at the Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, Spain. She worked as a lawyer in both Spain and Germany before heading the European Parliament's Legislative Affairs Unit. In 2014, her book Multilevel Citizenship: The Right to Consular Protection of EU Citizens Abroad was published. Poptcheva served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Citizens party from 2022 to 2024, and later joined the People's Party in 2024. She was a member and Vice-Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and part of the Centre for European Policy Studies/Heinrich Böll Foundation High-Level Group on Bolstering EU Democracy since 2023.

Evelyn Regner, Austrian politician, born 24 January 1966 in Vienna, Austria, member of the Social Democratic Party of Austria and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Studied law at the University of Salzburg. Worked as a refugee consultant at Amnesty International and as a lawyer at the Social Department of the Austrian Trade Union Federation. Served as head of the department of EU and International Affairs of the Austrian Trade Union Federation. Member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing Austria. Served as vice-chairwoman of the Committee on Legal Affairs, coordinator of the Committee on Legal Affairs for the S&D group, and chair of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Elected vice-president of the European Parliament on 19 January 2022. Focuses on labour-related affairs, tax justice, social Europe, employment, and equality.

Evelyne Gebhardt, a German politician, born 19 January 1954 in Paris, France. Studied linguistics, political science, and political economy at the University Paris Diderot, University of Tübingen, and University of Stuttgart. Member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Served as a Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 1994 to 1 February 2022, representing Germany. Key interests include bio-ethics, consumer protection, and citizens' rights. Held various positions in the European Parliament, such as rapporteur for the Services Directive and the digital single market, and vice-president of the European Parliament from 2017 to 2019. Awarded the Federal Cross of Merit in 1999.

Evin Incir, born 15 June 1984 in Diyarbakir, Turkey, of Kurdish descent, is a Swedish politician for the Swedish Social Democratic Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since the 2019 European elections. Incir is a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. She received the Best Newcomer award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020, the award for diversity, inclusion and social impact in 2022, the Promoting European Value Award in 2023, and the European Values Champion of the Mandate award in 2024.

Evžen Tošenovský, a Czech politician, was born on 26 February 1956 in Ostrava, Czechoslovakia. He graduated from the VSB – Technical University of Ostrava in 1981. Tošenovský served as the mayor of Ostrava from 1993 to 2000, then as the governor of the Moravian-Silesian Region from 21 December 2000 to 13 November 2008. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for the Czech Republic on 14 July 2009 and will serve until 15 July 2024. Tošenovský is a member of the Civic Democratic Party and a recipient of the Légion d'honneur. He is married with two children.

Ewa Kopacz, a Polish politician, served as Prime Minister of Poland from 2014 to 2015 and as Vice-President of the European Parliament since 2019. Born on December 3, 1956, in Skaryszew, Poland, she is a member of the Civic Platform party and previously belonged to the United People's Party and Freedom Union. Kopacz has held various offices, including Marshal of the Sejm, Minister of Health, and leader of the Civic Platform. She is a pediatrician and general practitioner by profession and has been recognized for her efforts in improving air quality and healthcare. Kopacz has been married once and has one daughter. She has received several awards, including the Royal Norwegian Order of Merit, Order of Saint-Charles, and Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana.

Fabienne Keller, born 20 October 1959 in Sélestat, Bas-Rhin, France. Education: Lycée Kléber, École Polytechnique, National School of Rural Engineering, Water and Forestry, Masters in Economics from Berkeley. Career: Ministry of Agriculture (1985-1988), Ministry of Finance (Treasury Department), CEO of CIAL bank (1989), General Manager of Crédit Commercial de France (1996-2001), Mayor of Strasbourg (2001-2008), Member of the Departmental council of Bas-Rhin (1992-2001), Member of the French Senate for Bas-Rhin (2005-2019), Member of the European Parliament for France (2019-present), Quaestor of the European Parliament (2022-present). Party affiliation: UDF, The Republicans, Agir, Renaissance. Notable actions: voted for same-sex marriage in France (2013), wrote a report on congestion pricing (2018).

Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Italian politician, born 18 September 1985 in Rome, Italy, practising lawyer, graduated from University of Rome Tor Vergata. Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy since 2 July 2014. Formerly a member of the Five Star Movement (2013-2024), currently a member of Action (2024-present). Served as Vice-President of the European Parliament from 15 November 2017 to 18 January 2022, under Presidents Antonio Tajani, David Sassoli, and Roberta Metsola.

Filip De Man, born 11 November 1955 in Roeselare, West Flanders, is a Flemish politician and journalist, with an M.A. in philosophy. He is a member of Vlaams Belang and has been a Federal Representative since 24 November 1991. He is known for his outspoken right-wing views, particularly on immigration, crime, and energy. He advocates for a tough approach on crime, including the death penalty for child murderers, and has expressed doubts about mankind's role in climate change. He supports the concept of sub-nationality in Brussels and a confederate Europe with a strong emphasis on subsidiarity. He has written several books, including 'The Eternal Struggle' and 'L'Etat-PS. De maffia aan de macht'. His occupation is politician, and his nationality is Belgian.

Franc Bogovič, Slovenian politician, born 2 February 1963, Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, re-elected in 2019, part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, representing the Slovenia constituency.

France Jamet, a French politician, born in 1961, member of National Rally, serving as Member of the European Parliament since 2017, FN regional councillor in the Languedoc-Roussillon region since 2004, niece of French journalist Dominique Jamet, daughter of Alain Jamet, and unsuccessful contestant of Hérault's 1st constituency at the Legislative elections in 2017 and 2022.

Frances Fitzgerald, born 1 August 1950 in Croom, County Limerick, Ireland, is an Irish politician who served as a Member of the European Parliament from Ireland for the Dublin constituency from 2019 to 2024. She is a member of Fine Gael, part of the European People's Party. Fitzgerald previously held various positions including Tánaiste from 2016 to 2017, Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation from 2017 to 2017, Minister for Justice and Equality from 2014 to 2017, Minister for Children and Youth Affairs from 2011 to 2014, and Leader of Fine Gael in the Seanad from 2007 to 2011. She served as a Teachta Dála from 1992 to 2002 and 2011 to 2019, and as a Senator for the Labour Panel from 2007 to 2011. Fitzgerald is married to Professor of Psychiatry Michael Fitzgerald, with whom she has three sons. She was educated at the Holy Family Secondary School Newbridge, the Dominican College Sion Hill, University College Dublin, and the London School of Economics, where she studied a Masters in Social Administration and Social Work.

Francesca Donato, Italian politician, MEP since 1 July 2019, representing Italy in the European Parliament, initially affiliated with Lega Nord and the Identity and Democracy group, later becoming an independent politician and a non-inscrit member after expulsion in September 2021, born 25 August 1969 in Ancona, Italy, educated at the University of Modena, profession: lawyer, height: 1.75m, party affiliation: Christian Democracy (since 2023), previously affiliated with Lega Nord (2014-2021), term end: 16 July 2024.
Francesca Peppucci, Italian politician, born 2 June 1993 in Todi, Italy, Member of the European Parliament for Forza Italia, representing Central Italy since 6 April 2023, succeeding Luisa Regimenti.

Francisco Guerreiro, born 12 September 1984 in Santiago do Cacém, Portugal, is a Portuguese politician serving as an independent Member of the European Parliament for Portugal. He was elected as a candidate for People Animals Nature. Guerreiro is a vegan, lives in Cascais with his wife Sandra Marques and two children, and commutes between Brussels and Cascais. He initially worked as a market researcher and project manager for the European Commission. Guerreiro joined People - Animals - Nature in 2012, rose to the party's communications head in 2014, and entered the European Parliament in 2019. He left PAN in 2020 due to differences in opinion and joined the Green/EFA group. In 2021, Guerreiro announced he would join Volt Portugal after his mandate expired. His party affiliation is European Green Party since 2020 and Volt Portugal since 2024.

Francisco José Millán Mon, born 8 March 1955 in Pontevedra, Spain, male, politician, Member of the European Parliament, People's Party, European People's Party, 1977 graduate in law from Santiago de Compostela, 1979 diploma in International Studies from School of Diplomacy in Madrid, diplomatic career started in 1980, former positions include Directorate-general of Consular Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International legal adviser, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, First Secretary of the Spanish Embassy in Bonn, Cabinet of the Secretary-General for Foreign Policy, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Director of the cabinet of the Secretary-General for Relations with the European Communities, First consul at the Spanish Embassy in Rabat, Director of the Cabinet of the Secretary-General for Foreign Policy and the European Union, Director-General for Europe, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Adviser to the First Deputy Prime Minister of the Spanish Government, holder of several Spanish and foreign decorations, sits on the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs, substitute for the Committee on Development, member of the Delegation to the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly.

Franco Roberti, Italian, born in Naples on 16 November 1947, educated at University of Naples Federico II, profession: Magistrate, member of the Democratic Party, elected as Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy on 2 July 2019, serving on the Committee on Legal Affairs, delegations for relations with the Mashreq countries and to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, substitute member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, previously served as National anti-mafia and anti-terrorist prosecutor from 2013 to 2017, and as anti-mafia prosecutor in Naples, where he led high-profile operations against organized crime, including the arrest of mafia boss Edoardo Contini and the seizure of 11 tonnes of cocaine.

Frans Timmermans, male, born 6 May 1961 in Maastricht, Netherlands, Dutch politician, Labour Party (1990–present), GroenLinks–PvdA (2023–present), previously Democrats 66 (1985), Party of European Socialists, married to Irene Timmermans (2000), 4 children, educated at Radboud University Nijmegen (BA, MA), Nancy 2 University (LLM, MA), fluently speaks Dutch, Limburgish, English, French, German, Italian, Russian, Roman Catholic, career: Member of the House of Representatives (1998–2007, 2010–2012, 2023–present), State Secretary for Foreign Affairs (2007–2010), Minister of Foreign Affairs (2012–2014), First Vice President of the European Commission (2014–2019), Executive Vice President of the European Commission for the European Green Deal and European Commissioner for Climate Action (2019–2023), lead candidate of the Party of European Socialists for President of the European Commission (2019), lead candidate for the GroenLinks–PvdA alliance in the 2023 Dutch general election, parliamentary leader of GL–PvdA (2023–present), awarded several honorary doctorates and decorations, including Commander of the Order For Merit (Romania, 2006), Officer of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland (Poland, 2006), Knight of the Legion of Honour (France, 2007), Grand Cross of the Order of the Southern Cross (Brazil, 2008), 1st Class of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (Estonia, 2008), Grand Cross of the Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas (Lithuania, 2008), Commander of the Order of the Polar Star (Sweden, 2009), Grand Cross of the Order of Merit (Chile, 2009), Knight of the Order of Orange-Nassau (Netherlands, 2010), Golden Palm Decoration of Honour (Bulgaria, 2018), Time 100 (2021), Politico Europe's 28 most influential people in Europe (2021).

François Alfonsi, a male politician from France, born on 14 September 1953 in Ajaccio, Corsica, affiliated with the Party of the Corsican Nation and Femu a Corsica. He has been a Corsican nationalist since the 1970s. He served as Mayor of Osani from 2002 until 2020. He was a Member of the European Parliament for South-East France from 2009 to 2014 and for France since 2019. He was the President of the European Free Alliance from 2014 to 2019. He is part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-UK Parliamentary Assembly and a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages.

François Thiollet, French politician, born 21 October 1975 in Châteaubriant, France, member of The Ecologists - EELV, professor of history and geography, deputy principal of the Augustin-Thierry college, municipal councillor of Blois (2008-2014), vice-president of the “Agglopolys” urban community, municipal councillor of Valencisse (2020), member of the federal council of Europe Écologie Les Verts (2016), co-treasurer of the party (2021), MEP for France (30 November 2023), successor of Michèle Rivasi.

François-Xavier Bellamy is a French politician, essayist, and high-school teacher, born on 11 October 1985 in Paris, France. He was educated at the École Sainte-Marie des Bourdonnais, Lycée Henri-IV, École normale supérieure, Paris-Sorbonne University, and the University of Cambridge. He is a member of The Republicans party and has been the Executive Vice President of the party since 18 February 2023. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019 and is part of the European People's Party group. He has also been the Vice-Chair of the European People's Party in the European Parliament since 19 June 2024. He has been a member of the municipal council of Versailles from 21 March 2008 to 28 June 2020. He has written four books, including "Les déshérités ou l'urgence de transmettre" and "Demeurer". He has expressed conservative views on social issues, including opposition to gay marriage, abortion, and assisted reproductive technology for lesbian couples. He has also taken a tough stance on China and has called for European leaders to avoid becoming dependent on the country for technology.

Fredrick Federley, Swedish politician, born 6 May 1978 in Munktorp, Köping Municipality, Västmanland County, Sweden. Federley is openly gay and was married to Johnny Kroneld from 2012 to 2019. He studied legal and political science at Örebro University. Federley is a member of the Centre Party and was part of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe and later Renew Europe. He was a member of the Swedish Parliament from 2006 to 2014 and a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2020. Federley held various positions including Vice President of the Renew Europe group, chairman of the Centre Party Youth, and member of several committees such as the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. He resigned from politics on 11 December 2020 due to criticism for his relationship with a man who was on parole for child rape.

Frédérique Ries, Belgian politician, born 14 May 1959 in Balen, Belgium, member of Mouvement Réformateur (MR), graduated in Economics and mastered in Journalism at the University of Liège in 1981, commercial director at Radio FM56 from 1981 to 1984, producer and TV presenter at RTL-TV Luxembourg from 1984 to 1987, journalist at RTL-TVI from 1987 to 1998, Member of the European Parliament since 1999, State Secretary for European Affairs and Foreign Affairs in 2004, vice-president of the European Friends of Israel, member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Subcommittee on Human Rights, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Committee on Petitions, European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, MEPs Against Cancer group, and delegation for relations with Israel, supported proposal to restrict cultivation of genetically modified organisms in 2014 and reduction of single-use plastics in 2018, one of eight vice chairs of the Renew Europe group since 2019, Member of the Board of Directors of Fondation EuroMedA.

Fulvio Martusciello, an Italian politician, born on May 25, 1968, in Naples, Italy, studied law at the University of Naples Federico II, and became a licensed lawyer in 1993. He specialized in civil law in 1994 and joined the political party Forza Italia the same year. He served as the provincial coordinator of Benevento from 1994 to 2004 and as the Regional Director of Campania from 1995. He was a member of the regional council from 1995 to 1999 and again from 2005 to 2010. He was elected to the European Parliament in 2014, representing the Southern District of Italy, and is a member of the European People's Party. He chairs the delegation for relations with Israel and is a member of several committees, including the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. He has been involved in controversies, including investigations for irregularities in costs and alleged agreements with the Mafia.

Gabriel Mato Adrover, Spanish People's Party politician, born 29 April 1961 in Madrid, Spain. Education: Law degree from Autonomous University of Madrid. Occupation: Lawyer. Positions held: Member of the European Parliament (2009-2019, 2020-present), President of the Parliament of the Canary Islands (2003-2007), Member of the Congress of Deputies (2000-2003, 2008-2009), Member of the Parliament of the Canary Islands (1995-2003). Notable actions: Voted against EU sanctions on Hungary in 2018. Personal life: Older sister Ana was an MEP for the same party, passionate about tennis, qualified umpire, awarded the Grand Cross of the Order of Civil Merit in 2004.

Gabriele Bischoff is a German politician, born on 4 January 1961 in Bad Wildungen, West Germany. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party (SPD) and the Party of European Socialists. Bischoff graduated from König-Heinrich-Gymnasium in Fritzlar in 1980 and holds a diploma in political science from the Free University of Berlin, where she studied after initially attending the University of Marburg. 

Bischoff worked at IG Metall from 1991 to 2000, focusing on gender equality issues. She then served as an advisor on social affairs at the Permanent Representation of Germany to the EU in Brussels from 2000 to 2005. From 2006 to 2008, Bischoff worked as a special advisor at the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS) in Berlin. 

From 2008 to 2019, Bischoff worked for the German Trade Union Confederation (DGB) in Berlin, leading the trade union's work on European policies and serving as a member of the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) in Brussels. She was the president of the employees' group from 2015. 

Bischoff has been a Member of the European Parliament since the 2019 European elections. She serves on the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Bischoff is also a member of the Working Group on the Conference on the Future of Europe, the Parliament's delegation for relations with Mercosur, the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. 

Since 2021, Bischoff has been serving as vice-chair of the S&D Group. She was part of her party's delegation in the working group on European affairs during the negotiations to form a traffic light coalition following the 2021 federal elections and the negotiations to form a coalition government between the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the SPD following Berlin's 2023 state elections.

Geert Bourgeois, born 6 July 1951 in Roeselare, Belgium, is a Belgian politician of the New Flemish Alliance (N-VA). He is married to Betty Hoste and has two sons. He studied law at Ghent University from 1970 to 1975. He was a member of the Catholic Student Action (Katholieke Studentenactie – KSA) and later became involved with the Flemish Nationalist Student Union (Vlaams-Nationale Studentenunie) and the Language Action Committee (Taal Aktie Komitee). He has been involved in local and regional politics in Flanders since 1976. He was a member of the federal Chamber of Representatives for the People's Union from 1995 to 2001, and then for the N-VA from 2001 to 2004. He served as the Minister-President of Flanders from 2014 to 2019 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He was awarded the Japanese Order of the Rising Sun, 3rd Class, in 2016.

Geoffrey Van Orden, Brigadier, CBE, born 10 April 1945 in Waterlooville, Hampshire, England. British politician and former British Army officer. Served as Leader of the Conservatives in the European Parliament from 2019 to 2020. Member of the European Parliament for the East of England region from 1999 to 2020. Married to Frances Elizabeth "Fanny" Weir with three daughters. Member of the Countryside Alliance, BASC, research associate at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, Service fellow of King's College London, Freeman of the City of London, and the Worshipful Company of Painter-Stainers. 

Education: Mons Officer Cadet School, University of Sussex. Profession: Soldier. Military career: Intelligence Corps, served in Borneo, Northern Ireland, Germany, Berlin, and NATO headquarters in Brussels. Promoted to brigadier in 1991. Resigned commission in 1995 to enter politics. Senior advisor in the European Commission from 1995 to 1999.

Politician: Conservative Party. Served as Conservatives' spokesman for Foreign, Defence and Security policy. Vice Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, member of the Security and Defence sub-committee, Conservative Defence & Security Spokesman. Opposed to EU defence integration, advocated for revitalisation of the NATO Alliance, and promotion of Britain's defence industries. Eurosceptic seeking reform of the EU, opposed to European political integration, British membership of the euro, the Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe, and the Treaty of Lisbon. Voted to remain in the Brexit referendum for pragmatic reasons. Founding president of the New Direction think tank, member of the Bow Group think tank.

Geoffroy Didier, a French lawyer and politician, born on April 12, 1976, in Boulogne-Billancourt, France, and educated at Sciences Po, Paris 2 Panthéon-Assas University, and ESSEC Business School. He is a member of The Republicans party, previously affiliated with the Union for a Popular Movement until 2015. Didier has held various positions, including advisor to Minister Brice Hortefeux, deputy spokesman for Nicolas Sarkozy's 2012 presidential campaign, and deputy secretary general of The Republicans. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for Île-de-France from 2017 to 2019 and for France from 2019 to 2024, serving on the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age. Didier has also been a member of the Regional Council of Île-de-France since 2010 and worked for the law firm CARLARA. He has expressed support for various politicians, including Valérie Pécresse, Alain Juppé, François Fillon, and Christian Jacob, and has advocated for action against parental child abduction affecting Europeans living in Japan.

Georg Mayer, Austrian politician, born 12 October 1973 in Vienna, Austria, member of the Freedom Party of Austria and the Europe of Nations and Freedom, serving as a Member of the European Parliament from Austria since 1 July 2014.

Gerolf Annemans, a Belgian politician, born on 8 November 1958 in Antwerp, Belgium. He is a lawyer, journalist, and member of the Flemish nationalist party Vlaams Belang (VB) and formerly of its predecessor, the Vlaams Blok. Annemans is married to Monika D'hooghe and has three children. He graduated in law from the University of Antwerp in 1982. Annemans has been a member of the European Parliament since 2014, a city councilor in Antwerp since 2000, and a member of the Chamber of Representatives from 1987 to 2014. He served as the leader of the VB from 2012 to 2014 and led the Vlaams Blok and VB parliamentary groups from 1991 to 2013. Annemans is known for his advocacy of Flemish independence, strict migration policy, and revision of EU cooperation. He has written ten books on republican, ethical, and security matters, including "After Belgium, the orderly split-up" and "1914–2014: Van loopgraven tot republiek".
Gheorghe Falcă, born 22 January 1967 in Brad, Hunedoara County, Romania, occupation: politician, engineer, mayor of Arad from 2004 to 2019, current position: MEP in the European Parliament.

Gianantonio Da Re, Italian politician, born 6 September 1953 in Cappella Maggiore, mayor of Vittorio Veneto, member of the League party, elected to the European Parliament representing North-East Italy constituency since 2 July 2019.

Gianna Gancia, Italian politician, born 31 December 1972 in Bra, President of the Province of Cuneo (2009), member of the Regional Council of Piedmont (2014), and member of the European Parliament (2019) for North-West Italy constituency, affiliated with the League party, serving from 2 July 2019 to 9 June 2024.

Gilbert Collard, a French writer, barrister, and politician, born 3 February 1948 in Marseille, France. He studied law at Aix-Marseille University and Panthéon-Assas University. He is a member of Reconquête since 2022 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He previously served as a member of the National Assembly for the 2nd constituency of Gard from 2012 until 2019 and as Secretary-General of the Rassemblement bleu Marine from 2012 to 2017. He was a member of the National Rally until 2022 and the Socialist Party until 1992. He has worked as a barrister since 1971 and has defended high-profile clients such as Laurent Gbagbo, Charles Pasqua, and Marine Le Pen. He resides in Gallician, Gard, and has been married to Anne-Marie Collard since 1987.

Gilles Boyer, born 4 July 1971 in Paris, France, is a French politician of the Horizons party and member of Renew Europe. He is a graduate of Paris Nanterre University and University of Paris 1 Panthéon-Sorbonne. Boyer has served as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of France. He was re-elected in 2024. From 2 July 2019 to 18 January 2022, he held the position of Quaestor of the European Parliament under President David Sassoli, succeeding him Fabienne Keller. Boyer has been a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs since 2019 and the Subcommittee on Tax Matters since 2020. He is also part of the MEPs Against Cancer group and serves on the Advisory Committee on the Conduct of Members. Boyer was a key negotiator in the creation of the Ensemble coalition in May 2022. He has worked as chief of staff to Mayor of Bordeaux Alain Juppé and as a political advisor to Juppé during his time as Minister of Defense and Minister for Foreign Affairs. Boyer was also an adviser to Prime Minister Édouard Philippe. He is a member of the Board of Directors of École nationale d'administration (ÉNA) since 2019. Boyer has two daughters.

Gilles Lebreton, born 11 October 1958 in Brest, France, is a French lawyer and politician. He earned a doctorate in public law from the University of Paris II in 1987 and a doctorate of philosophy from the University of Paris IV in 1988. Lebreton is an Associate professor of public law at the University of Le Havre since 1990 and was the dean of the university from 1995 to 2000. He was the director of a research laboratory from 2000 to 2011. Lebreton has authored 15 legal works in France and is a Knight in the National Order of Merit and an Officer in the Order of Academic palms. He is a member of the National Rally party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for West France since 2014. Lebreton was a municipal councilor for Montivilliers and a member of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Agriculture. He is known for his report on the use of artificial intelligence in the military and sovereign domains, recommending the use of Lethal Autonomous Weapon Systems only as a last resort. Lebreton has expressed concerns about the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on public freedoms, signing a letter calling for postponing new legislation within the framework of initiatives such as the European "Green Deal". He has also expressed his views on the philosophy of Carl Schmitt, denouncing the "danger to public freedoms" that the author's thought constitutes. Lebreton has been an adviser to Marine Le Pen and a member of her strategic council for the 2017 French presidential campaign.

Gina Dowding, a British politician, born on 15 July 1962 in London, England. She is a member of the Green Party of England and Wales. She served as a Member of the European Parliament for North West England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. She was preceded by Wajid Khan and succeeded by the constituency being abolished. She has also held various councillor positions: Lancaster City Councillor for Marsh from 3 May 2019, Lancashire County Councillor for Lancaster Central from 2 May 2013, and Lancaster City Councillor for Dukes from 6 May 1999 to 3 May 2007, and for Castle from 1999 to 2003. She was first elected as a councillor in 1999 and joined the Green Party in 1986. She stood in Fylde at the 2019 general election, coming in fourth place.

Giorgos Kyrtsos, Greek politician, born 4 June 1952 in Athens, Greece. Member of the European Parliament since 2014, representing Greece. Formerly affiliated with the European People's Party (2019-2022), currently affiliated with Renew Europe (2022-2023). Served on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs since 2014 and the Committee on Foreign Affairs since 2019. Part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the NATO Parliamentary Assembly (2014-2019) and with the Arab Peninsula (since 2019). Expelled from New Democracy in 2022 due to criticism of the government's handling of press freedom. Has expressed support for sending illegal immigrants to remote islands for deportation, endorsed policy proposals by Kyriakos Velopoulos, and visited Taiwan in 2021 to show support for the self-ruling island. Criticized the European Central Bank's climate strategy, tabling amendments to prioritize inflation control over environmental considerations.

Giorgos Georgiou, a Cypriot politician, born 9 April 1963, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Cyprus since 2 July 2019, affiliated with the Progressive Party of Working People (AKEL) in Cyprus and The Left (GUE-NGL) in the European Union.

Giuliano Pisapia, Italian politician, lawyer, and former mayor of Milan, born 20 May 1949 in Milan, Italy. Married to Cinzia Sasso since 2011. Graduated with a double degree in Political Sciences and Law from the University of Milan. Member of the Proletarian Democracy party from 1978 to 1991, then joined the Communist Refoundation Party from 1991 to 2010. Ran as an independent candidate from 2010 to 2017, then founded and joined the Progressive Camp party in 2017, before becoming an independent again in 2018. Served as a member of the Italian Parliament from 1996 to 2006, and as the Mayor of Milan from 2011 to 2016. Elected as a member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing North-West Italy, and served until 2024. Known for his involvement in several notable trials with political implications, including the defence of Abdullah Öcalan and the family of Carlo Giuliani.

Giuseppe Ferrandino, an Italian politician, born 21 March 1963, in Ischia, Italy. He is an engineer by profession and holds a degree from the University of Naples Federico II. Ferrandino is married with 3 children. He was a member of the Christian Democracy party until 1994, then joined the Italian People's Party until 2002, followed by membership in Democracy is Freedom – The Daisy until 2007, and the Democratic Party from 2007 to 2022. He was an independent politician from 2022 to 2023 and is currently a member of the Action party since 2023. In the European Union, he was affiliated with the Party of European Socialists from 2018 to 2022 and the European Democratic Party from 2022 to 2023, and is currently a member of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party since 2023. Ferrandino has been a Member of the European Parliament since 17 April 2018, representing Southern Italy, and is a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. He is also part of the Parliament's delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly.

Giuseppe Milazzo, Italian politician, born 21 August 1977 in Palermo, member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Italian Islands constituency, affiliated with Forza Italia from 2013 to 2021 and Brothers of Italy since 2021, previously a member of the European People's Party Group from 2019 to 2021 and the European Conservatives and Reformists Group since 2021, also a member of the Sicilian Regional Assembly from 2013 to 2019.

Pina Picierno, born on 10 May 1981 in Santa Maria Capua Vetere, Italy, studied at the University of Salerno. She is a member of the Italian Democratic Party and the Party of European Socialists. Picierno served in the Italian Parliament from 2008 to 2014 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2014, representing Italy. She is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats group and has served on the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Picierno has also been a member of various European Parliament intergroups, including those focused on cancer, poverty, integrity, and Western Sahara. She was the recipient of the Justice & Gender Equality Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2019. Since 18 January 2022, Picierno has served as Vice-President of the European Parliament alongside other vice-presidents under President Roberta Metsola.

Grace O'Sullivan, an Irish politician, was born on 8 March 1962 in Tramore, County Waterford, Ireland. She is a member of the Green Party and the European Green Party. O'Sullivan served as a Senator for the Agricultural Panel from 2016 to 2019 and as a Member of the European Parliament for the South constituency from 2019 to 2024. She has a background in environmental activism, having worked with Greenpeace for 20 years, including as a crew member on the Rainbow Warrior when it was bombed in New Zealand in 1985. O'Sullivan has also worked as an environmental education specialist and ecologist. She is a mother of three and holds diplomas from the Open University, Waterford Institute of Technology, and University College Cork.

Maria da Graça Martins da Silva Carvalho is a Portuguese politician. She was born on 9 April 1955 in Beja, Portugal. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party. She holds a degree in Mechanical Engineering from the Instituto Superior Técnico of the University of Lisbon and a Ph.D. from the Imperial College of Science, Technology, and Medicine in the United Kingdom. 

She was a professor at the Instituto Superior Técnico in the Department of Mechanical Engineering, in the area of energy, environment, climate change and sustainable development. She served as Minister of Science and Higher Education from 2003 to 2005, and later as Minister of Science, Innovation and Higher Education in the cabinets of successive prime ministers José Manuel Barroso and Pedro Santana Lopes. 

She acted as adviser to Durão Barroso in his capacity as President of the European Commission from 2006 to 2009. She was a Member of the European Parliament for the Social Democratic Party from 2009 to 2014 and again from 2019 to 2024. She was a member of the Parliament's Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Fisheries, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in the Digital Age. 

She was rapporteur for the Strategic Programme of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, the Single Basic Act covering nine partnerships with industry under the Horizon Europe framework program, the European Partnership for High-Performance Computing, and the opinions on the New European Industrial Strategy and the Data Regulation. She was the lead rapporteur for the Regulation on the Protection of the Union against manipulating the wholesale energy market. 

She has been committed to gender equality issues, having been a negotiator for the European People's Party Group regarding the directive on the participation of women on the boards of directors of listed companies and rapporteur of the report on the Digital Divide between Men and Women. 

She resigned as an MEP on 1 April 2024 to become Minister of Environment and Energy in the government of Prime Minister Luís Montenegro. She is a member of the European Network of European Foundations, the Wilfried Martens Centre for European Studies, the Instituto Francisco Sá Carneiro, and the Re-Imagine Europa. 

She has received several awards, including the Grand Officer of the Order of Public Instruction, the Member of the Council of the Orders of Civil Merit, the award for the best Member of the European Parliament in the Future of the EU and Innovation category, the Femina Prize of Honour, the Prize Maria de Lourdes Pintasilgo, the IUMRS International Union of Materials Research Societies Global Leadership and Service Award, the Medal of Merit of the City of Beja, the Prize for the best Member of the European Parliament in the area of Research and Innovation, the CIRCE Prize, and the Portuguese Great Cross-Chancellery of the International Order of Merit of the Discoverer of Brazil.

Grzegorz Józef Tobiszowski, born 1 November 1965 in Ruda Śląska, Polish politician, Member of the Sejm since 25 September 2005, representing 31 – Katowice constituency, affiliated with Law and Justice party, educated at John Paul II Catholic University of Lublin, spouse Dorota Tobiszowska, previously praised the United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement in 2017.

Guido Reil, German politician, Alternative for Germany Member of the European Parliament, former miner, foreman at Prosper-Haniel mine in Bottrop, trained as a locksmith, former union leader, former member of Social Democratic Party of Germany for 26 years, councilor for SPD in Essen in 2009, withdrew SPD membership in 2016 due to disagreements on immigration policies, joined AfD in 2016, ran in 2017 German federal election, elected to European Parliament in 2019, campaigned on "rescue of the Ruhr area" and limiting EU powers, declared solidarity with Ukraine following Russian invasion, constituency: Germany, term start: 2 July 2019, parliament: European.

Gunnar Beck is a German academic, lawyer, and politician who served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2024, representing the Alternative for Germany party. He held the position of vice-president of the Identity & Democracy Group from 2022 to May 2024. Beck is a specialist in EU law and has taught the subject at SOAS, University of London since 2005. He has been an outspoken critic of the European Central Bank's policies, the German government's climate and energy policies, and Ursula von der Leyen's presidency of the European Commission. Beck has also denounced the Conference on the Future of Europe as lacking democratic legitimacy. He has written several books, including "The Legal Reasoning of the Court of Justice of the EU" and "Fichte and Kant on Freedom, Rights and Law".

Guy Lavocat, a French politician from Renaissance, born on 14 February 1963 in Pondicherry, India, served as a Member of the European Parliament from 12 January 2024 to 15 July 2024, representing the constituency of France, previously held by Stéphane Séjourné.

Guy Verhofstadt, born 11 April 1953, is a Belgian politician who served as the Prime Minister of Belgium from 1999 to 2008 and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2009. He is a member of the Open Flemish Liberals and Democrats party and has been affiliated with the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe and Renew Europe. Verhofstadt was educated at Ghent University and has been married to Dominique Verkinderen, with whom he has two children. He has held various offices, including Deputy Prime Minister of Belgium, Minister of Budget, and leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group. Verhofstadt has been a strong advocate for European federalism and has written several books on the topic, including "United States of Europe." He has received numerous honors and awards, including the European Book Prize and the Outstanding Achievement award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards. Verhofstadt has been a vocal critic of Brexit and has expressed concerns about the rise of nationalism and populism in Europe. He has also been critical of Russian President Vladimir Putin and has called for a more united European approach to defense matters.

Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield, a French politician from the ecologist party Europe Ecologie Les Verts, born on 8 March 1977 in Solihull, England, with French nationality, and an alumnus of Grenoble Institute of Political Studies. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of France, with a term set to end on 15 July 2024. Delbos-Corfield is deputy chairwoman of the Greens–European Free Alliance group and has served on various committees including the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Committee on Constitutional Affairs, and the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union. She is also a member of several groups such as the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and has been part of the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe and the EU-UK Parliamentary Assembly since 2021. Additionally, Delbos-Corfield is a member of the Democracy, Rule of Law & Fundamental Rights Monitoring Group and the rapporteur on the rule of law in Hungary, and has been part of the Centre for European Policy Studies/Heinrich Böll Foundation High-Level Group on Bolstering EU Democracy since 2023. She has four children.

György Hölvényi, a Hungarian politician from the Christian Democratic People's Party, born on 13 June 1962 in Budapest, Hungary, educated at Eötvös Loránd University, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Hungary since 1 July 2014, and previously as Secretary of State for Human Resources from 9 July 2012 to 5 June 2014.

Günther Sidl, a male Austrian politician, born on 19 March 1975 in St. Pölten, Austria, member of the Social Democratic Party of Austria, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Austria since 2 July 2019, member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, substitute member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and part of the Parliament's delegations to the EU-Kazakhstan, EU-Kyrgyzstan, EU-Uzbekistan and EU-Tajikistan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees and for relations with Turkmenistan and Mongolia, also a member of the Animal Welfare Intergroup of the European Parliament.

Hannah Neumann, German politician, Alliance 90/The Greens, European Green Party, born 3 April 1984 in Speyer, West Germany, studied media studies at TU Ilmenau and political science and media studies at Free University of Berlin, worked as legislative assistant to Tom Koenigs and chief of staff to Omid Nouripour in the German Bundestag, associate fellow at the German Council on Foreign Relations, Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on Subcommittee on Human Rights, Subcommittee on Security and Defence, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware, chairs Parliament's delegation for relations with the Arab Peninsula, member of European Parliament Intergroups on Anti-Racism and Diversity, LGBT Rights, and Anti-Corruption, part of Green Party delegation in working group on foreign policy, defence, development cooperation and human rights in 2021 federal elections negotiations, member of European Council on Foreign Relations, German Council on Foreign Relations, and Berghof Foundation Advisory Council, opposed Arctic LNG 2 project due to climate change concerns.

Hannes Heide, born 17 October 1966 in Bad Ischl, is an Austrian politician and Member of the European Parliament for Austria, representing the Social Democratic Party of Austria and the Party of European Socialists, having taken office on 2 July 2019. Heide serves on the Committee on Culture and Education, the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware, the Parliament's delegation to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the URBAN Intergroup, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara.

Harald Vilimsky, Austrian far-right politician, born 22 July 1966 in Vienna, Austria, married with one daughter, member of the Freedom Party of Austria and Identity and Democracy Party, part of Patriots for Europe from 2024, Member of the European Parliament for Austria since 1 July 2014.

Heather Anderson, born 31 January 1959 in Dundee, Scotland, is a Scottish politician and organic farmer. She is a member of the Scottish National Party. Anderson was a councillor for the Tweeddale West ward from 2017, and briefly served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Scotland constituency from 27 January 2020 to 31 January 2020, following the departure of Alyn Smith. She owns her own produce and butcher's shop in the Scottish Borders. Anderson was later elected as a councillor for the Coldside Ward in Dundee City Council at the 2022 Scottish local elections, winning her seat with 31.1% of the vote at first preference.

Heidi Anneli Hautala, born 14 November 1955 in Oulu, Finland, is a Finnish politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Finland. She is a member of the Green League, part of the European Green Party. 

Education: master's degree in horticulture from the University of Helsinki. 

Languages: Finnish, English, Swedish, German, French, and some Russian.

Career: 
- Leader of the Finnish Green Party (1987-1991)
- Presidential candidate (2000, 2006)
- Member of the national parliament (1991-1995, 2003-2009)
- Member of the European Parliament (1995-2003, 2009-2011, 2014-2019, 2019-present)
- Chair of the Subcommittee on Human Rights (2009-2011)
- Minister for international development and ownership steering issues in Jyrki Katainen's cabinet (2011-2013)
- Vice-President of the European Parliament (2017-2019, 2019-present)

Committee assignments: 
- Committee on Women's Rights (chair, 1998-1999)
- Greens–European Free Alliance (leader, 1999-2002)
- Committee on Legal Affairs (1999-2003)
- Committee on Development (2014-2019)
- Committee on International Trade (2014-2019, 2019-present)
- Subcommittee on Human Rights (2009-2011, 2019-present)
- Committee on Budgets (substitute member, 2014-2019)
- Committee on Legal Affairs (substitute member, 2019-present)
- Delegation for relations with the countries of Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations ASEAN (member, 2019-present)
- Delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee (substitute member, 2019-present)
- Delegation to the EU-Armenia Parliamentary Partnership Committee, the EU-Azerbaijan Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, and the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee (substitute member, 2019-present)

Notable actions and positions:
- Led a campaign for the European Parliament to set up a public register of members’ assistants (2002)
- Successfully took the Council of the European Union to the European Court of Justice over access to a document on arms export rules (2001)
- Promoted transparency in the EU after winning the case against the Council on access to documents on arm trade (2009)
- Advocated for environmental responsibility, openness in politics, and global justice
- Opposed using development policy mechanisms as a basis for military intervention under EU umbrella
- Proposed to curb the global trade of illegal timber to prevent deforestation
- Presented a shadow EU Action Plan on Responsible Business Conduct to increase business accountability and responsibility
- Supported the promotion of health and well-being as an overall objective under which to work on matters such as global warming, air pollution, and energy efficiency of buildings
- Criticised Russia for "disproportionately tough measures" against Greenpeace activists detained in Russia under piracy charges
- Included in a Russian blacklist of prominent people from the European Union who are not allowed to enter the country (2015)

Awards:
- People's Choice: Outstanding Achievement in Public Service Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards (2022)

Other activities:
- EastWest Institute, Member of the Parliamentarians Network for Conflict Prevention
- European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR), member
- Green European Foundation, President (since 2008)
- Crisis Management Initiative, member of the Executive Bureau (2006-2010)
- Finnish League for Human Rights, member of the Board (2007-2009)
- Finnish-Russian Civic Forum, chair (2006-2010)
- Service Centre for Development Cooperation (KEPA), chair (2002-2007)
- German "Förderverein" of the Caucasian Chamber Orchestra, advisory board

Helmut Geuking, a German politician, born 16 January 1964, served as a Member of the European Parliament for Germany from 2 July 2019 to 4 February 2024, representing the Family Party of Germany, and is a member of the European People's Party. His previous party affiliations include the Social Democratic Party of Germany (1998-2005), Labour and Social Justice – The Electoral Alternative (2005-2007), and Social Justice North Rhine-Westphalia (2007-2012).

Helmut Scholz, German politician, The Left Party, Member of the European Parliament, constituency: Germany, studied at Moscow State Institute of International Relations, member of the Working Group on the Conference on the Future of Europe.

Heléne Fritzon, born 29 September 1960 in Kristianstad, Sweden, is a Swedish politician of the Social Democrats. She is married to Henrik Fritzon. She served as Minister for Migration and Asylum Policy from 27 July 2017 to 21 January 2019 under Prime Minister Stefan Löfven. She has been Vice-Chair of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and a Member of the European Parliament for Sweden since 2 July 2019, serving alongside Éric Andrieu, Biljana Borzan, Miriam Dalli, Roberto Gualtieri, Bernd Lange, Claude Moraes, Kati Piri, and Rovana Plumb under the leadership of chairwoman Iratxe García. She is a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and is part of the Parliament's delegation to the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.

Henk Jan Ormel, a male politician from the Netherlands, born on 15 December 1955 in Utrecht, Netherlands. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Appeal party since 1999. His occupations include politician and chief veterinary officer.
