He was a Member of the House of Representatives from 23 May 2002 to 19 September 2012, focusing on foreign policy, European Union, biotechnology, medical ethics, and animal welfare. He was Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs from 2007-2010 and Vice-President of the NATO Parliamentary Assembly from 2008-2010. He worked at FAO as chief veterinary officer, coordinator of anti-microbial resistance, and global coordinator of the Global Framework of transboundary Animal Diseases. He also worked as a One-Health expert for WHO. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 27 February 2024 to 15 July 2024, part of the European People's Party Group, and sat on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Delegation for relations with the People's Republic of China. He was awarded Knight of the Order of Orange-Nassau in 2012.

Henna Maria Virkkunen, a Finnish politician, born on 4 June 1972 in Joutsa, Finland, member of the National Coalition Party. Education: University of Jyväskylä. Married to Matti Mäkinen with 1 child. 

Past offices: 
Member of the Jyväskylä City Council (20 October 1996 - 9 April 2016), 
Member of the Finnish Parliament (21 March 2007 - 1 July 2014) representing Helsinki, 
Minister of Education (19 December 2008 - 22 June 2011) under Prime Ministers Matti Vanhanen and Mari Kiviniemi, 
Minister of Public Administration and Local Government (22 June 2011 - 24 June 2014) under Prime Minister Jyrki Katainen, 
Minister of Transport (4 April 2014 - 24 June 2014) under Prime Minister Jyrki Katainen.

Current office: 
Member of the European Parliament (1 July 2014 - present) representing Finland. 
Committees: 
European Parliament Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (since 2014), 
European Parliament Committee on Transport and Tourism (since 2021), 
European Parliament Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware (since 2022).
Delegations: 
Parliament's delegation for relations with South Africa (2014-2019), 
Parliament's delegation for relations with the Arabian Peninsula (since 2019).
Member of the European Internet Forum, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas.

Awards: 
The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards, Energy award (2020).
Upcoming office: 
Executive Vice President for Tech Sovereignty, Security and Democracy for the European Commission (2024-2029) under President Ursula von der Leyen.

Henrik Overgaard-Nielsen, Brexit Party MEP for North West England, born 2 August 1959 in Frederiksberg, Denmark, to a father who campaigned against Denmark joining the European Economic Community. He is a socialist who has been an active opponent of the EU since the late 1970s, first in the People's Movement against the EU and later in the June Movement. He was co-chairman of the "No" campaign in the Danish referendum on the Maastricht Treaty in 1992. He qualified as a dentist in Copenhagen in 1983 and moved to the UK in 1996, where he started an NHS dental practice in Fulham, London in 1999 with his British-born wife Sharon Bierer. He was elected as the chair of the General Dental Practice Committee of the British Dental Association in 2015 and re-elected in 2019. He was announced as a Brexit Party MEP candidate for the North West of England in April 2019 and won his seat in the 2019 European Parliament election. He considers the EU to be rooted in the interests of large multinational corporations and the middle-class establishment. He is married to Sharon Bierer, has two children, and became a British citizen in October 2020.

Henrike Hahn, a German politician and member of Alliance 90/The Greens, born on September 4, 1970, in Munich, Germany, studied at Sorbonne-Nouvelle, University of Michigan, Wayne State University, and Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich, worked as a consultant and political advisor, including at the Bavarian State Parliament and German Bundestag, researcher on Europe and Transatlantic relations at the Centre for Applied Policy Research and the German Institute for International and Security Affairs, board member of the Bavarian Greens from 2017 to 2019, Member of the European Parliament from July 2019 to July 2024, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and Committee on Budgets, deputy speaker of the German delegation and industrial policy speaker of The Greens/EFA, member of Amnesty International, the German Alpine Club, the German Federation for the Environment and Nature Conservation, and Greenpeace, living in Munich-Neuhausen and Brussels with her two daughters.

Herbert Dorfmann, Italian politician, born 4 March 1969 in Brixen, South Tyrol, Italy. Occupation: politician, agronomist. Education: Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore. Party affiliation: South Tyrolean People's Party. Term as Member of the European Parliament started on 1 July 2009, representing North-East Italy. Served as mayor of Feldthurns from 2005 to 2009. Current committee assignments include Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Subcommittee on Tax Matters. Member of the governing board of the European People's Party.

Hermann Leopold Tertsch del Valle-Lersundi, a Spanish journalist, lawyer, and politician, born on 9 April 1958 in Madrid, Spain. Parents: Ekkehard Tertsch, an Austrian-German diplomat and journalist, and Felisa del Valle-Lersundi. Cousins: Loyola de Palacio and Ana de Palacio. Member of the Communist Party of the Basque Country in his youth. Correspondent for Agencia EFE in 1982, covering Central and Eastern Europe, and later for the newspaper El País. Became a regular columnist and op-ed editor for El País, and a regular radio guest for Cadena SER, Radio Nacional de España, and Onda Cero. Left El País in 2007 to become a political opinion writer for the conservative newspaper ABC. Host of the early-morning Diario de la noche on Telemadrid from 2008 until 2009. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament for the Vox party in 2019, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Delegation to the EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, where he serves as vice-chair. Signer of the Madrid Charter. Awarded the Cirilo Rodríguez Journalism Award in 1989, the Golden Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary in 2019, and the Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland in 2022.

Hervé Juvin, a French essayist and politician, born on January 29, 1956, in Malestroit, France. He is affiliated with the National Rally party until 2022. He served as a Member of the European Parliament for France from July 2, 2019, to July 15, 2024, and as a Member of the Regional Council of Pays de la Loire from July 2, 2021. He subscribes to the Nouvelle Droite movement and has written several books, including "The Coming of the Body", "Le Renversement du monde: Politique de la crise", "La Grande Séparation: Pour une écologie des civilisations", "Le Mur de l'Ouest n'est pas tombé: Les idées qui ont pris le pouvoir et comment le reprendre", "Le Gouvernement du désir", and "France, le moment politique". He advocates for environmental protection through national sovereignty, localism, and the preservation of cultural diversity. He opposes immigration, globalization, and free-trade agreements, which he believes lead to the erosion of national identity and the destruction of local ecosystems.

Hilde Vautmans, a Belgian politician, born on 2 May 1972, in Sint-Truiden, Belgium. She is a member of the Open Vlaamse Liberalen en Democraten party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 January 2015, representing the Dutch-speaking electoral college of Belgium. Vautmans previously served in the Belgian Chamber of Representatives from 2003 to 2010, where she chaired the Committee on Foreign Affairs and was group leader of the Open Vld. She worked in the cabinet of Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt and helped with legalising same-sex marriage in Belgium. Vautmans is a member of several committees and delegations in the European Parliament, including the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and the delegation for relations with the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. She is also part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-UK Parliamentary Assembly and a member of various intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. Vautmans has been involved in initiatives calling for coordinated sanctions against Chinese leaders and officials responsible for human rights violations and has advocated for a tough stance on China. She was the recipient of the Economic, Monetary Affairs, Tax and Budget Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2022.

Hildegard Bentele is a German politician of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and member of the European People's Party (EPP). She was born on 9 May 1967, however, her infobox incorrectly lists her birthdate as 22 May 1976, in Ludwigsburg, West Germany. She graduated from the Margarete-Steiff-Gymnasium in Giengen in 1995, then studied at the University of Heidelberg from 1995 to 1997, Sciences Po in Paris from 1997 to 1998, and the Otto Suhr Institute of the Free University of Berlin until 1999. Bentele joined the Federal Foreign Office in 2002 and held various positions, including an advisor on economic affairs and relations to the United States, and worked at the German embassies in Zagreb and Tehran from 2005 to 2008. She was a foreign policy advisor to Hans-Peter Friedrich and Gerda Hasselfeldt from 2010 to 2013. Bentele was a member of the State Parliament of Berlin from 2011 to 2019, serving as her group's spokeswoman on European affairs from 2011 to 2016 and deputy chairwoman under Florian Graf. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Development since 2019, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy since 2020, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe since 2021. Bentele is part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with Canada, a member of the URBAN Intergroup, and was part of the European Parliament's official delegation to the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP26) in 2021. She was part of her party's delegation to the working group on European affairs in the negotiations to form a coalition government between the CDU and the Social Democratic Party (SPD) following Berlin's 2023 state elections. Bentele is married to Croatian diplomat Ivan Bojanić and has two children.

Hynek Blaško, Czech general and politician, born 15 July 1955 in Prague, Czechoslovakia, nationality Czech, educated at Military Academy in Brno, member of Communist Party of Czechoslovakia (1981-1989) and Freedom and Direct Democracy (2019-2022), Member of the European Parliament (2019-2024) representing Czech Republic, left Freedom and Direct Democracy on 14 September 2022, voted against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for human rights violations on 15 September 2022, ran for President of the Czech Republic in 2023 election with support from DSSS but withdrew due to insufficient signatures.

Hélène Laporte, born 29 December 1978 in Villeneuve-sur-Lot, France. Married with 2 children. Nationality: French. Profession: Politician, previously a banking analyst for Crédit Agricole. Member of the National Rally party. Served as councillor for the National Front/National Rally in Lot-et-Garonne since 2015. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, part of the Identity and Democracy group, and served until 2022. Served as a member of the Committee on Budgets and the delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly. Observed the 2020 Russian constitutional referendum as an international expert. Elected as a Member of the National Assembly for Lot-et-Garonne's 2nd constituency in 2022, and served as vice president of the National Assembly from 29 June 2022 to 2024.

Iban García del Blanco is a Spanish politician, born on 8 February 1977 in León, Spain. García del Blanco earned a licentiate degree in Law from the University of León. García del Blanco served as León municipal councillor, provincial deputy in León, and Senator. García del Blanco was appointed to the post of chairman of Acción Cultural Española in 2018. García del Blanco is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party. García del Blanco has been a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019. García del Blanco is part of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Spinelli Group, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital.

Idoia Villanueva Ruiz, a Spanish politician and engineer, born on 17 July 1980 in Pamplona, Spain, with a degree in IT engineering from the University of the Basque Country and a master's degree in Business Management from the Autonomous University of Madrid, worked for ten years in tech project management and development, joined the Podemos party, served as Senator in the Senate of Spain from 2015 to 2019, and has been a Member of the European Parliament representing Spain since 2 July 2019, integrated within the European United Left–Nordic Green Left political group.

Ignazio Corrao, independent Italian politician, born 14 January 1984 in Rome, Italy, grew up in Alcamo, Sicily, graduated in law from the University of Palermo, qualified as a lawyer at the Italian Court of Appeal. Member of the European Parliament since 20 July 2014, representing the Italian Islands constituency. Initially a member of the Five Star Movement, served as the first leader of the Five Star Movement's group in Parliament from 2014, joined the Greens/EFA group in December 2020.

Ilan De Basso, born 1 October 1969, is a Turkish-born ethnic Assyrian Swedish politician from the Social Democratic Party, with a background in policy analysis, NGO work, and public service, having served as a counsellor in Jönköping Municipality for 11 years, handling education, labour market, and care issues, and currently a member of the European Parliament, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and substitute for the committees on budgets and development, also a member of the Swedish Social Democratic Party's national board since 2013, and a Member of the Riksdag since the 2022 Swedish general election.

Ilana Cicurel, born 8 February 1972 in Paris, France, is a French lawyer and politician of La République En Marche! (LREM). She is the daughter of French artist Raymond Cicurel and the sister of French economist Michel Cicurel. Cicurel studied law at University of Paris 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne and is a Fulbright Scholar from Harvard Law School. She joined the Alliance israélite universelle in 2008, serving as General Manager until 2018. Since November 2017, Cicurel has been part of LREM's executive board. She lost the 2017 French legislative election by a narrow margin. Cicurel has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 February 2020, serving on the Committee on Culture and Education and the parliament's delegation for relations with Israel.

Ilhan Kyuchyuk, a Bulgarian politician, born on 16 September 1985 in Sevlievo, Bulgaria, to a nurse mother and an electrician father. He is married with one child. Kyuchyuk completed his secondary education in Sevlievo, holds a bachelor's degree in political science and management (2004-2008) and a master's degree in law (2005-2010) from the 'St. Cyril and St. Methodius' University of Veliko Turnovo. He participated in various trainings and specializations, including public policies academy (Prague, Czech Republic), International Academy for Leadership (Gummersbach, Germany), US State Department program on European economic, social and political issues, Rossotrudnichestvo program on Foreign Affairs (Moscow, Russia), Bulgarian School of Politics 'Dimitar Panitza' (2012), World Forum for Democracy in Strasbourg, France (2012), and École nationale d'administration in France (ENA) (2014). Kyuchyuk is a member of the DPS party and Renew Europe, serving as Co-President of the ALDE party since 11 June 2021, and Chair of the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament since 23 July 2024. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing Bulgaria. Kyuchyuk is also a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Substitute Member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and the Committee on Legal Affairs. He has received numerous awards, including the honorary sign of the municipality of Sevlievo (2017), 'MEP of the Year' award in the 'Culture and Media' category (2018), Order of Honour of the National Assembly of the Republic of Azerbaijan (2019), Order of Honour of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Azerbaijan (2019), award from the Council of Moroccans around the world (2020), honorary title "Doctor Honoris Causa" by the American University in Europe-FON (2022), Flame of Freedom Award (2022), "Progressive leader of the year" award from Darik Radio (2023), honorary title "Doctor Honoris Causa" by The University of Telecommunications and Post (UTP) (2023), honorary title „Doctor Honoris Causa“ by the University of World Economy and Diplomacy in Tashkent, Uzbekistan (2023), Human Rights Award (2023), and the international Giovanni Malagodi prize (2024).

Inese Vaidere is a Latvian politician born on 3 September 1952 in Jelgava, Latvian SSR. She graduated from the University of Latvia and works as an economist. Vaidere is a member of the Unity party, previously affiliated with For Fatherland and Freedom/LNNK and Civic Union. She has served as Minister of State for the Environment, Vice-Mayor of Riga, and a member of the Saeima. Vaidere has been a Member of the European Parliament for Latvia since 2004, with a brief interruption from 2014, and is a signatory of the Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism. She was included in a Russian blacklist of prominent EU individuals in 2015. Her committee assignments include Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Budgets, and Economic and Monetary Affairs. Vaidere is also a member of several European Parliament Intergroups, focusing on Integrity, Traditional Minorities, Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises, and the Digital Agenda.

Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández, a Spanish politician, was born on January 7, 1958, in Madrid. She is an economist and politician who earned a master's degree in economic theory from the University of Minnesota. Rodríguez-Piñero is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) and has held various positions within the party, including Secretary of Economic Policies and Employment and Secretary-General of Infrastructure. She served as a Member of the Congress of Deputies for Valencia from 2008 to 2009 and again from 2011 to 2014. Since 2014, Rodríguez-Piñero has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing Spain, and has served on the Committee on International Trade. She is also part of the parliament's delegation to the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee and a member of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Long-Term Investment and Reindustrialization and the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability.

Iratxe García Pérez, a Spanish politician of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), born on 7 October 1974 in Barakaldo, Spain. She obtained a diplomature in Social Work at the University of Valladolid in 1995. García served as municipal councillor of Laguna de Duero from 1995 to 2000, and as member of the Valladolid Provincial Deputation from 1995 to 2000. She became a member of the Congress of Deputies in 2000, representing Valladolid, and served until 2004. García has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004, representing Spain. She served on the Committee on Regional Development, the Delegation to the Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, and the Delegation for Relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union. García also serves on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Parliament's Delegation for Relations with the Arab Peninsula. She is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the European Parliament Intergroup on the Western Sahara. García was elected chairwoman of the European Parliament Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in July 2014, and became the head of the PSOE delegation of MEPs in the S&D Group in September 2014. She was chosen as the new leader of the S&D Group in 2019. García has been the Leader of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats since 1 July 2019.

Irena Joveva, Slovenian politician and journalist, born on February 26, 1989, in Kranj, SR Slovenia, Yugoslavia, to economic migrant parents from North Macedonia, has a master's degree in World Studies from the Faculty of Social Sciences in Ljubljana, worked as a journalist for the Slovenian Press Agency and POP TV, received the Watchdog Award in 2014, was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 with the List of Marjan Šarec, joined the Freedom Movement in 2022, serves on the Committee on Culture and Education, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and Subcommittee on Public Health, is a member of several European Parliament groups, including the Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, has one child, and is a Slovenian citizen.

Irene Tinagli, Italian politician and economist, born 16 April 1974 in Empoli, Italy. She holds a degree from Bocconi University and a Master in Public Administration from Carnegie Mellon University. Tinagli was a consultant for the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs and taught Management and Organizations at the Charles III University of Madrid. She is a member of the Advisory Council of the Florence School of Banking and Finance and the Advisory Board of the Center for Social Norms and Behavioral Dynamics of the University of Pennsylvania. Tinagli was a member of the Italian Parliament from 2013 to 2018 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving as chairperson of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. She was appointed deputy secretary of the Democratic Party in 2021. Tinagli has written several books, including "Europe in the Creative Age" and "La grande ignoranza." She was named Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum in 2010 and received a "Rising Star" award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2024.

Irina von Wiese, born 11 September 1967 in Cologne, West Germany, is a British politician with dual German and British citizenship. She earned a Master of Public Administration degree from Harvard University. Von Wiese has one teenage daughter and has been involved in housing refugees in her London home since 2016 through the charity Refugees at Home. She was a Liberal Democrat Member of the European Parliament for London from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, sitting within the Renew Europe group and serving as Vice-Chair on the European Parliament's Subcommittee on Human Rights. Prior to her European Parliament term, she stood in unsuccessful local election bids in 2017 and 2018, and was the prospective parliamentary candidate for Hammersmith in the 2019 UK general election. Von Wiese was later elected as a councillor for the Borough and Bankside ward of Southwark London Borough Council in May 2022 and is standing again in the 2024 London Assembly election, having been an unsuccessful candidate in the 2021 London Assembly election.

Irène Tolleret, a 56-year-old French winemaker and politician of La République En Marche!, born on 17 August 1967, in the Pic Saint-Loup region, where she owns a private wine domain. She was elected as Mayor of Fontanès in 2014, serving until 2019, and as a substitute in the departmental council of Hérault in 2015, replacing Marie-Christine Bousquet after her death. Tolleret has been a Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019, serving on the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and is part of several delegations and intergroups, including those focused on children's rights, climate change, and LGBT rights. She received the Food Safety award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020.

Isabel Benjumea Benjumea, a Spanish politician, born on September 5, 1982, in Madrid, Spain. She is a member of the European Parliament representing Spain since July 2, 2019. Benjumea is affiliated with the People's Party (PP) in Spain and the European People's Party (EPP) in the European Union. She holds a degree in law and international relations from Universidad Comillas (ICADE). Before entering politics, she worked at the World Bank, the international relations department of FAES, and as the director of her own business project, Greatness, in the tourism sector. She also worked as a partner at the strategic consulting firm IANUS Group and currently teaches in the Entrepreneurship degree at Universidad Francisco Marroquín in Madrid. In the European Parliament, she serves as vice president of the Committee on Regional Development, and is a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee, the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs), and the URBAN Intergroup.

Isabel Estrada Carvalhais, a female MEP from Portugal, born on 28 February 1973 in Negage, Portuguese Angola (now Angola), representing the Socialist Party, has a doctorate in sociology from the University of Warwick, and is a professor of political science and international relations at the University of Minho. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 3 September 2019, and her term is set to end on 15 July 2024. She is part of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the Committee on Fisheries, the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport, the parliament's delegations for relations with the United States, the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability.

Isabel García Muñoz, Spanish politician, born 3 March 1977 in Zaragoza, Spain, completed studies in Telecommunications Engineering at the University of Zaragoza, worked for the Institute for Engineering Research of Aragon's Department of Biomechanics, municipal councillor of Muel since 2007, Member of the Cortes of Aragon since 2015, Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019, vice-chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control, member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Tourism Task Force, member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability and the Spinelli Group, affiliated with the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party.

Isabel Santos, a female Portuguese politician, born on February 12, 1968, in Valbom, Gondomar, Porto District, Portugal, to parents Joaquim Fernando dos Anjos Coelho and Maria Adelina Cardoso Coelho. She is a member of the Socialist Party, and her occupation is a politician and civil servant. Santos graduated from the University of Porto. She was a member of the Assembly of the Republic from 2005 to 2011 and from 2015 to 2019, representing the Porto District. She served on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and was a member of the Portuguese delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe. Since 2019, she has been a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and its Subcommittee on Human Rights. She chairs the parliament's delegation for relations with the Mashriq countries and is a member of the delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights.

Isabel Wiseler-Santos Lima, a politician from the Christian Social People's Party, born on 29 December 1961 in Odivelas, Portugal, with Portuguese and Luxembourgish citizenship, educated at University of Sorbonne Nouvelle Paris 3, married to Claude Wiseler with three children, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Luxembourg since 2 July 2019, previously a municipal councillor and alderman in the city of Luxembourg, with committee assignments including the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights, and a member of the delegation to the Turkey-EU Joint Parliamentary Committee and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Isabella Adinolfi, Italian politician, born 27 March 1978 in Nocera Inferiore, Campania, Italy, Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing Southern Italy, initially a member of Five Star Movement until 2021, then joined Forza Italia, graduate in Conservation of Cultural Heritage and master's degree in Local Sustainable Development, elected in 2014 with 67,477 votes and top candidate in 2019.

Isabella Tovaglieri, Italian politician, born 25 June 1987, in Busto Arsizio, residence Busto Arsizio, nationality Italian, profession lawyer, educated at University Carlo Cattaneo, member of League for Salvini Premier, Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy since 2 July 2019.

Iskra Mihaylova, a Bulgarian politician, born on 7 September 1957 in Sofia, Bulgaria. She holds a master's degree in Library Studies and Information Technologies from the Saint-Petersburg State University of Culture and Arts. Mihaylova worked as a librarian and bibliographer before entering politics. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the Bulgaria constituency, and is affiliated with the Movement for Rights and Freedoms and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party. Mihaylova served as the chair of the Committee on Regional Development from 7 July 2014 to 1 July 2019. She is also a member of various parliamentary delegations and intergroups, including the EU-Armenia and EU-Azerbaijan Parliamentary Cooperation Committees, the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee, the EU-Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Joint Parliamentary Committee, the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises. In June 2019, Mihaylova was elected vice-president of the Renew Europe political group. She received the Regional Development Award at the 2017 MEP Awards.

Ismail Ertug, a male politician, born on December 5, 1975, in Amberg, Germany, of ethnic Turkish origin, with parents who immigrated from Seferihisar, Izmir, Turkey. He studied business management and worked as a customer consultant, coordinator, and social insurance expert. Ertug is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. He served as a Member of the European Parliament from Germany from 2009 to 2023, representing the Bavarian regions of Upper Palatinate and Lower Bavaria. Ertug was a member of the Committee for Transport and Tourism, coordinator of the Group of Socialists and Democrats in the TRAN committee, rapporteur on Trans-European Transport Networks and the 2019 Mobility Package, and a substitute member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. He co-chaired the EP Turkey Forum and was a member of various delegations and intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development. Ertug is also a member of several organizations, including the European Logistics Platform, German United Services Trade Union, Greenpeace, and German Worker's Welfare Association.

István Ujhelyi, born on 28 February 1975 in Berettyóújfalu, Hungary. Finished Tóth Árpád Grammar School in Debrecen in 1993 and graduated from the Faculty of Law and Political Sciences of the University of Szeged in 2002. Member of the Hungarian Socialist Party (MSZP) since 1993, serving as national vice-president of the Left-wing Youth Association and later national president of the Young Left-wing. Served as a Member of the National Assembly of Hungary from 2002 to 2014 and as a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024. Held various positions including governmental commissioner for Child and Youth Affairs, State Secretary of the Ministry for Local Government and Regional Development, and State Secretary of Prime Minister's Office. Left MSZP in 2022 and founded Esély Közösség, later becoming the leader of the Opportunity Community. Married to Éva Péntek with five children.
Claudiu Manda, a Romanian politician and Member of the European Parliament, representing the Social Democratic Party, from the constituency of Romania.

Iuliu Winkler, a male politician from Romania, born 14 March 1964, of ethnic Hungarian descent, married with one child, educated with a graduate degree in electronics and telecommunications from the Traian Vuia Polytechnic Institute of Timișoara in 1988 and a graduate degree in finance and insurance from the University of Petroșani in 2001, career as an engineer and economist, member of the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania (UDMR) since 1991, held positions including member of the Romanian Chamber of Deputies for Hunedoara County from 2000 to 2004, Minister-Delegate for Commerce from 2004 to 2007, Minister of Communications and Information Society in 2007, and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2007, sitting on the Committee on International Trade.

Ivan David, born 24 September 1952 in Prague, Czechoslovakia (now Czech Republic), is a Czech psychiatrist and politician. He graduated from Prague High School and the Faculty of General Medicine of Charles University. David worked as a psychiatrist and was the director of the Psychiatric Hospital of Bohnice until April 2008. He is the grandson of Jindřich Šnobl, a former deputy managing director of ČKD-Stalingrad. David was a Member of Parliament for the Czech Social Democratic Party from 1998 to 2002 and served as Minister of Health from 1998 to 1999 under Prime Minister Miloš Zeman. He was preceded by Zuzana Roithová and succeeded by Vladimír Špidla. David was a member of the Czech Social Democratic Party from 1993 to 2015 and later joined Freedom and Direct Democracy in 2019. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for the Czech Republic since 2 July 2019. On 15 September 2022, David voted against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for human rights violations.

Ivan Vilibor Sinčić, a Croatian politician and anti-eviction activist, born on 28 August 1990 in Karlovac, SR Croatia, SFR Yugoslavia, married to Vladimira Palfi since 2016, with two children, Ksaver and Iskra. He studied at the Faculty of Electrical Engineering in Zagreb, and worked as an electrical engineer. Sinčić was the chairman of the Key of Croatia party from 2011 to 2024 and a member of the Croatian Parliament from 2015 to 2019. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019. He was a candidate in the 2014 Croatian presidential election, coming in third with 16.42% of the vote. Sinčić is known for his views on abolishing private banks and was against the Croatian government's decision to grant financial aid to Ukrainian refugees.

Ivan Štefanec, born on September 30, 1961, in Považská Bystrica, Czechoslovakia, is a Slovak politician and manager. He is a member of the European Parliament for the Christian Democratic Movement (KDH) and the European People's Party (EPP). He studied Economic Mathematics at the University of Economics in Bratislava and later earned an MBA from the Rochester Institute of Technology in New York. Štefanec worked as a researcher, project manager, and branch manager before joining Coca-Cola, where he held various leadership positions, including general manager of Coca-Cola Beverages Slovakia. He was appointed EU integration manager of Coca-Cola HBC in Vienna in 2003. 

Štefanec was a member of the Slovak National Council from 2006 to 2014, focusing on economic issues and European affairs. He was the chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on European Affairs and led the Government Committee for the recovery and development of the High Tatras after the 2004 wind disaster. He was also the Plenipotentiary for the adoption of the Euro in Slovakia. 

Štefanec has been a member of the European Parliament since 2014, serving on various committees, including the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Delegation for relations with Japan. He is the president of SME Europe and co-chair of the European Investment Fund Programming Committee. Štefanec has received several awards, including the Dale Carnegie Leadership Award and the Taiwanese Friendship Medal of Diplomacy. 

He is married to Magdalena, an economic engineer, and has two children and three grandchildren. Štefanec has been involved in various social activities, including co-founding the Slovak Soft Drinks and Mineral Waters Association and serving as the chairman of the MBA Advisory Board for Comenius University in Bratislava.

Ivars Ijabs, a Latvian politician, born on 17 November 1972 in Riga, Latvia, is a lecturer and professor at the University of Latvia with a PhD in political science. From 2006 until 2012, he was State Council in Bremen, responsible for work, youth, social issues, health, and science. As an MEP, he is vice chairman of the SPD group, member of the Committee on International Trade (INTA), and substitute member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL). His main topics in the INTA include Africa, Ukraine, CETA, and TTIP, while in the EMPL, he focuses on digitalization. Schuster is a member of the EU delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and the EURONEST parliamentary assembly, as well as the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara. He is married with two children.
Joanna Kopcińska, a Polish politician, born January 2, 1967, in Łódź, Poland, currently serving as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the Law and Justice party, constituency Poland.

Johan Danielsson, born 30 June 1982 in Borlänge, Sweden, Swedish Social Democratic Party politician and trade unionist. Served as Minister for Housing from 30 November 2021 to 17 October 2022 under Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson and monarch Carl XVI Gustaf, succeeding Märta Stenevi. Previously, Vice-Chair of the European Parliament Committee on Transport and Tourism from 10 July 2019 to 30 November 2021, serving alongside Sven Schulze, István Ujhelyi, and Jan-Christoph Oetjen, under Chair Karima Delli. Member of the European Parliament for Sweden from 2 July 2019 to 30 November 2021 and from 16 July 2024.

Johan Harry Nissinen, born 17 May 1989 in Värnamo, Sweden, is a Swedish politician who served as a Member of the Riksdag from 29 September 2014 to 11 September 2022, representing the Skåne Northern and Eastern constituency, and has been a Member of the European Parliament since October 2022, initially representing the Sweden Democrats, but switching to the People's List on 2 May 2024.

Johan Van Overtveldt, a Belgian journalist and politician, born 24 August 1955 in Mortsel, Belgium, educated at Saint Ignatius University Centre, member of the New Flemish Alliance since 2013, served as chief editor of Trends from 2010 to 2013 and Knack from 2011 to 2012, awarded the Prize for Liberty by Libera! in 2012, elected as a member of the European Parliament in 2014, served as Minister of Finance of Belgium from 11 October 2014 to 9 December 2018 under Prime Minister Charles Michel, succeeding Koen Geens and preceding Alexander De Croo, Ex-Officio Member of the Board of Governors of the European Investment Bank, European Stability Mechanism, African Development Bank, Asian Development Bank, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Inter-American Investment Corporation, International Monetary Fund, Joint World Bank-IMF Development Committee, Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, and World Bank from 2014 to 2018, chair of the Parliament's Committee on Budgets and member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs since 2019, author of Het einde van de Euro, Maandag geen economie meer?, The Chicago School, and Bernanke's test.

John Howarth, a British Labour Party politician, born on October 31, 1958, in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, England. He is married to Jane Coney, a designer, and has two children from his first marriage and a step-daughter. Howarth studied Economics at the University of Essex and later gained a master's degree in the History and Theory of 20th Century Art. He has worked in various fields, including information technology, design, business communications, and public affairs. Howarth was a councillor on Berkshire County Council, Reading Borough Council, and the South East England Regional Assembly. He served as a Member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2017 to 2020, and was a member of several committees, including the Budget Committee, Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, and Regional Development Committee. Howarth has also worked as a Senior Advisor to Signum Global Advisors and returned to Instinctif Partners as a Senior Counsel. He is a trustee for Northumberland CVA, a voluntary sector charity, and writes a weekly column at Substack.

John Longworth, born 14 May 1958 in Bolton, Greater Manchester, England, is a British businessman and politician who was educated at Smithills School and the University of Salford. He holds bachelor's and master's degrees, a postgraduate certificate in microbiology, and an honorary doctorate from BPP University. Longworth is a chartered company secretary and has worked as a director-general of the British Chambers of Commerce and co-chairman of Leave Means Leave. He was a Member of the European Parliament for Yorkshire and the Humber from 2019 to 2020, initially as a member of the Brexit Party but later as an independent after being expelled. Longworth has also been a member of the European Parliament Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the European Parliament Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. He is currently affiliated with the Conservative Party.

John Tennant, born 25 December 1986 in Newcastle upon Tyne, England, full name John David Edward Tennant, is a British politician who was a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for North East England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. He was the former party leader of Independent Union, serving from 18 February 2019 to February 2020. Tennant is a councillor on Hartlepool Borough Council for the Jesmond ward, initially elected on 5 May 2016. His party affiliations include Reform UK (2019–present), Independent Union (2019–present), and formerly UKIP (2016–2018). Prior to his Brexit Party membership, he was a UKIP group leader for Hartlepool Borough Council and worked as an office manager for MEP Jonathan Arnott in 2018.

Jonathan Bullock, born 3 March 1963 in Nottingham, England, is a British politician. He was a Member of the European Parliament for the East Midlands constituency from 1 August 2017 to 31 January 2020. He was educated at Nottingham High School and Portsmouth University, where he received a BA (Hons) degree in politics. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts. He worked in the House of Commons, advertising agencies, the Advertising Association, the British Road Federation, and the Chartered Institute of Logistics and Transport. He was a councillor and cabinet member on Kettering Borough Council. He was a member of the Conservative Party, UKIP, and the Brexit Party, and has run for various offices under these parties, including the European Parliament, Northamptonshire County Council, and parliamentary seats in Manchester Gorton and Gedling. He resigned from UKIP in 2018 and joined the Brexit Party in 2019.

Jonás Fernández Álvarez, a Spanish politician, born 8 January 1979 in Oviedo, Spain. Economist by profession, Fernández earned a licentiate degree in Economics at the University of Oviedo, an M.A. in Economics and Finance from CEMFI-Bank of Spain, and an Executive MBA from IESE Business School. He served as Secretary-General of the Socialist Youth of Oviedo, worked for Solchaga Recio & asociados, and lectured at the Charles III University of Madrid. Fernández is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 1 July 2014. He is part of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, serving on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Subcommittee on Tax Matters. Fernández is the spokesperson for the S&D group in the ECON Committee and the parliament's rapporteur on measures to ease capital and accounting burdens on banks during the COVID-19 pandemic. He is the author of "Una alternativa progresista" (2013).

Jordan Bardella is a French politician born on 13 September 1995 in Drancy, Seine-Saint-Denis, France. He is the president of the National Rally (RN) since 2022 and a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2019. Bardella is a regional councillor of Île-de-France since 2015. He was raised by his single mother, a kindergarten assistant, in a local council tower block in Drancy. Bardella's father is a small-medium business owner specializing in beverage vending machines. He dropped out of Paris-Sorbonne University to focus on politics. Bardella has expressed opposition to same-sex marriage, supports cutting social services for people who illegally arrived in France, and advocates for legalizing cannabis for medical purposes. He has also stated that immigration could lead to the extinction of France, the French identity, French sovereignty, and "France's soul". Bardella intends to abolish birthright citizenship and toughen border control to limit refugees' freedom of movement. He has been in relationships with Nolwenn Olivier, Kelly Betesh, and Kerridwen Chatillon. Bardella is an agnostic. He has been indicted for describing the city of Trappes as an "Islamic republic" and has been suspected of fake employment at the European Parliament.

Jordi Cañas Pérez, born 12 December 1969 in Barcelona, Spain. Education: Degree in Geography and History from the University of Barcelona. Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019, term ending 16 July 2024. Member of Citizens - Party of the Citizenry since 2006, previously a member of the Socialist Party of Catalonia from 1987 to 2003. Former Member of the Catalan Parliament for Barcelona from 28 November 2010 to 29 April 2014. Served as National Spokesman of Citizens, Secretary of Political Action and Strategy, and Secretary of Communication and Spokesperson. Resigned from the Parliament of Catalonia in 2014 due to alleged tax fraud, later cleared of charges in 2018.

Jordi Solé i Ferrando, a male Catalan politician from Spain, born 26 October 1976 in Caldes de Montbui, Vallès Oriental, Catalonia, Spain, educated in political sciences at Autonomous University of Barcelona. He is a member of the Republican Left of Catalonia and has served as a Member of the European Parliament since January 2017, initially representing the constituency of Spain from 3 January 2017 to 30 June 2019, succeeding Ernest Maragall, and again from 23 July 2020, succeeding Oriol Junqueras. He is a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs since 2017 and the Committee on Budgets since 2017.

Jorge Buxadé Villalba, Spanish politician, MEP, born 16 June 1975 in Barcelona, Spain. Education: law degree from Abat Oliba CEU University. Occupation: lawyer, politician. Party affiliation: Vox (2014–present), previously Falange Española de las JONS (1995), Falange Española Auténtica (1996), People's Party (2004–2014). Positions held: Co-chairman of the European Conservatives and Reformists, Head of the Vox Delegation to the European Parliament, Member of the European Parliament for Spain (2 July 2019 - 5 July 2024). Awards: Order of Saint Raymond of Peñafort, Hungarian Order of Merit. Ideology: right-wing, anti-Catalan independence, conservative. Associations: Societat Civil Catalana, Fundación Joan Boscà, Foro Catalán de la Familia, Madrid Forum. Influences: José Antonio Primo de Rivera, Ernesto Giménez Caballero.

Josianne Cutajar, a Maltese Labour Party politician from Victoria, Malta, born 27 December 1989, served as a Member of the European Parliament for Malta from 2 July 2019 until 2024, sitting on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, supporting the MEP Alliance for Mental Health, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with Australia and New Zealand.

José Manuel García-Margallo y Marfil, Spanish politician, born 13 August 1944 in Madrid, Spain. Education: Law and Economics from University of Deusto (1965), master's degree in law from Harvard University (1972). 

Member of the European Parliament (1994-2011, 2019-present), Congress of Deputies (1977-1982, 1986-1994, 2016-2019), Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (2011-2016). 

Party affiliations: People's Party (1989-present), People's Democratic Party (1983-1989), Union of the Democratic Centre (1978-1983), People's Party (1976-1978).

José Guilherme Figueiredo Nobre de Gusmão, born 20 July 1976 in Lisbon, Portugal, son of writer and politician Manuel Gusmão, half-brother of politician commentator Daniel Oliveira. Member of the Left Bloc, formerly a member of the Portuguese Communist Party. Elected as a deputy from Santarém from 15 October 2009 to 19 June 2011. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal on 2 July 2019, serving until 15 July 2024. Ran for re-election in 2011 but failed. Ran as the main candidate of the Left Bloc in Faro in 2022 but failed to be elected, and was chosen again as the main candidate for the 2024 election.

José Manuel Ferreira Fernandes, Portuguese politician, born 26 July 1967 in Vila Verde, Portugal, Social Democratic Party, Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries since 2 April 2024, Member of the European Parliament for Portugal from 14 July 2009 to 1 April 2024, Mayor of Vila Verde from 14 December 1997 to 27 April 2009, president of JSD - Social Democratic Youth of Vila Verde from 1992-1993, leader of the Braga district political committee of JSD from 1994-1996, member of the Committee on Budgets, coordinator on the committee, rapporteur on the 2012 and 2016 annual budgets, co-rapporteur on a motion to assign new tax revenues to the European Union budget, member of the delegations to Brazil, China, Mercosur, the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, the Maghreb countries, and the Arab Maghreb Union, member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, voted the most influential Portuguese MEP of 2020, educated at the University of Minho, Information engineer and politician.

José Ramón Bauzá Díaz, Spanish politician, born 16 November 1970 in Madrid, Spain. Licensed pharmacist by the Complutense University of Madrid. Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019. Formerly president of the Autonomous Community of the Balearic Islands from 2011 to 2015. Served as president of the Partido Popular of the Balearic Islands from 2009 to 2015. Mayor of Marratxí from 2005 to 2011. Senator appointed by the Balearic Islands Parliament from 2015 to 2019. Member of the People's Party from 1996 to 2019, then joined Citizens in 2019. Held shares in the startup Gas2Move without disclosure upon joining the European Parliament. Investigated for workplace harassment allegations in 2023.

Jozef Mihál, born 18 March 1965 in Nitra, Czechoslovakia (now Slovakia), is a Slovak politician and tax consultant. He graduated in mathematics and physics from Charles University in Prague in 1988. Mihál worked for Aurus and later owned his own company, Relia, providing consultancy and training on tax. He served as an advisor to the government on reform of health insurance from 2005 to 2006. Mihál was a member of the National Council of the Slovak Republic from 2010 to 2020. He held various offices, including Deputy Prime Minister of Slovakia from 9 July 2010 to 4 April 2012, Minister for Labour, Social Affairs, and Family from 9 July 2010 to 4 April 2012, and State Secretary of the Ministry of Labour, Social Affairs and Family of the Slovak Republic from 21 March 2020. Mihál was affiliated with several parties: Nádej (2006-2009), Freedom and Solidarity (SaS) (2009-2017, 2020-2022), and Together – Civic Democracy (Spolu) (2017-2020). He has three children and is a tax consultant by profession.

João Albuquerque, a Portuguese politician and member of the Socialist Party, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 13 September 2022, born on 25 December 1986, in Portugal, succeeding Manuel Pizarro, with a term set to end on 15 July 2024.

João Manuel Peixoto Ferreira, Portuguese Communist Party, MEP, born 20 November 1978, Lisbon, Portugal, biologist, politician, member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 14 July 2009 until 5 July 2021, vice-chair of the European United Left-Nordic Green Left from 7 February 2012 to 30 June 2014, member of the Central Committee of the Portuguese Communist Party, member of the Lisbon Municipal Council since 29 September 2013.

João Pimenta Lopes, MEP, born 12 April 1980 in Lisbon, Campo Grande, Portugal. Member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 31 January 2016, representing the Portuguese Communist Party. Term ends 15 July 2024. Served as Vice-Chair, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality since 2016. Member of the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and Delegation for relations with the Federative Republic of Brazil. Voted against condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine on 2 March 2022 and against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for human rights violations on 15 September 2022.

Joëlle Mélin, born 26 March 1950 in Versailles, France, is a French politician with a medical education background from Aix-Marseille University. She joined the National Rally in 1993. Mélin held a seat in the Regional Council of Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur from 2010 to 2015 and has been a municipal councillor in Aubagne since 2014. She served as a Member of the European Parliament for South-West France from 2014 to 2019 and for France from 2019 to 2022. Since 22 June 2022, she has been a Member of the National Assembly for Bouches-du-Rhône's 9th constituency, succeeding Bernard Deflesselles.

Juan Fernando López Aguilar, a Spanish jurist and politician of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, was born on June 10, 1961, in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain. He holds a Ph.D. in law from the University of Bologna, Italy, and a master's degree in law and diplomacy from The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. López Aguilar has served as a member of the European Parliament since 2009, as Minister of Justice from 2004 to 2007, and as a member of the Congress of Deputies from 1996 to 2007 and 2008 to 2009. He has also been a member of the Parliament of the Canary Islands from 2007 to 2008. López Aguilar has chaired the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and has been a member of various committees and delegations, including the Special Committee on Organized Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering and the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion. He is a member of the Spinelli Group and the European Parliament Intergroup on Integrity. López Aguilar has also been a professor of constitutional law at the University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria and has worked as a newspaper caricaturist and comic-book illustrator.

Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez, a Spanish politician from the People's Party, born on 21 January 1957 in Montellano, Seville, Andalusia, Spain. He studied law at the University of Almeria and graduated from the University of Seville in 1979. Zoido served as a judge in various positions from 1983 to 2000, including First Instance and Inquiry Judge in Lanzarote, Utrera, and Seville. He was Director General of Relations with the Judiciary from 1996 to 2000 and Government's Delegate to Castilla-La Mancha from 2000 to 2002 and Andalusia from 2002 to 2004. Zoido was General Secretary of the People's Party of Andalusia from 2004 to 2006. He was elected to the Parliament of Andalusia in 2008 and served as Mayor of Seville from 2011 to 2015. Zoido was Chairman of the People's Party of Andalusia from 2012 to 2014 and Minister of the Interior from 2016 to 2018. He was a Member of the Congress of Deputies from 2016 to 2019 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019.

Judith Ann Bunting, a British television producer and politician, born in Dogsthorpe, Peterborough, educated at Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge with a Master's Degree in Natural Sciences (Chemistry), has a background in producing educational and science-based documentary television since the 1990s, including work on Tomorrow's World, Teen Species, Horizon, and The Museum, and has been series producer for over 30 episodes of Magic Hands, a programme for CBeebies featuring poetry and Shakespeare for children translated entirely into British Sign Language. She has been a Liberal Democrat Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for South East England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, serving as the Liberal Democrat Spokesperson on Education and Culture in Europe, and sat on the Industry, Research and Energy committee. She previously stood as the Liberal Democrat candidate for Newbury in the 2015 and 2017 UK General Elections, coming a distant second behind Richard Benyon both times.

Judith Kirton-Darling, a British Labour Party politician, born on 2 June 1977 in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, educated at the University of Sheffield and the University of Bath, with a background in European Social Policy Analysis. She worked as a programme assistant with the Quaker Council for European Affairs and as Confederal Secretary of the European Trade Union Confederation. She was a Member of the European Parliament for the North East England region from 1 July 2014 to 31 January 2020, serving on the Committee for International Trade and the Committee on Petitions. She is a practising Quaker.

Julie Lechanteux, a French politician, born on 22 December 1977 in Annecy, France, daughter of a hairdresser and a perfumery saleswoman, moved to Saint-Raphaël at age 8. Member of the National Rally since 2013. Served as Deputy Mayor of Fréjus from 2014 to 2019 and in the Departmental Council of Var from 2015 to 2021. Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 28 July 2022. Elected to the National Assembly for Var's 5th constituency on 22 June 2022.

Julie Ward, a British politician, was born on 7 March 1957 in Ripon, West Riding of Yorkshire, England. She is a member of the Labour Party and served as a Member of the European Parliament for the North West England region from 22 May 2014 to 31 January 2020. Ward holds a master's degree in Education and International Development from Newcastle University. Before her election as an MEP, she worked on an international delegation to Belfast and ran a social enterprise. She has expressed opposition to Brexit and has been involved in various campaigns, including One Billion Rising, to combat violence against women. Ward was a member of the Committee on Culture and Education and the Delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. She also served as a substitute member for the Committee on Regional Development, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and the Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.

June Mummery, born 1963 or 1964, British politician and businesswoman, Reform UK's Fisheries spokesperson since 2023, former Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for East of England constituency from 2019 to 2020, managing director of BFP Eastern Ltd, fish market auctioneers in Lowestoft, member of Lowestoft Fish Market Alliance, founder of Renaissance of East Anglian Fisheries, campaigned with pro-Brexit group Fishing for Leave, former sales director in the engineering sector, voted for Brexit in 2016, supports Brexit for greater control of UK fishing waters, stood as Reform UK candidate for Lowestoft in 2024 UK general election, coming third with 24.7% of the vote, resides in Lowestoft, Suffolk, occupation politician and businesswoman.

Juozas Olekas, a Lithuanian surgeon and politician, born 30 October 1955 in Bolshoy Ungut, Soviet Union (now Russia), studied at Kaunas Institute of Medicine from 1974 to 1976 and at Vilnius University from 1976 to 1980, served as Health Minister in 1990 and from 2003 to 2004, Minister of National Defence from 2006 to 2008 and from 2012 to 2016, chief physician at Vilnius University hospital from 1994 to 1997, married to Aurelija Olekienė with two daughters, elected to the European Parliament in 2019, member of the Social Democratic Party of Lithuania, finished second in the 2021 party leadership election with 44% of the vote.

Jutta Paulus, a German politician and member of the European Parliament for Alliance 90/The Greens, born on 9 May 1967 in Giessen, West Germany, educated at the University of Marburg with a degree in pharmacy. Paulus worked as a pharmacist and managing director of the laboratory LAUS GmbH before entering politics. She is a member of the European Parliament Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and Committee on Transport and Tourism. Paulus has been a rapporteur on CO2 emissions in the maritime sector and methane emissions reduction in the energy sector. She campaigns for sustainable fuels in shipping and aviation and has worked on key laws of the European Green Deal, including the Nature Restoration Regulation and EU Energy Efficiency Directive. Paulus is a proven nature and climate protection expert, ranked as the 10th most influential EU policymaker in 2020. She is a member of the German Industry Initiative for Energy Efficiency and has urged leaders not to support Arctic LNG 2 due to climate change concerns.

Jytte Guteland, Swedish politician, born September 16, 1979, in Huddinge, Sweden. Master's degree in Economics from Södertörn University. Member of the Social Democrats and the Party of European Socialists. Served as a Member of the European Parliament from July 1, 2014, to September 25, 2022, representing Sweden. Committee assignments included the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport. Member of the Parliament's delegation for relations with Iran and chaired the European Parliament Intergroup on the Western Sahara. Member of the European Council on Foreign Relations. Recipient of the Energy, Science and Research Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2022.

Jérémy Decerle, born 1 July 1984 in Saône-et-Loire, France. Farmer and politician, member of Renew Europe (French delegation), serving as Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for France since 2 July 2019. Term ends 15 July 2024. Former president of the "Young Farmers" union (2016-2019). Sits on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) and the Committee on International Trade (INTA), with a focus on agricultural issues and trade. Has been involved in several key reports, including the CAP reform and animal welfare on farms.

Jérôme Rivière, born 8 July 1964 in Suresnes, Hauts-de-Seine near Paris, France. Education: master's degree from ISG Business School, MBA from the European University of America at the University of San Francisco. Career: deputy chief of staff for the Minister of Defense (1993-1995), Regional Council of Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur (1998-2004), French National Assembly (2002-2007), Member of the European Parliament (2019-2024). Party affiliation: Union for a Popular Movement (until 2007), National Rally (2017-2022), Reconquête (2022-2023). Offices held: President of the French delegation to the Identity and Democracy group (2019-2022), Vice-Chairman of Reconquête.

József Szájer, a Hungarian politician, was born on September 7, 1961, in Sopron. He studied at Bibó István College and graduated as a legal expert from Eötvös Loránd University in 1986. Szájer was a founding member of the Fidesz party in 1988 and served as a member of the Hungarian Parliament from 1990 to 2004. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 2004 to 2020, representing Hungary. Szájer was a member of the European People's Party and served as the vice-chairman of the group from 2004 to 2020. He was also a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and the Committee on Legal Affairs. Szájer was married to Tünde Handó since 1983 and has one daughter. He resigned from his position as MEP in 2020 after being caught by Belgian police at a gay sex party, which led to his resignation from Fidesz and his honorary citizenship of Sopron.

Jörg Meuthen is a German economist and politician, born on June 29, 1961, in Essen, West Germany. He is married to Natalia Zvekic and has five children. Meuthen holds a degree in economics from the University of Cologne and is a professor of political economy and finance at the Academy of Kehl. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Union from 1977 to 2013, then joined the Alternative for Germany (AfD) and served as its federal spokesman and leader from 2015 to 2022. Meuthen was a member of the European Parliament for Germany from 2017 to 2024 and a member of the Landtag of Baden-Württemberg from 2016 to 2017. He was the leading candidate of the AfD for the 2019 European Parliament election. Meuthen has expressed opposition to the Eurozone, immigration, and asylum policies under Angela Merkel, and has advocated for a more conservative approach to politics. He has also expressed support for Israel and has called for a ban on the Lebanese-based militant group Hezbollah. Meuthen resigned from the AfD in 2022 due to the party's shift to the right and joined the Centre Party in 2022, but resigned from the party in 2023 due to disagreements over governance. He is currently an independent politician.

Jörgen Warborn, a male, born on January 23, 1969, in Varberg, Sweden, is a Swedish entrepreneur and politician of the Moderate Party. He is married to Titti Warborn and has three children. He studied economics and leadership at the International University of Monaco, international relations at the London School of Economics, and entrepreneurship at Babson College in Boston. Warborn started his first business at 17 and managed several small businesses in the IT and marketing sector. He served as Mayor of Varberg Municipality from 2011 to 2014 and Member of the Riksdag from 2014 to 2019. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving as coordinator and spokesperson for the European People's Party in the Committee on International Trade. He is also president of SME Global and SME Europe, and national chairman of the Moderate Party's business council.

Karen Melchior, a Danish lawyer and politician, born 15 October 1980 in Copenhagen, Denmark. She is a graduate of the University of Copenhagen. Melchior was a member of the Copenhagen Municipal Council and the Social Liberal Party until August 2022. She served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 2024, representing Denmark. During her tenure, she was part of several committees, including the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and delegations to the EU-Armenia, EU-Azerbaijan, and EU-Georgia Parliamentary Partnership Committees. Melchior was also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Internet Forum, the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group, and the Spinelli Group. She supervised tech issues and owned Apple shares. Melchior faced allegations of harassment against her assistants in 2021, resulting in her party's request for her resignation from the European Parliament in May 2022.

Karima Delli, a French politician, born 4 March 1979 in Roubaix, Nord, to Algerian parents. Grew up in poor conditions in Tourcoing as the ninth child in a family of 13. Obtained a Master of Advanced Studies in political science at the Lille IEP. Member of the European Parliament since 14 July 2009, representing the constituency of North-West France (2009-14) and Île-de-France (2014-present). Member of Europe Écologie–The Greens. Served on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (2009-2014), Committee on Transport and Tourism (2014-present), and as vice-chair of the Volkswagen emissions scandal inquiry (2016). Member of the parliament's delegations for relations with India (2009-2019) and China (since 2019). Endorsed Yannick Jadot as the Green movement's candidate for the French presidential election in 2022. Supported the ZAD (Zone to Defend) against a motorway near Strasbourg in 2018. Recipient of the Infrastructure, Transport and Mobility Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in June 2023.

Karin Karlsbro, born 23 September 1970 in Norrtälje, Sweden, is a Swedish politician of the Liberals. She holds a law degree from Stockholm University and has studied at the London School of Economics and Political Science. Karlsbro has served as chairman of the Liberal Youth of Sweden from 1995 to 1997, administrative director at the Parliament Office of the Liberal People's Party from 2000 to 2006, chief of staff for Nyamko Sabuni from 2006 to 2010, group leader in Norrtälje from 2014 to 2018, and Deputy Cabinet Member of the Riksdag from 29 September 2014 to 3 October 2014. She has been the president of the network Green Liberals since February 2012. Karlsbro has worked as a consultant, sustainability expert, and Chief Sustainability Officer at Fastighetsägarna Stockholm since September 2015. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, serving on the Committee on International Trade and as a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group. Karlsbro lives in Stockholm and has three daughters.

Karlo Ressler, a Croatian politician and member of the European Parliament, born on December 26, 1989, in Zagreb, Croatia. He graduated with honors from the Faculty of Law of the University of Zagreb and completed his senior year at the University of Sheffield through the Erasmus Programme. Ressler is currently completing his doctorate degree on human trafficking in Southeast Europe at the Max Planck Institute for Foreign and International Criminal Law in Freiburg, Germany. He is a member of the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) and the European People's Party (EPP). Ressler has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 2, 2019, representing the Croatia constituency. He serves on the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), and is the Vice-President of the Youth of the European People's Party (YEPP). Ressler is married to Karla Ressler and has three children. His stepfather is Vladimir Šeks.

Karol Adam Karski, a Polish politician, born 13 May 1966, holds a Doctor of Law degree from the University of Warsaw, and has taught at the University of Warsaw, the Warsaw University of Humanities, and the Academy of Economics in Białystok. He was elected to the Sejm on 25 September 2005 and 21 October 2007 in 19 Warsaw district as a candidate from the Law and Justice list. He has served as a Member of the European Parliament for Poland since 1 July 2014 and as Quaestor of the European Parliament from 2 July 2014 to 20 January 2022, alongside Élisabeth Morin, Andrey Kovatchev, Catherine Bearder, and Vladimír Maňka.

Karolin Braunsberger-Reinhold, a German politician, born 3 November 1986 in Wolfen, East Germany, served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2021 to 2024, representing the Christian Democratic Union of Germany.

Karoline Edtstadler, born 28 March 1981 in Salzburg, Austria, is an Austrian lawyer and politician. She studied law at the University of Salzburg, graduating in 2004 with a magistra degree. Edtstadler worked as a judge and prosecutor, including at the Salzburg regional court and the Vienna Corruption Prosecutor's Office. She was a legal employee at the European Court of Human Rights from 2016. Edtstadler is a member of the Austrian People's Party and the European People's Party. She served as a councilor in Henndorf am Wallersee from 2004 to 2006 and as State Secretary at the Ministry of the Interior from 2017 to 2019. Edtstadler was a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2020, serving on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights. Since 2020, she has been the Federal Minister for the EU and the Constitution at the Federal Chancellery, serving under Chancellors Sebastian Kurz, Alexander Schallenberg, and Karl Nehammer. Edtstadler is married with a son and lives in Salzburg.

Karsten Lucke, born 29 December 1974 in Kiel, Schleswig-Holstein, Germany, is a German politician and member of the Social Democratic Party. He studied at Kiel University. Since 2014, he has been the mayor of Lautzenbrücken. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 11 January 2022, representing the Germany constituency. He is affiliated with the Party of European Socialists at the EU level. In parliament, he serves on the Committee on Development and is part of the delegations for relations with the countries of South Asia, the OACPS-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and the Pacific-EU Parliamentary Assembly.

Katalin Cseh, a Canadian-born Hungarian physician and politician, born on 29 June 1988 in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, is a member of the Momentum Movement party, part of the Renew Europe party group, and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2 July 2019, representing Hungary. She graduated from Semmelweis University and Erasmus University Rotterdam with a master's degree in Health Economics, Policy, and Law. Cseh co-founded Momentum Movement in 2015 and was appointed to its governing board in 2017. She is a vice-chair of the Renew Europe political group, a member of the Committee on Industry, Research, and Energy, the Subcommittee on Human Rights, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. Cseh supports the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption, the MEP Alliance for Mental Health, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. She has called for coordinated sanctions against Chinese leaders and officials responsible for human rights violations. Cseh's term as an MEP is set to end on 16 July 2024.

Katarina Barley, born 19 November 1968 in Cologne, West Germany, German politician and lawyer, holds citizenship of Germany and the United Kingdom. She studied law at the University of Marburg, University of Paris-Sud, and the University of Münster. She worked as a corporate lawyer, judge, and governmental legal adviser. Barley is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving as one of its Vice-Presidents. She previously served as Federal Minister of Justice and Consumer Protection, Federal Minister of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth, and acting Federal Minister of Labour and Social Affairs in the fourth Cabinet of Angela Merkel. She was Secretary-General of the Social Democratic Party of Germany from 2015 to 2017. Barley is fluent in German, English, and French. She has been married to Marco van den Berg since 2020 and has two sons.

Katarína Roth Neveďalová, born 10 November 1982 in Nitra, Czechoslovakia (now Slovakia), is a Slovak politician from Direction – Slovak Social Democracy. She has been a Member of the European Parliament for Slovakia since 30 December 2022, previously holding the position from 14 July 2009 to 1 July 2014. She is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and became Vice-President of the Party of European Socialists in 2012.

Kateřina Konečná is a Czech politician born on 20 January 1981 in Nový Jičín, Czechoslovakia. She graduated from Masaryk University's Department of Economics and Administration in 2003, received a degree in engineering from the University of Finance and Administration in 2009, and obtained a law degree from Masaryk University in 2013. Konečná is the leader of the Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia since 23 October 2021, replacing Vojtěch Filip. She has been a Member of the European Parliament representing the Czech Republic since 2013 and is a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. Konečná has been involved in controversies related to her pro-Azerbaijan approach in the European Parliament and her voting record on human rights issues in Azerbaijan. She is married to businessman Zdenek Trefil and has a son named Šimon born on 22 October 2015.

Kathleen Van Brempt, a Belgian social-democratic politician, born 18 November 1969 in Wilrijk, Belgium, studied sociology at the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, and became a licentiate in 1991. She is a member of Vooruit and the Party of European Socialists. Her roles include Member of the European Parliament since 2009, State Secretary for Labor organization and Welfare in the working place from 2003 to 2004, Minister for Mobility, Social Economy and Equal Opportunities in the Flemish government, and member of the city council of Antwerp since 2001. She has served on various committees, including the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on International Trade, and the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and has been a member of several delegations and intergroups, such as the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara and the MEP Heart Group. She was vice-chairwoman of the Socialists and Democrats group from 2014 to 2019 and chair of the Parliament's Special Committee on COVID-19 since 2022. She is also a member of the European Council on Foreign Relations.

Kati Piri, born 8 April 1979 in Celldömölk, Hungary, is a Hungarian-born Dutch politician serving as a member of the House of Representatives since 2021. She is a member of the Labour Party (PvdA) and previously was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) within the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats from 2014 until 2021. Piri studied international relations at the University of Groningen, graduating in 2007.
