She worked as a political advisor to the Dutch Labour Party delegation in the European Parliament between 2006 and 2008 and later became programme manager for the Southern-Caucasus and Moldova at the Netherlands Institute for Multiparty Democracy. In the European Parliament, Piri was a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and served as the Parliament's rapporteur on Turkey's EU membership. She was a member of the Democracy Support and Election Coordination Group (DEG) and part of the parliament's mission to observe Ukraine's 2014 parliamentary elections. Piri has called for firm language by the EU towards Turkey and criticized the veto by the European Council on starting the accession procedures of Albania and North Macedonia to the EU. She is a member of the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) and a board member of the Progressive Alliance.

Katrin Langensiepen, a German politician and member of the Alliance 90/The Greens, born on 10 October 1979 in Langenhagen, West Germany. She is the first woman Member of the European Parliament with a visible disability. Langensiepen has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Germany. Prior to her election to the European Parliament, she was a member of the City Council of Hannover. Langensiepen is a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, the European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer. She is also a member of the Heinrich Böll Foundation, Nature and Biodiversity Conservation Union (NABU), German United Services Trade Union (ver.di), and Amnesty International.

Kim van Sparrentak, a Dutch politician born on 16 October 1989, is a member of the GroenLinks party since 2012, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands constituency since 2 July 2019.

Kinga Gál, a Hungarian politician and Member of the European Parliament from Hungary, born on 6 September 1970 in Cluj-Napoca, Romania. She moved to Hungary in 1986 and holds citizenship in both Hungary and Romania. Gál is a member of the Fidesz party and has been an MEP since 1 July 2004, representing the Hungary constituency. She is married to Máté Gál and has four sons: Áron, Gergő, Zsombor, and Márton. Gál graduated from the Institute for Comparative Human Rights in Strasbourg with a diploma of International Human Rights in 1993 and from the Political Science and Law Department of Eötvös Loránd University in 1994. Her career includes working as an advisor to the Democratic Alliance of Hungarians in Romania, analyst for the Government Office for Hungarian Minorities Abroad, researcher for the Teleki Foundation, international legal expert at the European Centre for Minority Issues, and vice-chairman of the Government Office for Hungarian Minorities Abroad. Gál was the vice-president of the European People's Party from 2015 to 2019 and received the annual MEP Award for Justice and Civil Liberties in 2014. She is currently a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Delegation for relations with the People's Republic of China, and co-chair of the Intergroup on Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages.

Kira Marie Peter-Hansen, a Danish politician, born on 23 February 1998 in Frederiksberg, Capital Region of Denmark. She is a member of the Green Left party and serves as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Denmark, elected in 2019 and 2024. Peter-Hansen is the youngest ever MEP, having taken office at the age of 21 years, 3 months, and 3 days. She is a financial officer in the Youth of the Socialist People's Party and previously worked as a barista and campaign manager for Astrid Aller's successful election as Copenhagen councillor in the 2017 Danish local elections. Peter-Hansen is a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, substitute member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and part of the parliament's delegation for relations with India. She is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions. Peter-Hansen has been serving as vice-chair of the Greens–European Free Alliance group since 2021 and has received the People's Choice: Best Young Leader Award and a "Rising Star" award at the MEP Awards. Her main priorities in parliament include promoting environmentally friendly policy and renegotiating the Common Agricultural Policy, and she advocates for LGBT rights.

Klaus Buchner, a German university professor and physicist, born 6 February 1941 in Munich, Germany, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Ecological Democratic Party, representing the Germany constituency from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2020, and sat with the Greens-European Free Alliance group. He was the Leader of the Ecological Democratic Party from 2003 to 2010 and is a fellow of the European Institute for International Law and International Relations.

Klemen Grošelj, Slovenian politician, born 8 March 1976 in Kranj, Yugoslavia, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Slovenia since 2 July 2019, affiliated with the List of Marjan Šarec (2018-2022), Freedom Movement (2022-2024), and Greens of Slovenia (2024-), member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, shadow rapporteur on the accession of Serbia to the European Union, part of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee and the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara.

Klára Dobrev, Hungarian politician, born 2 February 1972 in Sofia, Bulgaria, to a Hungarian Jewish mother and a Bulgarian father. She holds degrees in economics from the Budapest University of Economics and law from the Eötvös Loránd University. Dobrev is married to Ferenc Gyurcsány, the former Prime Minister of Hungary, and has three children. Her grandfather, Antal Apró, was a communist politician who served as Minister of Industry in the Hungarian People's Republic. Dobrev has been a member of the Democratic Coalition since 2011 and previously a member of the Hungarian Socialist Party from 1994 to 2011. She was the lead candidate for the Democratic Coalition in the 2019 European Parliament election, resulting in a 16.05% vote share, and served as Vice-President of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022. Dobrev was also the frontrunner in the primary election for the 2022 parliamentary election but was defeated by Péter Márki-Zay. She has been recognized as one of the BBC's 100 women of 2013.

Konstantinos Papadakis, a Greek politician born on 18 April 1975 in Athens, Greece, member of the Communist Party of Greece (KKE), serving as a Member of the European Parliament representing Greece since 1 July 2014, non-inscrit and not affiliated with any parliamentary group, member of the Committee on Regional Development, the Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council, and the Delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean.

Kosma Złotowski, born January 14, 1964, in Bydgoszcz, Poland. Graduated in Polish philology from University of Warsaw and obtained an MBA from Dominican University in Chicago in 2004. Member of Sejm of Poland (1997-2001, 2005-2007), President (Mayor) of Bydgoszcz (1994-1995), and member of Bydgoszcz City Council (2002-2005). Represented Bydgoszcz district in Senate of Poland III term and 4 Bydgoszcz district in Senate of Poland IV term. Candidate of Solidarity Electoral Action in 1997, Law and Justice in 2002 and 2005. Member of Centre Agreement (1990-1999), Conference of Polish Christian Democrats (1997-2001), and Law and Justice (since 2002).

Kostas Arvanitis, a Greek politician and journalist, born on 9 June 1964 in Sepolia, Athens, Greece, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Coalition of the Radical Left, representing the constituency of Greece since 2 July 2019.

Costas Mavrides, a Cypriot politician, born 27 May 1962 in Kato Dikomo, Cyprus, PhD in Economics from Houston University, academic from 1995-2004 in the USA, Greece, and Cyprus, member of the Democratic Party, Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing Cyprus, sits with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee.

Kris Peeters, a male politician from Belgium, born on May 18, 1962, in Reet, Belgium, is married to Ann, and has a child named Karel. He studied law at the University of Antwerp and obtained a degree in taxation and accounting from Vlerick Business School in Ghent. Peeters is a member of the Christen-Democratisch en Vlaams (CD&V) party. His political career includes serving as Minister-President of Flanders from 2007 to 2014, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Employment, Economy, and Consumer Affairs from 2014 to 2019, and Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2021. He also served as vice-president of the European Investment Bank (EIB) from 2021 to 2024.

Krzysztof Brejza, a Polish politician born on 16 May 1983 in Bydgoszcz, Poland, is a member of the European Parliament and the Civic Platform party. He graduated from the Law and Administration Faculty of the University of Warsaw. His father, Ryszard Brejza, is also a politician who has served as a Member of the 6th Sejm of the Polish Republic and as President (Mayor) of Inowrocław since 2002. Krzysztof Brejza was a member of the Kuyavian-Pomeranian Regional Assembly from 2005 to 2006 and the Sejm of the Republic of Poland from 2007 to 2024, representing the 4th district (Bydgoszcz). He was elected to the Sejm in 2007 with 6,441 votes and re-elected in 2015 with 15,951 votes. In 2024, he became a Member of the European Parliament, replacing Radosław Sikorski. He was head of the Civic Coalition election campaign during the 2019 Polish parliamentary election campaign, which was allegedly surveilled by the Polish government-controlled secret service using Pegasus spyware. He is married to Dorota Brejza.

Krzysztof Andrzej Hetman, born 27 June 1974 in Lublin, Poland, is a Polish politician who graduated from Maria Curie-Skłodowska University. He worked for Lublin Voivodeship as a deputy director from 2002 to 2005 and as a director of regional development from 2005 to 2007. In 2010, he was named Marshal of Lublin Voivodeship. He is a member of the Polish People's Party. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2014, representing Lublin, and served until 18 October 2023. He was elected to the Sejm from Lublin in the 2023 Polish parliamentary election as a member of Third Way. Since 13 December 2023, he has served as Minister of Economic Development and Technology under Prime Minister Donald Tusk, succeeding Marlena Maląg, until 13 May 2024, when he was succeeded by Krzysztof Paszyk.

Krzysztof Jurgiel, a Polish politician, born on 18 November 1953 in Ogrodniki, educated at Warsaw University of Technology, served as Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development from 16 November 2015 to 2018, member of Sejm 1997-2001, 2001-2005, 2005-2007, and Senate 2001-2005, elected to Sejm on 25 September 2005 with 42,920 votes in the 24th Białystok district, representing Law and Justice party, and a Member of the European Parliament for the Podlaskie and Warmian-Masurian constituency since 2019.

Kyriakos Velopoulos, born 24 October 1965 in Essen, West Germany, is the president of the Greek Solution party, a position he has held since its foundation in 2016. He is a member of the Hellenic Parliament, representing the constituency of Larissa since 7 July 2019. Velopoulos previously served as a member of the Hellenic Parliament for the constituency of Thessaloniki B from 16 September 2007 to 11 April 2012. He was a member of the European Parliament, representing Greece, from 2 July 2019 to 7 July 2019. Velopoulos is a journalist, author, and television personality, having worked for various radio and television stations, including "TV Thessaloniki", "Ερμής", "Best", "Top", "Opion", and "TeleAsty". He is the presenter and owner of the "Alert TV" channel. Velopoulos has written several books, including "Greece Bleeds" and "Alexander, the Greatest of the Greeks". He has been married to Olga Petropoulou and has one child. Velopoulos has been a member of the Popular Orthodox Rally party from 2004 to 2012 and the New Democracy party from 2012 to 2015. He has been a member of the Academy of the Greek language in Germany and the Union of Writers of Northern Greece. Velopoulos has been involved in several controversies, including the advertisement of a book containing copies of medieval manuscripts found in the monasteries of Mount Athos, which some critics disputed as inauthentic. He has also raised objections to the indictment of Golden Dawn's members, characterizing their arrests as a plot orchestrated by the domestic government and judicial system.

Ladislav Ilčić, a Croatian politician and former violinist, born on August 4, 1970, in Varaždin, Croatia, Yugoslavia. He is the son of Stanko Ilčić, a doctor and former director of the Varaždin Health Center. Ilčić graduated from the Academy of Music in Zagreb and specialized in playing the violin. He was a member of the symphony orchestra of the state radio and television broadcaster HRT and an occasional member of the mariachi band "El Combo". Ilčić co-founded the organization "GROZD" in 2006 and became its chairman in 2008. He is the president of the Oak Party - Movement for a Successful Croatia (Hrast) and was a member of the Patriotic Coalition. Ilčić was a member of the Croatian Parliament from 2015 to 2016 and served as a Member of the European Parliament from July 1, 2021, to 2024, replacing Ruža Tomašić. He is affiliated with the Croatian Growth party (2012-2021) and the Croatian Sovereignists party (2019-2024).

Lance Philip Forman, a British politician and businessman, born on 13 October 1962 in Islington, London, England, married to Rene Anisfeld with three children. Educated at Haberdashers' Aske's Boys' School and Trinity College, Cambridge. 

Initially affiliated with the Conservative Party, then joined the Brexit Party, served as a Member of the European Parliament for London from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, and later rejoined the Conservative Party. 

Forman is a climate change denier, in favour of reducing the size of the state, removing red tape, and supports Brexit due to claimed negative impacts of EU regulations on his business. He is the fourth-generation owner of H. Forman and Son, a smoked salmon business, and has been involved in various controversies, including anti-semitic attacks on his business and criticism for hosting a public meeting of Turning Point UK.

Lara Comi, Italian politician, born 18 February 1983 in Garbagnate Milanese, Italy. Education: Bachelor's degree in economics from Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore in Milan (2005), Master's in economics from Università Commerciale Luigi Bocconi in Milan (2007). Career: Internships at Uruguayan consulate in Italy and Beiersdorf Italy, brand manager for Giochi Preziosi. Member of European Parliament (2009-2019, 2022-present), delegations for relations with Afghanistan (2009-10) and Latin America (2010-14), EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee (2010-14), Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection (2012-14, 2014-present), delegation for relations with the United States. Party affiliations: Forza Italia (2002-2009, 2013-present), The People of Freedom (2009-2013). Sanctioned for hiring mother as personal assistant in European Parliament office.

Lara Ianthe Wolters, a Dutch politician, Labour Party (PvdA), born 12 April 1986 in Amsterdam, Netherlands, married to a Greek husband with two sons born in 2021 and 2023. She studied law and European social and political studies at University College London, spent a year at the University of Strasbourg through the Erasmus Programme, and holds a degree in International Relations and Diplomacy from the College of Europe in Bruges. Wolters worked as a policy advisor in Brussels and became a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in 2019, replacing Frans Timmermans. She is a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control and Vice Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs, and has been involved in several key legislative initiatives, including the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive and a directive on improving the gender balance on boards of directors of listed companies. Wolters is also part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with China and a member of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption and the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity. She was re-elected in June 2024 as the seventh candidate on the shared GroenLinks–PvdA list.

Lars Patrick Berg, born 22 January 1966 in Frankfurt, Germany, is a German politician. He is a lieutenant colonel in the reserve of the German Armed Forces. Berg grew up bilingual in the Böblingen area as the son of an Englishwoman and a German man. He graduated from high school in 1988 at the Kolleg St. Blasien. He studied Eastern European history in Tübingen, Heidelberg, and Munich. After working in Herrenberg and Frankfurt, he studied international energy economics in Leipzig and Moscow from 2007 to 2009. He then worked as an independent PR consultant. From 2013 to 2014, Berg was press spokesman for the Sigmaringen district office. He then worked as a press spokesman for the AfD in the European Parliament in Brussels. Berg is married and lives in Heidelberg. He is a member of the KDStV Arminia Heidelberg and the Catholic student association AV Guestfalia Tübingen. 

Berg was a member of the Alternative for Germany from March 2013 to 2021. He was a member of the AfD Baden-Württemberg state executive committee from April 2013 to October 2014 and from July 2015 to March 2016. He was elected to the Baden-Württemberg state parliament in the 2016 election. There he served as domestic policy spokesman for the AfD parliamentary group and as a member of the Committee on Home Affairs, Digitisation and Migration and the Committee on Europe and International Affairs. Berg was Deputy Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Baden-Württemberg Development Cooperation Foundation (SEZ). 

Berg was elected to the European Parliament in the 2019 European elections via the 4th place on the list of the Alternative for Germany. There he was a member of the Identity and Democracy Group (ID) and a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), the Subcommittee on Human Rights (DROI), the Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) and the Delegation for relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union, including the EU-Morocco, EU-Tunisia and EU-Algeria Joint Parliamentary Committees (DMAG). 

In May 2021, Berg declared his resignation from the AfD and the ID faction. He criticized the resolutions of the AfD party conference of April 2021, in which, among other things, a withdrawal from the EU was demanded by Germany. In the meantime, he was a non-attached member before joining the European Conservatives and Reformists Group on 23 June 2021. Berg has been a member of the Liberal-Conservative Reformers party from July 2021 to January 2023. Since January 2023 he is a member of the Alliance Germany party. 

Berg has shown his support for Morocco as one of the partners of the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership and in general of the European Neighbourhood Policy and for the EU-Morocco Agreement. On the subject of the Syrian conflict, Berg has sharply criticized Turkey's military actions against the Kurdish population.

Laura Ballarin Cereza, a Spanish politician from the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, born 19 July 1984 in Barcelona, Spain, educated at Pompeu Fabra University, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 6 September 2023, replacing Adriana Maldonado López.

Italian politician Laura Ferrara, born 11 September 1983 in Naples, Italy, nationality Italian, lawyer by profession, educated at University of Calabria, University of Bologna, and University of Florence, member of Five Star Movement, served as Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy constituency since 1 July 2014.

Laura Huhtasaari is a Finnish politician and teacher born on 30 March 1979 in Vilppula, Pirkanmaa, Finland. She holds a Master of Education degree from the University of Jyväskylä. Huhtasaari is a member of the Finns Party and has represented Satakunta in the Parliament of Finland from 2015 to 2019 and again from 2023. She was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 with 92,760 votes and served until 2023. Huhtasaari has also been a member of the City Council of Pori since 2012. She was the Finns Party candidate for the 2018 Finnish presidential election, where she placed third with 6.9 percent of the votes. Huhtasaari has expressed Eurosceptic views, opposing Finland's membership in the EU and NATO, and has been a supporter of former US President Donald Trump and Brexit. She has also made controversial statements on feminism, Islam, and evolution. Huhtasaari has been accused of plagiarizing parts of her 2003 M.Sc. thesis, with investigations finding serious plagiarism and disregard for the scientific method.

Laurence Farreng, French politician, born 6 September 1966 in Nîmes, member of Democratic Movement and European Democratic Party, serving as Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019, re-elected in 2024, also Pau town Councillor and Community Councillor of the Pau Béarn Pyrénées Agglomeration, previously worked in communication for consumer goods companies and local public institutions, founded association "Bonjour l'Europe" to promote experience of studies, internships and work in other European countries, coordinator of Renew Europe in Committee on Culture, Education, Youth and Sport, substitute member of Committee on Regional Development, part of Parliament's delegation to Conference on the Future of Europe, negotiator for Erasmus+ 2021-2027 programme, rapporteur on European Green Deal measures for education and culture programmes.

Lefteris Christoforou is a Greek Cypriot politician, born on August 31, 1963, in Prastio, Famagusta, Cyprus. He is an economist by occupation and is married to Diamanto Orthodoxou with a son, Panagiotis, and a daughter, Loukia. Christoforou is a member of the Democratic Rally and the European People's Party. He was a member of the Cyprus Parliament from 1996 to 2014, representing the Famagusta District. Christoforou has been a member of the European Parliament since July 1, 2014, representing Cyprus and serving as the leader of the Cyprus delegation in the European People's Party Group. He has been a member of various committees, including the Committee on Budgets, the Committee on Budgetary Control, and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Christoforou has also been a member of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Freedom of Religion or Belief and Religious Tolerance, the European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability.
Lefteris Nikolaou-Alavanos, Greek politician and Member of the European Parliament for the Communist Party of Greece, serving since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Greece.

Lena Düpont, a 38-year-old German politician, born on 30 April 1986, in Dortmund, West Germany. She is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Düpont studied political science and journalism at the University of Erlangen–Nuremberg. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Germany since 2019, specifically on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and as a substitute on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Düpont has also been the parliament's rapporteur on a 2020 law establishing a common border procedure for international protection and part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Montenegro Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee. Additionally, she serves as deputy chairwoman of the CDU in Lower Saxony.

Leopoldo López Gil, a Spanish-Venezuelan politician, born on October 20, 1944, in Caracas, Venezuela, with Venezuelan and Spanish citizenship since 2015, married to Antonieta Mendoza Coburn, with three children, including Leopoldo López, educated at Columbia University, member of the People's Party since 2019 and Popular Will since 2009, served as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since July 2, 2019, and currently sits on the Subcommittee on Human Rights, the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly.

Leszek Miller, a Polish politician, born on 3 July 1946 in Żyrardów, Poland. He comes from a poor, working-class family, with his father being a tailor and his mother a needlewoman. Miller's parents broke up when he was six months old, and he was raised by his mother in a religious spirit. He graduated from a vocational school and later completed his military service on the ORP Bielik submarine. In 1969, Miller married Aleksandra and had a son, Leszek Junior, and a granddaughter, Monika.

Miller started his political career as an activist of the Socialist Youth Union and later became a member of the Polish United Workers' Party (PZPR) in 1969. He held various positions within the party, including Secretary of the PZPR Plant Committee, and later became a member of the PZPR Political Bureau in 1989. After the PZPR was dissolved, Miller co-founded the Social Democracy of the Polish Republic and became its Chairman in 1997.

Miller served as the Prime Minister of Poland from 2001 to 2004, leading a government that faced a difficult economic situation, including high unemployment and public debt. During his term, he implemented various reforms, including a flat tax, and played a key role in Poland's accession to the European Union.

Miller has also held various other positions, including Minister of Labour and Social Policy, Minister of Interior and Administration, and Leader of the Democratic Left Alliance. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2019 and has written for various publications, including the "Wprost" weekly.

Miller's political career has been marked by controversy, including accusations of acting anti-constitutionally by tolerating the imprisonment and torture of prisoners at a secret CIA prison in Poland. He has also been criticized for his liberal economic approach and his leadership style.

Education: Vocational school, Higher School of Political Sciences (Wyższa Szkoła Nauk Społecznych)

Career: 
- Activist of the Socialist Youth Union
- Member of the Polish United Workers' Party (PZPR) (1969-1990)
- Co-founder of the Social Democracy of the Polish Republic (1990)
- Chairman of the Social Democracy of the Polish Republic (1997-1999)
- Leader of the Democratic Left Alliance (1999-2004, 2011-2016)
- Prime Minister of Poland (2001-2004)
- Minister of Labour and Social Policy (1993-1996)
- Minister of Interior and Administration (1997)
- Member of the European Parliament (2019-2024)

Awards: 
- Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana
- National Order of Merit (Malta)
- Order of the Smile

Party affiliations: 
- Polish United Workers' Party (PZPR) (1969-1990)
- Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland (1990-1999)
- Democratic Left Alliance (1999-2007, 2010-2021)
- Polish Left (2007-2010)
- Self-Defence of the Republic of Poland (2007)

Leïla Chaibi, born October 5, 1982, in Dijon, France, is a French politician and Member of the European Parliament. She studied at the Institute of Political Studies of Toulouse, graduating in 2005. Chaibi's early career involved temporary jobs and working at the Paris town hall. She served as the coordinator of youth initiatives for the city of Gennevilliers and later as the head of community life and citizenship for the department of Stains. 

Chaibi was a member of the SUD Étudiant student union and participated in the counter-globalization movement. She co-founded Jeudi noir, an organization that aimed to shine light on the housing crisis. Chaibi joined the New Anticapitalist Party in 2009, but left in 2011 due to disappointment with the party's failure to work with other radical left-wing parties. She then joined the Left Party, becoming national secretary and a member of the campaign committee for the 2012 presidential elections. 

In 2016, Chaibi joined La France Insoumise, co-authoring the party's agenda on housing and co-leading its civil disobedience committee. She was a candidate for La France Insoumise in the 2017 parliamentary elections and was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019. Chaibi presides over La France Insoumise's delegation in the European Parliament and is a substitute member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Delegation to the EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee.

Chaibi has advocated for the rights of platform workers, proposing a European directive on platform workers and leading the fight for the presumption of salaried employment. She has also established herself as an opponent of Amazon's business model, denouncing its history of tax avoidance and treatment of workers. Chaibi has spoken out against private jets, environmental pollution, and the carbon market. She is in favor of the creation of a menstrual leave and the abolition of VAT on menstrual protection products.

Chaibi denounced President Emmanuel Macron's decision to award the Legion of Honor to Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon. She criticized the social climate fund as insufficient and warned of the risk of a resurgence of the Gilets jaunes across Europe. Chaibi opposed the extension of the carbon market proposed by the European Parliament and denounced the French government's unwillingness to defend rail freight.

Chaibi is a board member of the Progressive International and has endorsed Chile's first draft of a new constitution. She called for an overhaul of the European Parliament's rules of conduct and greater transparency in the wake of the Qatargate scandal. Chaibi uses social media platforms, such as TikTok, to reveal behind-the-scenes of the European Parliament and tackle political issues. She published the book Députée pirate: comment j'ai infiltrée la machine européenne in January 2024, recounting her entry into the European Parliament and her fight for platform workers.

Liesje Schreinemacher is a Dutch lawyer and politician of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD). Born on 13 May 1983 in Rotterdam, Netherlands, she studied at the University of Amsterdam (UvA) and Leiden University, obtaining degrees in Communication Science, Law, and Civil Law. Schreinemacher served as an assistant to Dutch MPs, an adviser at the Dutch Ministry of Defence, and a lawyer specialising in construction law and contract law. She was a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022, part of the Renew Europe parliamentary group, and a member of several committees, including the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Legal Affairs. Schreinemacher served as Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation in the fourth Rutte cabinet from 10 January 2022 to 2 July 2024, taking a maternity leave from 4 December 2023 to 15 April 2024. She is a member of the Board of Governors of the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and the Inter-American Development Bank, and an Alternate Member of the Joint World Bank-IMF Development Committee. Schreinemacher has advocated for a two-way street regarding trade with China, supporting European companies' access to the Chinese market.

Lina Gálvez Muñoz, a Spanish economic historian and politician, born on 13 June 1969 in Seville, Spain, with Spanish nationality. She studied history at the University of Seville, Lumière University Lyon 2, and the European University Institute, becoming a historian and professor. Gálvez was the Minister of Knowledge, Research and University of the Junta of Andalusia from 2018 to 2019 and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Spain. She is affiliated with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and serves as vice-president on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and is a member of the Commission on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Panel for the Future of Science and Technology, and the parliament's delegation for relations with the United States. Gálvez is an expert in feminist economics and a member of Economists Without Borders, with over a hundred scientific publications and recognition through several awards, including the Ramón Carande Award for Economic History, the Award of the I3 Programme, the Meridiana Award, the Emilio Castelar Award, and the María Matilde Schemm Award.

Linea Søgaard-Lidell, a Danish politician, was born on 30 March 1987, in Aarhus, Denmark. She is affiliated with the Venstre party and has a background in education from Aarhus University and Maastricht University. Søgaard-Lidell stood in the 2019 European Parliament election in Denmark, where she secured 24,153 personal votes and initially wasn't elected but took a seat redistributed after Brexit. She served in the European Parliament from 1 February 2020 to 14 November 2022, sitting with the Renew Europe group. She resigned from the European Parliament after being elected to the Folketing in the 2022 general election, taking office on 1 November 2022, and was succeeded in the European Parliament by Bergur Løkke Rasmussen.
Linus Glanzelius, Swedish politician, born 28 December 1990, member of the Social Democratic Party, Member of the European Parliament for Sweden since 27 February 2024, replacing Erik Bergkvist.
Liudas Mažylis, a Lithuanian politician and current Member of the European Parliament for the Homeland Union, serving the Lithuania constituency since 2 July 2019.

Ljudmila Novak, born 1 August 1959 in Maribor, Slovenia, studied Slovene and German language at the University of Maribor. She worked as a school teacher from 1982 to 2001. Novak entered politics in 2001 as the mayor of Moravče. She became a member of the Executive Council of New Slovenia party in 2002 and the president of the party in 2008. Novak was elected to the European Parliament in 2004 and has been a member of the Committee on Culture and Education. She has also been a member of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware since 2022. Novak is a substitute for the Committee on Regional Development and a member of the delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. She has been the vice-president of the Slovenian National Assembly since 21 December 2011. Novak has held various offices including Deputy Prime Minister of Slovenia, Minister Without Portfolio for the Slovenian Diaspora, and Deputy-Speaker of the National Assembly. She is a member of the New Slovenia – Christian People's Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Slovenia since 20 July 2004, with a break from 30 July 2009 to 1 July 2019.

Lóránt Vincze, a 46-year-old Romanian politician from the Hungarian minority, born on November 3, 1977, in Târgu Mureș, Romania, currently serving as a Member of the European Parliament representing Romania and affiliated with the Democratic Alliance of Hungarians in Romania (UDMR/RMDSZ) and the European People's Party (EPP), also holding the position of president of the Federal Union of European Nationalities (FUEN).

Louis Stedman-Bryce, born December 1974, British, care home director and property investor, openly gay, married to Gavin Stedman-Bryce, Member of the European Parliament for Scotland from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, initially elected as Brexit Party candidate, later sat as an independent, co-founder of iNkfish Capital, director of iNkfish Care and iNkfish Property Developments, first black parliamentarian elected in Scotland and first gay black man to represent the United Kingdom in the European Parliament.

Loukas Fourlas, a Cypriot MEP, born August 21, 1969, in Limassol, Cyprus, representing the Democratic Rally party, educated at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, serving on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, part of the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, recipient of the Health and Wellbeing Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2022.

Italian politician Lucia Vuolo, born 15 February 1963, Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Southern Italy, affiliated with Forza Italia since 2021, previously with League until 2021, nationality Italian.

Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová, a Slovak politician, born on 28 November 1976 in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, as Lucia Kubovičová. She is a former journalist and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Slovakia. Nicholsonová was a member of the Freedom and Solidarity party from 2010 to 2021, then founded the Jablko party in 2023. She has previously served as State Secretary of the Ministry of Labor, Social and Family Affairs, and vice-chairwoman of the National Council of Slovakia. Nicholsonová has been married twice, first to Tom Nicholson, a journalist, with whom she had two children, Dominik (1999) and Lilly (2008), and then to Peter Ďuriš, with whom she had a son, Jakub (2016). She has focused on employment and social matters, including rights of persons with disabilities and active ageing. Nicholsonová is known for proposing reforms to improve living conditions of Romani people in Slovakia and has been a vocal critic of government corruption scandals.

Lucy Elizabeth Harris, a British Conservative Party politician, born on 19 October 1990 in Ipswich, Suffolk, England. She studied classical singing at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, and completed a master's degree in Publishing at University College London. Harris worked as a corporate communications executive for The Quarto Group and as a press officer for the GLA Conservatives. She was elected as a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for Yorkshire and the Humber in 2019, later becoming an independent MEP, and then a Conservative MEP in January 2020, until the UK's withdrawal from the EU. Harris was a member of the Committee on International Trade and the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee. She has written pro-Brexit articles and suggested that leaving the EU would have a short-term negative effect on the economy, lasting around 30 years, but considered it a cost worth paying for regaining sovereignty and democracy. Harris was a special adviser in the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities in 2022. She is engaged to former special adviser Hugh Bennett.

Lucy Nethsingha, a British Liberal Democrat politician, was born on 6 February 1973 in Southampton, England, and grew up in Cornwall. She holds a BSc degree in Psychology from the University of Southampton and a master's degree from the University of Cambridge. Nethsingha is a teacher by profession. She is married to Andrew Nethsingha, the organist and master of the choristers at Westminster Abbey, and they have three children. Nethsingha served as a councillor on Gloucester City Council from 2004 to 2008 and has been a member of Cambridgeshire County Council since 2009, representing the Newnham division. She was leader of the Liberal Democrat Group on the council from 2015 to 2021 and became the leader of the council in 2021. Nethsingha was a Member of the European Parliament for the East of England from 2019 to 2020 and chair of the Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs. She contested the North East Cambridgeshire parliamentary constituency in the 2015 general election and South East Cambridgeshire in the 2017 general election.

Luděk Niedermayer, a Czech politician and economist, born on 13 March 1966 in Brno, Czechoslovakia, currently serves as a Member of the European Parliament for the Czech Republic since 1 July 2014, representing TOP 09, part of the European People's Party. He studied theoretical cybernetics, mathematical informatics, and systems theory at Jan Evangelista Purkyně University, now Masaryk University, completing his education in 1989. Prior to entering European politics, he worked at the Czech National Bank from 1991 to 2008, holding various roles including director, member of the Bank's board, and Vice-Governor. He then worked as a director at Deloitte Czech Republic from 2008 until his election in 2014. Niedermayer held senior roles within international financial administration, including a term as a member of a working group of the Bank for International Settlements and Representative of the Czech Republic at meetings of the International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. He chaired the Scientific Council of the Czech Banking Association from 2005 to 2008. In the European Parliament, he serves as Vice-Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and is a member of the Delegation for relations with the United States, Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect (TAXE 2), and Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect.

Luis Garicano, a Spanish economist and politician, born in 1967 in Valladolid, Spain, with a background in economics and law from the University of Valladolid, master's degrees from the College of Europe and the University of Chicago, and a PhD in economics from the University of Chicago. He was a professor of strategy and economics at IE Business School in Madrid, the London School of Economics, and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. Garicano was a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022, vice president of Renew Europe, and vice president of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party. He was the chief economist of the Spanish center-right liberal party Ciudadanos and the main architect behind the party's economic proposals. Garicano has published numerous academic articles and books on economics, focusing on productivity, technological innovation, and the organization of work, and has been a prominent advocate for structural reforms to the Spanish and European economies.

Luisa Manon Porritt, born 23 May 1987 at Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead, London, England. Educated at a local private school in Camden, Royal Holloway, University of London (2008), and Sciences Po Paris. Worked as a journalist, consultant for Global Counsel, and political researcher for Shriti Vadera. Became Head of Investment Content at Edelman Smithfield in 2021. Joined Liberal Democrats in 2016. Served as a councillor for Belsize ward in Camden (2018-2022), leader of the Liberal Democrats on Camden Council (2020-2022), and Member of the European Parliament for London (2019-2020). Was the Liberal Democrat candidate for the 2021 London mayoral election and ran for the parliamentary constituency of Sutton and Cheam in 2024 but lost the selection. Resides in Camden.

Luisa Regimenti, Italian coroner and politician, born 5 June 1958 in Rome, served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 6 April 2023, representing Central Italy, initially a member of the League until 2021, then joined Forza Italia.

Lukas Mandl, Austrian politician, born 12 July 1979 in Vienna, Austria, nationality Austrian, member of the Austrian People's Party and the European People's Party, Member of the European Parliament since 30 November 2017, representing the Austria constituency, previously served as MP in the state parliament of Lower Austria from 2008 to 2016, district chairman for the Austrian People's Party in Lower Austrian district of Wien Umgebung from 2008 to 2016, vice mayor of Grasdorf from 2015 to 2017, secretary general of the ÖAAB from 2010, graduate in communications from the University of Vienna in 2004, completed a traineeship at the Federation of Austrian Industries from 2002 to 2005, chair of the parliament's delegation for relations with the Korean Peninsula since 2020, member of the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, and the URBAN Intergroup, member of the board of trustees of the Institute of the Regions of Europe, member of Rotary International, and member of SK Rapid Wien.

Luke 'Ming' Flanagan, MEP from Ireland, Midlands–North-West constituency, born 22 January 1972 in Roscommon, Ireland. Married to Judith Flanagan with three daughters. Identifies as an atheist and is autistic. Convicted of possession of cannabis for personal use. Served sentences at Loughan House open prison in County Cavan. 

Education: studied science at Galway Regional Technical College, mechanical engineering at Sligo RTC.

Career: 
- Member of Roscommon County Council (2004-2011)
- Mayor of Roscommon County Council (2010-2011)
- Teachta Dála (2011-2014)
- Member of the European Parliament (2014-present)

Party affiliation: 
- Independent in Ireland
- The Left in the European Parliament – GUE/NGL in the EU
- Part of the New Vision electoral alliance in 2011

Policy positions:
- Advocates for the legalisation of cannabis
- Supports turf-cutting from protected bogs
- Opposes the European Fiscal Compact Treaty
- Advocates for Ireland to leave the economic and monetary union
- Supports a 'Yes' vote in the Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018 to repeal the constitutional ban on abortion
- Has been critical of the Garda Síochána and the European Union

Personal characteristics:
- Has depression
- Smoked cannabis until 2011, then stopped in Ireland but continued abroad
- Took a 50% salary cut as a TD and encouraged other politicians to do so
- Refused to lead prayers as Mayor of Roscommon County Council due to being a non-believer

László Trócsányi, born 6 March 1956, Hungarian lawyer, academic, diplomat, politician, and Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He studied law at the Attila József University of Szeged and Eötvös Loránd University in Budapest. Trócsányi obtained his doctorate in 1991 with a thesis on administrative jurisdiction in comparative law. He co-founded the law firm Nagy & Trócsányi in 1991. He served as Ambassador of Hungary to Belgium and Luxembourg from 2000 to 2004, and to France from 2010 to 2014. Trócsányi was a member of the Constitutional Court of Hungary between 2007 and 2010 and Minister of Justice in the third and fourth Orbán cabinets from 2014 to 2019. He was the lead candidate of the Fidesz party list at the 2019 European Parliament election and was nominated as EU commissioner from Hungary in 2019, but his nomination was rejected due to potential conflict of interest. Trócsányi is married to Krisztina Doór and has three children.

Ana Lídia Fernandes Oliveira Pereira, a Portuguese politician, born on 26 July 1991, in Coimbra, Portugal. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Portugal. She holds a degree in Economics from the University of Coimbra and a MSc in European Economic Studies from the College of Europe. She is also the president of the Youth of the European People's Party. Her parliamentary work focuses on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Subcommittee on Tax Matters. She is also part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption and the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas. She has been recognized with the Youth Champion Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2023. She was elected vice-president of the EPP group in April 2024.

Lívia Járóka, born 6 October 1974 in Tata, Hungary, is a Hungarian politician and Member of the European Parliament for Fidesz. She is of mixed ethnicity, with a Roma father and Hungarian mother. Járóka studied sociology at the Central European University and anthropology at the University College London, focusing on Romani issues and culture. She has a PhD in Social Anthropology from the University College London. Járóka has been a member of the European Parliament since 2004, with a break from 2014 to 2017. She served as Vice-President of the European Parliament from 2017 to 2022. Járóka is a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality and the Delegation for Relations with South Africa. She has been criticized for her party's treatment of Hungarian Roma and has declined to criticize Fidesz' campaign against George Soros and the party's attacks on the Central European University. Járóka has received several awards, including the Young Global Leader award, the MEP award in the category of Justice and Fundamental Rights, and the Presidential Order of Merit of Hungary. She is married and has two children.

Magdalena Adamowicz, born on 10 April 1973 in Słupsk, Poland, is a Polish politician and widow of Paweł Adamowicz. She graduated from the University of Gdańsk with a law degree and later earned a PhD in law. Adamowicz also completed an MBA from the University of Northampton and the Higher Banking School in Gdańsk. She is a member of the Civic Coalition and the European People's Party. Adamowicz was elected to the European Parliament in 2019, representing the Pomeranian constituency, and serves on the Committee on Transport and Tourism. She is also part of the Parliament's delegation for relations to South Africa. Adamowicz has been accused of tax evasion and has two daughters from her marriage to Paweł Adamowicz. Her educational background includes studying at the University of Cambridge and the University of Bonn, and she has trained in several European cities.

This is a politician profile for Magid Magid:

Name: Magid Magid
Birth Date: 26 June 1989
Birth Place: Burao, Somali Democratic Republic
Nationality: Somali
Citizenship: British
Residence: Burngreave, Sheffield, South Yorkshire
Alma Mater: University of Hull

Party Affiliation: Green Party of England and Wales

Elected Offices:
- Member of the European Parliament for Yorkshire and the Humber (2 July 2019 - 31 January 2020)
- 122nd Lord Mayor of Sheffield (16 May 2018 - 16 May 2019)
- Sheffield City Councillor for Broomhill and Sharrow Vale (5 May 2016 - 2 May 2019)

Committees:
- European Parliament Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (July 2019 - January 2020)

Previous Roles:
- President of Hull University Union
- Fundraising Officer of the Sheffield Green Party
- Digital marketing professional
- Self-employed
- Worked for the charity Shelter

Education:
- Studied Aquatic Zoology at the University of Hull
- A Levels in Psychology, Law, and Philosophy at Longley Park Sixth Form College

Notable Actions:
- Ran the Sheffield Half Marathon dressed as a tree to object to the council's felling policies
- Ran the London Marathon to raise money for St John Ambulance
- Led a static cycling challenge to raise money for Sheffield war memorial
- Appointed Sheffield's first poet laureate, rapper Otis Mensah
- Set up the initiative Union of Justice, dedicated to racial justice and climate justice

Public Statements:
- Described US President Donald Trump as a "wasteman" and stated that he was banning him from the city of Sheffield
- Criticised populist politicians such as Matteo Salvini and Nigel Farage, saying that their rhetoric is "a daily declaration of war on the... peace of Europe"
- Condemned racism and "post-Brexit xenophobia" in his inaugural speech as Lord Mayor of Sheffield

Personal Life:
- Came to Britain as a child refugee in 1994
- Grew up in Burngreave, Sheffield
- Has an interest in mountaineering and music
- Has been self-employed and worked in digital marketing

Mairead McGuinness, born 13 June 1959, is an Irish politician from Fine Gael and the European People's Party. She is the European Commissioner for Financial Stability, Financial Services and the Capital Markets Union, serving since 12 October 2020, under President Ursula von der Leyen. Previously, she served as the First Vice-President of the European Parliament from 18 January 2017 to 12 October 2020, under Presidents Antonio Tajani and David Sassoli. McGuinness was a Member of the European Parliament for the East constituency from 1 July 2004 to 1 July 2014 and for the Midlands–North-West constituency from 1 July 2014 to 12 October 2020. She is a graduate of University College Dublin, with a Bachelor of Science degree in Agricultural economics and a diploma in accounting and finance. McGuinness is married to Tom Duff, a sheep farmer, and they have four children.

Maite Pagazaurtundúa, a Spanish politician, was born on February 11, 1965, in Hernani, Guipuzcoa. She is a member of the European Parliament, representing Spain from 2014 to 2024, first with Union, Progress and Democracy and then as an independent linked to Citizens. Pagazaurtundúa has been recognized with multiple awards, including the Sakharov Prize for Human Rights in 2000 and the Medal of the Order of Constitutional Merit in 2003. Her work focuses on the defense of the Rule of Law, fundamental rights, and the fight against terrorism, foreign interference, and disinformation. She has been a member of various committees, including the LIBE Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the DROI subcommittee on Human Rights, and the DEVE Committee on Development. Pagazaurtundúa has also been a rapporteur for reports on hate speech and hate crime, European Citizenship, and the implementation of Treaty provisions on EU citizenship. She has promoted initiatives to protect the rule of law, defend civil and political liberties, and combat hate crimes. Pagazaurtundúa has written several books and articles, and has participated in various courses and seminars at Spanish and foreign universities.

Malik Azmani, born January 20, 1976, in Heerenveen, Netherlands, is a Dutch politician of Moroccan and Frisian descent. He is a member of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) and Renew Europe. Azmani studied law at the University of Groningen. He served as a member of the House of Representatives from 2010 to 2019 and as a member of the municipal council of Ommen from 2010 to 2014. Azmani has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2019, representing the Netherlands. He is a former chair of the Committee on European Affairs in the House of Representatives and has been a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and a substitute member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Azmani was deputy chairman of the Renew Europe group and briefly led the group in January 2024. He is part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union and is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights.

Malin Anna Björk, MEP, born 22 May 1972 in Gothenburg, Sweden. Member of the European Parliament for Sweden since 1 July 2014. Member of the Swedish Left Party and European United Left–Nordic Green Left. Full member of the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and substitute member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Former employee of the European Women's Lobby in Brussels and political advisor in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Feminist, focused on anti-racism, LGBT rights, protection of welfare and workers' rights, and opposition to austerity policies. Married with two children, living in Brussels.

Malte Lenz Gallée, born 5 September 1993 in Schwäbisch Gmünd, Baden-Württemberg, Germany, is a German politician from Alliance 90/The Greens. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 22 December 2021 to 1 March 2024, representing the constituency of Germany. He is affiliated with The Greens–European Free Alliance at the European level. He attended the University of Bayreuth and resigned from his seat after allegations of sexual assault and bullying by staff since 2022.

Manfred Weber, a German politician, born on 14 July 1972 in Niederhatzkofen, West Germany, is a member of the Christian Social Union (CSU) and the European People's Party (EPP). He is the President of the EPP since 2022 and the Leader of the EPP Group in the European Parliament since 2014. Weber has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Germany since 2004. 

Weber studied engineering at the Munich Higher Technical Institute (now Munich University of Applied Sciences), graduating in 1996. He founded his own consultancy firm in 1996 and was self-employed until 2014. 

Weber's early career includes being a member of the Bavarian Parliament from 2002 to 2004 and the Kelheim District Council from 2002 to 2014. He was chairman of the Junge Union in Bavaria from 2003 to 2007 and chairman of the CSU of Lower Bavaria from 2008 to 2014.

As an MEP, Weber served on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs from 2004 to 2012 and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs from 2012 to 2014. He was vice-chairman of the EPP group in the European Parliament from 2009 to 2014 and has been chairing the EPP group since 2014.

Weber's notable positions include supporting the EU's ever-closer union, opposing the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project, and advocating for free Interrail tickets for EU citizens on their 18th birthday. He also voted against prohibiting gay conversion therapies in 2018 and disagreed with the European Commission's stance on the Doñana National Park conflict in 2023.

Weber has been involved in various controversies, including the conflict over Hungary, the Sargentini report, and the Fidesz party's suspension from the EPP. He has also been critical of Russia, demanding that the EU cut financial transactions from President Vladimir Putin's inner circle in response to the arrest of Alexey Navalny.

Weber's current roles include being a member of the Conference of Presidents of the European Parliament, the European Academy of Bavaria's Board of Trustees, the Institute for European Politics' Board of Trustees, and the Central Committee of German Catholics.

Manolis K. Kefalogiannis, Greek politician, born 25 May 1959, Heraklion, Crete, member of New Democracy party, Member of the European Parliament since 2014, previously Member of the Greek Parliament 1990-2014, Minister for Mercantile Marine 2004-2007, served on Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Security and Defence, Committee on Regional Development, rapporteur on Just Transition Fund, delegations to EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, EU-Albania Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee, member of European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, URBAN Intergroup, Spinelli Group, nephew of politician Manolis V. Kefalogiannis.

Manon Aubry, French politician, born December 22, 1989, in Fréjus, France. Member of the European Parliament for France since July 1, 2019. Co-chair of The Left in the European Parliament (GUE/NGL) group alongside Martin Schirdewan since July 18, 2019. Represents the left-wing party La France Insoumise. Background in advocacy, having worked as a senior advocacy officer for Oxfam France from 2014 to 2018, focusing on tax justice and inequality. Educated at Sciences Po, University of Sydney, and Columbia University. Has been involved in various committees, including Legal Affairs, Economic and Monetary Affairs, and Tax Matters. Has campaigned for the creation of an independent ethics body to enforce standards across EU institutions.

Manuel "Manu" Pineda Marín, MEP, is a Spanish communist politician from the United Left coalition, born on 2 September 1965 in Málaga, Spain. He is affiliated with the Communist Party of Spain, United Left, and Workers' Commissions. He has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing Spain, since 2 July 2019, and is the long-time head of international relations for the Spanish Communist Party.

Manuel Bompard, a French politician, born on March 30, 1986, in Firminy, Loire, France, male, representing the 4th constituency of the Bouches-du-Rhône department in the National Assembly since June 22, 2022. Member of La France Insoumise, previously served as a Member of the European Parliament from July 2, 2019, to July 28, 2022. Graduated from Grenoble Institute of Technology and University of Nice Sophia Antipolis with a doctorate in mathematics. Formerly a member of the Left Party from 2009 to 2018.

Manuel Francisco Pizarro de Sampaio e Castro, a male physician and politician from Portugal, born on 2 February 1964 in Coimbra, Portugal. He is married to Alexandra Pinto and holds a degree from the University of Porto. Pizarro was a member of the Portuguese Communist Party from 1978 to 1990 and joined the Socialist Party in 1993. He has held various offices, including Member of the Ramalde Parish Assembly from 1982 to 2001, Member of the Porto Municipal Assembly from 2001 to 2005, Member of the Porto City Council from 2013 to 2021, Member of the Assembly of the Republic from 2005 to 2015, Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022, and Minister of Health from 2022 to 2024. He served on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, the Committee on Fisheries, and was part of the parliament's delegation for relations with Brazil during his time as a Member of the European Parliament.

Manuela Ripa, born 1976, German, lawyer, politician, Ecological-Democratic Party, ÖDP, Member of the European Parliament since 16 July 2020, succeeding Klaus Buchner, Group of the Greens–European Free Alliance, Committees: Industry, Research and Energy, Special Committee on Beating Cancer, Intergroup on Animal Welfare and Conservation of Animals, substitute member in Committees: International Trade, Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Delegations for relations with Iran and India, core-themes: environment protection, climate protection, biodiversity protection, animal welfare, consumer protection, married, two children, lives between Saarbrücken and Brussels.

Mara Bizzotto, Italian League politician, born June 3, 1972, in Bassano del Grappa, Italy, member of Regional Council of Veneto 2000-2005 and 2006-2009, European Parliament member 2009-2022, re-elected in 2014 and 2019, Senator for Veneto since 2022.

Marc Angel, Luxembourgish politician, born March 12, 1963, in Luxembourg City, Luxembourg, nationality Luxembourgish, member of the Luxembourg Socialist Workers' Party, educated at the University of Vienna, served as vice-president of the European Parliament from January 18, 2023, to 2024, Member of the European Parliament since December 10, 2019, representing the Luxembourg constituency, previously Member of the Luxembourgish Parliament from 2004 to 2019, and member of the Luxembourg City Council from 1994 to 2020, known for being a 'Champion of Equality', co-chair of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and a UNAIDS Champion for the 90-90-90 Treatment Target.

Marc Botenga, a Belgian politician, born on 29 December 1980, in Brussels, Belgium. He is a member of the Workers' Party of Belgium (PVDA-PTB) and the European United Left–Nordic Green Left (GUE/NGL). He studied law at the Université libre de Bruxelles and later at IMT Lucca. He was involved in various movements, including advocating for the step-down of the Belgian Minister of the Interior Louis Tobback and participating in workers' mobilization against the close-down of the Forges de Clabecq iron works. He became more involved in European politics during the European debt crisis, participating in actions of political support for Greece. He served as the political advisor of the European GUE/NGL parliamentary group from 2016. He is a Member of the European Parliament since the 2019 elections, representing the French-speaking electoral college of Belgium, and is a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.

Marc Tarabella, born 11 March 1963, in Ougrée, Belgium, to a family originally from Versilia, Italy. He holds a degree in sociology from the University of Liège (1986) and was seconded to the office of the Premier of the Walloon Region (1988). He worked as a customer adviser for the General Savings and Retirement Fund (1990). He is a member of the Parti Socialiste and the Socialist Group in the European Parliament, representing the French Community of Belgium. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2004, serving on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and as a substitute for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and as vice-chair of the Delegation for relations with the countries of Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). He was a member of the Italian left-wing party Article One (2021) and the Walloon Socialist party, but was revoked from the latter amid the Qatar corruption scandal. He has been charged with corruption and money laundering in connection with the Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament (February 2023) and has denied any wrongdoing.

Marcel Kolaja, Czech Pirate Party, European Pirate Party, Greens/EFA, born 29 June 1980, Moravská Třebová, Czech Republic, Masaryk University, software engineer, Internet freedom and digital rights activist, Member of the European Parliament for the Czech Republic 2019-2024, Quaestor of the European Parliament 2022-2024, Vice-President of the European Parliament 2019-2022, Vice-President of the Czech Pirate Party 2022-2024, priorities: digital rights, prevention of increasing Internet censorship, environmental protection, consumer protection, addressing tax avoidance by multinational corporations, fair competition in the online economy, open technologies, freedom on the Internet, independence of media, transparency, united Europe.

Marcel de Graaff, born 7 April 1962 in Rotterdam, Netherlands, Roman Catholic, married to Gabriëlle Popken. Studied theology at Radboud University Nijmegen from 1981 to 1988. Worked as a consultant for IT & Operations from 1989, teacher of religion at a secondary school in Rotterdam from 2010, and manager for KPN telecommunications company. Member of the Senate of the Netherlands for the Party for Freedom from 2011 to 2014, parliamentary group leader of the PVV in the Senate from 2012 to 2014. Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands from 2014 to 2019 and 2020 to 2024, initially for the Party for Freedom, then for Forum for Democracy from 2022. Co-president of the Europe of Nations and Freedom group from 2015 to 2019. Suspended from Identity and Democracy in 2022, became a Non-Inscrit member of European Parliament. Voted against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for human rights violations and against condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Defended Russia's actions in Ukraine, claimed Ukraine was responsible for bombing hundreds of thousands of children and supplying children for pedophile rings and organ trade.
Marco Campomenosi, Italian politician, born 2 September 1975 in Genoa, Liguria, Italy, member of the League party, serving in the European Parliament representing North-West Italy since 2 July 2019.

Marco Dreosto, Italian politician, born 18 March 1969 in Spilimbergo, Italy. Member of the European Parliament for North-East Italy constituency since 2 July 2019, representing the League party. Background in marketing, with professional experience in the automotive sector. Held various local political positions in Italy, including municipal councillor, assessor, and deputy mayor. In the European Parliament, member of the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Commission, Industry, Research and Energy Commission, and delegations to the Parliamentary Stabilization and Association Committee EU-Montenegro and EU-Serbia. Rapporteur and shadow rapporteur for several reports and proposals, focusing on civil protection, recovery and resilience, and sustainable Europe. Active in supporting causes related to food security, agriculture, livestock, foreign policy, and immigration issues, particularly the Balkan route.

Marco Zanni, Italian politician, born 11 July 1986 in Lovere, near Bergamo, Italy, graduated in business administration at Bocconi University of Milan and ESADE Business School in Barcelona, former employee of Banca IMI, elected as MEP in 2014 for the Five Star Movement and in 2019 for the League, member of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy, Europe of Nations and Freedom, and Identity and Democracy parliamentary groups, served as President of the Identity and Democracy group from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024.

Marco Zullo, Italian politician, born 29 October 1978 in Verona, nationality Italian, honorific-suffix MEP, party affiliation Five Star Movement (2014-2021) and Renew Europe group (2021-present), constituency North-East Italy, term started 1 July 2014, parliament European, alma mater University of Padua, degree bachelor's in computer science and electronic engineering, profession product manager, previously worked at Hager Group from 2012 to 2014, committee assignments include Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (since 2015), Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (since 2019), and Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (2014-2019), delegation to EU-Albania Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee, co-chairs European Parliament Intergroup on Demographic Challenges, Family-Work Balance and Youth Transitions, member of European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals and Cultural Creators Friendship Group (CCFG).

Marcos Ros Sempere, male, born 24 March 1974, in Murcia, Spain, architect, professor, affiliated with the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, Member of the European Parliament since 1 February 2020, previously councilor of the Murcia City Council from 2003 to 2011, Vice Chancellor of Campus and Sustainability of the Polytechnic University of Cartagena since 2016, professor at the Polytechnic University of Cartagena since 2008, holds a doctorate from the Complutense University of Madrid.

Marek Balt, a Polish politician and economist, born on 8 April 1973 in Częstochowa, Poland. He holds a Master's degree in business management from the Częstochowa University of Technology and graduated from WSB University in 2017. Balt has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2019, initially representing the Democratic Left Alliance and later the New Left party since 2021. He is also affiliated with the European Coalition and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Prior to his European Parliament tenure, he was a member of the Polish Parliament from 2011 to 2015 and served on various committees, including the Health Committee and the Committee for Environmental Protection. Balt has also held local offices, such as chairman of the Częstochowa City Council from 2010 to 2011 and councilor to the Silesian Regional Assembly since 2018.

Marek Belka, a Polish economist and politician, born on January 9, 1952, in Łódź, Poland. Education: University of Łódź, M.A. in economics of foreign trade, and PhD in economics, with a thesis on US anti-inflationary policy. Married to Krystyna Belka, with two children. 

Positions held: 
- Professor at the University of Łódź 
- Prime Minister of Poland (May 2, 2004 - October 31, 2005) 
- President of the National Bank of Poland (June 11, 2010 - June 20, 2016) 
- Member of the European Parliament (July 1, 2019 - July 15, 2024) 
- Deputy Prime Minister of Poland (February 4, 1997 - October 17, 1997, and October 19, 2001 - July 6, 2002) 
- Minister of Finance (February 4, 1997 - October 17, 1997, and October 19, 2001 - July 6, 2002) 
- Director of the European Department at the International Monetary Fund (November 1, 2008 - 2010) 
- Executive Secretary of the UN Economic Commission for Europe (2006-2008) 
- Chairman of the Board of Directors at LOT Polish Airlines (2002-2003) 
- Member of the Supervisory Board at Bank Millennium (2002-2004) 
- Independent Member of the Board of Directors at Echo Polska Properties (since 2016) 
- Chairman of the Steering Committee at the European Bank Coordination Initiative (2013-2016) 
- Chairman of the Joint World Bank-IMF Development Committee (2011-2015) 
- Member of the Steering Committee at the European Systemic Risk Board (2011-2016) 
- Ex-Officio Member of the Board of Governors at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (2010-2016) 
- Member of the Appointment Advisory Committee at the European Investment Bank (since 2017) 
- Member of the Council for the Future of Europe at the Berggruen Institute 
- Member of the International Council at the Museum Berggruen 
- Member of the European Group at the Trilateral Commission 
- Member of the Board of Directors at the Polish-American Freedom Foundation (2000-2010)

Party affiliations: 
- Polish United Workers' Party (1973-1990) 
- Democratic Left Alliance (1999-2005) 
- Independent (1990-1999, 2005-2019) 
- Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (since 2019) 
- The Left (since 2019)

Awards: 
- Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas 
- Bene Merito (Poland)

Margarida Marques, a female, born on 3 February 1954, in Bombarral, Portugal, is a Portuguese politician of the Socialist Party. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2019, representing the Portugal constituency. Her term is set to end on 15 July 2024. Marques has previously worked for the European Commission, and served as a member of the Parliament of Portugal from 2015 to 2019. She was the State Secretary for European Affairs in the government of Prime Minister António Costa from 2015 to 2017. Marques is a member of the Committee on Budgets, Committee on International Trade, and delegations for relations with China and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean. She has received the Grand Cross of the Order of Honour from Greece, Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, and Dame Grand Cross of the Order of Isabella the Catholic from Spain.

Margarita de la Pisa Carrión, Spanish Vox politician, born 19 September 1975 in Madrid, Spain, educated at Complutense University of Madrid, elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain in 2019, took office on 1 February 2020 following Brexit, served on the EU Special Committee on COVID-19.

Margrete Helle Auken, a Danish politician, born on 6 January 1945 in Århus, Denmark. She is a member of the Socialistisk Folkeparti and the European Green Party. Auken is a parish priest at the Frederiksberg Church in the Church of Denmark and was educated at the University of Copenhagen. She served as a Member of the European Parliament from 20 July 2004 to 2024, representing the Denmark constituency, and previously as a Member of the Folketing from 22 October 1979 to 20 July 2004, representing Århus. Auken was part of several committees, including the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Committee on Transport and Tourism, Committee on Development, and Committee on Petitions. She was also a member of the delegation for relations with Palestine and the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals and the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas. Auken is married to Erik Aksel Nielsen, has three children, including Ida Auken, and is the sister of Svend Auken and daughter of Kirsten Auken.

Italian politician Maria Angela Danzì, born 5 July 1957 in Librizzi, Italy, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Five Star Movement from 3 October 2022 to 9 June 2024, representing the North-West Italy constituency.

Maria Grapini, a Romanian businesswoman and politician, born on 7 November 1954 in Berești, Romania. She graduated from the Berești Theoretical High School in 1973 and the Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iași in 1978. Grapini held various positions at the Garofita Textile Enterprise in Timișoara until 1989 and was the president of the Council of Administration and general manager of Pasmatex from 1995 to 2012. She served as the Deputy Minister in the Second Ponta cabinet from 21 December 2012 to 5 March 2014. Grapini has been a Member of the European Parliament for the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats since 1 July 2014, representing the Romania constituency. She was a member of the Conservative Party from 2006 to 2015, the Humanist Power Party from 2015 to 2019, and the Social Democratic Party from 2019 to 2020, and has been a member of the Humanist Power Party since 2020. Grapini has published four books and has been the recipient of the Internal Market & Consumer Protection Award at the annual MEP Awards of The Parliament Magazine in 2019.

Maria Manuel Leitão Marques, a female politician from Portugal, born 23 August 1952 in Quelimane, Portuguese Mozambique, representing the Socialist Party. She served as Minister of the Presidency and of Administrative Modernisation from 26 November 2015 to 18 February 2019 under Prime Minister António Costa. She was a Member of the Assembly of the Republic, representing the Viseu constituency from 2015 to 2019, and Secretary of State for Administrative Modernization under the XVIII and XIX Constitutional Government of Portugal. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, serving as vice chair of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital. Her current term as a Member of the European Parliament is set to end on 15 July 2024.

Maria Noichl, a German politician and Member of the European Parliament, born 9 January 1967 in Rosenheim, Bavaria, Germany. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Prior to entering politics, she worked as a teacher of nutrition and design. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the constituency of Germany. She is a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, and a former member of the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly. Additionally, she is part of the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals and a member of the German United Services Trade Union (ver.di).

Maria Spyraki, Greek journalist and politician, born 11 September 1965 in Larissa, Greece, studied chemistry at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki and journalism at London School of Journalism.
