Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for New Democracy since 1 July 2014, affiliated with the European People's Party (EPP), serving on the Committee on Regional Development and Delegation to the EU-Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Joint Parliamentary Committee. Served as Nea Dimokratia's spokesperson from 31 December 2014 to 26 January 2015. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Maria Veronica Rossi, Italian politician, born 22 September 1988 in Ferentino, Italy, Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy constituency since 6 April 2023, initially affiliated with Lega Nord until April 2024, then joined Fratelli d'Italia.

Maria Walsh, MEP from Midlands–North-West constituency, born 11 June 1987 in Boston, Massachusetts, to Irish parents, with dual US-Irish citizenship. Studied journalism at Griffith College Dublin. Member of Fine Gael and the European People's Party. Served in the Army Reserve as a trooper with the Cavalry Corps from 2017 to 2019. Winner of the 2014 Rose of Tralee pageant. Publicly came out as a lesbian in 2014. Founded a wedding planning company focused on LGBT weddings. Does not drink alcohol as a member of the Pioneers. Voted against an EU resolution to increase search and rescue missions in the Mediterranean due to concerns about sharing radar information with human smugglers. Supported a veto on the construction of fossil fuel projects across Europe, including a liquefied natural gas station in Ireland. Advocated for more focus on sexual and reproductive rights in education. Supported the European Commission's legal action against Hungary and Poland over their attempts to introduce laws concerning the LGBT Community.

Marian-Jean Marinescu, male, born August 11, 1952, in Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania, married with three children, Romanian politician, member of PNL, part of the European People's Party–European Democrats, Grand Officer of the Order of the Star of Romania, fluent speaker of French and English, graduated from the Bucharest Politehnica Institute's Faculty of Aerospace engineering in 1976, worked as an engineer for Avioane SA and Aviation Institute branch in Craiova, entered politics in 1992 as a member of the PDL, vice-president of the PPE Group, chair of the PPE Working Group "Budgets and Structural Policies", coordinator of the PPE working group for the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021–2027, Vice-Coordinator of the Transport and Tourism Commission (TRAN), vice-president of the "Sky and Space" Intergroup, member of the Board of Directors of the European Agency for Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GSA), ambassador and founding member of the Erasmus program for entrepreneurs, member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN), alternate member in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and an alternate member of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), coordinator of the PPE group for transport policies, twice awarded the MEP of the Year (2014 and 2016), Personality of the Year Award in the field of aviation (2017), Red Arrow Award 2017 for Europe's Essential Commitment, Transport & Tourism award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards (2020).

Marianne Vind, a Danish politician, MEP for the Social Democrats, born December 3, 1970, in Køge, Denmark, educated at Roskilde University, served as hospital laboratory technician, union representative, chair for Dansk Laborant-Forening, and vice-president of Danish trade union HK/Private, member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee of Employment and Social Affairs, Committee of Transport and Tourism, and several intergroups, including LGBT Rights, Disability, and Trade Unions.

Marie Arena, born 17 December 1966, in Mons, Belgium. Member of the Socialist Party (PS) and the Party of European Socialists (PES). Served as Walloon Minister of Employment and Training from 2000 to 2003, Federal Minister of the Civil Service, Social Integration, Cities and Equal Opportunities from 2003 to 2004, Minister-President of the French Community of Belgium from 2004 to 2008, and Federal Minister for Social Integration, Pensions and Large Cities from 2008 to 2009. Elected as Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in 2014, serving on various committees including Committee on International Trade, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Committee on Foreign Affairs, and Subcommittee on Human Rights, which she chaired from 2019 to 2023. Grand Officer of the Order of Leopold in 2010. Involved in controversy surrounding the Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament.

Marie Dauchy, a French politician and member of the National Rally party, was born on 5 February 1987 in Calais, France. She has been a Member of the European Parliament representing France since 28 July 2022, and was re-elected in 2024, succeeding Hélène Laporte.

Marie Toussaint, a French jurist and politician, born 27 May 1987 in Lille, France, with a master's degree in international environmental law from Sciences Po. She is a member of the Europe Ecology – The Greens party and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019. She serves on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and is part of several delegations and intergroups, including those focused on anti-corruption, anti-racism, climate change, and animal welfare. She is leading the EU's environmental crime directive for the Greens and supports making ecocide a crime in the EU. She has been serving as deputy chairwoman of the Greens–European Free Alliance group since 25 June 2024, alongside co-chairs Terry Reintke and Bas Eickhout.

Marie-Pierre Vedrenne, a French lawyer and politician, born on 13 November 1982 in Limoges, France, educated at the University of Rennes 1. She is a member of the Democratic Movement and the European Democratic Party. She has been a Member of the European Parliament for the France constituency since 2 July 2019, serving as a vice-chair of the Committee on International Trade and a member of the Committee on Petitions. She is also part of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Children’s Rights, Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, as well as the Spinelli Group. She co-chaired President Emmanuel Macron's "Renaissance" electoral list in the European Parliament from 2021 to 2024, and has been the sole leader of the Renaissance members within the Renew Europe group since 2024. She is a member of the Board of Directors of the French Institute for International and Strategic Affairs.

Marina Kaljurand, Estonian politician, born 6 September 1962 in Tallinn, Estonia, of Latvian and Russian descent, identifies as ethnically Russian, speaks Estonian, Russian, and English, educated at University of Tartu, Estonian School of Diplomacy, and Tufts University, married to Kalle Kaljurand with two children, hobbies include reading, badminton, and long walks with dogs. Formerly Ambassador of Estonia to the United States, Russia, Mexico, Canada, Kazakhstan, and Israel, served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2015 to 2016, Member of the European Parliament since 2019, affiliated with the Social Democratic Party, previously an independent politician, decorated with Order of the National Coat of Arms and Order of White Star, supports women's rights, gender equality, and NATO, emphasizes the importance of cybersecurity, European integration, and respect for cultures and languages, has worked on border treaties and international law in cyberspace.

Marina Mesure, a French politician born on July 12, 1989, in Marseille, France, and raised in Gréasque. She graduated from HEC Montréal in 2013. Mesure has been a member of the European Parliament since July 2022. She was a candidate for the 2019 European Parliament election in France, representing La France Insoumise, and was supported by trade unionists from 38 countries. In the 2022 legislative elections, Mesure ran in the Bouches-du-Rhône's 10th constituency but lost to José Gonzalez of the National Rally. However, she secured the majority vote in Gardanne. Mesure succeeded Manuel Bompard as MEP in July 2022 and retained her seat after the 2024 European Parliament election in France.

Mario Furore, Italian politician, born 25 December 1988 in Foggia, Italy, elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in the 2019 European Parliament election, representing Southern Italy, affiliated with the Five Star Movement, educated at Luiss Guido Carli, serving since 2 July 2019.

Marion Walsmann, a German politician, was born on March 17, 1963, in Erfurt, East Germany. She studied law at the University of Leipzig from 1981 to 1985. Walsmann is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing Germany. Her previous roles include serving as a member of the Landtag of Thuringia from 2004 to 2018, State Minister of Justice, State Minister of Finance, Head of the State Chancellery, and State Minister for European Affairs. Walsmann is currently part of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Parliament's delegation to the EU-North Macedonia Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the European Parliament Intergroups on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, Disability, and Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises.

Marisa Matias, a Portuguese sociologist and politician, born 20 February 1976 in Coimbra, Portugal, representing the Left Bloc party. She was a Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, sitting on the Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industry, Research and Energy Committees. She was Chairwoman of the Delegation of the European Parliament for relations with the Mashreq countries and Vice-President of the Party of the European Left from 2010 to 2016. She was a candidate in the 2016 and 2021 Portuguese presidential elections, finishing 3rd with 10.12% of the votes in 2016 and 5th with 3.95% of the vote in 2021. She has been a member of the Assembly of the Republic since 2024, representing the Porto constituency.

Markus Buchheit, German politician, born August 11, 1983, in Zweibrücken, raised in Pollenfeld, educated in law and political science at University of Bayreuth and Bavarian School of Public Policy, worked in Franco-German law firm in Strasbourg and Paris, member of Young Union, assistant to FPÖ MEP Franz Obermayr, adviser on international trade for Europe of Nations and Freedom, joined Alternative for Germany in 2016, elected to European Parliament in 2019, advocates for Eurozone referendum, common European regulations on foreign investments, and withdrawal from "Green Deal" climate policy, affiliated with Alternative for Germany and formerly Christian Social Union in Bavaria, serving as Member of the European Parliament for Germany since July 2, 2019.

Markus Ferber, a German engineer and politician, born January 15, 1965, in Augsburg, Bavaria, Germany, is a member of the Christian Social Union and the European People's Party. He has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 1, 1994, representing Germany. Ferber holds a degree in electrical engineering from the Technische Universität München. His career includes positions as a development engineer at Siemens, an engineer in the marketing department of Pfister, and president of the Hanns Seidel Foundation since 2020. Ferber has held various committee assignments in the European Parliament, including the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, and the Committee on Transport and Tourism. He has also been involved in national politics, serving as a CSU delegate to the Federal Convention for the purpose of electing the President of Germany. Ferber's political positions include advocating for the suspension of Romania in the European Council during the 2012 Romanian constitutional crisis. He has been involved in controversies, including promoting a commercial product related to MiFID II and claiming a stay allowance during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ferber is a member of various corporate boards and non-profit organizations, including Deutsche Vermögensberatung, Kreissparkasse Augsburg, and the European Academy of Bavaria. He has received the Bundesverdienstkreuz and the Bavarian Medal of Honour for Bavarians in Europe.

Markus Pieper, a German politician and Member of the European Parliament for Germany since 2004, representing the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Born on 15 May 1963 in Hamelin, West Germany. Educated at Leibniz University Hannover and the University of Göttingen. Serves on the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Biodiversity, Countryside, Hunting and Recreational Fisheries since 2014. Leads the parliament's work on the revision of the Renewable Energy Directive since 2021. Member of the Advisory Board of the Energy and Climate Policy and Innovation Council (EPICO) since 2021 and the Board of Trustees of the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Biomedicine. Appointed as EU small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) Envoy in 2024.

Markéta Gregorová, a Czech politician born on 14 January 1993 in Most, Czech Republic, studied International Relations and European Studies at Masaryk University and received her master's degree in Public Administration and Security Studies at the CEVRO Institute. She worked in the private sector in marketing and web testing before entering politics. Gregorová was the president of the European Pirate Party from December 2018 to November 2019. She was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, representing the Czech Pirate Party. She serves as the Vice-Chair of the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly and is a member of the Committee on International Trade and the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, including Disinformation. Her priorities include transparency in EU free trade agreements and addressing EU involvement in international arms sales to war zones.

Marlene Mortler, a German politician, born 16 October 1955 in Lauf an der Pegnitz, Germany. She is a member of the Christian Social Union in Bavaria (CSU) and the European People's Party. Mortler was a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 9 June 2024 and a member of the German Parliament from 17 October 2002 to 1 July 2019, representing the Roth district. She served as Commissioner on Narcotic Drugs at the Federal Ministry of Health in the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel from 2014 until 2019. Mortler is Protestant, married to Siegfried Mortler from 1975 until his death in June 2017, and is the mother of three children. She attended the agricultural school in Roth in 1981, gaining a master's certificate, and took over her parents' farm in Dehnberg in 1983, focusing on the production of grain and renewable resources.

Martin Buschmann, a German politician, born 17 April 1970 in Hamburg, West Germany, married, and living in Neu Wulmstorf. He is a member of the European Parliament for Germany since 26 May 2019. Previously, he was a member of the National Democratic Party of Germany from 1992 to 1996 and joined the Human Environment Animal Protection Party in 2009. He was a member of the GUE/NGL parliamentary group until his resignation in January 2020. He advocates for a vegan lifestyle and a ban on factory farming. His professional background includes training as a foreign trade merchant and working in supply chain management for various shipping companies.

Martin Edward Daubney, born 22 June 1970, is a British commentator, journalist, and former politician. He was the deputy leader of the Reclaim Party from 2021 to 2022 and a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands from 2019 to 2020. Daubney was the longest-serving editor of the men's lifestyle magazine Loaded. He grew up in Gedling, Nottinghamshire, studied geography at the University of Manchester, and graduated with a third-class degree. Daubney's career includes working as a researcher for Bella, commissioning editor, features editor for FHM, editor of page3.com for The Sun, and deputy editor of Loaded. He supports the men's rights movement and has voted for the Labour Party, Liberal Democrats, and Women's Equality Party. Daubney voted for the United Kingdom to leave the European Union in the 2016 membership referendum and supported a no-deal Brexit. He was a candidate for the Brexit Party in the European Parliament election and the 2019 general election, and the Reclaim Party candidate in the 2021 North Shropshire by-election. Daubney has a partner, Diana James, and two children.

Martin Hlaváček, Czech politician, born January 14, 1980, in Prague, Czechoslovakia, Czech nationality, graduated from Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing the Czech Republic constituency, affiliated with the Independent party, nominated by ANO 2011, has been in office since July 2, 2019.

Martin Hojsík is a Slovak politician born on January 27, 1977, in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia. He is a member of the Progressive Slovakia party and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Slovakia since July 2, 2019. He is also the Vice-President of the European Parliament, assuming office on October 18, 2023. Hojsík is a graduate in genetics from Comenius University in Bratislava and holds a certificate from Schumacher College in leadership and teamwork. He is fluent in five languages: Slovak, Czech, Russian, English, and German. Prior to his political career, he worked as an environmental expert and activist for organizations such as Greenpeace and FOUR PAWS, focusing on issues like animal welfare, environmental protection, and sustainability.

Martin Charles Horwood, a British Liberal Democrat politician, born 12 October 1962 in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, England, educated at Pate's Junior School, Cheltenham College, and The Queen's College, Oxford, reading Modern History. Married to Shona Arora since 1995, with 2 children. Served as Member of Parliament for Cheltenham from 2005 to 2015, and as Member of the European Parliament for South West England from 2019 to 2020. Founder and chairman of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Tribal Peoples. Director of engagement and impact at Development Initiatives since 2015, and councillor for the Leckhampton ward on Cheltenham Borough Council since 2018. Cabinet Member for Corporate affairs as of February 2021.

Martin Häusling, a German politician, born 26 March 1961 in Bad Wildungen, Germany, member of the European Parliament since 14 July 2009, representing Germany, affiliated with Alliance 90/The Greens and The Greens-European Free Alliance, managed a 75 hectare organic farm near Kassel before entering politics, served on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Committee on Budgetary Control, and delegations to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and the MEP Heart Group, participated in the working group on agriculture and nutrition for the traffic light coalition negotiations in 2021.

Martin Schirdewan, born 12 July 1975 in East Berlin, East Germany, studied at the Free University of Berlin, achieving a doctorate in political science in 2007. He is a journalist and politician, serving as co-chairman of The Left since June 2022, and as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2017. He was elected co-chair of The Left in the European Parliament (GUE/NGL) parliamentary group in 2019. Schirdewan was a researcher for a Bundestag member from The Left, senior editor of Sacco & Vanzetti, and head of the Brussels office of the Rosa Luxemburg Foundation. He has served on the party executive of The Left and is a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). Schirdewan has voted against motions condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine and human rights violations in Nicaragua. He is considered a reformer close in outlook to moderates and is a grandson of East German politician Karl Schirdewan.

Martin Hans Sonneborn, born 15 May 1965 in Göttingen, West Germany, is a German politician, Member of the European Parliament, and founder and federal chairman of Die PARTEI. He studied communication, German, and politics in Münster, Vienna, and Berlin. Sonneborn was editor-in-chief of the satirical magazine Titanic from 2000 to 2005 and worked for Spiegel Online and ZDF. He has been a member of the European Parliament Committee on Culture and Education, the Korea-delegation, and substitute of the European Parliament Committee on Budgetary Control since 2014. Sonneborn has two daughters and is known for his satirical work and activism, including a blackface Obama billboard in 2011 and support for Armenian activities within the European Parliament. He signed the Manifest für Frieden in 2023, calling for a stop to arms deliveries to Ukraine and a ceasefire and peace negotiations with Russia.

Martina Anderson, born April 16, 1962, in Derry, Northern Ireland, to a well-known Irish republican family with a Protestant father. She has six sisters and three brothers, including a former Sinn Féin councillor and a niece who is a former Irish Senator and Foyle MP. Educated at St Cecilia's College from 1973 to 1980. 

Anderson was involved in the Irish republican movement and a former Provisional Irish Republican Army volunteer. She was convicted of conspiring to cause explosions in 1986 and sentenced to life in prison. Released in 1998 under the Good Friday Agreement. Married fellow prisoner and IRA member Paul Kavanagh in 1989. Obtained a first-class honours degree in social science from the Open University while in prison.

Member of Sinn Féin. Served as Junior Minister at the Office of the First Minister and deputy First Minister from 2011 to 2012. Member of the Legislative Assembly for Foyle from 2007 to 2012 and 2020 to 2021. Member of the European Parliament representing Northern Ireland from 2012 to 2020.

Martina Dlabajová, born 26 July 1976, in Zlín, Czech Republic. 
Education: grammar school Zlín-Lesni ctvrt (1990-1994), University of Padua (1995-2000), studied political science with a specialization in the European Union. 
Languages: Italian, English, German, Spanish, Russian. 
Career: coordinator of the Office of the Zlín Region in Brussels, president of the Regional Chamber of Commerce of the Zlín Region (2012-2014), founder and manager of several companies in the Czech Republic, Slovak Republic, and Italy. 
Member of the European Parliament (2014-2024), Vice-Chair in the Committee on Budgetary Control, member in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, substitute in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, member of the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic. 
Founder of the traineeship programme "PročBynNe?" - "Why not?". 
Member of the Board of Directors of the European Liberal Forum, Rotary Club Zlín, and director of a public benefit corporation Zlinsky zamek. 
Party affiliation: Independent (2023-present), Renew Europe (2014-present), ANO 2011 (until 2023).

Martina Michels, a female German politician, born on 1 December 1955 in Berlin, Germany. She is a member of The Left party in Germany and the European United Left–Nordic Green Left. She served as a Member of the European Parliament for Germany from 5 September 2013 to 15 July 2024. Her parliamentary service includes membership in the Committee on Regional Development, Delegation for relations with Israel, Committee on Culture and Education (2013), and Vice-Chair of the Committee on Culture and Education (2013).

Martine Kemp, a Luxembourgish politician from the Christian Social People's Party (CSV), born on 8 July 1994 in Luxembourg, with Luxembourgish nationality. She holds a degree in social sciences from the Vienna University of Economics and Business and a Master of Science in Traffic and Transport from the Technical University of Darmstadt. Her work experience includes an internship in the European Parliament, a position as a traffic-planning engineer for the City of Luxembourg, and membership in the Youth Parliament in Luxembourg. She started her political career at 14, later becoming vice-president of the Jeunesse Chrétienne-Sociale (CSJ), a member of the CSJ National Committee, and Secretary for International Affairs within the CSV. As a Member of the European Parliament since 24 October 2023, she serves on the Committee on International Trade (INTA), Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), and Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI).

María Eugenia Rodríguez Palop, a Spanish jurist, professor of Philosophy of Law at the Charles III University of Madrid, specializing in human rights. Born on 9 March 1970 in Llerena, Spain. Obtained a degree in Law at the Comillas Pontifical University in 1993, later obtaining a PhD in the same field at the UC3M in 2000. Served as a Member of European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 16 July 2024, representing Spain. Associated with Movimiento Sumar since 2023, previously linked to Podemos from 2019 to 2023. Self-described as "feminist" and "ecologist".

Massimiliano Salini, Italian politician, born 11 March 1973 in Soresina, Italy, educated at University of Milan, member of The People of Freedom (2009-2013), New Centre-Right (2013-2015), and Forza Italia (since 2015), served as President of the Province of Cremona from 7 June 2009 to 21 July 2014, and as Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy since 1 July 2014.

Massimiliano Smeriglio, Italian politician, born 8 May 1966 in Rome, Italy, university professor, writer, and member of the European Parliament. Education: Sapienza University of Rome. Party affiliations: Communist Refoundation Party (until 2009), Left Ecology Freedom (2009-2016), Progressive Camp (2017), Democratic Party (2018-2024). Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Central Italy. Served on the Committee on Culture and Education and the Committee on Petitions. Voted against the European Parliament resolution of 23 November 2022 on recognising the Russian Federation as a state sponsor of terrorism. Previously served as Member of the Chamber of Deputies from 28 April 2006 to 28 April 2008 and from 15 March 2013 to 16 April 2013, and as Vice-president of the Lazio region.

Massimo Casanova, Italian politician, born 31 August 1970 in Bologna, owner of Papeete Beach disco in Milano Marittima, member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Southern Italy, affiliated with the League party, holds the title of MEP.

Mathilde Androuët, a French politician, born on 3 July 1984 in Rueil-Malmaison, Paris, France, with father Didier Palix, a National Republican Movement candidate in 2001. Graduated from Sciences Po Aix in Aix-en-Provence, worked for liberal think tank Terra Nova in 2010, and joined the National Front in 2011. Served as parliamentary assistant to Florian Philippot in 2014, contested the 2017 French legislative election in Yvelines's 11th constituency, and was elected as a National Rally Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, representing France, and is a member of the Identity and Democracy group and the Committee on Regional Development.

Matjaž Nemec, born 10 April 1980 in Nova Gorica, Slovenia, is a Slovenian politician and member of the European Parliament since 18 May 2022. He was a member of the National Assembly of Slovenia from 1 August 2014 to 13 May 2022. Nemec is a member of the Social Democrats party and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. He studied at CDI Univerzum, graduating in 2007, and later obtained a master's degree in international business and sustainable development from IBS mednarodna poslovna šola Ljubljana in 2017. Nemec has worked as a salesman, personal secretary to Prime Minister Borut Pahor, and assistant to the President of Slovenia. He has been vice-president of the National Assembly of Slovenia and has served on various committees, including the Commission for Oversight of Intelligence and Security Services, Committee for Culture, and Committee on Foreign Policy. Nemec is divorced from his first wife, Iryna Osypenko, and has a son, Maj, with his partner Nina Tršelič.

Matthew Carthy, Irish Sinn Féin politician, born 19 July 1977 in Birmingham, England, to a mother from County Monaghan and a father from County Roscommon. He lived in County Roscommon until age 10, then in Holywell, Wales, before moving to Carrickmacross, County Monaghan. He studied marketing at the Dublin Institute of Technology and was a founding member of Ógra Shinn Féin. Carthy was elected to Carrickmacross Town Council in 1999, becoming the youngest elected representative in Ireland at 21. He served as Mayor of Carrickmacross Town Council in 2006 and as a member of Monaghan County Council from 2004 to 2014. In 2014, he was elected to the European Parliament for the Midlands-North-West constituency, serving until 2020. He was a member of the Agriculture and Rural Affairs Committee, Special Committee on Financial Crimes, and substitute member of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. Carthy was appointed Sinn Féin's Uniting Ireland project coordinator in 2015 and served as party whip in the European Parliament. He was elected as a Teachta Dála for the Cavan-Monaghan constituency in the 2020 general election. He is married to Lynn and has five children.

Matteo Adinolfi, Italian politician, born 24 December 1963 in Latina, Lazio, Member of the European Parliament for the Lega Nord, representing Central Italy, in office since 2019, educated at Sapienza University of Rome.

Matteo Gazzini, Hon. MEP, Italian politician, born 9 July 1985 in Bolzano, Italy, educated at Syracuse University, occupation: politician, real estate developer, agricultural entrepreneur, airplane pilot. Member of the European Parliament for North-East Italy constituency since 3 October 2022. Initially a member of Lega until 2023, then joined Forza Italia and became party leader in South Tyrol. Member of the EPP group in the European Parliament since January 2024. Served on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Committee on Budgets, Committee on Transport and Tourism, and Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Part of the Delegation for relations with the United States and the Delegation for relations with the Federative Republic of Brazil.

Matthew Patten is a British politician born on 21 May 1962 in Bishop's Stortford, Hertfordshire, England. He was a Member of the European Parliament for the East Midlands constituency from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, representing the Brexit Party. Previously, he was a Conservative councillor for Bradfield, Wix and Wrabness in Tendring District, Essex. Patten was the Chief Executive of The Lord's Taverners and the Mayor's Fund for London from 2012 to 2018. He served as a member of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, the Delegation for Relations with Iran, and the Delegation to the EU-North Macedonia Joint Parliamentary Committee. Patten was the prospective parliamentary candidate for Clacton-on-Sea in the 2019 general election but withdrew, and briefly served as campaign manager for London mayoral candidate Laurence Fox in 2021. He is currently the Political & Communications Director of the Centre for Social Justice.

Matthias Ecke, a 40-year-old German politician, born on 12 April 1983 in Meerane, East Germany. He is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 3 October 2022, representing the constituency of Germany. Prior to his current role, he worked as an advisor to Martin Dulig at Saxony's State Ministry for Economic Affairs. In parliament, he serves on the Committee on Regional Development and is part of the delegation for relations with Belarus. In 2024, he was assaulted by a group of young males, believed to be affiliated with the far-right, while putting up campaign posters in Dresden-Striesen, resulting in emergency surgery.

Mauri Pekkarinen, a Finnish politician from the Centre Party, born on 6 October 1947 in Kinnula, Finland. He graduated from the University of Jyväskylä with a Master's in Social Studies in 1974. Pekkarinen was first elected to parliament in 1979 in the Central Finland constituency and served as Minister of the Interior from 1991 to 1995, Minister of Trade and Industry from 2003 to 2008, and Minister of Economic Affairs from 2008 to 2011. He was a Member of the European Parliament for Finland from 2019 to 2024. Pekkarinen is married to Raija since 1972 and has four children. He is an avid long distance runner. In 2014, he suggested higher food VAT to collect more taxes. He was portrayed in the Finnish political satire TV series The Autocrats in the early 2000s.

Max-Léo Orville, born 1962 in Ivory Coast, French politician, member of the Democratic Movement, Member of the European Parliament since 2022, served on Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and Special Committee on the COVID-19 Pandemic.

Maxette Grisoni-Pirbakas, a French politician from Guadeloupe, born 14 April 1975 in Les Abymes, Guadeloupe, France. She was the leader of the Fédération nationale des syndicats d'exploitants agricoles in Guadeloupe. She served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024. She was the spokesperson for the National Rally from 16 March 2019 to February 2022, under the party's president Marine Le Pen. She defected to the Reconquête party in February 2022, endorsing Éric Zemmour in the presidential election. She was her party's candidate in the 2021 French regional elections in Guadeloupe. She was ordered to pay more than €160,000 to a former parliamentary assistant in 2024.

Maximilian Krah, a German politician, was born on 28 January 1977 in Räckelwitz, East Germany. He is a member of the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2 July 2019, representing the Germany constituency. 

Krah is a lawyer by profession and has worked with the Traditionalist-Catholic SSPX. He is a practising Catholic, widowed, and has eight children by three women. 

Krah's political career began when he joined the Junge Union in 1991, the youth wing of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), and later became active in the Association of Christian Democratic Students. He left the CDU in 2016 and joined the AfD, becoming the deputy chairman of the AfD Saxony in February 2018. 

As an MEP, Krah has been a member of the committees for Relations with the United States, International Trade (INTA), and Deputy Member of the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. He has also served as the spokesman for the AfD in the European Parliament until 2022.

Krah has been involved in several controversies, including his comments on the Nazi era, his association with right-wing extremist groups, and allegations of financial influence from China and Russia. He has been accused of employing a potential Chinese spy, Jian Guo, as his parliamentary assistant, and has been investigated for fraud and corruption. 

Krah's political positions include rejecting the term "conservative" and describing himself as "right-wing". He has called for a "great reset" for the EU and has expressed anti-American and anti-international law views. He has also been critical of the European Union and has called for greater cooperation with Russia and China. 

Krah has been suspended from the "Identity and Democracy" parliamentary group due to allegations of fraud and has been accused of failing to investigate allegations of espionage against his employee Jian Guo.

Mazaly Aguilar Pinar, a Spanish politician, born on 20 September 1949 in Cuenca, Spain. She is a member of the Vox party. Aguilar holds a degree in Economics from the Complutense University of Madrid and has worked for various companies, including Bank of America, BBVA, Banesto, Trasmediterrànea, and Airtel-Vodafone. She serves as Vice President of Vox, responsible for relations with private bodies and public institutions. Aguilar was elected as a Member of the European Parliament on 2 July 2019, representing Spain, and is Vice-Chairwoman of the Agriculture Committee, where she focuses on defending Community aid to Spanish farmers under the Common Agricultural Policy and scrutinizing the Free Trade Agreement between Mercosur and the European Union.

Axel Voss, a German lawyer and politician, born on 7 April 1963 in Hamelin, Germany, is a member of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany and the European People's Party. He has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2009 and is the coordinator of the European People's Party group in the Committee on Legal Affairs. He is married to Sabine Voss and has two daughters. Voss studied law at the Universities of Trier, Munich, and Freiburg, specializing in European and international law. He worked as a lawyer and was the Citizens' adviser of the European Commission at the regional Commission Representation in Bonn. Voss has been a strong advocate for digital and legal topics, focusing on issues such as data protection, artificial intelligence, and copyright law. He has been a rapporteur or shadow rapporteur for several key EU regulations, including the General Data Protection Regulation and the Digital Content Directive. Voss has also been critical of the inconsistent interpretation of EU laws among Member States and has argued for new technical approaches to simplify data processing and protect citizens' personal data. He has warned about the risks of Europe becoming a "digital colony" of the USA or China and has proposed a "European path of digitalization" based on EU values in data protection and data sovereignty.

Mercedes Bresso, born 12 July 1944 in Sanremo, Italy, economist, university professor of economic institutions at Politecnico di Torino, married to Claude Raffestin, resides in Turin. Member of the Democratic Party. Education: degree in Economics from the University of Turin in 1969. Career: university professor since 1973, Member of the European Parliament (2014-2019, 2023-), President of the Turin Province (1995-2004), Member of the Regional Council (1985-1995) and of the Regional Executive (1994-1995) with responsibility for regional planning in Piedmont, President of the Piedmont region (2005-2010), President of the Committee of the Regions (2010-2012), President of the Union of European Federalists (2005-2008), Chairperson of the World Federation of United Cities (2000-2004), founding Chairperson of the Organisation Cités et Gouvernements locaux Unis (2004-2005).

Miapetra Kumpula-Natri, a female, born on 19 May 1972 in Vaasa, Finland. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Her term as a Member of the European Parliament from Finland started on 1 July 2014 and is set to end on 16 July 2024. She serves on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and has been a rapporteur on European Union roaming regulations and the European strategy for data. She is part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the United States, and has been part of the delegations to the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Association Committee and the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. She is a member of intergroups on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, Anti-Racism and Diversity, Fighting against Poverty, and LGBT Rights.

Michael Bloss, a German politician, born on November 6, 1986, member of the Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 2, 2019, representing the constituency of Germany, educated at TU Dresden, SOAS University of London, University of Dar es Salaam, and University of Vienna, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with the United States, rapporteur on the European Green Deal, participated in negotiations for the 2021 state and federal elections in Germany, focusing on climate, environmental policy, energy, and climate protection, criticized the European Commission's draft hydrogen strategy in 2020, and opposed the Arctic LNG 2 project in 2021 due to climate change concerns.

Michael Gahler, a German politician, born 22 April 1960 in Frankfurt, West Germany, studied in Mainz and Dijon (1981-1987), and later trained as a lawyer. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Gahler has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 1 July 1999, representing Germany. He serves as Vice-President of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and is a member of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, the Democracy Support and Election Coordination Group, and the Parliament's delegations to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and the one for relations with Iran. Gahler has also headed the EU Election Observation Mission in Tunisia (2011) and Pakistan (2013), and is a member of the High-level Group of Personalities on Defence Research and the European Parliament's Sky and Space Intergroup. He is a signatory of the Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism, and has called for a tough stance on China and promoted the EU-Taiwan relationship. Gahler has also urged the replacement of the European Union's ambassador to Cuba.

Michael Eric Heaver, born 22 September 1989 in Cambridge, Cambridgeshire, England, British politician and broadcaster, former Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for East of England constituency, served from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, previously chair of UK Independence Party's youth wing Young Independence, graduated from University of East Anglia with a bachelor's degree in European Politics in 2011, joined UKIP at 17, left UKIP and joined Conservative Party in 2018, later joined Brexit Party, stood as candidate for Brexit Party in 2019 European parliamentary election, member of Committee on Budgetary Control, part of delegation for relations with the Korean Peninsula, resigned from Nigel Farage's staff in 2017, launched news website Westmonster, has a YouTube channel with over 150,000 subscribers, GB News Community Editor, previously prospective parliamentary candidate for Castle Point constituency in Essex, lives in Benfleet, Essex, England.

Michaela Šojdrová, a female politician from the Czech Republic, born on 28 October 1963, in Gottwaldov, Czechoslovakia, now Zlín, Czech Republic, member of the Christian and Democratic Union – Czechoslovak People's Party and the European People's Party, served as a Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024, representing the Czech Republic constituency, with a background in education administration, having worked at the Czech School Inspection head office, focused on women's rights and gender equality, served on the Committee on Culture and Education, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and various delegations, including the EU-Armenia Parliamentary Partnership Committee, EU-Azerbaijan Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, and EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee, married to Ludvík Šojdr, with two children, and an alumnus of Mendel University in Brno.

Michal Wiezik, a Slovak environmentalist and politician, born on 14 June 1979 in Martin, Czechoslovakia. He studied environmental protection at the Technical University in Zvolen, where he later obtained his PhD and became a professor. Wiezik is a member of the European Parliament, representing Slovakia since 2 July 2019. He is affiliated with Progressive Slovakia (since 2021) and was previously a member of Democrats (until 2021). He is part of the European Parliament Intergroups on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, and Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas. Wiezik is also a member of the Renew Europe group. He lives in Zvolen.

Michal Šimečka, born 10 May 1984, in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia (now Slovakia), is a Slovak politician, journalist, and researcher. He is a member of the Progressive Slovakia party, which he co-founded and has led since 2022. Šimečka is also affiliated with the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. He holds a BA in political sciences and international relations from Charles University, an MPhil in Russian and East European Studies from St Antony's College at the University of Oxford, and a DPhil in Politics and International Relations from Nuffield College. Šimečka has served as a Member of the European Parliament (2019-2023), Vice-President of the European Parliament (2022-2023), and Deputy Speaker of the National Council of Slovakia (2023-2024). He has been a strong supporter of the LGBT community and has advocated for the protection of democracy and the rule of law in Slovakia.

Michiel P. Hoogeveen, born July 6, 1989, in Leiden, Netherlands, is a Dutch politician and former Member of the European Parliament. He is a member of the right-wing conservative JA21 party and has a background in finance and North Korea research. Hoogeveen holds a Bachelor of Business Administration degree from The Hague University of Applied Sciences and a Master of Science degree in political science from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. He worked at several banks, including KAS Bank, and served as an independent researcher of North Korea, traveling to the country three times between 2014 and 2017. Hoogeveen joined the Forum for Democracy party in 2016 and was elected to the States of South Holland in 2019. He left the party in 2020 and joined JA21, representing the party in the European Parliament as part of the European Conservatives and Reformists group from April 2021 to July 2024. Hoogeveen has been a vocal critic of the West's approach towards North Korea and has advocated for diplomatic talks and normalization of relations. He opposes the introduction of a digital euro and has raised concerns about its potential impact on the financial system. Hoogeveen has also served on the board of Pugwash Netherlands, an organization addressing weapons of mass destruction, and has written a book on North Korea titled "The Hermit Kingdom: About the Rise and Future of North Korea."

Michèle Rivasi, a French politician, born 9 February 1953 in Montélimar, France, died 29 November 2023 in Brussels, Belgium. She was a member of the European Parliament from 14 July 2009 until her death, representing South-East France for Europe Écologie–The Greens. Previously, she was a member of the French National Assembly from 12 June 1997 to 18 June 2002, representing Drôme's 1st constituency, first as an independent ecologist close to the Socialist Party, then joining Europe Écologie–The Greens. She was also the director of Greenpeace in France from September 2003 to November 2004. Rivasi was an alumna of the École normale supérieure de Fontenay-aux-Roses and taught biology before entering politics. She was an environmentalist active since the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 and a strong supporter of alternative medicine and homeopathy. Rivasi described herself as a "vaccination skeptic" and opposed the planned Midi-Catalonia pipeline.

Mick Wallace, born November 9, 1955, in Wexford, Ireland, is an Irish politician and former Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the South constituency from 2019 to 2024. He is a member of Independents 4 Change and part of The Left in the European Parliament – GUE/NGL. 

Wallace was a Teachta Dála (TD) for the Wexford constituency from 2011 to 2019. He gained a reputation for anti-establishment and left-wing populist views. 

Wallace has been married to Mary Murphy from 1979 to 1992 and has four children. He graduated from University College Dublin with a degree in English, history, and philosophy, and later obtained a teaching qualification.

As a politician, Wallace has expressed support for various authoritarian regimes and has been critical of Western policies. He has voted against resolutions critical of Vladimir Putin's Russia and has described himself as fighting against "anti-Russian" rhetoric. 

Wallace has also been a vocal supporter of the Syrian government, opposing sanctions against it and voting against a resolution condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine. He has expressed admiration for China, saying it has a "much more healthy state involvement in the organization of society." 

Wallace has been involved in several controversies, including being declared bankrupt in 2016 with debts of over €30 million and being fined €2,000 for being in an airside area without permission at Shannon Airport. He has also been accused of withholding employees' pension contributions and underpaying tax.

Wallace has been a frequent guest on the political debate show Tonight with Vincent Browne and has used social media to express his views, including criticizing the EU's response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and accusing the EU of promoting war.

Miguel Urbán Crespo, Spanish politician and activist, born 26 March 1980 in Madrid, Spain, son of Luis Miguel Urbán Fernández, a member of the Trotskyist Revolutionary Communist League. Studied history at Complutense University of Madrid but did not graduate. Worked as a librarian in La Marabunta. Co-founder of Podemos, member of the European Parliament since 2015, representing Spain. Formerly part of Anticapitalistas, left Podemos in 2020. Served on various committees, including Industry, Research and Energy, Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, and Development. Voted against the resolution condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Author of "El viejo fascismo y la nueva derecha radical" and "La emergencia de Vox. Apuntes para combatir a la extrema derecha española".

Mihai Tudose, born March 6, 1967, in Braila, Romania, is a Romanian politician, jurist, and academic. He holds a doctorate in Military Sciences and Information from Dimitrie Cantemir Christian University. He is married to Corina Tudose and has one child. He was a member of the Democratic National Salvation Front (FDSN) from 1992 to 1993, the Party of Social Democracy in Romania (PDSR) from 1993 to 2001, the Social Democratic Party (PSD) from 2001 to 2019, PRO Romania from 2019 to 2020, and rejoined the PSD in 2020. He served as the Prime Minister of Romania from June 29, 2017, to January 16, 2018, under President Klaus Iohannis, and as Minister of Economy from December 17, 2014, to November 17, 2015, and from February 23, 2017, to June 29, 2017. He was involved in a plagiarism scandal and made controversial statements regarding Székely autonomy. He was also accused of sexual harassment in 2023, which he denied.

Mikuláš Peksa, a Czech biophysicist, activist, and politician, born on 18 June 1986 in Prague, Czech Republic (then Czechoslovakia), studied biophysics at Charles University, focusing on nuclear magnetic resonance, and worked as a researcher and software engineer. He is a member of the Czech Pirate Party, which he joined in 2013, and the European Pirate Party. He was elected as a Member of the Chamber of Deputies in the 2017 Czech legislative election, serving from 21 October 2017 to 6 June 2019. He was succeeded by František Navrkal. He served as the Fourth vice-chairman of the Czech Pirate Party from 24 April 2017 to 5 November 2019. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in the 2019 election, taking office on 2 July 2019, and is set to serve until 15 July 2024. He is a member of the Greens–European Free Alliance parliamentary group, and sits on the European Parliament Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Delegation to the EU-Ukraine Parliamentary Association Committee. He became the Chairman of the European Pirate Party on 11 November 2019, succeeding Markéta Gregorová.

Milan Brglez, a Slovenian politician, born on 1 September 1967, in Ljubljana, SR Slovenia, Yugoslavia. He is a member of the Social Democrats and previously a member of the Modern Centre Party. Brglez graduated in political science and completed his master's degree in international law at the University of Ljubljana, and obtained his PhD in international relations. He worked as a teaching assistant and assistant professor at the Faculty of Social, Political Sciences and Journalism, and as head of the Department for International Relations at the Faculty of Social Sciences. Brglez served as the Speaker of the National Assembly of Slovenia from 2014 to 2018 and as a Member of the European Parliament since 2019. He is a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and substitute member of the committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Brglez was a candidate in the 2022 presidential election and has received several awards for his academic work, including the Prešeren Award and the Zore Award. He is also the President of the Slovenian Chess Association and Vice-President of the Slovenian Red Cross.

Milan Uhrík, a Slovak politician, was born on 21 December 1984 in Komjatice, Czechoslovakia. He is a Catholic, married to Zuzana Uhríková, and has two children. Uhrík is fluent in Slovak, English, German, and Russian. He resides in Nitra, Slovakia. 

Uhrík's political career began in 2010 when he ran for local councillor in Komjatice for the SDKÚ party. He later became a member of the National Council of the Slovak Republic for the ĽSNS party from 23 March 2016 to 1 July 2019. Uhrík was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 for the ĽSNS party and served until 2021. 

In 2021, Uhrík founded the Republic Movement and became its chairman. He is also a former deputy of the Nitra self-governing region and a member of the Foreign Committee of the Slovak Republic. Uhrík's party affiliation has changed over time, from SDKÚ (2010) to ĽSNS (until 2021) and finally to the Republic Movement (since 2021).

Milan Zver, Slovenian politician, born 25 May 1962 in Ljubljana, FPR Yugoslavia, member of the Slovenian Democratic Party and the European People's Party, Vice-President of the Slovenian Democratic Party, served as Minister of Education and Sports from 2004 to 2008, Member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing Slovenia, fluent in Slovene, English, German, and Serbo-Croatian, married with two daughters, amateur football player, holds a PhD in sociology and political science from the University of Ljubljana, author of several books on political analysis and history of political thought, signatory of the Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism, member of the Reconciliation of European Histories Group, former advisor to the Deputy Prime Minister Jože Pučnik and the Minister of Defence Janez Janša, former secretary of the Municipal Council of Ljubljana, former member of the Municipal Council of Ljubljana, former member of the National Assembly of Slovenia.

Mircea Hava, born 26 December 1956 in Oradea, Bihor County, Romania, Romanian politician, engineer, and member of the European Parliament, elected on the list of the National Liberal Party at the 2019 European Parliament election in Romania, previously mayor of Alba Iulia for 25 years, member of the Democratic Party before joining the National Liberal Party, reelected in 2004 with more than 70% of the votes, Officer National Order of Merit in 2011, and Knight National Order of Merit in 2004.

Miriam Dalli, a Maltese politician of the Labour Party and former journalist, was born on 19 May 1976 in St. Julian's, Malta. She graduated from the University of Malta with a Bachelor of Laws, Bachelor in Communications, Master's in European Studies, and Master's in Business Administration. Dalli worked as a journalist for over 15 years, producing and presenting current-affairs programmes and serving as a news editor for ONE TV and ONE Radio. She was a government advisor in the Ministry of Energy and Conservation of Water. Dalli was a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2020, serving on several committees, including the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Petitions. She was also a substitute member on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. In 2020, Dalli became a Member of the Parliament of Malta and was appointed Minister for Energy, Enterprise and Sustainable Development, later becoming Minister for the Environment, Energy and Enterprise in 2022. She is a member of the Labour Party and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats.

Miriam Lexmann, born December 2, 1972, in Bratislava, Slovakia, to Eugen and Marta Lexmann, with German descent. Graduated from Comenius University. Worked for the International Republican Institute. Member of the Christian Democratic Movement since 2016. Married to Milan Majerský in 2020. Elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Slovakia in 2019, assuming the mandate on February 1, 2020. Became a full member of the European Parliament Committee on Foreign Affairs and a substitute in the European Parliament Subcommittee on Security and Defence. Became a quaestor of the European Parliament on July 17, 2024. Considering candidacy in the 2024 Slovak presidential election. Placed on China's sanctions list in 2021.

Miroslav Radačovský, a Slovak politician and former judge, born on 24 September 1953 in Ľutina, Czechoslovakia, served as a non-attached Member of the European Parliament for Slovakia from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, previously working as a judge for 37 years and 214 days, including a notable case against former Slovak President Andrej Kiska, later becoming the chairman of the Slovak PATRIOT party in 2021, and married to Mária Radačovská.

Miroslav Číž, a Slovak politician, born on 11 February 1954 in Banská Štiavnica, Czechoslovakia, died on 29 December 2022 at the age of 68. He studied Law at Comenius University, graduating in 1978, and later taught at the university. Číž served as a high-ranking official of the National Committees of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia during socialism and remained in the Communist Party of Slovakia after the fall of the regime, later renamed the Party of the Democratic Left. In 1999, he left the Party of the Democratic Left, led by Robert Fico, and co-founded the Direction party. He was a member of the National Council from 2002 to 2019 and its Deputy Speaker from 2006 to 2010 and 2014 to 2016. Číž was a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 until his death, representing the Slovakia constituency. He was involved in a public incident in 2019, where he yelled at a cook in the National Council canteen for not having chicken legs available. His seat was taken by Katarína Roth Neveďalová after his death.

Mislav Kolakušić, a Croatian politician, born on 15 September 1969 in Zagreb, Croatia, with Croatian nationality, and a graduate of the University of Zagreb. He is a lawyer and judge by profession. He was a judge at the Zagreb Commercial Court and previously worked at the Commercial Court in Zagreb, the Municipal and County Courts in Zagreb, and the Administrative Court of the Republic of Croatia. He was also the spokesperson of the High Administrative Court of the Republic of Croatia and the president of the Croatian Association of Judicial Advisers and Trainees. He was elected as an Independent to the European Parliament in 2019 and has been a member since 2 July 2019, representing Croatia. He is a member of the Parliament Committee on Budgets, the Committee on Legal Affairs, and a substitute of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. He was affiliated with the Law and Justice party, the European Alliance for Freedom and Democracy from 2020 to 2023, and has been an Independent since 2023. He has expressed anti-vaccination mandate views and has criticized the EU's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, Pfizer's vaccine, and the lack of transparency regarding vaccine ingredients. He has also been a candidate for the Constitutional Court of Croatia and the Croatian presidential election in 2019.

Mohammed Chahim, a Moroccan-born Dutch politician, born on 18 April 1985 in Fez, Morocco, with dual Dutch and Moroccan nationality. He graduated with a PhD in econometrics from Tilburg University in 2013. Chahim is a member of the Labour Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Netherlands. He serves on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, is the rapporteur for the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, and is part of the European Parliament's delegation for relations with India. Chahim is also the head of the European Parliament's work on the carbon border tax and is the EU's Socialists & Democrats vice president.

Molly Scott Cato, a British Green politician, economist, and activist, born on 21 May 1963, in the UK. She holds a BA/MA in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics from the University of Oxford, an MSc in advanced social research methods from the Open University, and a PhD from Aberystwyth University. Scott Cato was a Professor of Strategy and Sustainability at the University of Roehampton from 2012 to 2014 and has worked as a Senior lecturer and Reader in green economics at Cardiff Metropolitan University. She is a member of the Green Party of England and Wales and has served as a Member of the European Parliament for South West England from 2014 to 2020. Scott Cato has been involved in various local and community activities, including being a director of Stroud Common Wealth and Transition Stroud, and has founded Green Audit, an environmental consultancy and publishing organisation. She has written several books on green economics, localism, and anti-capitalism, and has contributed to works on the risks of nuclear power. Scott Cato is a Quaker, has three children, and lives in Stroud, Gloucestershire.

Monica Semedo, born 15 June 1984, in Grevenmacher, Luxembourg, of Cape Verdean descent, Luxembourgish politician and former TV presenter, currently serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the constituency of Luxembourg since 2 July 2019, initially as a member of the Democratic Party, but since January 2021 as an Independent Renew Europe member, and as of February 2024, a member of Fokus. She has served on several committees including the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Committee on Petitions, and Committee on Culture and Education. Semedo has been involved in controversy, including a 15-day suspension and loss of parliamentary allowances due to moral harassment of her parliamentary assistants, with ongoing investigations into further allegations.

Monika Beňová, a Slovak politician, born 15 August 1968 in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, with a master's degree in international relations from Matej Bel University and a PhDr. in eastern Europe studies. She has been a member of the European Parliament since 2004, representing Slovakia, and is affiliated with the Direction-Social Democracy party (SMER-SD), a centre-left party and member of the Party of European Socialists. Beňová has been a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and previously served on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Delegation for Relations with Israel. She has been a Quaestor of the European Parliament since 2019 and has expressed progressive and left-wing views, sometimes differing from her party's stance on issues like the European Union, NATO, LGBTQ rights, and the conflict in Ukraine. Beňová was previously a member of the National Council of Slovakia from 2002 to 2004 and has been married twice, with two children.

Monika Hohlmeier is a German politician and member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the Christian Social Union (CSU) and the European People's Party (EPP). She was born on 2 July 1962 in Munich, Bavaria, Germany, to former German politician Franz Josef Strauss. She completed a training as a hotel manager. Hohlmeier served as Bavarian State Minister for Education and Cultural Affairs from 1998 to 2005 under Minister-President Edmund Stoiber. She has been a member of the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets, Committee on Budgetary Control, and the parliament's delegation for relations with the People's Republic of China. She has also served on the Special Committee on Organized Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Hohlmeier is married to Franc Hohlmeier and has two children. She is a member of several non-profit organizations, including the Christliches Jugenddorfwerk Deutschlands, European Academy of Bavaria, and Hanns Seidel Foundation.

Monika Vana, Austrian politician of The Greens-The Green Alternative and the European Green Party, born 14 September 1969 in Vienna, Austria. Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the Austria constituency. Serves on the Committee on Budgets, Committee on Regional Development, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and delegations for relations with Australia, New Zealand, and the United States. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup Urban and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights.

Moritz Körner, a German politician, born on August 3, 1990, in Wiesbaden, Germany. He is a member of the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. Körner has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing Germany. He is the leader of the FDP group in the European Parliament, and has served on the Committee on Budgets, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware. Körner is also a member of various European Parliament Intergroups, including those focused on Anti-Corruption, Artificial Intelligence and Digital, LGBT Rights, and the Welfare and Conservation of Animals. He is openly gay and has been involved in various party leadership roles, including as Secretary General of the FDP in North Rhine-Westphalia. Körner holds degrees from Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf and the University of Duisburg-Essen.

Morten Helveg Petersen, born 14 September 1966, in Copenhagen, Denmark, son of former Danish foreign minister Niels Helveg Petersen and brother of former minister Rasmus Helveg Petersen. Education: Master of Science degree in economics from the University of Copenhagen in 1992. Career: Worked for the European Commission 1992-1993, Confederation of Danish Industries 1993-1998, member of the Folketing 1998-2009, CEO of Foreningen af Danske Interaktive Medier 2009-2011, vice-CEO of Danske Medier 2011-2013. Member of the European Parliament since 2014, representing the Danish Social Liberal Party, affiliated with the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party. Served on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, member of the Parliament's delegations for relations with Japan and the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee. Considered to be on the right flank of the party, opposed to the party's decision to be part of Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt's coalition government. Author of books "Midt i maskinrummet" (1999) and "Enter – et personligt bud på Danmarks IT-fremtid" (2001).

Morten Løkkegaard, born 20 December 1964 in Helsingør, Denmark, is a Danish politician and Member of the European Parliament representing the Venstre party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. He has served intermittently since 2009 and continuously since 2016. Løkkegaard studied at Denmark's Journalist Folk High School and worked as a writer and TV host before entering politics. He was a rapporteur and deputy chairman of the Danish delegation to the Nordic Council and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Mediterranean. He has served on various committees, including the Committee on Culture and Education, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Løkkegaard has been a vice chair of the Renew Europe group and has been involved in issues related to communication, jobs, and growth creation. He has been married twice, first to Paula Larrain and then to Connie Dahl Løkkegaard, and has several children.

Mounir Satouri, a French politician, born on 25 May 1975, in Casablanca, Morocco, is a member of the European Parliament representing France for the Europe Ecology – The Greens party since 2 July 2019. He serves on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and is part of the delegations to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean and for relations with the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity. Satouri previously endorsed Benoît Hamon in the 2017 French Socialist Party presidential primary and supported Yannick Jadot in the 2022 presidential elections. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the French Office for the Protection of Refugees and Stateless Persons.

Márton Gyöngyösi, Hungarian politician, born 8 June 1977 in Kecskemét, Hungary, married to Ágnes Gyöngyösiné Cserhalmi, with one child. Graduated from Trinity College, Dublin in 2000 with a degree in economy and political science. Worked as a tax consultant at KPMG and expert at Ernst&Young. Speaks Hungarian, English, German, and Russian. Member of Jobbik party since 2006, leader of the party since 2 July 2022. Served as Member of the National Assembly from 14 May 2010 to 25 June 2019, and as Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019. Former leader of Jobbik's parliamentary group and vice-chair of the Foreign Committee of the Hungarian National Assembly. Has been a key figure in the transformation of Jobbik to a mainstream party, advocating for a Wage Union European Citizens’ Initiative and closer cooperation between EU member states. Has condemned authoritarian actions in Russia, China, Venezuela, Bolivia, and Nicaragua. Made controversial statements about Jews and Israel in the past, which he later apologized for.

Mónica Silvana González, born 12 February 1976 in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentine and Spanish politician, Member of the European Parliament since 2019, member of the Federal Executive Commission of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), previously member of the Assembly of Madrid, city councillor of Alcalá de Henares from 2007 to 2015, graduated in Tourism at the National University of the Northeast of Corrientes, moved to Spain in 1998, settling in Alcalá de Henares, served on the Parliament’s Committee on Development, rapporteur on humanitarian aid from 2019 to 2023, member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, the European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, lost entitlement to a daily subsistence allowance and parliamentary activity for 30 days in January 2023 for 'psychological harassment' towards her three accredited parliamentary assistants.

José Ignacio "Nacho" Sánchez Amor, a Spanish politician, was born on May 15, 1960, in Cáceres, Spain. He is a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) since 1978, initially joining the People's Socialist Party (PSP) in 1977. Sánchez Amor earned a licentiate degree in Law at the Complutense University of Madrid (UCM) and was a postgraduate scholar at the Centro de Estudios Constitucionales (CEC). He has held various positions, including Chief of Staff of Juan Carlos Rodríguez Ibarra (1996-2004), regional Vice-President of Extremadura (2004-2007), Spokesperson of the Socialist Parliamentary Group in the Assembly of Extremadura, and member of the Congress of Deputies (2011-2019). Sánchez Amor served as Secretary of State for Territorial Policy (2018-2019) and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since July 2, 2019, representing Spain. He is part of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Human Rights, EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the Spinelli Group.

Nadine Morano, a French politician, born on November 6, 1963, in Nancy, France, to a truck driver father and a switchboard operator mother. Her mother is the daughter of a Piedmontese mason from Verbano-Cusio-Ossola. Morano has been divorced, with three children, including a son who passed away in 2024. She studied at the University of Lorraine. Morano's early career includes being a member of the National Assembly from 2002 to 2008, representing Meurthe-et-Moselle, and serving as Deputy Minister for Apprenticeship and Vocational Training, and Secretary of State for Family. Since 2014, Morano has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing East France, and serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. She is a member of the Republicans party and has been involved in several controversies, including making comments about France being a "white race" country and criticizing government spokesperson Sibeth Ndiaye's dress and French citizenship. Morano has also been a supporter of various presidential candidates, including François Fillon and Michel Barnier.

Naomi Long is the Minister of Justice in the Northern Ireland Executive, leader of the Alliance Party, and Member of the Legislative Assembly for Belfast East. Born on 13 December 1971 in Belfast, Northern Ireland, she is married to Michael Long, an Alliance councillor, and son of engineer Professor Adrian Long. Long graduated from Queen's University of Belfast with a degree in civil engineering in 1994 and worked in structural engineering consultancy and environmental and hydraulic engineering consultancy before entering politics. She first took political office in 2001 when she was elected to Belfast City Council for the Victoria ward. Long served as Lord Mayor of Belfast from 2009 to 2010 and represented Belfast East in the Northern Ireland Assembly from 2003 to 2010 and again from 2016 to 2019 and 2020 to present. She was elected as Member of Parliament for Belfast East in the 2010 general election but lost her seat in 2015. Long was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for Northern Ireland in 2019 but returned to the Northern Ireland Assembly in 2020. She became the leader of the Alliance Party in 2016 and has been a strong advocate for a united, open, liberal, and progressive society. Long has been a member of the Committee for Communities, the All Party Group on Fairtrade, the All Party Group for Housing, and chaired the All Party Group on Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. She has also been a vocal critic of Sinn Féin and the DUP for delaying the publication of a working group report on abortion and has called for the harmonisation and strengthening of equality and anti-discrimination measures, the introduction of civil marriage equality, development of integrated education, and a Northern Ireland framework to tackle climate change. Long was elected as Minister of Justice in the Northern Ireland Executive in 2020 and has announced plans to progress new domestic abuse legislation, introduce unexplained wealth orders, and review the support available for prison officers. She has also expressed concerns about the DUP's deployment of a cross-community vote to prevent an extension of COVID-19 regulations and has stated that she is seriously reconsidering her position within the Executive. Long is a member of Bloomfield Presbyterian Church and has expressed "great concern" over the Church's decision to exclude those in same-sex relationships from being full members. She has been suffering from endometriosis and underwent surgery for the condition in 2017.

Nathalie Colin-Oesterlé, born 5 May 1965 in Ollioules, France, is a French lawyer and politician of The Centrists. She is the daughter of Daniel Colin and has three children. Colin-Oesterlé graduated from Panthéon-Assas University. Since 2001, she has been a member of the municipal council of Metz. From 2019 to 2024, she served as a Member of the European Parliament for France, where she was part of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. She was also part of the Parliament's delegations for relations to Israel and to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, as well as the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development and the MEPs Against Cancer group. She has been a Member of the National Assembly for Moselle's 3rd constituency since 18 July 2024, succeeding Charlotte Leduc.

Nathalie Loiseau, French politician, diplomat, and academic administrator, born on 1 June 1964 in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France, married to Bertrand Loiseau since 1992, with four children, Roman Catholic, and feminist. Education: Lycée Carnot, Sciences Po (1983), and Institut national des langues et civilisations orientales (studied Chinese language). Career: French foreign service (1986), diplomat in Indonesia (1990-1992), advisor to Foreign Minister Alain Juppé (1993-1995), diplomatic missions in Dakar, Senegal, and Rabat, Morocco, Communications Director at the Embassy of France, Washington, D.C. (2002-2007), head of Human Resources at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (2009-2011), and chief of staff (2011-2012). Director of the École nationale d'administration (2012-2017). Minister for European Affairs (21 June 2017 - 27 March 2019). Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing France, member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and member of various parliamentary delegations and intergroups. Member of the Renaissance party (2017-2021) and Horizons party (2021-present). Author of "Choisissez tout" (2014) and "La démocratie en BD" (2017).

Nathan Lee Gill, a British former politician, was born on July 6, 1973, in Kingston upon Hull, East Riding of Yorkshire, England. He is married to Jana, an American, and has five children. Gill is a practicing member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and served as a Bishop for the Anglesey ward for six years. He was educated at Ysgol David Hughes and Coleg Menai. Gill founded and managed Burgill Ltd in 2004, a company that provided domiciliary and home care services, but it collapsed into administration in 2007. He has been a member of the Conservative Party, UK Independence Party (UKIP), and Reform UK. Gill was the Leader of Reform UK Wales from March 26, 2021, to May 8, 2021, and previously served as the Leader of UKIP Wales from December 6, 2014, to September 26, 2016. He was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Wales from July 1, 2014, to January 31, 2020, and a Member of the National Assembly for Wales for North Wales from May 5, 2016, to December 27, 2017.
