Gill has also been involved in various elections, including the 2019 European Parliament election, the 2019 general election, and the 2021 Senedd election. He has met with pro-Russian leaders in Ukraine and Moldova and has been critical of human involvement in climate change. Gill has worked as a businessman and has been a regional list candidate for the North Wales electoral region.

Neena Gill, a British Labour Party politician, born in Ludhiana, Punjab, India, emigrated to the UK at age 10, graduated with a bachelor's degree in social studies from Liverpool John Moores University in 1979, and later gained a postgraduate professional qualification from the Chartered Institute of Housing in 1984 and completed the senior executive programme at the London Business School in 1996. She worked as a housing officer, chief executive of ASRA Group and Newlon Housing Group, and vice president for corporate affairs at SAS. She served as a Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands from 1999 to 2009 and again from 2014 to 2020, holding various positions including President of the Delegation for Relations with India and President of the Delegation for Relations with South Asia and SAARC countries. She was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2017 and received the Pravasi Bharatiya Samman in 2017. She was married to Dr. John Towner from 1982 to 2009 and has one son.

Niclas Herbst, a German politician, born on 28 February 1973 in Ratzeburg, West Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the European People's Party. Herbst graduated from the University of Kiel. He joined the CDU in 1990 and has been a member of the party's leadership in Schleswig-Holstein since 2000. Herbst served as a member of the Landtag of Schleswig-Holstein from 2005 to 2012 and as advisor to Minister-President Daniel Günther from 2017 to 2019. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Fisheries. Herbst is also part of the Parliament's delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages. He received the Agriculture, Rural Development and Fisheries award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020. Herbst is a member of Hamburger SV and the Reservist Association of Deutsche Bundeswehr.

Nico Semsrott, a German Kabarett artist, slam poet, and politician, born on 11 March 1986 in Hamburg, West Germany. He is the brother of Arne Semsrott. Semsrott was a member of the satirical German political party Die PARTEI before becoming an independent politician in 2021. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, serving from 2 July 2019, and is affiliated with the Greens–European Free Alliance group. Semsrott previously ran in the 2017 German federal election, receiving 2.1% of the votes, and was part of the ZDF heute-show team from 2017 to 2019. He has won several awards, including the NDR-Comedy Contest, Karl-Marx-Poesie-Preis, Stuttgarter Besen, and Deutscher Kleinkunstpreis. Semsrott has been known for his satirical performances, often portraying a depressive persona, and has been involved in controversy, including revealing thefts in the European Parliament and criticizing the handling of racism and blackfacing accusations within his former party.

Nicola Beer, born 23 January 1970 in Wiesbaden, West Germany, studied law at the University of Frankfurt from 1991 to 1997. She is a member of the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and has been married to lawyer Jürgen Illing since 2018. Beer is a mother of twins and was previously in a relationship with fellow FDP politician Volker Stein, with whom she separated in 2001. She has been a member of the FDP since 1991 and has held various positions, including State Secretary for European Affairs in Hesse from 2009 to 2012, State Minister of Education and Cultural Affairs in Hesse from 2012 to 2014, Member of the German Bundestag from 2017 to 2019, and Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2023. She has also been the Deputy Leader of the FDP and General Secretary of the FDP. Beer has been an outspoken proponent of Taiwan's independence and has publicly denied the consensus of climate science on extreme weather events. She has been a member of several boards and associations, including the International Martin Luther Foundation, the Association of Private Higher Education Institutions, and the German-French Lawyers' Association.

Nicola Danti, Italian politician, born in Pelago on 6 September 1966, member of Italia Viva, vice-president of the Renew Europe Group at the European Parliament, graduated in Political Science at Florence's University in 1993, managed a consulting company until 2000, scout in the Association of Catholic Guides and Scouts of Italy (AGESCI), three children, published book "La strada da percorrere" in 2015, elected in Pontassieve municipal council in 1990, deputy-mayor of Pontassieve from 1995 to 1999, president of the Florentine Mountain Community from 2002 to 2008, coordinator of The Daisy for the area of Florence from 2004 to 2007, member of the regional council of Tuscany from 2007 to 2014, president of the regional council's committee for education and culture from 2010 to 2014, member of the European Parliament since 2014, member of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament from 2014 to 2020, member of the Renew Europe Group since 2020, member of the European Democratic Party since 2020, coordinator of Matteo Renzi's committees in Tuscany in 2012, spokesman of the regional secretaryship of the Democratic Party, member of the National directorate of the Democratic Party, served on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, Committee on International Trade, delegations for relations with Brazil and Mercosur, Committee of Inquiry into Emission Measurements in the Automotive Sector, European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Integrity.

Nicola Procaccini, Italian politician, born 21 January 1976 in Rome, Italy, educated at Sapienza University of Rome. Member of Brothers of Italy since 2012, previously affiliated with Italian Social Movement, National Alliance, and The People of Freedom. Served as Mayor of Terracina from 2011 to 2015 and 2016 to 2019, succeeding Stefano Nardi and Erminia Ocello, and preceded by Erminia Ocello and Roberta Tintari. Elected as Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy in 2019, term started on 2 July 2019. Awarded "Rising Star" at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in March 2024.

Nicolae Ștefănuță, a progressive Romanian politician, born on 3 January 1982, in Rășinari, Romania, with Romanian nationality, and educated at West University of Timișoara (BEcon), University of Vienna (MA), Diplomatic Academy of Vienna (MA), and Georgetown University (MPP). He is a member of the European Parliament, representing Romania since 2 July 2019, initially as part of USR PLUS, and later as an independent since 2023, affiliated with the Greens–European Free Alliance. Ștefănuță has been part of various committees, including the Committee on Budgets, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, and has served as the parliament's lead rapporteur on the European Union's budget for 2023. He is also a member of several intergroups, such as the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Children’s Rights. Ștefănuță has expressed support for Palestine, attended the 2024 Bucharest Pride, and has co-signed a letter calling on the European Commission to stop the United Kingdom from holding EU nationals in immigration removal centers.

Nicolas Bay, born 21 December 1977 in Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France. 
Education: Paris Nanterre University (DEUG).
Married to Marion Bay since 2008 with 3 children. 
Self-declared Roman Catholic, participated in protests against same-sex marriage law in 2013.
Former boy scout in the Scouts Unitaires de France.
Joined the National Front at 15, in 1992.
Member of European Conservatives and Reformists Group (ECR).
Assumed offices: 
- Member of the European Parliament for France since 1 July 2014.
- Executive Vice President of Reconquête from 18 February 2022 to 12 June 2024.
- Member of the Regional Council of Normandy since 4 January 2016.
- General Secretary of the National Front from 30 November 2014 to 30 September 2017.
- Member of the Municipal council of Elbeuf from 23 March 2014 to 16 March 2015.
Formerly affiliated with National Republican Movement (MNR) from 1999 to 2008 and National Rally (FN/RN) from 1992 to 1999 and 2009 to 2022, currently affiliated with Identity–Freedoms (IDL) since 2024 and Reconquête (REC) from 2022 to 2024.

Nicolas Schmit, European Commissioner for Jobs and Social Rights, born 10 December 1953 in Differdange, Luxembourg, studied economics at Institut d'études politiques d'Aix-en-Provence, member of the Luxembourg Socialist Workers' Party and Party of European Socialists, served as Minister-Delegate for Foreign Affairs and Immigration, Minister of Labour, Employment and Immigration of Luxembourg, and Member of the European Parliament, married with four children, previously involved in controversy regarding undue influence on the Grand Ducal Police.

Generate a voting profile for Nicolaus Fest, a 61-year-old male German politician from Hamburg, born on 1 July 1962, member of the Alternative for Germany party, serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Germany constituency, and former journalist who was deputy editor-in-chief of Bild am Sonntag, known for controversies including calling Islam an "obstacle to integration" and making a derogatory comment about the late European Parliament president David Sassoli.

Nicolás González Casares, a Spanish nurse and politician, Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019, affiliated with the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, educated at the University of Santiago de Compostela, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, the parliament's delegation for relations with Japan, the Spinelli Group, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital.

Niels Fuglsang, a Danish politician, born 29 June 1985 in Copenhagen, Denmark. He holds a cand.scient.pol. degree from the University of Copenhagen and was writing his ph.d. thesis in 2019. Fuglsang is a member of the Social Democrats party and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Denmark since 2 July 2019, sitting with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) group. He has been a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and previously of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs until September 2019. Fuglsang has also been part of the European Parliament's delegations for relations with China and the Korean Peninsula, and since April 2023, the Arab Peninsula, serving as vice chair since May 2023. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals.

Niels Geuking, a German politician born on 17 November 1992 in Coesfeld, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. He is a member of the Family Party of Germany. Niels Geuking has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Germany since 5 February 2024. His predecessor is his father, Helmut Geuking, who initially resigned, causing the vacancy, but later intended to seek re-election in 2024, and was elected, yet opted not to take the seat, allowing Niels Geuking to remain as MEP.

Nigel Farage is a British politician and broadcaster. He was born on 3 April 1964 in Farnborough, Kent, England. He has been the Member of Parliament for Clacton and Leader of Reform UK since 2024. He previously served as the leader of the UK Independence Party from 2006 to 2009 and 2010 to 2016. Farage was a member of the European Parliament for South East England from 1999 to 2020. He is known for his Eurosceptic views and his role in the Brexit campaign. Farage has been married twice and has four children. He was educated at Dulwich College.

Niklas Nienaß, a German politician born on 14 April 1992 in Marl, Germany, is a member of the Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party. He served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 2024, representing the Germany constituency. Nienaß was part of several committees, including the Committee on Regional Development, the Committee on Culture and Education, and the parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. He also participated in various intergroups, such as the Spinelli Group, the European Parliament Intergroup on Children’s Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights. In 2021, he joined a group of lawmakers urging leaders of Germany, France, and Italy not to support the Arctic LNG 2 project due to climate change concerns. Nienaß studied at the University of Rostock.

Nikolaj Villumsen, a Danish politician, born on 28 February 1983 in Aarhus, Denmark, is a member of Enhedslisten and represents Denmark in the European Parliament since 2 July 2019. He has a bachelor's degree in history and has served as a member of the Folketing from September 2011 to June 2019. In the European Parliament, he is a vice-chair of The Left group and a member of the Committee of Employment and Social Affairs, Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Committee of Constitutional Affairs. He has received a Certificate of Appreciation from the former Palestinian Ambassador in Denmark, Mufeed Shami, for his solidarity and support for Palestine and the Palestinian people.

Nikos Androulakis, a Greek politician, born on 7 February 1979, in Heraklion, Greece. He graduated from the Democritus University of Thrace with a degree in civil engineering and a Master's in "New Materials and Environment." Androulakis worked in the tourism industry and as a civil engineer, also teaching at the School of Pedagogical and Technological Education. He became a member of the Central Council of PASOK Youth in 2001 and the National Council of PASOK in 2008. Androulakis served as the Secretary of the Central Political Committee of PASOK from 2013 to 2015, and as a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2023, affiliated with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. He was the president of PASOK – Movement for Change since 2021 and a member of the Hellenic Parliament, representing the constituency of Thessaloniki A, since 2023. Androulakis was a target of an attempted wiretapping scandal in 2022. He is a member of PASOK – KINAL and has been involved in various leadership roles within the party.

Nils Ole Hilmer Torvalds, MEP, born 7 August 1945 in Ekenäs, Finland, son of poet Ole Torvalds and father of software engineer Linus Torvalds. Member of the Swedish People's Party of Finland and Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. Former member of the Communist Party of Finland from 1969 to 1982. Studied economics in Moscow. Worked as a foreign correspondent for the Finnish Broadcasting Company in Moscow and Washington from 1995 to 2004. Fluent in Swedish, Finnish, English, German, and Russian, with understanding of Flemish, Danish, and Norwegian. Elected to Helsinki City Council in 2008 and to the European Parliament in 2012, serving as vice-chair of the Fisheries committee and member of the committee for Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Opposed the Copyright Directive and supported Finland's NATO membership. Awarded the Order of the Lion of Finland in 2021 and the Environment and Climate Action Award in 2023. Author of books on Finnish-Russian economic strategy and Russian history.

Nils Ušakovs, born on 8 June 1976 in Riga, Latvia, is a Latvian politician who served as the Mayor of Riga from 2009 to 2019 and is currently a Member of the European Parliament. He was a naturalized citizen of Latvia in 1999, having previously held USSR citizenship and being stateless from 1991 to 1998. Ušakovs is fluent in Russian, English, and Latvian, with basic knowledge of Swedish, Danish, and German. He holds a bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Latvia and a candidatus oeconomices degree with specialization in European integration issues from the University of Southern Denmark. 

Ušakovs' career began as a journalist, working in various positions within Russian and Latvian-language media from 1998 to 2005. He was conferred the Cicero Award in 2004 for his contribution to journalism. In 2005, Ušakovs joined the National Harmony Party and became the leader of the Harmony Centre alliance. He was elected as a Saeima member in 2006 and served until 2009. 

As Mayor of Riga, Ušakovs held the post from 2009 to 2019, representing the Harmony Centre. During his tenure, he focused on strengthening ties with Russia, emphasizing education and protection of local industries. Ušakovs was also involved in several controversies, including the Zolitūde shopping centre roof collapse in 2013, for which he was criticized for not resigning. In 2019, he was suspended from his position as mayor due to at least eight legal and regulatory violations and later submitted his resignation.

Ušakovs has been a member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Budgets and being part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the United States and to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights.

Niyazi Kızılyürek, a Turkish Cypriot political scientist and politician, was born on 19 February 1959 in Potamia, Cyprus. He is a professor of political history at the University of Cyprus, specializing in the political history of Turkey and Cyprus, and the Dean of the School of Humanities. Kızılyürek has authored around 20 books, including Glafcos Clerides: The Path of a Country, and is a columnist in the Turkish Cypriot left-wing newspaper Yeni Düzen and the right-wing Greek Cypriot newspaper Simerini. He has command of five languages: Turkish, Greek, English, German, and French. Kızılyürek entered politics in 2019 as a candidate for the 2019 European Parliament election with the left-wing Progressive Party of Working People (AKEL) and was elected to the European Parliament with 25,051 votes. He is a member of the European Parliament for Cyprus, serving from 2 July 2019 to 16 July 2024, and is affiliated with the GUE-NGL party at the EU level.

Nora Mebarek, a French politician of the Socialist Party, born on 22 July 1972 in Port-Saint-Louis-du-Rhône, Bouches-du-Rhône, France. Member of the European Parliament since 1 February 2020, representing France. Serves on the Committee on Regional Development, and is part of the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe and the delegation for relations with the Mashreq countries. Signed a letter in 2021 urging against support for the Arctic LNG 2 project due to climate change concerns. Supported Anne Hidalgo in the 2022 presidential elections and endorsed Olivier Faure's re-election as party chairman in 2023. Re-elected as an MEP in 2024.

Norbert Lins, a German politician, born 22 December 1977 in Ravensburg, Baden-Württemberg, West Germany. He graduated from High School of Economics in Ravensburg in 1997, completed military service with the German Armed Forces in Sigmaringen, and studied at the University of Applied Sciences in Kehl and Ludwigsburg. He worked as head of office to Andreas Schwab at the European Parliament in Brussels from 2004 to 2009 and as a lecturer at Kehl University of Applied Sciences from 2006 to 2011. Lins was a personal assistant to Rudolf Köberle in the Ministry of Rural Areas and Consumer Protection Baden-Württemberg and held the Division for Broadband Funding in the Ministry of Rural Affairs and Consumer Protection of the Federal State of Baden-Württemberg from 2013. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Lins has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2014, serving on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and other delegations. He chaired the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development since 2019 and supports the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development and the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals. Lins publicly endorsed Friedrich Merz to succeed Angela Merkel as the party's chair in 2018.

Norbert Neuser, a German teacher and politician of the Social Democratic Party (SPD), served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2022, representing the constituency of Germany. He resigned from parliament in January 2022, succeeded by Karsten Lucke.

This is a politician profile for Nosheena Mobarik, Baroness Mobarik: 
A British Conservative politician and Life Peer, born 16 October 1957 in Glasgow to a Pakistani family. 
She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts with Honours in History from the University of Strathclyde in 1991. 
She was the founder of M Computer Technologies, an IT business solutions company. 
She held various positions including Member of the Business Advisory Forum of Glasgow Caledonian University, Member of the West Regional Advisory Board of Scottish Enterprise, Chairman of CBI Scotland, and chair of the Pakistan Britain Trade & Investment Forum. 
She was a founder of the Save the Bosnian People Campaign and director of the multi-faith charity Glasgow the Caring City. 
She was appointed to the Strathclyde Commission on future devolution in Scotland and joined the board of the Better Together Campaign. 
She was a Scottish Conservative Party candidate in the May 2014 European Parliament elections. 
She was appointed as a Conservative life peer in 2014 and served as a party whip and government whip. 
She served as a Member of European Parliament for Scotland from 2017 to 2020. 
She was appointed an Officer of the Order of the British Empire in 2004 and promoted to Commander in 2014. 
She was awarded the Tamgha-e-Imtiaz in 2012 and an honorary doctorate from the University of Edinburgh in 2013.

Nuno Melo, a Portuguese conservative politician, was born on March 18, 1966, in Joane, Vila Nova de Famalicão, Portugal. He is a lawyer and politician, married to Ana Melo, with two children. He graduated from Universidade Portucalense Infante D. Henrique. He has been a member of the CDS – People's Party since 1987. His political career includes being a member of the Assembly of the Republic from 1999 to 2009 and again in 2024, representing the Porto constituency. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, representing Portugal. He served on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. He was Vice President of the Assembly of the Republic from 2007 to 2009. He became the President of the CDS-PP in 2022, winning 73% of the votes. He was appointed as Minister of National Defence in the XXIV Constitutional Government in 2024.

Olivier Chastel, a Belgian politician, born on 22 November 1964 in Liège, Belgium. He is a pharmacist by profession and a member of the Liberal Party "Mouvement Réformateur" (MR). Chastel served as a city councillor in Charleroi from 1993 and as a member of the Parliament of Wallonia from 1998. He was a Federal Representative from 1999 to 2019, holding various positions such as Minister of Arts, Literature and Audiovisual Matters, State Secretary for European Affairs, Minister of Development Cooperation, and Minister for Budget and Administrative Simplification. Since 2019, Chastel has been a Member of the European Parliament, serving as a vice-chair of the Committee on Budgets and a member of several committees and delegations. He was the President of the Mouvement Réformateur from 2014 to 2019. Chastel has received several honors, including Knight in the Order of Leopold, Knight in the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana, Commander in the Order of Leopold II, Middle Cross with the star in the Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary, and Grand-Cross in the Order of Civil Merit of the Kingdom of Spain.

Ondřej Knotek, born on 31 August 1984, in Sušice, Czechoslovakia, is a Czech politician. He holds a degree from the University of Chemistry and Technology, Prague. Knotek initially worked as a quality manager in an engineering company in Tachov and served on the supervisory board of the Mariánské Lázně Hospital between 2015 and 2016. He was a member of the Czech Pirate Party from 2012 to 2015, then joined ANO 2011. Knotek was elected as a representative of Mariánské Lázně in 2014 and became a city councilor, but resigned in 2016. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, serving on the Committee on Regional Development and the Special Committee on Beating Cancer. In the 2024 European Parliament election, he defended his mandate as a member of ANO, receiving 8,565 preferential votes.

Ondřej Kovařík, a Czech politician, born on August 21, 1980, in Kyjov, Czechoslovakia, studied international trade and international affairs at the Prague University of Economics and Business. He is affiliated with the ANO 2011 movement and was nominated by the party as an independent candidate. He served as chief advisor of the parliamentary delegation of ANO in the European Parliament from October 2015 and as parliamentary assistant to MEP Dita Charanzová. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, re-elected in 2024, and serves on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and is part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with Canada.

Oriol Junqueras i Vies, born 11 April 1969 in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain, is a Catalan politician and historian. He is the president of the Republican Left of Catalonia (ERC) and was Vice President of Catalonia from January 2016 to October 2017. He was a member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2012 and a member of the Parliament of Catalonia for the Province of Barcelona from 2012 to 2018. He was also the Mayor of Sant Vicenç dels Horts from 2011 to 2015. He was imprisoned from 2017 to 2021 for his role in the 2017 Catalan independence referendum. He was pardoned by the Spanish government in 2021. He is married to Neus Bramona and has two children, Lluc and Joana. He is a Catholic and has a PhD in History of Economic Thought from the Autonomous University of Barcelona. He has written several books on Catalan history and economics.

Othmar Karas, born 24 December 1957 in Ybbs an der Donau, Austria, is an Austrian politician. He is a member of the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the European People's Party (EPP). Karas has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 1999, representing Austria. He has served on various committees, including the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect. 

Karas was educated at the University of Vienna, where he earned a Magister of Philosophy in political science (1996) and a Doctor of Philosophy in political science (2017). He also holds a Master of European and International Business Law (MBL) from the University of St. Gallen (1997). 

Before entering politics, Karas worked as a manager in the banking and insurance sector (since 1981). He has held various leadership positions within the ÖVP, including Federal Chairman of the Young ÖVP (1981-1990), Secretary-General of the ÖVP (1995-1999), and leader of the ÖVP delegation within the EPP group (2011-2019). 

Karas has been a vice president of the European Parliament since 2012 and was elected as First Vice-President on 18 January 2022. He is married to Dr. Christa Waldheim-Karas and has two children.

Pablo Arias Echeverría, a Spanish politician, born 30 June 1970 in Madrid, Spain, member of the People's Party and the European People's Party, served as assistant to Alejandro Agag from 2000 to 2002, and to Prime Minister José María Aznar in 2002, office manager for Aznar from 2004, management position at IESE Business School from 2008 to 2009, Member of the European Parliament for Spain from 2009 to 2014 and since 2019, serving on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and part of the parliament's delegation for relations with the United States.

Paola Ghidoni, an Italian politician and Member of the European Parliament for Lega Nord since 3 October 2022, representing North-East Italy, born 8 July 1963 in Montecchio Maggiore, Italy, replacing Mara Bizzotto.

Paolo Borchia, Italian politician and Member of the European Parliament, born 27 May 1980 in Negrar, Italy. He is a member of the League party. He holds a degree in political science from the University of Padua. He worked as an administration and production manager for his family's marble business and later as a consultant for a financial services company. He served as an accredited parliamentary assistant to Lorenzo Fontana MEP and as a political adviser to the Europe of Freedom and Nations (ENF) group. He was appointed as Head of the international Department "Lega nel Mondo" in 2018. He was elected to the European Parliament in 2019, representing the North-East Italy constituency. He is a coordinator of the "Identity and Democracy" group in the committee for Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly. He has been involved in various initiatives, including promoting the interests of Italian nationals abroad, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, and advocating for structural change within EU governance.

Paolo De Castro, born 2 February 1958 in San Pietro Vernotico, Italy, is an Italian politician and university professor. He graduated with a degree in Agricultural Science from the University of Bologna in 1980. De Castro has held various positions, including Minister of Agriculture, Food and Forestry Policies in the D'Alema I, D'Alema II, and Prodi II cabinets, and Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy and North-East Italy. He is a member of the Democratic Party and has previously been affiliated with The Democrats and The Daisy. De Castro has also served as professor of Agricultural Economics at the Veterinary Medicine University of Bologna and has chaired the Nomisma Economics Studies Institute and the Qualivita Foundation. He is married with two sons.

Pascal Arimont, a Belgian politician, born 25 September 1974 in Malmedy, is a member of the Christian Social Party (CSP), part of the EPP Group. He represents the German-speaking electoral college of Belgium in the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, succeeding Mathieu Grosch. Arimont serves on the Committee on Regional Development and the Committee on Legal Affairs, and is part of the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. He is also a member of delegations for relations with Central America and the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, as well as the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals.

Pascal Canfin, born August 22, 1974, in Arras, France. Education: Bordeaux Institute of Political Studies, Newcastle University. Career: Journalist for Alternatives économiques, human resources consultant, representative of the French Democratic Confederation of Labour trade union. Politician for The Greens, Europe Ecology – The Greens, La République En Marche. Member of the European Parliament (2009-2012, 2019-present), Minister for Development (2012-2014). Former head of the French section of WWF, Senior Advisor on Climate at World Resources Institute. Chair of the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee. Advocate for climate action, sustainable development, and environmental protection. Author of several books on economics, ecology, and climate change.

Pascal Durand, a French lawyer and politician, born on October 3, 1960, in Montreuil, France. He served as national secretary of Europe Ecology – The Greens from June 23, 2012, to November 30, 2013, succeeding Cécile Duflot and preceding Emmanuelle Cosse. Durand was a member of Europe Ecology – The Greens from 2010 to 2016 and joined La République En Marche in 2019. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since July 1, 2014, representing the constituency of France, and his term is set to end on July 15, 2024. Durand has served on several committees, including the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, Committee on Legal Affairs, Committee on Budgetary Control, Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion. He has also been part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty, the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group, the MEPs Against Cancer group, and the Spinelli Group. Notably, Durand authored an own-initiative report on the extension of product lifetime in 2017 and served as lead rapporteur on the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive in 2022. He voted against the Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market in 2019 and has expressed concerns about climate change, specifically opposing the Arctic LNG 2 project in 2021.

Patricia Caro Maya, a Spanish psychologist, feminist activist, and politician from Podemos, born in 1982 in Arles, France, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 30 November 2023, succeeding Sira Rego.

Patricia Chagnon, a French politician from the National Rally, born on 20 November 1963, of Dutch origin, fluent in English and Dutch. Held the office of Member of the European Parliament from 29 July 2022 to 15 July 2024. Served as regional councillor for the Hauts-de-France region from 2015 to 2021. Was an opposition municipal councilor for Abbeville and a community councilor for the Communauté d'agglomération de la Baie de Somme since 2014. President of the Abbeville Tourist Office, previously sentenced to a fine and ineligibility for moral harassment, later had the ineligibility canceled. Was a candidate in the 2019 European Parliament election and nominated by the RN to contest Saint Pierre and Miquelon's 1st constituency in the 2024 French legislative election, despite not being from the territory.

Patrick Breyer, Pirate Party Germany politician, born 29 April 1977 in Frankfurt am Main, West Germany. Studied law, awarded Doctorate of Law in 2004. Judge in Schleswig-Holstein from 2004. Founding member of Pirate Party Germany in 2006. Member of Schleswig-Holstein state parliament from 2012 to 2017, leader of Pirate group from 2012 to 2013 and 2016 to 2017. Member of European Parliament for Germany since 2019, part of Greens–European Free Alliance group. Involved in various legal proceedings concerning digital civil rights, including data retention and government access to telecommunications subscriber data. Filed lawsuits against European Commission and Federal Republic of Germany on issues such as data retention and compulsory identification of prepaid SIM cards. Criticized vending machine industry for donations to politicians and revealed accusations of misogynistic behavior by police cadets. Awarded "Backbone Prize" in 2017 for efforts. Ran for European Parliament in 2019, elected as only member of German Pirate Party. Alternate member of European Parliament Committee on Legal Affairs and member of Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Did not run for office in 2024 European elections.

Patrizia Toia, Italian politician, born 17 March 1950 in Pogliano Milanese, Italy, occupation: political scientist, education: graduate in political science from University of Milan, specialised in strategic planning from Bocconi University, Milan, party affiliation: Christian Democracy (1975-1994), Italian People's Party (1994-2002), Democracy is Freedom – The Daisy (2002-2007), Democratic Party (since 2007), current office: Member of European Parliament for North-West Italy since 13 June 2004, past offices: Minister for European Affairs (22 December 1999 - 26 April 2000), Minister for Parliamentary Relations (26 April 2000 - 11 June 2001), Member of the Chamber of Deputies (29 June 1995 - 8 May 1996), Member of the Senate (8 May 1996 - 13 June 2004), Municipal Councillor of Vanzago (1975-1985), Member of Lombardy Regional Council (1985-1995), Member of Regional Executive with responsibility for coordination of social services, health, and budget, Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Minister for Community Policies, Minister for Relations with Parliament, committee assignments: Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Delegation to the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee, Delegation to the EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, MEP Heart Group, MEPs Against Cancer group, European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer, European Parliament Intergroup on Integrity, European Parliament Intergroup on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights, European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights.

Patryk Jaki, a Polish politician, was born on 11 May 1985 in Opole, Poland. He is a member of the European Parliament, former Secretary of State in the Ministry of Justice, and former First Deputy Attorney General. He is married to Anna Kuszkiewicz and has two children, Radosław and Aleksandra. Radosław was born with Down syndrome in 2014. He earned a Master of Arts in political science from the University of Wrocław and a Doctor of Philosophy degree from the War Studies Academy. He has been a member of the Sovereign Poland party since 2013, previously affiliated with Law and Justice and Civic Platform. He has held various positions, including Chairman of the Verification Committee for Reprivatisation, Plenipotentiary of the Minister of Justice for the Implementation of the Electronic Monitoring System, and chairman of the Team for the Protection of Family Autonomy and Family Life in the Ministry of Justice. He initiated the establishment of the Verification Committee for Reprivatisation and the registry of sex offenders in Poland. He is also responsible for the "Save the Heroes" campaign and the legislation initiative "Let's Restore History Lessons at Schools".

Paul Tang, a Dutch economist and politician, born on April 23, 1967, in Haarlem, Netherlands. He studied economics at the University of Amsterdam, graduating cum laude in 1991 and earning a doctorate in Economic Sciences in 2000. Tang worked at the Central Planning Bureau from 1995 to 2005 and later at the Ministry of Economic Affairs. He was a member of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands from 2007 to 2010 and a member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, representing the Labour Party. Tang was the leader of the PvdA delegation in the S&D group and served on several committees, including Economic and Monetary Affairs, Budget, and Industry, Research and Energy. He was rapporteur for several legislation initiatives, including Simple Transparent and Standardized securitization, European Common Corporate Tax Base, and Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation. Tang was also involved in the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act negotiations. He is married with two sons and has been a supporter of the football club AZ Alkmaar. Tang is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and has been the chairman of the Subcommittee on Taxation (FISC) in the European Parliament.

Paulo Artur dos Santos Castro de Campos Rangel, born 18 February 1968, is a Portuguese jurist and politician of the Social Democratic Party. He was Minister of Foreign Affairs since 2024, Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, and treasurer of the European People's Party. Rangel was educated at the Portuguese Catholic University. He has been a member of the Social Democratic Party since 2005 and previously a member of the CDS – People's Party from 1996 to 1999. Rangel has served on various committees, including the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and Working Group on the Conference on the Future of Europe. He has also been a member of several delegations, including the ACP–EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly and the delegations for relations with the United States, Brazil, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, and Montenegro. Rangel has held various leadership positions, including vice-president of the European People's Party Group and chairman of the Working Group on EPP Membership. He has been a vocal advocate for LGBTQ+ rights, publicly coming out as gay in 2021.

Pedro Manuel Dias de Jesus Marques, born August 1, 1976, in Lisbon, Portugal, is a Portuguese politician of the Socialist Party who served as Member of the European Parliament from July 1, 2019, until July 15, 2024, representing Portugal. He was vice-president for the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament. Marques previously served as Secretary of State for Social Security from 2005 to 2011 and as Minister of Planning and Infrastructure in the government of Prime Minister António Costa from November 26, 2015, to February 18, 2019. He holds a bachelor's degree in economics from the Lisbon School of Economics and Management and a master's degree in International Economics. Marques was a councilor of the Municipality of Montijo, a deputy to the Assembly of the Republic for the constituencies of Setúbal and Portalegre, and worked in the private sector for companies such as CISED Consultores and Capgemini Portugal. In the European Parliament, he was a member of the committees AFET, ECON, and FISC, and the Delegation for Relations with the Maghreb Countries, India, and other countries.

Pedro Silva Pereira, born 15 August 1962, Portuguese politician, lawyer, and legal expert. Education: Master's degree in Law from the University of Lisbon. Member of the Socialist Party since 2000. Career: Member of the European Parliament (2014-2024), Vice-President of the European Parliament (2019-2024), Minister of the Presidency (2005-2011), Secretary of State of Spatial Planning and Nature Conservation (1999-2002), Member of the Portuguese Parliament (2002-2014). Committee assignments: Committee on Constitutional Affairs, Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Committee on Development, Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe, Parliament's delegation for relations with Japan. Awards: Order of the Rising Sun (2019).

Pernando Barrena, a Basque politician from Spain, born on 1 November 1965 in Pamplona, Navarre, with a Técnico Superior qualification in international trade and a degree in international relations. He is a translator by profession, worked at Txalaparta publishing house, and has been a member of various Basque nationalist parties, including Herri Batasuna, Batasuna, Sortu, and EH Bildu. He was a municipal councillor in Berriozar from 1984 to 1999, a member of the Parliament of Navarre from 1999 to 2003, and a member of the European Parliament for Spain from 2019 to 2022. He has been arrested multiple times for alleged links to the separatist organization ETA and for supporting the activity of an illegal political party. His term as a member of the European Parliament started on 2 July 2019 and ended on 2 September 2022.

Pernille Weiss, a Danish politician and businesswoman, born on 12 March 1968 in Gamborg, Middelfart, Denmark. She is the chief executive officer (CEO) of Archimed, a healthcare and architectural consultancy. Weiss is a member of the Conservative People's Party and was elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in the 2019 European parliamentary election in Denmark. She serves on the Committee on Industry, Research, and Energy and is part of the EPP group. Weiss has been married twice and has three children. Her priorities in the parliament include strengthening the European Union's energy and climate policy, and controls on immigration. She has a background in nursing and forensic nursing, and holds degrees from the Odense School of Nursing, University of Southern Denmark, and Copenhagen Business School. Weiss is also a certified sexologist. She has been involved in controversies, including an internal investigation that uncovered reports of bullying in her office, which led to the Conservative People's Party deciding not to nominate her as a candidate for the 2024 European Parliament election.

Petar Vitanov is a Bulgarian politician and member of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, serving as a Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024. He was born on 18 April 1982 in Sliven, Bulgaria, and graduated from Sofia University. Vitanov is a strong advocate for social mobility, equality, and environmental protection. He has expressed opposition to the Denkov Government, the proposed change of the national holiday from the 3d of March to 24 May, and the equalisation of Communism and Fascism in terms of guilt for the Second World War. Vitanov has also encouraged Bulgarians to vaccinate using the COVID-19 vaccine and supported the exemption made for Bulgaria in the 6th Anti-Russian Sanctions packet. He has called for greater cooperation between the nations of Greece, Bulgaria, and Romania within the EU and has opposed the continuation of the Mechanism for Cooperation and Verification. Vitanov has voted in favour of imposing sanctions on the Russian Federation but opposes the sending of lethal aid or the closing down of diplomatic channels with Russia. He has also expressed support for the implementation of a 30 km/h speed limit in residential areas and stricter punishments for driving under the influence. Vitanov was expelled from the Bulgarian Socialist Party in February 2023 but was restored as a member in June 2024.

Peter Jahr is a German politician born on 24 April 1959 in Burgstädt, Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Jahr studied agricultural science at the University of Leipzig, graduating with a Diplom-Landwirt in 1984 and a doctorate in 1988. He worked as a research assistant and later as an administrator before becoming a manager and a sideline farmer. Jahr was a member of the Landtag of Saxony from 1990 to 2002 and the German Bundestag from 2002 to 2009. He served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, where he was part of the Committee on Petitions, Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and Committee on Regional Development. Jahr was also a member of the Delegation to the EU-Armenia, EU-Azerbaijan and EU-Georgia Parliamentary Cooperation Committees and the Delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. He is married with four children. Jahr publicly endorsed Friedrich Merz for the Christian Democrats' leadership election in 2018 and was part of the working group on agriculture in the coalition government negotiations in 2017. He announced his resignation from active politics in 2024.

Peter Kofod Hristov, a Danish politician, was born on 27 February 1990 in Snogebæk, Denmark, son of a blacksmith and nurse. He graduated from the Signal Regiment in 2010 and worked as a primary school teacher in Haderslev. Kofod served as a city councillor in Haderslev Municipality from 2014, and in the regional council for Southern Denmark from 2014-2015. He represented the Danish People's Party and was a Member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2019 to 14 November 2022 for the Denmark constituency. Kofod served in the Folketing from June 2015 to June 2019 and again from 15 November 2022 for the South Jutland constituency, receiving 3,887 person votes. He married Vasileva in 2018, adopting the surname Hristov, but did not use it in political contexts, and they agreed to divorce on 10 November 2022.

Peter Liese, a German physician and politician, born on May 20, 1965, in Olsberg, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. He has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 1, 1994, representing Germany. Liese is a graduate in medicine from the University of Bonn and worked as a ward doctor and general practitioner before entering politics. He is known for his conservative stance on stem cell research and his work on a human cells and tissues directive. Liese has held various positions within the European Parliament, including coordinator for the European People's Party Group on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. He has also been involved in national politics, serving as a member of the CDU leadership and participating in coalition negotiations. Liese is a member of several organizations, including the Central Committee of German Catholics and the German Industry Initiative for Energy Efficiency.

Kent Peter Lundgren, a Swedish politician, born on 2 February 1963, in Bjuv, Sweden. He was a member of the Sweden Democrats until 2022 and then became an independent politician. Lundgren served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, representing Sweden. He was a Vice-Chair of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group from 2019 to 2022, alongside Roberts Zīle, Assita Kanko, Derk Jan Eppink, and Hermann Tertsch. Lundgren's previous occupation was as a truck driver, and he was a member of the executive board of the Sweden Democrats since 2013. He was convicted of sexual assault in 2021 and sentenced to a 60-day fine.

Peter Pollák, a Slovak politician of Romani origin, born on 20 April 1973 in Levoča, Czechoslovakia, educated at the Catholic University in Ružomberok. He has served as a Member of the European Parliament for the OĽaNO party, representing Slovakia from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, and as a Member of the National Council of the Slovak Republic from 4 April 2012 to 23 March 2016.

Peter van Dalen, a Dutch politician, was born on 3 September 1958 in Zwijndrecht, Netherlands. He is a member of the Christian Union and the European People's Party. Van Dalen served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands constituency from 14 July 2009 to 3 September 2023. He is married to Corry van Dalen and has three children. Van Dalen was educated at Utrecht University, where he studied History and International Relations. He is a "Euro-realist" who believes in European cooperation but opposes a bureaucratic "superstate" and Turkish membership in the EU. Van Dalen is also opposed to secularisation, which he believes is the biggest threat to Europe. He is a member of the Protestant Church in the Netherlands and lives in Houten, Utrecht.

Petra De Sutter, Belgian politician, Deputy Prime Minister of Belgium since 1 October 2020, Minister of Civil Service since 1 October 2020, Member of the European Parliament for Belgium from 2 July 2019 to 30 September 2020, Member of the Belgian Senate from 3 July 2014 to 29 March 2019, born 10 June 1963 in Oudenaarde, Belgium, female, trans woman, Groen party, Ghent University alumni, professor of gynaecology, head of the Department of Reproductive Medicine at Ghent University Hospital, married with 1 child.

Petra Kammerevert, a German politician, was born on June 1, 1966, in Duisburg, Germany. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Kammerevert studied sociology and political science at the University of Duisburg-Essen. She worked as a scientific adviser to a Member of the European Parliament from 1992 to 2002 and as a consultant for the ARD public service broadcasting company from 2002 to 2009. Kammerevert has been a member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the North Rhine-Westphalia constituency. She is a member of the Committee on Culture and Education and has served as its chairwoman from 2017 to 2019. Kammerevert is also a substitute member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the EU-Croatia Joint Parliamentary Committee. She is married and lives in Düsseldorf.

Petras Auštrevičius, a Lithuanian politician, born on May 16, 1963, in Juodšiliai, Lithuanian SSR, Soviet Union. He is married to Gintarė Auštrevičienė and has two children. Auštrevičius graduated from Vilnius Secondary School No. 39 in 1981, received a degree in Economics from Vilnius University in 1986, and completed a diplomat-training program at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University in 1993. He worked as a Junior Research Fellow at the Institute of Economics from 1988 to 1991 and held various positions in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, including Senior Specialist, First Secretary, and Head of the Nordic States Division. Auštrevičius served as Lithuania's Ambassador to Finland from 1994 to 1997 and became the youngest ambassador in Lithuanian history at the age of 31. He was a member of the Seimas from 2004 to 2014 and has been a member of the European Parliament since 2014, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and as the standing rapporteur for Belarus since 2019. Auštrevičius is a member of the Liberal Movement and has been affiliated with the Liberal and Centre Union. He has received several awards, including the Cross of Commander of the Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas, the Medal to commemorate Lithuania's membership of the EU and NATO, the Order of Honor of Georgia, and the Order of Merit of Ukraine, Third Class.

Petri Ilari Sarvamaa, born 15 September 1960 in Joensuu, Finland, is a Finnish politician and Orthodox Christian, who served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2012 to 2024. He is a member of the National Coalition Party and the European People's Party. Sarvamaa was educated at the University of Helsinki. He is divorced since 2021. Before his political career, he worked as a journalist at Finland's national broadcasting company Yle. He served on the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the Committee on Budgets, and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. He supports the MEP Alliance for Mental Health, the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption. In 2019, he drafted legislation on cutting EU funds to member states that undermine the rule of law. He received the Agriculture, Fisheries and Rural Development Award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2022. He was ranked as one of the 15 most influential MEPs in the 2014-19 legislature by VoteWatch. In June 2024, he began his term at the European Court of Auditors.

Petros S. Kokkalis, Greek, born 26 February 1970 in Athens, Greece, is a businessman and member of the European Parliament for Greece. He holds a B.A. in history from Hampshire College and an M.P.A. from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. He has served as Vice-President and shareholder of Intracom Holdings and Intralot S.A., Vice-President of Olympiacos football club, and Vice-President of the Kokkalis Foundation. He is Secretary General of Organization Earth. He was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 as a member of Syriza but left the party in November 2023 and joined Kosmos. His term in the European Parliament started on 2 July 2019 and is set to end on 16 July 2024.

Phil Bennion, a British Liberal Democrat politician, was born on October 7, 1954, in Tamworth, Staffordshire, England. He was educated at Queen Elizabeth Grammar School, the University of Aberdeen, Newcastle University, and the University of Birmingham, where he studied agriculture, agronomy, history, and economic history. Bennion worked as a farmer and advised Charles Kennedy on agricultural issues during his leadership of the Liberal Democrats. He served on the party's federal policy committee for eight years and was a councillor on Lichfield District Council from 1999 to 2011 and on Staffordshire County Council from 2002 to 2005. Bennion was a Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands from 2012 to 2014 and again from 2019 to 2020. He sat on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Sub-Committee on Human Rights, and acted as a substitute on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

Philippe Lamberts, a Belgian politician, born on 14 March 1963, in Brussels, Belgium, educated as an engineer at the University of Louvain (UCLouvain) in 1986, worked at IBM from 1987 to 2009, and served as a councillor for the French-speaking Green Party Ecolo in Anderlecht from 1994 to 2006. He was an adviser to the Vice-Prime Minister Isabelle Durant on foreign affairs and defence from 1999 to 2003. Lamberts has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the Ecolo party since 2009, co-spokesperson of the European Green Party from 2006 to 2012, and leader of the Greens–European Free Alliance in the European Parliament since 2014. He is a member of the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), known for his amendment to the Fourth Capital Requirements Directive and his advocacy for a new approach to growth, inspired by his Christian faith, and has been part of the Parliament's Brexit Steering Group and the European Internet Forum.

Philippe Olivier, a French politician, was born on August 30, 1961, in Juvisy-sur-Orge, Essonne, France. He is a lawyer by profession and graduated from Paris-Est Créteil University. Olivier has been a member of the National Rally party since 2016, with previous affiliations including the National Republican Movement from 1998-2000. He was a member of the Regional Council of Île-de-France from March 27, 1992, to March 28, 2004. Olivier was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024, representing the France constituency. He is married to Marie-Caroline Le Pen, sister of French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen, and has four children. Olivier previously ran in the 2017 French parliamentary election in Pas-de-Calais's 7th constituency but was defeated.

Pierfrancesco Majorino, Italian politician, born May 14, 1973, in Milan, Italy, served as assessor of social policies of Milan from 2011 to 2019, Member of the European Parliament for North-West Italy from July 2, 2019, to April 4, 2023, member of the Committee on Development, the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, the European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty, the European Parliament Intergroup on Trade Unions, and the URBAN Intergroup, affiliated with the Democrats of the Left (until 2007) and the Democratic Party (since 2007), candidate for regional president in the 2023 Lombard regional election, supported by the centre-left Democratic Party and the Five Star Movement.

Piernicola Pedicini, born 22 May 1969 in Benevento, Italian politician and member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing Southern Italy, affiliated with the August 24th Movement since 2021, previously with the Five Star Movement from 2013 to 2020 and Independent from 2020 to 2021, member of the Greens/EFA group since December 2020, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, educated at the University of Naples Federico II, occupation as a Researcher.

Pierre Karleskind, a French oceanographer and politician, born on 19 October 1979, with French nationality. He is a member of La République En Marche! (LREM) since 2016, previously a member of the Socialist Party (PS) from 2005 to 2016. He holds degrees from École Polytechnique and European University Institute of the Sea. Karleskind has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019, and as a Member of the Regional Council of Brittany since 17 December 2015. He has been on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Fisheries, becoming the chairman of the latter in 2020. Additionally, he is part of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. Karleskind has been involved in initiatives such as referring the police's mass arrest of LGBT activists in Poland to the European Commission and urging the EU to take measures to end British water treatment facilities' discharges of raw sewage into shared waters. He was awarded a "Rising Star" award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in March 2024.

Pierre Larrouturou, a French economist and politician, born on 19 September 1964 in Périgueux, France, member of the Socialist Party, served as a Member of the European Parliament for France from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, previously a regional councilor of the Île-de-France, married with two children, known for advocating a four-day workweek in France, served on the Committee on Budgets, rapporteur on the EU budget for 2021, member of the Spinelli Group and the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, went on hunger strike in 2020 to demand a financial transaction tax and protest against budget plans downgrading health, research, and climate change programs, sanctioned in 2019 for allowing misbehaving visitors in the European Parliament, opposed renting office space for the European Parliament in Strasbourg in 2023 due to budgetary constraints.

Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana, a German-Malian politician, born on March 20, 1949, in Bamako, Mali, and grew up in Senegal. She holds citizenship in Germany. Herzberger-Fofana is a member of Alliance 90/The Greens and has been a member of the European Parliament since July 1, 2019, representing the constituency of Germany. She serves on the Committee on Development as one of four vice-chairs and is part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the Pan-African Parliament and to the CARIFORUM-EU Parliamentary Committee. She also co-chairs the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup. Herzberger-Fofana has a background in German sociolinguistics, with a degree from Paris and a further degree from the University of Trier, as well as a doctorate from the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg. She has three children and has written several books, including Écrivains africains et identités culturelles, Litterature feminine francophone d'Afrique noire, Die Nacht des Baobab, and Berlin 125 Jahre danach.

Pietro Bartolo, a medical doctor and politician from Italy, born on 10 February 1956 in Lampedusa e Linosa. He is married with three children. He graduated as a medical surgeon from the University of Catania and specialized in gynecology. From 1988 to 2007, he was a town councillor in Lampedusa e Linosa and vice mayor and health councillor of the municipality of Pelagie from 1988 to 1993. He was the responsible medician for first visits to migrants who landed in Lampedusa from 1992 to 2019. He was appointed coordinator of all health activities in the Pelagian Islands in 2011. He took part in the documentary film Fire at Sea and is a supporter of the reception of immigrants and asylum seekers. He was a member of Solidary Democracy from 2019 to 2023 and is currently a member of the Democratic Party. He was elected as a member of the European Parliament in 2019 for the Italian Islands constituency and is vice-chairman of the European Parliament Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. He is also a member of several intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer and the European Parliament Intergroup on Fighting against Poverty. He voted against the European Parliament resolution recognizing the Russian Federation as a state sponsor of terrorism in 2022.

Pietro Fiocchi, Italian politician and entrepreneur, born on 22 May 1964 in Milan, Italy, with 2 children, graduated in aerospace engineering from the University of Missouri, served in the Italian Navy from 1990 to 1992, worked at Ravasi Robotics, Fiocchi Munizioni, Fiocchi of America, and Target, elected as a member of the European Parliament for the North-West Italy constituency on 2 July 2019, representing the Brothers of Italy party.

Pilar del Castillo Vera, a Spanish politician, born on 31 July 1952 in Nador, Spanish protectorate in Morocco. Education: Law graduate at Complutense University of Madrid, 1974; Master's degree in political science at Ohio State University, United States, 1980; PhD in law from Complutense University of Madrid, 1983. Career: Assistant professor in constitutional law at UNED, 1986; Professor in political science and administration, 1994; Editor-in-chief of the Journal Nueva Revista de Política, Cultura y Arte, 1995-1996; Director of the Spanish Sociological Research Centre, 1996-2000. Political career: Minister of Education, Culture and Sport, 2000-2004; Member of the European Parliament, 2004-present. Party affiliation: People's Party (2000-present), previously OCE-BR (1970-1974). Committee assignments: Coordinator for the Group of the European People's Party in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy; Substitute member in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Other positions: Chairwoman of the European Internet Foundation; Member of the European Energy Forum, European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, Transatlantic Policy Network, and Knowledge4Innovation. Personal life: Married to Guillermo Gortázar, with two children.

Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner, a Finnish politician and Member of the European Parliament, born on 6 February 1957 in Hyvinkää, Finland. She is a member of the Finns Party and the European Conservatives and Reformists. Ruohonen-Lerner was educated at the University of Helsinki. Her political career includes being a member of the council of the municipality of Myrskylä from 1985 to 1988, initially with the National Coalition Party, and a member of the council of the city of Porvoo since 1996. She served as a member of the Finnish Parliament from 21 March 2007 to 6 May 2015, and as the chair of the party's parliamentary group from 2011 to 2014. Ruohonen-Lerner was first elected to the European Parliament on 27 April 2015, succeeding Sampo Terho, and served until 1 July 2019. She returned to the European Parliament on 11 April 2023, following the resignation of Laura Huhtasaari, representing the constituency of Finland.

Predrag Fred Matić, a centre-left Croatian politician, born on 2 June 1962 in Požega, Croatia, died on 23 August 2024. He graduated with a B.A. in education from the University of Osijek. Matić served in the Croatian Armed Forces during the Croatian War of Independence, was captured in 1991, and held in Serbian concentration camps for nine months. He was awarded numerous medals and military decorations, including the Order of Duke Domagoj, Order of Nikola Šubić Zrinski, Order of the Croatian Cross, Order of the Croatian Trefoil, and Order of the Croatian Interlace. 

Matić held various political offices, including Minister of Veterans' Affairs from 2011 to 2016, Member of the Croatian Parliament, and Member of the European Parliament from 2019 until his death. He was a member of the Social Democratic Party of Croatia and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Matić was married to Svetlana Patković, with whom he had one child.

Pär Anders Holmgren, a male MEP from Sweden, born on 24 October 1964 in Gävle, Sweden, member of the Green Party and Greens-European Free Alliance, former meteorologist, served as weather reporter for SVT from 1988 to 2008, holds an honorary doctorate from Uppsala University, worked for the Swedish Air Force and insurance company Länsförsäkringar, joined politics in 2018, elected to European Parliament in 2019, serving on Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee delegation.

Radan Kanev, a Bulgarian politician, was born on 30 September 1975 in Sofia. He is a member of the DSB party and the European People's Party. Kanev graduated from the Lycée Français de Sofia and Sofia University with a degree in law. He served as the chairman of the youth organization of the Bulgarian Red Cross in the 1990s and became involved in politics in 2004. Kanev led the DSB party from 2013 to 2017 and was a Member of the National Assembly from 2014 to 2017. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019 and re-elected in 2024. Kanev is married with one child. He has been a vocal critic of Bulgaria's Prime Minister Boyko Borisov and has advocated for the European Greens to be part of the governing majority in the European Parliament. Kanev has also called for unity regarding Bulgaria's foreign policy despite political differences.

Radka Maxová, a Czech politician and Member of the European Parliament, born on 2 December 1968 in Pardubice, Czechoslovakia, educated at the University of Chemistry and Technology, Prague. She was elected to the European Parliament in 2019, representing the Czech Republic constituency. Her term started on 2 July 2019 and is set to end on 15 July 2024. Maxová initially belonged to the ANO 2011 party from 2012 to 2020, then joined the Czech Social Democratic Party in 2020. She serves as the vice-chair of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, is a member of the Special Committee on foreign interference in all democratic processes in the European Union, including disinformation, and a substitute of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Additionally, she is part of the Parliament's delegations to the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee, the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, and the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Association Committee. Maxová is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on Disability, and a supporter of the MEP Alliance for Mental Health.

Radosław Sikorski: 
Polish politician and journalist, born 23 February 1963 in Bydgoszcz, Poland. 
Education: Pembroke College, Oxford, Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Politics and Economics. 
Citizenship: Polish, previously held British citizenship from 1987 to 2006. 
Party affiliation: Civic Platform (since 2007), previously affiliated with Law and Justice (2005-2007). 
Spouse: Anne Applebaum, married on 27 June 1992. 
Children: 2 sons, Aleksander (born 1997) and Tadeusz (born 2000). 
Career: 
- Journalist for The Observer, The Spectator, and National Review (1985-1992). 
- Deputy Minister of National Defence (1992). 
- Undersecretary of State at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (1998-2001). 
- Resident fellow of the American Enterprise Institute (2002-2005). 
- Minister of National Defence (2005-2007). 
- Minister of Foreign Affairs (2007-2014, 2023-present). 
- Member of the European Parliament (2019-2023). 
- Marshal of the Sejm (2014-2015). 
Honors and awards: 
- Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany. 
- Member 1st Class of the Order of Merit, Ukraine. 
- Grand Officer of the Legion of Honour, France. 
- Knight of Freedom Award. 
- Listed among the "Top 100 Global Thinkers 2012" by Foreign Policy.

Rafał Romanowski, a Polish politician, born on 15 February 1978 in Ciechanów, Poland, representing the Law and Justice party, with a background in journalism and public relations, and a PhD in social sciences. He served as Undersecretary of State at the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development from 2007, 2015-2020, and 2021-2022, and as Secretary of State from 2022-2023. He was a member of the Sejm from 2019-2023 and became a Member of the European Parliament in November 2023, replacing Zbigniew Kuźmiuk, and joined the European Conservatives and Reformists group.

Raffaele Fitto, born August 28, 1969, in Maglie, Italy, studied at the University of Bari. He is married to Adriana Panzera and has three children. Fitto has been a member of multiple political parties, including Christian Democracy (DC), Italian People's Party (PPI), United Christian Democrats (CDU), Christian Democrats for Freedom (CDL), Forza Italia (FI), The People of Freedom (PdL), Conservatives and Reformists (CoR), Direction Italy (DI), and Brothers of Italy (FdI) since 2019. He has held various offices, including President of Apulia from 2000 to 2005, Minister for Regional Affairs and Territorial Cohesion from 2008 to 2011 under Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and Minister for European Affairs and Minister for the South and Cohesion Policies since 2022 under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni. Fitto was a member of the European Parliament from 1999 to 2000 and again from 2014 to 2022, and a member of the Chamber of Deputies from 2006 to 2014 and again since 2022. He was investigated and tried for bribery and corruption related to the Italian public health care system and the bankruptcy of Cedis, but was ultimately acquitted of all charges.

Raffaele Stancanelli, born 30 June 1950 in Regalbuto, Italy, is an Italian politician and lawyer who graduated in Law from the University of Catania. He has been affiliated with the Italian Social Movement (MSI), National Alliance (AN), The People of Freedom (PdL), Brothers of Italy (FdI), Diventerà Bellissima (DB), and Lega per Salvini Premier (Lega). His political career includes being municipal councilor in Regalbuto (1978-1983) and Catania (1985-1992), a member of the Sicilian Regional Assembly (1996-2008), Councilor for Labor, Vocational Training, Social Security and Emigration (2001-2004), Councilor for the Family, Social Policies and Local Autonomies (2004-2006), vicar vice-president of the Sicilian Regional Assembly (2006-2008), Senator (2008-2011, 2018-2019), mayor of Catania (2008-2013), and Member of the European Parliament (2019-present) representing the Italian Islands constituency.

Rainer Wieland, a German politician, born on 19 February 1957 in Stuttgart, West Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. Wieland studied law at the University of Tübingen and the University of Heidelberg. He is a lawyer and founding partner of the law firm "Theumer, Wieland & Weisenburger" in Stuttgart. Wieland is married and has two children. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 1997, representing Germany, and has been one of its vice-presidents since 2009. His area of responsibility includes the Stuttgart administrative district. Wieland is president of the non-partisan Europa-Union Deutschland. He is a member of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, the Committee on Budgets, and the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Wieland has been chairman of the CDU Ludwigsburg since 1993 and is a member of the presidium of CDU Baden-Württemberg. He has received several awards, including the Federal Cross of Merit with ribbon, honorary citizenship of the Kosovar city of Drenas, and the Order of Merit of the State of Baden-Württemberg.

Ralf Seekatz, a German politician, born on 9 May 1967 in Dernbach, Westerwaldkreis, West Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) in Germany and the European People's Party in the EU. Seekatz served as mayor of Westerburg from 2007 to 2019 and was a member of the Landtag of Rhineland-Palatinate from 2006 to 2019, where he held roles on the Committee on Internal Affairs and the Committee on European Affairs. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and as part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with India, representing the constituency of Germany.

Ramona Strugariu, a Romanian politician from REPER and previously USR PLUS/USR, born on August 6, 1979, in Bârlad, Vaslui County, Romania, educated at Alexandru Ioan Cuza University, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Romania since 2019, on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, rapporteur on the European Media Freedom Act since 2023, part of the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly delegation, member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Anti-Corruption, LGBT Rights, and the MEPs Against Cancer group, co-signer of a 2021 letter to the European Commission regarding EU nationals in UK immigration removal centers.

Raphaël Glucksmann, a French politician, was born on 15 October 1979 in Boulogne-Billancourt, France. He is the son of philosopher André Glucksmann and Françoise Glucksmann. Glucksmann is a member of the European Parliament, representing the constituency of France since 2 July 2019, and is affiliated with the Place Publique party. He was previously an adviser to the President of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, from 2005 to 2012. Glucksmann was married to Eka Zguladze, with whom he has a son, and is currently in a relationship with journalist Léa Salamé, with whom he has another son, Gabriel. He is an alumnus of Sciences Po. Glucksmann has focused on issues such as human rights, labor exploitation, and climate change, and has led public campaigns to raise awareness and enact legislation. He has also been a strong proponent for deepened cooperation with Taiwan. In 2024, he led the list “Réveiller l'Europe”, an alliance of his own Place publique party and the historical Parti socialiste, which obtained 13.83% of the national votes.

Rareș Bogdan, a conservative Romanian politician, born on 17 September 1974 in Ocna Mureș, Alba County, Romania, with a father who was a local councillor and a member of the Social Democracy Party of Romania. He is a member of the National Liberal Party and the European People's Party, identifying as a Christian-conservative and nationalist, educated at Babeș-Bolyai University, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Romania since 2 July 2019.

Rasa Juknevičienė is a Lithuanian politician and paediatrician, born on 26 January 1958 in Tiltagaliai, Lithuanian SSR, Soviet Union. She is a member of the center-right Homeland Union party. Juknevičienė is a graduate of the Lithuanian University of Health Sciences and worked as a doctor until 1992. She has been a member of the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas) from 1996 to 2019, serving as Deputy Speaker of the Seimas, Deputy Chair of the Committee on National Security and Defense, and Head of the Seimas Delegation to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly.
