She was the Minister of National Defence of Lithuania from 2008 to 2012, serving under Presidents Valdas Adamkus and Dalia Grybauskaitė, and Prime Minister Andrius Kubilius. Juknevičienė has been a member of the NATO Parliamentary Assembly since 1999, serving as Vice-President from 2016 to 2018 and President from 2018. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Development and as Vice-Chair of the Group of the European People's Party. Juknevičienė is also a member of the European Council on Foreign Relations and the Center for European Policy Analysis. She is divorced from Rolandas Rastaustkas and married to Zenonas Juknevičius.

Rasmus Andresen, German politician, born 20 February 1986, in Essen, West Germany, to the Danish minority of Southern Schleswig, raised in Flensburg, graduated from Duborg-Skolen in Flensburg and Roskilde University in Denmark, member of Alliance 90/The Greens and European Green Party, served as member of Landtag of Schleswig-Holstein from 2005 to 2019, vice-president of Landtag from 2017 to 2019, Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on Committee on Budgets, coordinator for parliamentary group on Committee on Budgets, part of Parliament's delegation for relations with Canada, member of European Internet Forum, European Parliament Intergroups on Anti-Corruption, Anti-Racism and Diversity, LGBT Rights, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages, leader of German delegation within Greens-European Free Alliance group since 2021, member of Institut Solidarische Moderne since 2010, opposed to Arctic LNG 2 project due to climate change concerns, taken on godparenthood for Igor Bancer, a singer and political prisoner from Belarus.

Reinhard Hans Bütikofer, born 26 January 1953 in Mannheim, Germany, studied philosophy, sinology, and history at the University of Heidelberg but did not graduate. He is a member of Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party. Bütikofer served as co-chair of Alliance 90/The Greens from 2002 to 2008 and of the European Green Party from 2012 to 2019. He was a member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2024, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and as a substitute member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Security and Defense. Bütikofer was the Green Group's spokesperson on industrial policy and speaker of the delegation from the German Green Party to the European Parliament. He has been critical of China's human rights record and has called for a more open and clear-cut language from the West regarding Russia's behavior. Bütikofer has also advocated for reducing the use of resources and has opposed lifting the arms embargo on China. He has been a member of various organizations, including the European Council on Foreign Relations, the Center for Global Politics, and the Heinrich Böll Foundation. Bütikofer has received the Fray International Sustainability Award for his achievements in sustainable development in politics.

René Repasi, a male, born on 8 November 1979 in Karlsruhe, Baden-Württemberg, Germany. He is a German politician, member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. He holds a position as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the constituency of Germany, since 2 February 2022, succeeding Evelyne Gebhardt. He serves on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, where he is the rapporteur on the right to repair. Prior to entering parliament, he worked as Professor of Public and Private Interests at Erasmus University Rotterdam, and he is an alumnus of Heidelberg University and the University of Montpellier.

Ricardo Morgado, a Portuguese politician, born on 13 May 1987, in Lamego, Portugal, with a law degree from the University of Porto, and a professor at the European University of Lisbon. He is a member of the Social Democratic Party and the Social Democratic Youth, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal since 2 April 2024, succeeding Cláudia Aguiar, and previously served as President of the Municipal Assembly of Lamego from 16 October 2021 to 1 April 2024.

Richard Graham Corbett, Labour Party, born 6 January 1955 in Southport, England, educated at Trinity College, Oxford and University of Hull, speaks English, French, German and Dutch. 

Positions: 
Member of the European Parliament for Merseyside West (1996-1999), Yorkshire and the Humber (1999-2009, 2014-2020), 
Leader of the European Parliamentary Labour Party (2017-2020), 
Deputy Leader of the European Parliamentary Labour Party (2006-2009, 2014-2017),

Advisor to the President of the European Council (2010-2014), 
Honorary President of the Grimethorpe Colliery Band, 
Honorary Vice President of the UK European Movement, 
Visiting professor at the College of Europe in Bruges, 
Member of the board of the Salzburg Centre for European Union Studies.

Married to Lorraine Kirkwood, previously married to Inge Van Gaal and Anne De Malsche, three children, five grandchildren.

Richard Tice is a British businessman and politician who has been Member of Parliament for Boston and Skegness and Deputy Leader of Reform UK since 2024. He was born on 13 September 1964 in Farnham, Surrey. Tice was educated at Uppingham School and the University of Salford, where he received a bachelor's degree in construction economics and quantity surveying. He is a multi-millionaire and has been the CEO of Quidnet Capital LLP. Tice is a Eurosceptic and co-founded the pro-Brexit campaign groups Leave.EU and Leave Means Leave. He was a member of the Conservative Party until 2019, when he financed the founding of the Brexit Party, which was later renamed Reform UK. Tice owns one-third of the company that controls the party. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament for East of England in 2019 and served until the UK's withdrawal from the European Union in January 2020. Tice became the leader of Reform UK in March 2021 but stood down in June 2024 and was succeeded by Nigel Farage. He was elected as the Reform UK MP for Boston and Skegness at the 2024 general election. Tice is divorced and has three children. He is in a relationship with journalist Isabel Oakeshott.

Riho Terras, Estonian politician and former military officer, born on April 17, 1967, in Kohtla-Järve, Estonia, served as Commander of the Estonian Defence Forces from 2011 to 2018, promoted to general in 2017, elected as Member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing Estonia, fluent in Estonian, English, German, and Russian, married with two sons, hobbies include opera, medieval history, and hunting, educated at University of Tartu and Bundeswehr University Munich, with a master's degree in Political Science and Sociology, served in various military positions, including Chief of Staff of the Defence League Headquarters, Estonian Defence Attaché in Germany and Poland, and Permanent Secretary of the Estonian Ministry of Defence, participated in the Iraq War, member of the Isamaa party.

Rob Jan Rooken, Dutch politician, born 5 October 1969 in Groningen, Netherlands, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Netherlands constituency from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, initially as a member of Forum for Democracy, then as an Independent in 2020, and later joined JA21 in 2020, leaving the party in 2023, with a background as a web designer and founder of the IT company XOIP.

Robert "Rob" Roos, a Dutch politician, born 2 August 1966. He worked in the telecoms industry before entering politics. He was a member of Forum for Democracy (FvD) until 2020, then joined JA21 until 2023. Roos served in the States of South Holland from 28 March 2019 to 4 September 2019, chairing the FvD group. He was lijsttrekker in the 2019 provincial election, second on the list led by Derk Jan Eppink in the 2019 European Parliament election, and thirteenth on the list led by Henk Otten in the 2019 Senate election. Roos represented JA21 in the EU Parliament as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 2019 to 2024, serving as vice-chair of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group. He participated in the 2023 Madrid Forum of the Spanish political party Vox in Lima, Peru.

Robert Biedroń, a Polish politician, was born on April 13, 1976, in Rymanów, Subcarpathian Voivodeship, Poland. He is an atheist and lives with his life partner Krzysztof Śmiszek, with whom he married in an informal, non-legally binding ceremony in 2023. Biedroń is a graduate of the University of Warmia and Mazury in Olsztyn, where he received a bachelor's degree in Political Science in 2000 and a master's degree in the same field in 2003. He also attended the School of Political and Social Leaders and the School of Human Rights at the Helsinki Human Rights Foundation. 

Biedroń is fluent in Polish, English, French, Russian, Esperanto, and Italian. He has been involved in various LGBT rights organizations and has co-founded the Polish Campaign Against Homophobia. Biedroń was a member of the Sejm from 2011 to 2014 and served as the mayor of Słupsk from 2014 to 2018. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019 and chairs the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. 

Biedroń is the founder of the Institute for Democratic Thought and the Progressive Cities' network. He has written several books, including "Turn Democracy On," "Against the current," and "New Chapter." Biedroń has received numerous awards for his work, including the title of 'Rainbow Man,' the French National Order of Merit, and the Parliament MEP Award in the Diversity, Inclusion and Social Impact category. 

He is a member of the New Left party and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. Previously, he was a member of the Democratic Left Alliance, Your Movement, and Spring. Biedroń advocates for social liberalism, secularism, feminism, same-sex marriages, free access to contraception, and sexual education. He supports a separation of church and state and the removal of catechism classes from public schools.

Robert Andrew Rowland, a British politician, born 28 February 1966 in Bowdon, Greater Manchester, England, died 23 January 2021 in the Bahamas. He was a member of the Brexit Party and served as a Member of the European Parliament for South East England from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. He attended Sedbergh School and graduated from Newcastle University in 1988 with a BA (Hons). Rowland had a career in the investment industry, working at Lazard Asset Management, Odey Asset Management, Soros Fund Management, and Cheyne Capital Management. He was a director of the charity 'Tickets for Troops'. Rowland was a climate change denier and held conservative views on economics. He was married to Lisa Marie and had four children.

Roberta Metsola, born January 18, 1979, in St. Julian's, Malta, is a Maltese politician who has been the President of the European Parliament since January 2022. She is a member of the Nationalist Party (PN) and the European People's Party (EPP). Metsola has been married to Ukko Metsola, a lobbyist, since 2005, and they have four children together. She studied law at the University of Malta and European studies at the College of Europe. Metsola has been active in politics since her youth, serving in various roles within the PN and EPP, including as Secretary General of the European Democrat Students and as a member of the European Youth Forum. She was first elected as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) in 2013 and has since held various positions, including First Vice-President of the European Parliament. Metsola has been a strong advocate for the European People's Party and has voted consistently with the party line. She has also been a vocal opponent of abortion, which is legal in every EU member state except Malta and Poland. Metsola has been involved in several controversies, including a dispute over her refusal to shake hands with Malta's then-prime minister Joseph Muscat and her role in tabling amendments to a parliamentary resolution on the rule of law and fundamental rights in Bulgaria. She has called for strengthening the powers of the European Parliament and has been a strong supporter of European integration. Metsola has received several honors, including the First Class of the Order of Princess Olga from Ukraine and the Cross of Good Neighbourhood from the United Transitional Cabinet of Belarus.

Roberto Gualtieri, male, born 19 July 1966, in Rome, Italy. Married to Valentina Castaldi, with one son. Education: graduated in Literature and Philology at Sapienza University of Rome in 1992, and Ph.D. in history at the Scuola Superiore di Studi Storici di San Marino in 1997. Academic career: professor of Contemporary history at Sapienza University of Rome. Member of the Italian Communist Party (PCI) from 1985 to 1991, Democratic Party of the Left (PDS) from 1991 to 1998, Democrats of the Left (DS) from 1998 to 2007, and the Democratic Party (PD) since 2007. Member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). Politician with the following experience: Member of the European Parliament from 2009 to 2019, Chairman of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs from 2014 to 2019, Minister of Economy and Finance from 2019 to 2021, and Mayor of Rome since 2021. Describes himself as a social democrat and Keynesian.

Roberts Zīle, a Latvian economist and politician, born on 20 June 1958 in Riga, Latvia. He is a member of the National Alliance party and has been the Vice President of the European Parliament since 18 January 2022. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for Latvia since 20 July 2004. Zīle has a baccalaureate degree in economics from the University of Latvia and a doctorate degree in economics from the Latvia University of Agriculture. He has worked as an editor, research fellow, and head of unit at various institutions, including the Latvian State Institute of Agrarian Economics. He has also been a Minister of Finance, Minister of Special Affairs, and Minister of Transport in the Latvian government. Zīle is a member of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group Executive and has worked on various committees, including Transport and Tourism, Industry, Research and Energy, and Economic and Monetary Affairs. He has represented Latvia in international scientific projects and has published articles on property rights and agricultural policy issues. Zīle is also a member of the board of the Economists Association 2010 and the Foundation for the Development of Public Ideas. He has developed an extensive economic reform program and has focused on issues related to EU transport policy, overcoming the economic crisis, and energy independence.

Roman Haider, born 13 April 1967, is an Austrian politician and member of the Freedom Party of Austria. He has served as a member of the National Council from 28 October 2008 to 1 July 2019 and as a member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019.

Romana Jerković, a female MEP from Croatia, born on 28 November 1964 in Split, Socialist Republic of Croatia, Yugoslavia, representing the Social Democratic Party of Croatia, educated at the University of Rijeka and the University of Padua, with a background in medicine and biomedical research, having served as a member of the Croatian Parliament from 2008 to 2020 and deputy mayor of Rijeka from 2006 to 2009, currently serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Croatia since 1 February 2020, re-elected in 2024, member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, rapporteur on the European Commission's 2021 proposal for a regulation on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions, part of the delegation to the EU-Albania Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee and the European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer.

Romana Tomc, a Slovenian politician and Member of the European Parliament from Slovenia, born on 2 November 1965 in Ljubljana, Slovenia. She is a member of the Slovenian Democratic Party and the European People's Party. Tomc has been a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, serving on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and is part of the parliament's delegation for Northern cooperation and for relations with Switzerland and Norway, the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the European Economic Area (EEA) Joint Parliamentary Committee. She is also a supporter of the MEP Alliance for Mental Health and the MEPs Against Cancer group. Tomc was a candidate in the 2017 Slovenian presidential election and received the Employment, Social Affairs and Regions award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020. She is the Vice-Chair of the European People's Party Group in the European Parliament since 19 June 2024.

Romeo Franz, a German politician and musician, born on 28 October 1966 in Kaiserslautern, West Germany, serves as a Member of the European Parliament for Germany since 3 July 2018, representing Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party, with past experience as a board member of the Central Council of German Sinti and Roma from 2003 to 2013, and is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights and the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup.

Rory Palmer, a Labour Party member, was born on 19 November 1981 in Worksop, Nottinghamshire, England. He studied Social Policy at the University of York, graduating with a BA in 2003. Palmer worked as a research assistant for the Institute for Public Policy Research, a parliamentary assistant to Labour MPs John Mann and Peter Soulsby, and a senior policy, public affairs and campaigns manager at the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association. He was a councillor for the Eyres Monsell ward of Leicester City Council from 2007 to 2017, serving as one of the council's deputy mayors from 2011 to 2017. Palmer was a Member of the European Parliament for the East Midlands from 2017 to 2020, and the network lead for the Trussell Trust East Midlands after leaving the European Parliament. He was the Labour candidate in the 2024 Leicestershire Police and Crime Commissioner election. Palmer is a member of the Fabian Society, serving on the Executive Committee from 2019 to 2021.

Italian politician Rosa D'Amato, born 30 March 1969 in Taranto, Italian nationality, educated at the University of Florence, member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy since 1 July 2014, initially representing the Five Star Movement until 2020, then as an Independent politician, joined the Greens/EFA group in December 2020.

María Rosa Estaràs Ferragut, a Spanish politician and Member of the European Parliament, born October 21, 1965, in Valldemosa, Balearic Islands, Spain. She is a member of the People's Party and has been serving as an MEP since June 7, 2009, representing Spain. She currently serves as vice-chairwoman of the Committee on Petitions and as a full member of the Committee on Legal Affairs, and is part of various European Parliament Intergroups, including those focused on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, LGBT Rights, Disability, and Mental Health.

Italian politician Rosanna Conte, born on 17 April 1968 in Portogruaro, Italy, is affiliated with the League party, graduated from the University of Bologna, and works as a lawyer. She was elected as a member of the European Parliament representing the North-East Italy constituency, serving from 2 July 2019 until 9 June 2024.

Rovana Plumb, a Romanian politician, born on 22 June 1960 in Bucharest, Romania. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party (PSD) and also affiliated with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and the Party of European Socialists. Plumb attended the Bucharest University of Economic Studies. She served as Minister of Environment and Climate Change from 7 May 2012 to 5 March 2014, Minister of Labour, Family, Social Protection and Elders from 5 March 2014 to 9 November 2015, and Minister of European Funds from 29 January 2018 to 24 April 2019. She was also the Acting President of the Social Democratic Party from 24 June 2015 to 22 July 2015. Plumb was a member of the Parliament of Romania from 2004 to 2007, the European Parliament from 2009 to 2012, and rejoined the European Parliament in 2019. She was involved in a corruption case in 2017.

Rupert Lowe is a British Reform UK politician and multi-millionaire businessman. He was born on 31 October 1957 in Oxford, Oxfordshire, England, and educated at Radley College and the University of Reading. Lowe worked in the City of London for companies such as Morgan Grenfell, Deutsche Bank, and Barings Bank. He founded Secure Retirements, a quoted care home provider, and was the chairman of Southampton Football Club from 1996 to 2006 and again from 2008 to 2009. Lowe was a Brexit Party Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands from 2019 to 2020 and has been Reform UK's Business and Agriculture spokesman since 2023. He was elected as the Member of Parliament for Great Yarmouth in the 2024 general election, gaining 35.3% of the vote. Lowe has been involved in various controversies, including denying the scientific consensus on man-made climate change and compiling a list of schools in his constituency where he claimed teachers had a bias against Reform UK. He has also been involved in a libel case against The Times and received undisclosed damages payouts from Mirror Group Newspapers as part of the phone hacking scandal. Lowe regards Oliver Cromwell as his hero and has pledged to donate his MP salary to a different local charity or worthy cause each month.

Ruža Tomašić, a Croatian politician, born on May 10, 1958, in Mladoševica, PR Bosnia and Herzegovina, Yugoslavia. She is a practicing Roman Catholic, adhering to traditional Christian values. Tomašić is married to Vlado, with whom she has two children, and currently resides in Brna, on the island of Korčula. She graduated from the Ontario Police College and worked as a police officer in Canada, primarily dealing with juvenile delinquency and illegal drug trade. Tomašić moved to Croatia in 1990 and served as a bodyguard for top government officials. She was diagnosed with uterine cancer in 1992 but recovered completely in 1998. Tomašić has been a member of the Croatian Party of Rights, Croatian Party of Rights Dr. Ante Starčević, and the Croatian Conservative Party. She served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2013 to 2021, representing Croatia, and was a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and Special Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering. Tomašić received the Order of Stjepan Radić for her efforts in fighting organized crime.

Ryszard Czarnecki, born Richard Henry Czarnecki on January 25, 1963, in London, United Kingdom. He is a Polish politician and former Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Poland. He is a member of the Law and Justice party, part of the European Conservatives and Reformists. He was previously a member of the Self-Defense party and the Christian National Union. He was educated at the University of Wrocław, earning a Master's degree in History. He has worked as a journalist, editor, and lecturer, and has held various positions in the Polish government, including Deputy Minister of Culture, Minister for European Integration, and Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on European Integration. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2004 and has served as Vice-President of the European Parliament. He is married to Emilia Czarnecka and has three children. He has been awarded the Order of Merit (Ukraine). He has been involved in controversies, including comparing Róża Thun to Nazi collaborators and being charged with corruption.

Ryszard Legutko, a Polish philosopher and politician, born on December 24, 1949, in Kraków, Poland. He is a professor of philosophy at the Jagiellonian University, specializing in ancient philosophy and political theory. Legutko is a member of the Law and Justice party and has served as a Member of the European Parliament since 2009. He has held various positions, including Deputy Speaker of the Polish Senate, Poland's Education Minister, and Secretary of State in the Chancellery of President Lech Kaczyński. Legutko is a fellow of Collegium Invisibile and has written several books on philosophy and politics. He has expressed conservative views on same-sex marriage, homosexuality, and religion. Legutko has been involved in controversies, including a lawsuit for violating personal rights and a cancelled lecture at Middlebury College due to protests. He is married with two children.

Róbert Hajšel is a Slovak politician, born on 28 March 1967 in Slovakia. He is a member of the Direction – Social Democracy party. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament, representing the Slovakia constituency, and served from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024.

fullName: Róża Maria Barbara Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein
prompt: Róża Maria Thun, a Polish politician, born on 13 April 1954 in Kraków, Poland, to a Polish nobleman father Jacek Woźniakowski and Countess Maria Karolina of Plater-Zyberk, a biologist. She graduated with a Master's degree in English Philology from the Jagiellonian University in 1979. Thun was involved in anti-communist organizations, including the Student Committee of Solidarity and the Workers' Defence Committee. She was the chairwoman of the Polish Robert Schuman Foundation, promoting European integration, from 1992 to 2005. Thun served as the head of the European Commission Representation to Poland from 2005 to 2009. She is a Member of the European Parliament for Poland, representing Civic Platform from 2009 to 2021, and then Poland 2050, and is part of the Renew Europe group. Thun is a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and has been Vice President of the European Movement International since 2011. She has received several honors, including the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Award in 2017, and has been nominated for the prize of "best MEP" in 2011 and 2013. Thun is married to Franz, 5th Prince von Thun und Hohenstein, and they have four children. She has been critical of the Polish government and has voted in favor of a resolution invoking Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, potentially stripping Poland of voting rights in the EU.

Sabine Verheyen is a German politician who serves as the First Vice-President of the European Parliament. She was born on 24 October 1964 in Aachen, Germany. Verheyen studied architecture at the Aachen University of Applied Sciences from 1983 to 1988. She is married and has three children. Verheyen joined the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) in 1990. She was a member of the city council of Aachen from 1994 to 2009 and served as mayor of Aachen from 1999 to 2009. Verheyen has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2009, representing Germany. She is a member of the European People's Party and has served on several committees, including the Committee on Culture and Education, which she chaired from 2019. Verheyen has also been a member of the Parliament's delegation for relations with South Africa and has served as a substitute member on the Committee on Regional Development and the Delegation for relations with Iran. She is a member of the European Internet Forum, the European Parliament Intergroup on the Digital Agenda, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights. Verheyen was elected as one of five deputies of Hendrik Wüst as chair of the CDU in North Rhine-Westphalia in 2021. She was nominated by her party as delegate to the Federal Convention for the purpose of electing the President of Germany in 2022. Verheyen publicly endorsed Armin Laschet to succeed Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer as the party’s chair in 2021.

Sabrina Pignedoli, Italian politician and journalist, born 24 October 1983 in Castelnovo ne' Monti, Italy. Education: University of Bologna (DAMS, Cinema, Television and Multimedia Production, Journalism), University of Modena and Reggio Emilia (International Law and Economics). Career: journalist since 2010, collaborates with national newspapers and ANSA. Author of "Operazione Aemilia" and "Le mafie sulle macerie del muro di Berlino". Member of the European Parliament for the Five Star Movement since 2 July 2019, representing the North-East Italy constituency.

Salima Yenbou, French politician, born 14 March 1971 in Aubervilliers, France. Member of the European Parliament for France since 2 July 2019. Served on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee on Culture and Education, and Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware. Member of the Parliament's delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity, European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara, and Inter-Parliamentary Alliance on China. Joined the Renew Europe group in 2022 after declaring support for Emmanuel Macron in the 2022 French presidential election. Affiliated with the Cap Écologie party.

Salvatore De Meo, Italian politician, born 27 October 1971 in Fondi, member of Forza Italia, member of the European Parliament representing Central Italy since 1 February 2020, chairman of the European Parliament Committee on Constitutional Affairs as of 2022.

Samira Rafaela, Dutch politician of Democrats 66, born 11 February 1989 in Zoetermeer, Netherlands, to a Jewish Dutch-Curaçaoan mother and a Ghanaian-Nigerian father, identifies as a progressive, liberal, feminist Muslim. Studied public administration at Leiden University, researched radicalization and terrorism, and obtained a master's degree in Crisis and Security Management. Worked as policy maker, administrative advisor, and project leader for inclusion. Member of the European Parliament from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, representing the Netherlands, part of the Renew Europe parliamentary group. Served on the Committee on International Trade, Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Co-chaired the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup and was a member of intergroups on Artificial Intelligence, Disability, and others. Awarded International Woman of the Year in 2020 by Harper's Bazaar.

Sandra Kalniete, born 22 December 1952, is a Latvian politician, author, diplomat, and independence movement leader. She is a member of the European People's Party and has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) since 2009, representing Latvia. She served as Foreign Minister of Latvia from 2002 to 2004 and as European Commissioner for Agriculture, Rural Development, and Fisheries in 2004. Kalniete has also held various ambassadorial positions, including Ambassador to the United Nations, France, and UNESCO. She is fluent in Latvian, English, French, and Russian. Kalniete has been involved in various human rights causes, particularly related to totalitarian crimes, and has written several books, including "Latvian Textile Art" and "With Dancing Shoes in Siberian Snows." She has received numerous awards for her work, including the Commander of the Order of the Three Stars, the Commander of the Legion of Honor, and the Truman-Reagan Medal of Freedom. Kalniete is currently a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and a substitute member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development in the European Parliament.
Sandra Pereira, a Portuguese Communist Party politician, MEP from Portugal, serving from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024.

Sandro Gozi, born 25 March 1968 in Sogliano al Rubicone, Italy, is an Italian politician and current Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for France since 1 February 2020. He was a member of the Italian Parliament from 2006 to 2018, serving as Undersecretary to European Affairs from 2014 to 2018 under Prime Ministers Matteo Renzi and Paolo Gentiloni. Gozi holds a law degree from the University of Bologna, a diplôme d'études approfondies from SciencesPo in Paris, and a PhD in public law from the University of Bologna. He has been a visiting lecturer at various European universities, including the College of Europe in Bruges and the European College in Parma. Gozi has worked as a diplomatic adviser, a coordinator for the Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe, and a director of the ISMaPP institute in Brussels. He has been a member of several parties, including the Italian Social Movement, the Italian Republican Party, the Democratic Party, and Italia Viva. Gozi is also the President of the Brussels-based EU-India Association and The Spinelli Group, and the Secretary General of the European Democratic Party since 5 May 2021. He has written several books on European integration and politics.

Sara Cerdas, a Portuguese medical doctor and politician, born on 23 March 1989, in Portugal, represents the Socialist Party in the European Parliament, serving the constituency of Portugal. She holds master's degrees in Medicine from the University of Lisbon, Travel Medicine from NOVA University of Lisbon, and Public Health Sciences from the University of Umeå, and is a PhD student in Public Health Sciences at Stockholm University. Cerdas is a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, co-chair of the European Parliament's Health Working Group, and part of various intergroups, including LGBT Rights, Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, and Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas. She received the Health award at The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Awards in 2020 and was recognized as one of the 100 Influential Women in Oncology by OncoDaily in 2023.

Sara Magdalena Skyttedal, born 6 August 1986 in Tyresö, Sweden. Practising Catholic. Studied political science, political economy, history science, rhetoric, Swedish language, and law at Stockholm University. Participated in Miss Sweden 2006, made the Top 15. Married with 2 children. Member of the Young Christian Democrats since 2002, chairperson from 2013 to 2016. Member of the Christian Democrats party from 2002 to 2024, municipal commissioner for Linköping from 2016 to 2019. Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2024, serving on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. Founded Folklistan (The People's List) in 2024. Advocates for decriminalization of drug use and legalization of cannabis, has used cannabis on a handful of occasions in countries where it was legal. Has also tried psychedelic mushrooms where it was legal.

Career: Entrepreneur, television chef, politician, restaurateur, radio host
Education: Attended a girls' boarding school
Notable activities: Set up the Sarah Wiener Foundation to promote healthy eating habits among children and teenagers, operated an organic farm in the Uckermark region, involved with food quality group Foodwatch, filed for insolvency for her restaurants and catering business during the COVID-19 pandemic
Awards: Herforder price (2006), Order One 100 (2007), Trophée Gourmet (2007), Golden Cloche (2008), Woman of Exception Award (2008), Les Trophees de l'Esprit Alimentaire / French Food Spirit Award (2008), Flair de Parfum (2008), Blue Hearts Award (2010), Fairness Price (2012), Gourmet of the Year (2012), Chevalier of the Ordre national du Mérite (2013)

Sara Matthieu, a 42-year-old Belgian politician from Groen, born on 21 May 1981, in Aalst, Belgium, educated at Ghent University, has been serving as a member of the European Parliament for Belgium since 8 October 2020, where she is on the Committee on International Trade, co-rapporteur on minimum income, and part of the delegation for relations with the countries of South Asia, and the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights.

Saskia Bricmont, a Belgian politician and Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the French-speaking electoral college of Belgium. Born on 16 March 1985 in Tournai, Belgium. Member of the Ecolo party. Serves on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the Committee on International Trade, and the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware. Part of the Parliament's delegation for relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union, and member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Children’s Rights, LGBT Rights, and the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, as well as the Responsible Business Conduct Working Group.

Scott John Ainslie, a British politician and actor, was born on 27 December 1968 in Edinburgh, Scotland. He graduated from Edinburgh Napier University with an economics degree and later studied at Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts on a scholarship. Ainslie moved to Streatham in London in 1997. He is a member of the Green Party of England and Wales. Ainslie has been a councillor representing St Leonard's Ward on the Lambeth Council in London since 22 May 2014, with a majority of 474 votes. He was elected as a Green Party Member of the European Parliament for London from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020, succeeding Jean Lambert. Ainslie was a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and part of the delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. He was the Opposition Lead on Standards and Monitoring since 2018. Ainslie stood as a candidate for the Green Party in the 2019 general election for the South London-based seat of Streatham, finishing fourth with 4.5% of the vote. In the 2024 general election, he stood for the new constituency of Streatham and Croydon North, coming in second place with 17.1% of the vote.

Seb Dance, a British Labour Party politician, born 1 December 1981 in London, UK, married to Spencer Livermore, Baron Livermore. Served as Member of the European Parliament for the London region from 2014 to 2020 and as Deputy Mayor of London for Transport since January 2022. Deputy Leader of the European Parliamentary Labour Party and Vice-Chair of the European Parliament Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety from 2019 to 2020. Interim chair of the Labour Movement for Europe. Worked for development charity ActionAid UK and as an advisor to the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland. Supported Owen Smith in the 2016 Labour Party leadership election and opposed Brexit. Elected as a Vice-Chair of the ENVI Committee in 2019. Served under Mayor Sadiq Khan as Deputy Mayor of London for Transport.

Sergey Stanishev, a Bulgarian politician, was born on May 5, 1966, in Kherson, Ukrainian SSR, to a Bulgarian Communist official father and a Soviet citizen mother. He acquired Bulgarian citizenship in 1996. Stanishev graduated from Moscow State University with a degree in history and later obtained his PhD-equivalent in the same field. He worked as a freelance journalist and was a visiting fellow in international relations at the London School of Economics and Political Science. 

Stanishev is a member of the Bulgarian Socialist Party and served as its leader from 2001 to 2014. He was the Prime Minister of Bulgaria from 2005 to 2009, leading a coalition government. During his term, Bulgaria joined the European Union. Stanishev has been a strong supporter of European integration and has served as the President of the European Socialists from 2011 to 2022. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024.

Stanishev has been involved in several controversies, including the Hochegger scandal and the European elections project scandal. He has also faced criminal prosecution for allegedly losing classified documents, but was acquitted in 2016.

Stanishev is married to Monika Yosifova, a PR agent, and they have two children together. He enjoys fitness, skiing, swimming, and motorcycling in his free time.

Sergey Lagodinsky is a German lawyer and politician of the Alliance 90/The Greens. He was born on December 1, 1975, in Astrakhan, Russian SFSR, Soviet Union, and holds German nationality. Lagodinsky studied law at the University of Göttingen, public administration at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, and received a PhD in law from the Humboldt University of Berlin. He completed the second state examination in law in Berlin. Lagodinsky was a member of the Social Democratic Party from 2001 to 2011 and joined Alliance 90/The Greens in 2011. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Legal Affairs, and is a member of the Democracy, Rule of Law & Fundamental Rights Monitoring Group. Lagodinsky has also been a part of the Parliament's delegations to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee and the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. He is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Racism and Diversity. Since 2024, Lagodinsky has been serving as deputy chair of the Greens–European Free Alliance group.

Sergio Berlato, Italian politician, born 27 July 1959 in Vicenza, Italy. He was elected to the Regional Council of Veneto in 1990 for the Hunting Fishing Environment list, and later served as regional minister from 1994 to 1995. Berlato was re-elected in 1995 for National Alliance and served as Minister of Agriculture until 1999. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 1999 to 2014, initially for National Alliance and later for The People of Freedom. Berlato was a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and held various other committee and delegation roles. In 2013, he joined Forza Italia, but left the party in 2014 to join Brothers of Italy. Berlato returned to the Regional Council in 2015 and took his seat in the European Parliament in 2020 after initially being elected in 2019. His party affiliations include: Hunting – Fishing – Environment (1990-1995), National Alliance (1995-2009), The People of Freedom (2009-2013), Movement for Hunting and Rural Culture (since 2012), Forza Italia (2013-2014), and Brothers of Italy (since 2014).

Seán Kelly, a male politician from Ireland, born on 26 April 1952 in Killarney, County Kerry, married to Juliette Kelly since 1987, with 4 children, educated at St Brendan's College, Killarney, St Patrick's College of Education, and University College Dublin, a member of Fine Gael and the European People's Party, served as the 34th President of the Gaelic Athletic Association from 2003 to 2006, Executive Chairman of the Irish Institute of Sport from 2006 to 2008, and a Member of the European Parliament for the South constituency since 1 July 2009, leader of Fine Gael in the European Parliament since 4 May 2014, awarded an honorary doctorate by Dublin Institute of Technology in 2007, MEP of the Year for Research and Innovation in 2012, recipient of IAB Europe's Award for Leadership and Excellence in Public Policy, and winner of The Parliament Magazine's annual MEP Award for Industry, Research & Innovation in 2020.

Shaffaq Mohammed, a British politician, born 21 July 1972 in Pakistani administered Kashmir, moved to Sheffield in 1977, and graduated from the University of Sheffield. He is a member of the Liberal Democrats and served as a councillor for Broomhill Ward, Crookes Ward, and Ecclesall Ward on Sheffield City Council between 2004 and 2014 and from 2016 to present. He was the leader of the Liberal Democrat Group on Sheffield City Council from 2011 to 2014 and again from 2016. He was appointed a Member of the Order of the British Empire in 2015. He was a Member of the European Parliament for Yorkshire and the Humber from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. He stood as the Liberal Democrat candidate for Sheffield Brightside and Hillsborough in 2016, Sheffield Central in 2017, and Sheffield Hallam in 2024, coming in second to Olivia Blake of Labour in the latter.

Sheila Ritchie, a Scottish Liberal Democrat politician and solicitor, born on 18 May 1957, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Scotland constituency from 2 July 2019 to 31 January 2020. Ritchie is a retired Solicitor of an Aberdeen law firm and formerly a Councillor and leader of Gordon District Council. She was a Scottish Government appointee to the European Economic and Social Committee between 2000 and 2003. Ritchie is a Trustee of The Macaulay Development Trust, Articulate Cultural Trust, and Celebrate Aberdeen. As an MEP, she sat with Renew Europe group and was a member of the European Parliament Committee on Budgetary Control and the European Parliament Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Ritchie stood in Moray at the 2021 Scottish Parliament election and was the fifth candidate on the list vote for the Highlands and Islands region. She was appointed Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) in the 2023 New Year Honours for political service in Scotland and appointed as a Commissioner for the Electoral Commission in February 2024.

Siegfried Mureșan, a Romanian economist and politician, born on 20 September 1981 in Hunedoara, Hunedoara County, Socialist Republic of Romania. He graduated from the Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies (ASE) in 2004 and holds a master's degree in Economics and Management from Humboldt University of Berlin. Mureșan is a member of the National Liberal Party (PNL) since 2018 and the European People's Party (EPP). He was previously a member of the Democratic Liberal Party (PDL) and the People's Movement Party (PMP). Mureșan has been a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Romania since 1 July 2014. He served as Vice-President of the EPP Group in the European Parliament and Vice-President of the European People's Party. Mureșan was the rapporteur on the financing of the European Green Deal, co-rapporteur for the European Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF), and rapporteur on the adoption by Croatia of the euro on 1 January 2023. He chairs the European Parliament's delegation to the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Association Committee. Mureșan is married to Cătălina Manea and is a fan of tennis player Rafael Nadal.

Silvia Modig, Finnish politician, MEP, born 8 July 1976 in Helsinki, Finland, Swedish-speaking minority, openly lesbian, vegetarian, married to Meri Valkama from 2019 to 2023, member of the Left Alliance and European United Left-Nordic Green Left, elected to Helsinki City Council in 2008, member of the Parliament of Finland from 2011 to 2019 representing Helsinki, member of the European Parliament since 2019 representing Finland.

Silvia Serafina Sardone, Italian politician, born 25 December 1982 in Milan, Italy. She is a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, representing North-West Italy. She graduated in Law from Bocconi University in 2007, holds a research doctorate from the University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, and a master's degree in Business administration from the Polytechnic University of Milan. She is married to Roberto Di Stefano, the mayor of Sesto San Giovanni, and has 2 children. Her party affiliations include Forza Italia (2006-2018) and the League (2018-present).

Silvio Berlusconi, Prime Minister of Italy from 1994 to 1995, 2001 to 2006, and 2008 to 2011. Born on September 29, 1936, in Milan, Italy, and died on June 12, 2023. He was a member of the Chamber of Deputies from 1994 to 2013 and a member of the Senate of the Republic from 2022 until his death. He was also a member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022. He was the leader of the centre-right party Forza Italia from 1994 to 2009 and its successor party The People of Freedom from 2009 to 2013. He led the revived Forza Italia from 2013 to 2023. He was convicted of tax fraud in 2013 and banned from holding public office for two years. He was married to Carla Elvira Dall'Oglio from 1965 to 1985 and to Veronica Lario from 1990 to 2010. He had five children, including Marina, Pier Silvio, and Barbara. He was the founder and owner of Fininvest and the owner of AC Milan. He was known for his populist political style and his ability to maintain strong and close foreign relations with both the United States and Russia.

Simona Renata Baldassarre, Italian politician, born 12 November 1970 in Giurdignano, member of the League party, served in the European Parliament representing Central Italy from 2 July 2019 to 6 April 2023.

Simona Bonafé, Italian politician and journalist, born 24 June 1973 in Varese, Italy. Member of the Chamber of Deputies since 13 October 2022, representing Tuscany, and previously from 15 March 2013 to 25 June 2014, representing Lombardy 2. Served as Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy from 25 May 2014 to 12 October 2022. Councillor for the Environment in Scandicci from 2004 to 2013. Worked as a journalist for Corriere di Firenze and Europa from 2007. Member of the Democratic Party since 2007, previously with The Daisy party from 2002 to 2007. Served on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and was the parliament's rapporteur on the EU Circular Economy Package. Represented the Parliament at the 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh. Vice-chairwoman of the European Parliament Intergroup on Long Term Investment and Reindustrialisation, and member of several other intergroups. Vice-chair of the S&D Group since late 2019.

Simone Schmiedtbauer, an Austrian politician, born 8 June 1974 in Graz, Austria, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Austrian People's Party from 2 July 2019 to 16 October 2023, representing the Austria constituency, and held committee assignments including the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development from 2019 to 2023 and the Committee on Budgetary Control from 2022 to 2023, and was part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises, succeeded by Wolfram Pirchner.

Sira Abed Rego, Minister of Youth and Children in the Government of Spain since 2023, born 20 November 1973 in Valencia, Spain to a Spanish mother and a Palestinian father, spent part of her early life in 'Anata, her father lives with Rego's brother in the West Bank. She is affiliated with United Left (IU) and the Communist Party of Spain. She was a Member of the European Parliament between 2019 and 2023, representing Spain. She was nominated as European United Left–Nordic Green Left's candidate for President of the European Parliament in 2019. She voted against condemning President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua for alleged human rights violations in 2022. She has expressed commitment to the fight against violence against women and has posted in favour of Palestinian right to resist. She has been a member of the Rivas-Vaciamadrid City Council from 2007 to 2019.

Sirpa Pietikäinen, a Finnish politician, born on 19 April 1959 in Parikkala, Finland. She is a member of the National Coalition Party and the European People's Party. Pietikäinen holds an MBA degree from Helsinki School of Economics, now Aalto University. She speaks Finnish, English, French, Swedish, and German. 

Pietikäinen has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2008, representing Finland. She was previously a Member of the Finnish Parliament from 1983 to 2003 and served as Minister for the Environment from 1991 to 1995 under Prime Minister Esko Aho. 

She has been a member of several committees, including the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Pietikäinen is also a member of various intergroups, including the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and the European Parliament Intergroup on Children's Rights. 

She has authored reports on organic farming and the circular economy, and has served as rapporteur for proposals on venture capital, social entrepreneurship, and sustainable investment. Pietikäinen is a member of the World Future Council and the Energy Watch Group. 

She was convicted of aggravated drunk driving in 2003 and was fined, given a suspended prison sentence, and banned from driving for five months. Pietikäinen is married to Tapio Määttä.

Ska Keller is a German politician, born on 22 November 1981 in Guben, East Germany. She is a member of the Alliance 90/The Greens and the European Green Party. Keller studied Islamic studies, Turkish, and Jewish Studies at the Free University of Berlin and Sabancı University in Istanbul. She is fluent in German, English, French, Spanish, and has knowledge of Turkish and Arabic. Keller has been a member of the European Parliament for the Germany constituency from 2009 to 2024. She served as co-president of the Greens/EFA group in the European Parliament from 2016 to 2022. Keller was a leading candidate of the European Green Party for the European elections in 2014 and 2019. She has been a member of the Committee on Fisheries, Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Committee on Development, and Committee on International Trade. Keller has focused on issues such as migration, EU-Turkey relations, and fighting corruption in the European Union. She is married to Finnish politician Markus Drake. Keller announced her resignation as co-chair of her party's group in September 2022 and decided not to run again in the 2024 elections.

Sophie in 't Veld, a Dutch politician, born on 13 September 1963 in Vollenhove, Netherlands. She studied history at Leiden University from 1982 to 1991 and worked as a freelance translator and trainee in the economic affairs department in Gouda. In 't Veld was an assistant to D66 MEP Johanna Boogerd-Quaak in 1994, and secretary general of the ELDR group in the Committee of the Regions from 1996 to 2004. She has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2004, initially for Democrats 66 and later for Volt, serving on various committees including Economic and Monetary Affairs, Women's Rights and Gender Equality, and Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. In 't Veld is an opponent of the death penalty, supports abortion rights, and has advocated for improved gender balance in the European Commission. She has also been involved in lawsuits related to privacy and access to information, and has criticized measures she sees as threats to democracy. In 't Veld has been a strong supporter of secularism and has received the Secularist of the Year prize in 2011. She has been involved in controversy related to reimbursements for hotel stays.

María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos, Spanish politician, born December 1, 1963, in Valladolid, Spain, lawyer, member of Ciudadanos, previously PSOE, education: Universidad de Valladolid, law degree with specialization in Community Law, 1987, career: lawyer at the Center for the Reception of Women Victims of Ill-treatment in Valladolid, 1988-1990, professor at the University School of Labor Relations of Valladolid, 1991, director of the Center for Women in Valladolid, 1994-1997, legal advisor to the Local Administration, 1998, Secretary of Organization in the Provincial Executive of the PSOE in Valladolid, 1994, member of the Federal Committee of the PSOE, 2000-2008, Deputy in the Congress of Deputies, 2004-2011, Secretary of State for International Cooperation, 2008-2011, Member of the European Parliament for Ciudadanos, 2019-present, committees: Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Intergroups: Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, LGBT Rights, personal: divorced, two children.

Stanislav Polčák, a Czech politician, born on 21 February 1980 in Slavičín, Czechoslovakia. He is a lawyer by profession and graduated from Charles University in Prague. Polčák is a member of the Mayors and Independents party and has held various positions, including 1st Vice-Chair of STAN, Member of the Chamber of Deputies, and Member of the European Parliament, representing the Czech Republic constituency from 1 July 2014 to 15 July 2024. He was re-elected as an MEP in 2019, receiving 25,352 preferential votes. Polčák has been involved in controversies, including claiming CZK 7.5 million and CZK 7.7 million for representing clients, and his ties with businessman Michal Redl. He suspended his membership in the Mayors and Independents party in June 2022 but reestablished it after eight months. Polčák voted for the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive as part of the European Union's Green Deal for Europe.

Stasys Jakeliūnas, a Lithuanian politician, born on 2 October 1958 in Karaganda, Kazakh SSR, with Lithuanian nationality. He was a member of the European Parliament for Lithuania from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, representing the Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union. Jakeliūnas has one child, Kostas Jakeliūnas. He previously served as an MP in the Lithuanian Seimas, initiating the impeachment process of Mykolas Majauskas, and as an economic advisor to PM Algirdas Butkevičius. Jakeliūnas has been involved in controversies, including accusations of electoral fraud, asking to apply pressure on fintech Revolut to leave Lithuania, and abstaining in parliamentary votes on support for the 2020-2021 Belarusian protests and the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. He has also expressed anti-Israeli statements bordering on anti-Semitic and defended an accused Russian spy. Jakeliūnas has a history of frivolous litigation, with multiple lawsuits being refused by Lithuanian courts and the General Court of the European Union.

Stefan Berger is a German economist and politician born on September 15, 1969, in Mönchengladbach, West Germany. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the European People's Party (EPP). Berger studied economics at the Johannes Gutenberg University of Mainz, graduating in 1995 with a diploma as a business teacher and passing the Second State Examination in 1997. He received his doctorate in 1999. Berger is married and has one daughter. 

Berger's political career includes being a member of the State Parliament of North Rhine-Westphalia from 2000 to 2019, serving as a councillor of the Schwalmtal municipality from 1999 to 2009, and being a member of the district council of the district of Viersen from 2001 to 2004. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Delegation for relations with Japan. Berger is also an alternate member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), and the Delegation for bilateral relations with the Arab Peninsula.

Berger has expressed concerns about Facebook's digital currency Diem, calling for the rapid development of a European stable coin as a secure and stable alternative. He has also welcomed the nomination of Ursula von der Leyen as President of the EU Commission. Berger has published several articles on topics such as crypto-assets, digital currencies, and the need for regulation and innovation in the financial system.

Berger is a member of various organizations, including the Arbeiter-Samariter-Bund Nordrhein-Westfalen, the Bau- und Liegenschaftsbetrieb NRW (BLB), and the Johannes Rau Research Association. He is also a supporter of the Freundes- und Förderkreis der Jungen Union NRW e.V.

Stefania Zambelli, Italian politician, born 6 April 1971 in Salò, member of Forza Italia since 2023, previously member of Lega Nord from 1995 to 2023, elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2019, representing North-West Italy, serving since 2 July 2019.

Stelios Kouloglou, a Greek journalist, writer, and documentary director, born on February 27, 1953, in Athens, Greece. He graduated from the University of Athens and studied journalism in Paris, Tokyo, and India. Kouloglou worked as a political correspondent in Greece and as a foreign correspondent in Paris and Moscow, covering the Soviet Union and ex-communist countries. He created the news web channel "TVXS" and was a political analyst and columnist for major Greek publications and Le Monde Diplomatique. Kouloglou was a member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2024, initially representing Syriza from 2015 to 2023 and then the New Left from 2023 to present.

Stelios Kympouropoulos, Greek psychiatrist and politician, born 9 July 1985 in Athens, Greece, diagnosed with spinal muscular atrophy at 14 months. Educated at National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, degree in medicine 2010, master's degree in Mental Health Promotion 2014, degree in psychiatry 2016. Worked as Curator B at 2nd University Psychiatric Clinic of University General Hospital "Attikon" 2016-2019. Member of New Democracy party, Member of European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Greece, member of European People's Party, Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, Delegation for relations with Mashreq countries, Delegation to Parliamentary Assembly of Union for Mediterranean, Special Committee on COVID-19 pandemic, alternate member of Committee on Regional Development and Subcommittee on Human Rights, member of Disability Intergroup. Recipient of Health and Wellbeing Award at MEP Awards 2023 and Rising Star award at MEP Awards 2024.

Stéphane Bijoux, a French politician and journalist, born 8 October 1970 in Saint-Denis, Réunion, France, educated at Bordeaux Montaigne University. He served as director of television editorials Overseas at La Première and France Ô, and was responsible for diversity in the Information at France Télévisions. As a member of La République En Marche!, he was elected to the European Parliament in 2019, representing France, and served on the Committee on Regional Development until 15 July 2024. He was also part of the European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Stéphane Séjourné, a French politician, was born on March 26, 1985, in Versailles, France. He studied at the University of Poitiers and grew up in Madrid and Buenos Aires. Séjourné is openly gay and was in a civil union with Gabriel Attal from 2015 to 2022. He suffers from severe dyslexia. He is a member of the Renaissance party and previously belonged to the Socialist Party from 2001 to 2016. Séjourné served as Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs from January 2024 to September 2024, as General Secretary of Renaissance from September 2022, and as Leader of Renew Europe from October 2021 to January 2024. He was a Member of the European Parliament from July 2019 to January 2024 and a Member of the National Assembly for Hauts-de-Seine's 9th constituency from July 2024 to September 2024. Séjourné is considered a close ally of President Emmanuel Macron and has expressed opposition to the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment and the far-right in the European Parliament.

Stéphanie Yon-Courtin, a French lawyer and politician, born on 28 March 1974 in Coutances, France. She is a member of the Renaissance party since 2019, previously a member of The Republicans from 2015 to 2018. Yon-Courtin has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of France. She chairs the Parliament's delegation for relations with Canada and serves on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, where she is the parliament's rapporteur on competition law and the 2021 Digital Markets Act. Yon-Courtin is also a member of several European Parliament Intergroups, including Artificial Intelligence and Digital, Children's Rights, Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development, Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, and the MEPs Against Cancer group. She has urged the EU to take measures to end British water treatment facilities' discharges of raw sewage into shared waters. Yon-Courtin was educated at the University of Caen Normandy and the University of Bristol. She has previously worked at the European Commission, law firms Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer and Allen & Overy, and as an advisor to France's Competition Authority. Yon-Courtin has also held various local offices, including Mayor of Saint-Contest from 2014 to 2019, Member of the Departmental council of Calvados from 2015 to 2021, and Member of the Regional Council of Normandy since 2021. She was re-elected as an MEP in 2024.

Sunčana Glavak, a Croatian politician and member of the Croatian Democratic Union, born on December 9, 1968, in Čakovec, SR Croatia, SFR Yugoslavia, has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Croatia since December 1, 2019, succeeding Dubravka Šuica. Glavak has a background in journalism, having worked as a speaker, presenter, and editor at Radio Čakovec. She has held various positions, including spokesperson for the Ministry of Culture, deputy spokesperson of the government led by Prime Minister Ivo Sanader, and spokesperson for the Government of the Republic of Croatia under successive prime ministers Tihomir Orešković and Andrej Plenković. She has been a member of the Croatian Parliament and served on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, as well as being part of the parliament's delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo and of the European Parliament Intergroup on Cancer.

Susana Solís Pérez, a female politician from Spain, born on 21 December 1971 in Avilés, Spain, educated at the University of Oviedo. She is a member of the People's Party (2024–present) and previously a member of Citizens (2015–2024). She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Spain since 2 July 2019 and on the Committee on Regional Development. She also joined the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age in 2020. Additionally, she is a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, the European Internet Forum, the MEPs Against Cancer group, and the MEP Interest Group on Obesity & Health System Resilience. She previously served as a Member of the Assembly of Madrid from 9 June 2015 to 11 June 2019.

Susanna Ceccardi, born March 19, 1987, in Pisa, Italy, is an Italian politician. She is a member of the Lega party, previously Lega Nord, and has been a Member of the European Parliament for Central Italy since July 2, 2019. She was the mayor of Cascina from June 21, 2016, to June 27, 2019. Ceccardi is known for her critical views on the European Union and immigration. She opposes the construction of mosques and has expressed concerns about Islamic extremism. She has also been involved in controversy, including a "rescue expedition" during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ceccardi is in a relationship with Andrea Barabotti and has one child, Kinzika, born on September 28, 2019.

Sven Giegold, a male politician, born on 17 November 1969 in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain, represents the Alliance 90/The Greens party in Germany and The Greens–European Free Alliance in the EU. He holds a Master's degree from the University of Birmingham. Giegold was a member of the European Parliament from 1 July 2009 to 15 December 2021, serving on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and holding various other committee positions. He is a founding member of Attac Germany and has been involved in several organizations focused on sustainable development, taxation, and social justice. Since 2021, he has been serving as State Secretary in the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action in the coalition government of Chancellor Olaf Scholz.

Sven Mikser, a male politician from Estonia, born on 8 November 1973 in Tartu, Estonia, graduated from the University of Tartu, and has been a member of the Estonian Centre Party from 2002 to 2003 and the Social Democratic Party since 2005. He served as the Minister of Defence from 28 January 2002 to 10 April 2003 under Prime Minister Siim Kallas, from 26 March 2014 to 14 September 2015 under Prime Minister Taavi Rõivas, and as the Minister of Foreign Affairs from 23 November 2016 to 29 April 2019 under Prime Minister Jüri Ratas. He was the leader of the Social Democratic Party from 16 October 2010 to 30 May 2015. Since 2 July 2019, he has been a Member of the European Parliament for Estonia, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and its Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and is part of the Parliament's delegation to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly and to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly.

Sven Schulze, a German politician, born on 31 July 1979 in Quedlinburg, East Germany, studied industrial engineering at Technical University Clausthal. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the European People's Party (EPP). Schulze served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 1 July 2014 to 2021, representing Germany. He was a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and the Committee on Transport and Tourism, serving as vice-chair from 2019. Schulze also participated in delegations for relations with the Mashreq Countries, the Parliamentary Assembly - Union for the Mediterranean, and Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. He is the chairman of the CDU in Saxony-Anhalt since 2021 and has been serving as State Minister for Economic Affairs in the government of Minister-President Reiner Haseloff since 2021. Schulze is a member of the German-Russian Friendship Group and the Bundesrat, serving on the Committee on Agriculture and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Economic Affairs. He endorsed Friedrich Merz as the party's chair in the 2022 Christian Democrats' leadership election.

Sven Simon, a German politician, born on October 9, 1978, in Lahn, Hesse, Germany. He is a law professor and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since July 2, 2019, representing Germany as a member of the Christian Democratic Union and the European People's Party. He previously taught international and European law at Philipps University of Marburg. His academic career includes a doctorate in law from Justus Liebig University Giessen and a habilitation from the same university. He has worked as a visiting researcher at the Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law in Heidelberg, the European Commission in Brussels, and the World Trade Organization in Geneva. He has also held various positions within the Christian Democratic Union, including deputy chairman of his party's chapter in the District of Giessen and member of the district parliament in Giessen. He serves on the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in the European Parliament. He is also a member of the Spinelli Group and the Union of European Federalists, and has received several awards for his academic work, including the Medal for Public Service of the District of Giessen, the Dr. Herbert Stolzenberg Award, and the Hessian State Award for Excellence in Academic Teaching.

Svenja Hahn is a German politician, born on 25 July 1989 in Hamburg, West Germany. She is a member of the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe. Hahn studied history and cultural studies at the University of Giessen and media studies at the Humboldt University of Berlin. She worked in public relations at edding in Hamburg from 2015 to 2019. Since 2019, Hahn has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament, representing Germany. She is part of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Special Committee on Artificial Intelligence in a Digital Age. Hahn also serves on the Parliament's delegation for relations with Southeast Asia and ASEAN, and is a member of several intergroups, including those focused on anti-racism, diversity, LGBT rights, and seas, rivers, islands, and coastal areas. She was the President of the European Liberal Youth from 2018 to 2020 and is the First Vice-President of the European Liberal Forum.

Sylvia Limmer, a German politician and member of the Alternative for Germany party, born in 1966, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Germany constituency since 2 July 2019, sitting on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and delegations for relations with Israel and the People's Republic of China, with a background as a veterinary nurse and a PhD in biology from the University of Bayreuth.

Sylvie Brunet, a French politician of the Democratic Movement (MoDem) and European Democratic Party, born on 12 March 1959 in Versailles, France. She has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing France, since 2 July 2019, with her term set to end on 15 July 2024. Brunet has served on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and has been part of various delegations, including those for relations with Palestine and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean. She has also been a member of several intergroups, including those focused on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, Trade Unions, the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and MEPs Against Cancer. Brunet served as deputy chair of the Renew Europe parliamentary group from 2019 to 2021. Her key contributions to plenary debates include discussions on mental health in the digital world of work, women's poverty in Europe, global threats to abortion rights, women in politics, specific measures to address the COVID-19 crisis, and a social Europe in a digital world. She has also contributed to reports on fair working treatment and conditions for workers throughout Europe, specifically platform workers. Brunet's brother is Stéphane Richard.

Sylvie Guillaume, a female French politician, born on June 11, 1962, in Antony, France, serving as a Member of the European Parliament from July 1, 2009, to July 15, 2024, representing South-East France and later France, affiliated with the Socialist Party and the Party of European Socialists, holding various roles including Vice President of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2019, and having a background as a civil servant and parliamentary aid, with a history of involvement in local politics as Deputy Mayor of Lyon and Member of the Municipal Council of Lyon, and holding positions in the Regional Council of Rhône-Alpes, with committee assignments focused on human rights, women's rights, and immigration, and being part of various intergroups including those on Artificial Intelligence, LGBT Rights, Disability, and Integrity.

Sylwia Spurek is a Polish lawyer and politician, born on January 29, 1976, in Skarżysko-Kamienna, Poland. She is a member of the European Parliament, serving from 2019 to 2024. Spurek is a specialist in criminal law and has been involved in various social and political activism, including women's rights, LGBTQIA+ rights, animal rights, and climate education. She is a vegan and an animal rights activist. Spurek has been a lecturer at the University of Warsaw and the Polish Academy of Sciences, and has authored several publications on domestic violence, equal treatment, and discrimination. She has been a member of the European Parliament Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Spurek has proposed several legislative initiatives, including a ban on animal farming, angling, horse riding, and hunting, and has advocated for the separation of the State and the Church. She is married to Marcin Anaszewicz and has been in a relationship with him since 2001. Spurek is autistic.

Sándor Rónai, Hungarian politician, born 22 November 1988, graduated from Eötvös Loránd University, speaks English and German, elected as a member of the Pest County Municipality in 2014, founding member and spokesperson of the Democratic Coalition since 2018, Member of the European Parliament for Hungary since 2 July 2019, representing the Democratic Coalition, vice-chair of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware since 2022, member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Delegation for relations with the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, and European Parliament Intergroup on Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development.

Søren Gade Jensen, born 27 January 1963, is a Danish politician from the Liberal party, Venstre. He was a military officer and businessman before entering politics. Gade served as Defence Minister from 2004 to 2010, leading Danish efforts in Afghanistan. He was a Member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2022, chairing the Committee on Fisheries and serving on the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Gade was elected Speaker of the Folketing in 2022. He was previously CEO of Landbrug & Fødevarer from 2012 to 2014. Gade has been a member of the Folketing since 2001, with terms in Ringkøbing County, Western Jutland, and North Jutland. He is a member of the Renew Europe group and has been part of the European Leadership Network's Advisory Board. Gade lost his wife Helle Buskbjerg Poulsen in 2008 and has two children. He holds the rank of Major in the Reserve in the Royal Danish Army.

Tamás Deutsch, a Hungarian politician, born on 27 July 1966 in Budapest, Hungary, and a member of Fidesz since 1988. He is a Jewish, divorced twice, and currently married to Erika Lazsányi since 2012, with five children, including Bence Deutsch. Deutsch graduated from the Eötvös Loránd University in Budapest. He was the Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports from 1 January 1999 to 27 May 2002, and a Member of the National Assembly from 2 May 1990 to 13 July 2009. Deutsch has been a Member of the European Parliament since 14 July 2009, representing Hungary. He was appointed Prime Ministerial Commissioner for the Digital Prosperity Programme on 19 December 2014. Deutsch has been involved in several controversies, including a Twitter incident where he made derogatory comments about Ferenc Gyurcsány and a comparison of a statement by Manfred Weber to the Gestapo's and ÁVH's principles.

Tanja Fajon, Slovenian politician, born 9 May 1971 in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Graduated in journalism at the Faculty of Political and Social Sciences, University of Ljubljana, and holds a master's degree in Science and International Politics from the College of Interdisciplinary Studies, University of Paris. Speaks Slovenian, English, German, French, and Croatian. Worked as a journalist and assistant editor at Radio Glas Ljubljana, reporter and writer for Republika, and correspondent for RTV Slovenia in Brussels and CNN. Elected to the European Parliament in 2009, served as vice chairwoman of the European Parliament delegation with Croatia, member of the Committee on Organised Crime, Corruption and Money Laundering, and full member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Served as Minister of Foreign and European Affairs in the government of Prime Minister Robert Golob since 1 June 2022. Leader of the Social Democrats since October 2020. Member of the European Council on Foreign Relations and Friends of Europe. Received several honors and awards, including Person of the Year 2009 in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a copy of the key of the city of Tirana, and an honorary doctorate from the American University in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
