Married to Veit-Ulrich Braun, a German journalist.

Tatjana Ždanoka, born 8 May 1950 in Riga, Latvian SSR, Soviet Union, to a Soviet navy officer father and a mathematics teacher mother, of mixed Latvian Jewish-Russian origin. She graduated from the Latvian State University with a degree in mathematics in 1972, and later gained the Candidate of Sciences degree in physics and mathematics in 1980, and a Doctor of Sciences degree in mathematics in 1992. Ždanoka was a member of the Communist Party of Latvia from 1971 to 1991, and later co-founded the Equal Rights party in 1993, and the For Human Rights in a United Latvia alliance in 2007. She was a member of the Supreme Soviet of the Latvian SSR from 1990 to 1993, and later served as a Member of the European Parliament from 2004 to 2018, and again from 2019 to 2024, representing the Latvian Russian Union party. Ždanoka has been accused of being a Russian intelligence agent since at least 2004, and has been criticized for her support of the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation, and her opposition to NATO and the European Union's sanctions against Russia. She has also been accused of inciting ethnic hatred or discord, and has been included in the European Platform for Democratic Elections database of "biased observers" for backing disputed elections in Russia and separatist areas in Ukraine. Ždanoka has described herself as a social democrat, and has advocated for the recognition of Russian as an official language in Latvia and the European Union. She has been married to Aleksandr Zhdanok from 1975 to 1988, and has been a citizen of Latvia since 1996, after previously being a citizen of the Soviet Union and later stateless.

Theresa Reintke, German politician, born 9 May 1987 in Gelsenkirchen, West Germany. Education: Otto-Suhr-Institut of the Free University of Berlin, thesis on "Local NGOs and sexualised violence in the Balkan conflicts". Party affiliation: Alliance 90/The Greens, part of The Greens–European Free Alliance. Occupation: Member of the European Parliament from Germany since 2014. Co-president of the Greens/EFA Group in the European Parliament. Former roles: spokesperson of the Federation of Young European Greens, legislative advisor at the Bundestag, member of the executive board of German Green Youth. Committee assignments: Women's Rights and Gender Equality, Employment and Social Affairs, Regional Development, Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, Anti-Corruption, and Trade Unions. Member of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-UK Parliamentary Assembly. Part of the party's delegation in the working group on European affairs for the 2021 German elections and the 2022 state elections in North Rhine-Westphalia. Chosen to steer the European Green Party's campaign for the 2024 European Parliament election. Member of the Advisory Board on Participation, Gender Democracy and Anti-Discrimination at the Heinrich Böll Foundation. Personal life: in a relationship with Mélanie Vogel, lives in Brussels.

Teuvo Hakkarainen, Finnish politician, born 12 April 1960 in Viitasaari, Finland. Former member of the European Parliament (2 July 2019 - 15 July 2024) and the Finnish Parliament (20 April 2011 - 2 July 2019), representing Central Finland. Initially a member of the Finns Party, expelled in 2024, and subsequently ran as an uncommitted candidate for the Freedom Alliance in the 2024 European Parliament election. Convicted of incitement against an ethnic group in 2017 and assault and sexual harassment in 2017, fined 5,440 euros. Made controversial comments on sexual minorities, death penalty, and racism, including suggesting the deportation of homosexuals, lesbians, and Somalis to Åland. Used a pejorative racial slur in an interview and made a mocking imitation of the Islamic call to prayer. Supported the re-enactment of capital punishment in certain cases. Co-owner of the Haka-Wood saw mill, which received European Union subsidies despite his Eurosceptic campaign. Worked as a sawmill consultant in Central America. Had a suspended sentence for a 1986 church break-in and theft.

Teófilo Santos, born 12 February 1951, in Viana do Castelo, Portugal, is a Portuguese politician and lawyer. He is a member of the Social Democratic Party. His political career includes serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal from 2 April 2024 to 15 July 2024, succeeding José Manuel Fernandes. Additionally, he was a Member of the Leiria Municipal Assembly from 1 October 2017 to 26 September 2021.

Theodoros Zagorakis is a Greek politician and former professional footballer. He was born on October 27, 1971, in Lydia, Kavala, Greece. Zagorakis is a member of the New Democracy party and has been a Member of the European Parliament since July 1, 2014. He was re-elected in the European Parliament in the elections of 2019 but was not re-elected in 2024, after switching to PASOK. He served as the president of the Hellenic Football Federation from March 2021 to September 2021 and was previously the president of PAOK from June 2007 to October 2009 and January 2010 to January 2012. Zagorakis is a former captain of the Greece national football team and won the UEFA European Championship in 2004.

Theresa Muigg, born 15 June 1984, in Schwaz, Tyrol, Austria, is an Austrian politician and a member of the Social Democratic Party of Austria. She has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for Austria since 10 October 2022, succeeding Bettina Vollath.

Theresa Griffin, Labour Party, North West England, born 11 December 1962 in Coventry, Warwickshire, to Irish immigrant parents, father a machinist, mother a teaching assistant, attended Bishop Ullathorne Comprehensive school, first class B.A. and M.A. from Lancaster University, member of Labour Party since 1988, Unite's North West Political Committee, Regional Organiser for UNISON, Director of Communications and Research at North West Arts, Liverpool City Councillor, lead member for Economic Development and Europe, supported Owen Smith in 2016 Labour Party leadership election, winner of Energy Award, MEP Awards 2017, supported Cammell Laird strikers, Fair Pay Fortnight, Carbon Capture and Storage technology, Market Stability Reserve for EU Emissions Trading System, advocated EU-wide coordination of national energy policies, contributed to UK Parliament's Energy and Climate Change Committee report, called for more EU funding to global health research, full member and Labour Party Spokesperson for Industry, Research and Energy Committee, substitute member on Transport and Tourism Committee, member of Delegation to EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, Delegation for Relations with People's Republic of China, EU Intergroups on Disability Rights, Digital Agenda for Europe, Children's Rights and Well-being, LGBTI, SMEs, Tourism, Trade Union, Urban, Chair of European Parliamentary Labour Party from 14 September 2016 to 31 January 2020, Member of European Parliament for North West England from 1 July 2014 to 31 January 2020.

Thierry Mariani, born 8 August 1958 in Orange, France, is a French politician with Italian origin from Castellafiume. He is married to Irina Chaikhoullina, a Russian national who obtained French citizenship in 2011. Mariani's political career started in 1976 alongside Nicolas Sarkozy. He was a member of the Union of Democrats for the Republic, Rally for the Republic, Union for a Popular Movement, The Republicans, and has been a member of the National Rally since 2019. 

Mariani held various positions, including Mayor of Valréas from 1989 to 2005, regional councillor of Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur from 1992 to 1993 and 2004 to 2015, General councillor of Vaucluse from 1988 to 2001, Vice President of the General Council of Vaucluse from 1992 to 2001, Member of the National Assembly for Vaucluse's 4th constituency from 1993 to 2010, Member of the National Assembly for French residents overseas from 2012 to 2017, and Member of the European Parliament for France since 2019.

He served as Secretary of State for Transport from 2010 to 2011 and Minister in charge of Transport from 2011 to 2012. Mariani was also the French Special Representative for Pakistan and Afghanistan during the Kabul elections in 2009. He has been involved in various controversies, including links with Azerbaijan, support for the Assad regime in Syria, and suspected corruption and influence peddling related to his activities within the Franco-Russian Dialogue association.

Thijs Reuten is a Dutch Labour Party politician. He was born in 1974 in Bussum, North Holland, to a father who was an Augustinian priest and a mother whose parents had immigrated to the Netherlands from Italy. Reuten studied political science and international relations at the University of Amsterdam. He began his career as a policy advisor of the Labour Party's parliamentary group in the House of Representatives and was a member of the Amsterdam municipal council from 2002 to 2007. He then served as a district alderman in Amsterdam-Oost from 2010 to 2018, focusing on housing and the economy. Reuten worked as an independent consultant and as head of policy at the Global Reporting Initiative from 2018 to 2021. He was appointed to the European Parliament in April 2021, replacing Kati Piri, and was re-elected in June 2024. Reuten is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and serves on several committees, including the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. He has been a vocal advocate for human rights and has proposed designating the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a terrorist organization. Reuten has been sanctioned by the Iranian government for his support of European sanctions against the regime. He is a resident of Zaandam, has a son, and is an avid piano player. His relatives include actress Thekla Reuten, economist and Socialist Party politician Geert Reuten, and actress Rosa Reuten.

Thomas Rudner, a German politician and Member of the European Parliament for the Social Democratic Party of Germany, representing the constituency of Germany since 2 July 2023, born 11 September 1961 in Schwäbisch Gmünd, West Germany.

Thomas Waitz, born 16 May 1973 in Vienna, Austria, is an ecological farmer, forester, and politician for the Greens Party. He has been a member of the European Parliament since November 2017, serving on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Committee on Agriculture and Petitions, Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Committee, and the Committee of Inquiry on the Protection of Animals during Transport. He is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals. Waitz has been the co-chair of the European Green Party since 10 November 2019, alongside Evelyne Huytebroeck until 5 June 2022, and currently alongside Mélanie Vogel. He is committed to a common, eco-social economic policy of the EU, uniform social standards within Europe, and focuses on agriculture, food quality, food safety, animal welfare, and combating climate change. Waitz also supports a Europe-wide ban on nuclear weapons and has been involved in actionism, including protests against illegal animal transport and nuclear warheads in Europe.

Tiemo Wölken, a German lawyer and politician, born on 5 December 1985 in Otterndorf, Lower Saxony, Germany. Educated at Halepaghen Grammar School, University of Osnabrück, and University of Hull. Member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Party of European Socialists. Member of the European Parliament since 14 November 2016, representing Germany. Served on the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Committee on Budgets, and Committee on Legal Affairs. Coordinator for his parliamentary group on the Committee on Legal Affairs and lead rapporteur on health technology assessment. Co-authored a resolution to protect journalists and critical voices from strategic lawsuits against public participation. Part of the Parliament's delegations to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly, EU-Mexico Joint Parliamentary Committee, and Canada. Co-chairs the MEP Interest Group on Antimicrobial Resistance. Member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Anti-Corruption, Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas, Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, European Internet Forum, and Responsible Business Conduct Working Group. Nominated as delegate to the Federal Convention for the purpose of electing the President of Germany in 2022. Member of the Political Advisory Board of the Business Forum of the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Education and Science Workers' Union.

Tilly Metz, a Luxembourgish politician, born on 26 May 1967 in Luxembourg City, Luxembourg. She is a member of the Green Party (déi Gréng) and has been a Member of the European Parliament since June 2018, as part of the Greens/EFA political group. Metz is married to Barbara Agostino. She succeeded Claude Turmes in the European Parliament. Metz has been involved in various committees, including the Subcommittee on Public Health (SANT), Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), Delegation for relations with South Africa (DZA), Committee on Agriculture and Sustainable Development (AGRI), and Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN). She has also chaired the Delegation for relations with Central American countries (DCAM) and the special ANIT committee. Metz is known for her stance on animal welfare, health-related issues, and human rights. She has been a strong advocate for environmental protection, sustainable tourism, and the rights of people with rare diseases and disabilities. Metz has also been involved in the cause of human rights, particularly in Central America, and has spoken out against nuclear weapons and animal testing.

Tineke Strik, born Martina Hermina Antonia Strik on 28 September 1961 in Alphen, Netherlands, studied social-cultural work at the social academy "Den Elzent" in Eindhoven and international law at the Radboud University. She worked as a youth worker, legal consultant, judicial secretary, policy advisor, and policy coordinator. She was alderman for social affairs in Wageningen from 2002 to 2006 and researcher-PhD-candidate at the Centre for Migration law of the Radboud University from 2004. She was a member of the Senate from 2007 to 2019 and has been a member of the European Parliament for the Greens since 2019, representing the Netherlands. She was re-elected in June 2024 as the fifth candidate on the shared GroenLinks–PvdA list.

Tiziana Beghin, Italian politician, born 4 February 1971 in Genoa, Italy, graduated in economics and business from the University of Genoa, with specialization in Human Resources & Management, worked as a financial advisor, provided consultancy to SMEs for business development from 2005 to 2014, member of the Five Star Movement, elected as a Member of the European Parliament in 2014 with 22,485 preferences and re-elected in 2019 with 15,039 votes, representing the North-West Italy constituency, serving from 1 July 2014 to 16 July 2024.

Toine Manders, a male politician from the Netherlands, born on 14 March 1956 in Stiphout, Netherlands, educated at the Academy for Industrial Design in Tilburg and Maastricht University, with a degree in law. He is a member of the Christian Democratic Appeal party since 2020, previously a member of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy until 2013 and 50PLUS from 2013 to 2020. He served as a Member of the European Parliament from 20 July 1999 to 30 June 2014 and again from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, representing the Netherlands constituency. He was part of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe until 2013 and the European People's Party Group since 2019. His committee assignments include the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and he was the Parliament's rapporteur on the Environmental Liability Directive in 2004.

Tom B. W. Berendsen, a Dutch politician, was born on 11 April 1983 in Breda, Netherlands, and is a member of the Christian Democratic Appeal party. He studied public administration at Tilburg University and the Catholic University of Leuven. Berendsen worked as an intern at the lobbying office for North Brabant, then for the CDA delegation at the European Parliament from 2009 until 2015, and later as a sustainability consultant for PricewaterhouseCoopers in the Netherlands. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing the Netherlands constituency, and is a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Regional Development, and the European Parliament's delegation for relations to the Pan-African Parliament. He is married and supports football club NAC Breda.

Tom Vandendriessche, a Belgian politician and businessman, born on 27 October 1978 in Leuven, Belgium. He holds a master's degree in political sciences and a master's degree in business economics from Ghent University. Vandendriessche is a member of the Vlaams Belang party and has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Dutch-speaking electoral college since 2 July 2019. He is known for his strong stance on migration, advocating for strict migration policies, and is a proponent of the 'Fortress Europe' plan. Vandendriessche is also a vocal critic of the European migration pact and the Global Compact on Migration. In economics, he supports a free market economy with social corrections, promoting a Rhineland model. He is opposed to labour migration and globalist trends, instead advocating for innovation, automation, and family-friendly policies. Vandendriessche has also expressed his opposition to the European Green Deal, supporting European farmers' protests, and is a staunch defender of European cultural heritage and traditions, opposing the woke movement.

Tom Vandenkendelaere, a Belgian politician, born on 2 September 1984 in Roeselare, member of the Christian Democratic and Flemish party (CD&V), served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 6 November 2014 to 2019 and again since 2021. He was chairman of the CD&V youth wing from 2013 to 2014. His committee assignments have included the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), the "Panama Papers" Inquiry Committee (PANA), the delegation for relations with the People's Republic of China, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence. He has also been a member of the parliament's delegation for relations with Iran and has chaired the delegation to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. In 2021, he initiated a nonbinding resolution denouncing the “illegal arrest” and conviction of Rwandan politician Paul Rusesabagina and urging the EU to ramp up its efforts to secure his release.

Tomas Tobé, a Swedish politician, was born on 16 February 1978 in Gävle, Sweden. He is a member of the Moderate Party. Tobé is married to Markus Tobé, and they have twins born via surrogacy. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Sweden. Tobé has also been a Member of the Riksdag from 2 October 2006 to 1 July 2019, representing Stockholm County and Gävleborg County. His previous roles include Secretary-General of the Moderate Party from 10 January 2015 to 2 June 2017, and Vice-Chair of the European People's Party in the European Parliament since 19 June 2024. Tobé is the Chair of the Parliament's Committee on Development since 2019, and a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. He has also been a rapporteur on asylum and migration since 2020. Tobé supported Swedish membership in NATO after the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Tomasz Frankowski, born August 16, 1974, in Białystok, Poland, height 5 ft 9 in, is a Polish former professional footballer who played as a striker and a member of the European Parliament for the Civic Platform. He was capped 22 times for the Poland national team, scoring ten goals, and played for several clubs including Jagiellonia Białystok, RC Strasbourg, Nagoya Grampus Eight, Wisła Kraków, Elche CF, Wolverhampton Wanderers, CD Tenerife, and Chicago Fire. Frankowski achieved his greatest success at Wisła Kraków, where he helped fire them to a collection of domestic honours. He was top league goalscorer four times and the league's third all-time scorer with 168 goals in 302 matches in Polish Ekstraklasa. He was elected to the European Parliament in 2019 from the first place in Podlaskie and Warmian-Masurian constituency. In 2021, he voiced his opposition to the planned European Super League and to holding the World Cup every two years.

Tomasz Piotr Poręba, a Polish politician, was born on March 31, 1973, in Grybów, Lesser Poland Voivodeship, to Maria and Antoni, a railway worker. He studied history and political science at the Pedagogical University of Cracow, later continuing his studies in journalism. He also holds a postgraduate degree in European studies from the University of Warsaw and Maastricht University. Professionally, he played football as a striker in III league Cracow’s clubs, including Kabel Kraków, Karpaty Siepraw, and Górnik Wieliczka. He worked as a sport journalist in Gazeta Krakowska. He was employed in the Chancellery of the Prime Minister and the Institute of National Remembrance in Warsaw. He joined the Law and Justice Party in 2003, serving as the Head of Information and Public Relations Department. He worked as a Senior Advisor in the European Parliament and as a spokesperson for Law and Justice Members. He was elected as a Member of the European Parliament from Podkarpackie Voivodeship in 2009, 2014, and 2019, serving as vice-chair of the Delegation of Law and Justice and the Committee of Transport and Tourism. He led the Law and Justice Election Committee for the national parliament and local government elections. He is the president of the conservative European think tank "New Direction" and the Vice-President of the Polish Olympic Committee. He is married with two daughters.

Tomislav Sokol, a Croatian politician, born on 20 September 1982 in Zagreb, SR Croatia, Yugoslavia, currently serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Croatian Democratic Union since 2 July 2019, representing the constituency of Croatia, affiliated with the European People's Party, and holding committee assignments including the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and rapporteur on the European Commission’s proposal for a European Health Data Space, as well as being part of the Parliament's delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, and a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Tomáš Zdechovský, a Czech politician and businessperson, born on 2 November 1979 in Havlíčkův Brod, Czechoslovakia, is a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the Czech Republic for the Christian and Democratic Union-Czechoslovak People's Party and the European People's Party. He holds master's degrees in Pastoral Assistant and Educator of Free Time from the University of South Bohemia and Media studies from Masaryk University, as well as a bachelor's degree in Political Communication from the Salesian Pontifical University. Zdechovský has been involved in various initiatives, including criticism of the Norwegian child protection policy, the European migrant crisis, and alleged fraud in obtaining EU subsidies. He has also been an advocate for Czech Christmas traditions and has published several collections of poems and a novel. His profession includes being a crisis manager, media analyst, and author.

Tonino Picula, a Croatian politician from the Social Democratic Party, born on August 31, 1961, in Mali Lošinj, Croatia. He graduated in sociology from the University of Zagreb and earned the title of professor of sociology. He is married to Marijana Mikić and has one daughter. Picula served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2000 to 2003, and as mayor of Velika Gorica from 2005 to 2009. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for Croatia since 2013, sitting with the Progressive Alliance of Socialists & Democrats. He is a strong proponent of EU enlargement and has been involved in various parliamentary activities, including the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and Delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo. Picula has also been recognized for his work, including being awarded the “Greening the Islands Award” in 2017 and being voted “MEP of the year” by the European Small Island Federation in 2018.

Traian Băsescu, 5th President of Romania, served from 20 December 2004 to 21 December 2014. Born on 4 November 1951 in Basarabi, Romania. He is a member of the People's Movement Party and the European People's Party. He was previously a member of the Romanian Communist Party, National Salvation Front, and the Democratic Party. He was the Mayor of Bucharest from 26 June 2000 to 20 December 2004, Minister of Transport from 30 April 1991 to 19 November 1992, 12 December 1996 to 11 February 1998, and 17 April 1998 to 26 June 2000. He was a Member of the Chamber of Deputies from October 1992 to 14 November 2000, and a Member of the European Parliament for Romania from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024. He holds dual citizenship of Romania and Moldova from 2016 to 2017. He is married to Maria Andrușca and has two children, including Elena. He graduated from Mircea cel Bătrân Naval Academy.

Tsvetelina Penkova, a Bulgarian politician, born 19 February 1988 in Sofia, Bulgaria, is a Member of the European Parliament for Bulgaria since 2 July 2019, affiliated with the Bulgarian Socialist Party, educated at the American College, Central European University, Bocconi University, McGill University, and the University of Oxford, with a background in finance, having worked at Hayfin Capital Management and the Royal Bank of Scotland, and co-founded the Millenium Club Bulgaria.

Tudor Ciuhodaru, a Romanian medical doctor and politician, serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Social Democratic Party since 2019, representing the constituency of Romania, and holding the position of MEP.

Udo Bullmann, a male, born 8 June 1956, in Giessen, West Germany, is a German politician and a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD). He is married with 3 children. Bullmann studied political science, sociology, public law, and economics at the University of Giessen, receiving a M.A. in 1982 and a doctorate in 1988. He worked as a research assistant at the University of Giessen from 1989 to 1996 and held a scholarship of the German Research Council from 1994 to 1997. Bullmann was a Visiting Research Fellow at the Department of Government at Strathclyde University in Glasgow, Scotland, from 1994 to 1998 and a university lecturer and Jean Monnet Professor for Studies in European integration at the University of Giessen in 1998. He has been a member of the European Parliament since 1999, representing Germany. He served as deputy chair of the SPD group in the European Parliament from 2003 to 2012 and as its chair from 2012 to 2017. Bullmann was the leader of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats from 20 March 2018 to 1 July 2019. He is a member of the Committee on Development and the Committee on International Trade, and the chair of the Subcommittee on Human Rights since February 2023. Bullmann was re-elected to the European Parliament in 2024.

Ulrike Müller is a German politician and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Germany, born on 7 December 1962 in Augsburg, Germany. She is a member of Free Voters and part of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (2014–2019) and the Renew Group (since 2019). Since October 2023, she is also a Member of the Bavarian Parliament. Müller has a background in dairy production, running a family farm in Oberallgäu. She is married with two adult children. Müller's previous roles include local councillor (1996-2008), deputy mayor (2002-2008), county council member (1996-2014), and deputy county commissioner (2002-2008). She was a member of the Bavarian state parliament (2008-2014) and served on committees for Nutrition, Agriculture, and Forestry. Müller joined the European Parliament in 2014 and has been a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, and the Committee on Petitions. She has also been part of various parliamentary delegations, including the Delegation for relations with Australia and New Zealand, which she chairs. Müller has been the Renew spokeswoman on agricultural affairs since 2019 and deputy executive vice president of the European Democratic Party since 2019.

Urmas Paet, Estonian politician, born 20 April 1974 in Tallinn, Estonia, member of the Reform Party. Education: University of Tartu, BA in political science, 1996. Career: journalist at Estonian Radio and Postimees, 1996-1999; professional advisor, Reform Party, 1999; Deputy Mayor of Nõmme, 1999-2003; Minister of Culture, 2003-2005; Minister of Foreign Affairs, 2005-2014; Member of the Estonian Parliament, 2003-2014; Member of the European Parliament, 2014-present. Committees: Committee on Budgets, 2014-2019; Committee on Foreign Affairs, Subcommittee on Security and Defence, 2019-present. Delegations: relations with Southeast Asia and ASEAN, Digital Agenda, Welfare and Conservation of Animals, LGBT Rights. Awards: Security & Defence Award, 2019 and 2022.

Valentino Grant, Italian politician, born 21 April 1964 in Rome, member of the European Parliament since 2 July 2019, representing Southern Italy, affiliated with the League party, serving until 9 June 2024, profession banker, President Board of Directors of Banca di Credito Cooperativo Terra di Lavoro San Vincenzo dè Paoli.

Valter Flego, a Croatian politician, was born on 15 August 1972 in Koper, SR Slovenia, Yugoslavia. He is a member of the liberal Istrian Democratic Assembly party and Renew Europe. Flego is a mechanical engineer, graduating from the University of Rijeka in 1996. He also holds a scientific master's degree in economics from the Rijeka Faculty of Economics. Flego served as the Mayor of Buzet from 2001 to 2013 and as the Prefect of Istria County from 7 June 2013 to 2 July 2019. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for Croatia since 2 July 2019. Flego is married to Branka Flego and has two sons, Dinko and Ivo.

Valérie Hayer, a 37-year-old French lawyer and politician, born on April 6, 1986, in Château-Gontier, France, to dairy farmers from La Mayenne. She is a member of Renaissance (RE, formerly La République En Marche!) since 2017, and previously affiliated with the Union of Democrats and Independents (UDI) and Centrist Alliance (AC). Hayer is a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for France since July 2, 2019, and has been the leader of Renew Europe since January 25, 2024. She served as a departmental councillor of Mayenne from April 2, 2015, to June 27, 2021, and as a municipal councillor of Saint-Denis-d'Anjou from March 21, 2008, to July 1, 2019. Hayer holds degrees from the University of Angers and Paris 1 Panthéon-Sorbonne University. She has worked as a parliamentary assistant for several members of the Senate of France and the European Parliament, including Pierre Jarlier and Jean Arthuis. Hayer is the president of the Association for European Revival, which is financed by LREM. She has been critical of Marine Le Pen and Viktor Orban's relationships with Russian president Vladimir Putin and has expressed concerns about the persecution of Uyghurs in China. Hayer is part of the European Parliament's delegation for relations with Southeast Asia and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), the European Internet Forum, the European Parliament Intergroup on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, and the MEPs Against Cancer group.

Vangelis Meimarakis, a Greek politician born on December 14, 1953, in Athens, Greece, of Cretan descent, with a father who was a Member of the Hellenic Parliament. He is married to Ioanna Kolokota, has two daughters, and is fluent in English. Meimarakis studied at Panteion University and the University of Athens, and is a lawyer by profession. He joined New Democracy in 1974 and co-founded the Youth Organisation of New Democracy (ONNED) the same year. Meimarakis held various positions, including Deputy Minister for Sports, Secretary of the Central Committee of New Democracy, Minister for National Defence, Speaker of the Hellenic Parliament, and acting President of New Democracy and Leader of the Opposition. He has been a Member of the Hellenic Parliament for Athens B from 1989 to 2019 and a Member of the European Parliament since 2019, serving on the Committee on Foreign Affairs and its Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and as part of the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe.

Vasco Emanuel Vinagre Becker-Weinberg, a Portuguese politician, born 21 September 1979 in Lisbon, Portugal, educated at the University of Lisbon and the University of Hamburg, occupation: Lawyer and Politician, member of the CDS – People's Party, part of the EPP Group, served as a Member of the European Parliament for Portugal from 26 March 2024 to 15 July 2024, succeeding Nuno Melo.

Vasile Blaga, born on 26 July 1956, in Petrileni, Bihor County, Romania. He is a Romanian politician, educated at Polytechnic University of Timișoara and Carol I National Defence University. Blaga is married to Margareta Violett Blaga and has two children. He has been affiliated with the National Salvation Front (1990-1993), Democratic Party (1993-2007), Democratic Liberal Party (2007-2014), and National Liberal Party (2014-present). Blaga's political career includes: Member of the Chamber of Deputies (1990-1992) representing Bihor County; Prefect of Bihor County (1991-1993); Member of the Senate (1996-2000, 2004-2016) representing Bihor County and Bucharest; Minister of Internal Affairs (2004-2007, 2009-2010); Minister of Regional Development and Public Administration (2008-2009); President of the Senate (2011-2012); President of the Democratic Liberal Party (2012-2014); and co-President of the National Liberal Party (2014-2016).

Vera E. R. Tax, a Dutch politician, born on 8 February 1972 in Venlo, Netherlands, served as a Member of the European Parliament for the Labour Party, representing the Netherlands constituency from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024.

Veronika Vrecionová is a Czech politician, born on 8 September 1965 in České Budějovice, Czechoslovakia. She holds the position of Member of the European Parliament, representing the Czech Republic constituency since 2 July 2019. Vrecionová is affiliated with the Civic Democratic Party and serves as the chairwoman of the EU Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. She has a background in economics, having graduated from the University of Economics, Prague. Vrecionová is a pet owner, with three dogs and seven cats, and has two children.

Victor Negrescu, born 17 August 1985, is a Romanian politician of the Social Democratic Party. He holds an MBA in executive business and a PhD in development cooperation from the National University of Political Studies and Public Administration. Negrescu was a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2017 and again from 2020 to 2024, serving on the Committee on Budgets, Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Committee on Legal Affairs, Committee on Culture and Education. He was the Minister Delegate for European Affairs in the government of Romania from 29 June 2017 to 10 November 2018. Negrescu is the president and national coordinator of the Romanian network of PES activists since 2007 and a lecturer at the National School of Political Science and Public Administration since 2012. He won the "MEP of the Year" Award in the Digital Agenda category of the MEP Awards 2015. Negrescu's work focuses on promoting the Romanian IT sector, supporting youth in the EU, and contributing to the development of the European digital sector.

Viktor Uspaskich, born 24 July 1959, Russian-born Lithuanian entrepreneur and politician. He graduated from Urdom high school in 1976 and served in the Soviet Army from 1977 to 1979. Uspaskich formed his own company Efektas in 1990 and took citizenship of the newly formed Republic of Lithuania in 1991. He was chairman of the Association of Lithuanian Employers from 1997 to 2003 and a non-party member of the Naujoji sąjunga (New Union) social liberal party in the Seimas (parliament) from 2000. Uspaskich formed the Darbo Partija (Labour Party) in 2003 and became Minister of Economic Affairs in Lithuania's coalition government from 2004 to 2006. He has been a Member of the European Parliament for Lithuania since 2014 and previously from 2009 to 2012. Uspaskich has been involved in controversies, including tax fraud, pseudoscientific beliefs, alleged COVID-19 cure, homophobic and transphobic remarks, and financially supporting fake news websites. He was sentenced to 4 years in prison for tax fraud in 2013 but has not served the sentence due to his legal immunity as a member of the Lithuanian Parliament and the European Parliament. Uspaskich has been married to Jolanta Blažytė from 1991 to 2017 and has 4 children.

Vilija Blinkevičiūtė is a Lithuanian lawyer and politician, born on 3 March 1960 in Linkuva, Lithuania. She graduated with honours from Linkuva Secondary School and obtained a Master of Laws from Vilnius State University in 1983. Blinkevičiūtė is a member of the Social Democratic Party of Lithuania since 2006 and previously a member of the New Union (Social Liberals) from 2000-2006. She has served as the Minister for Social Security and Labour from 2000-2008, Member of the Seimas from 2004-2009, and Member of the European Parliament since 2009. She has been the Chairwoman of the Social Democratic Party of Lithuania since 29 May 2021. She was a Vice-Chair of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality and later became the Chair of the committee in January 2017. She is also a full member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and a substitute member of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee. She was bestowed with the Cross of Commander of the Order for Merits to Lithuania in 2004.

Ville Matti Niinistö, Finnish politician, born 30 July 1976 in Turku, Finland, nephew of Sauli Niinistö, former president of Finland. Master's degree in political science from the University of Turku. Member of the European Parliament since 5 July 2019, representing Finland. Former Minister of the Environment from 22 June 2011 to 25 September 2014, under Prime Ministers Jyrki Katainen and Alexander Stubb. Former chairperson of the Green League from 11 June 2011 to 17 June 2017. Member of the Finnish Parliament from 18 March 2007 to 16 April 2019, representing Finland Proper. Member of the city council of Turku. Married to Maria Wetterstrand from 2004 to 2012, with two children, Elias and Linnea. Member of the Supervisory Board of Finnvera since 2016.

Vincenzo Sofo, Italian politician, born 18 December 1986 in Milan, Italy, married to Marion Maréchal, with one child, graduated in Economics from the Catholic University of the Sacred Heart, member of Brothers of Italy, previously affiliated with The Right, Lega Nord, and League for Salvini Premier, served as Member of the European Parliament for Southern Italy from 1 February 2020 to 15 July 2024.

Viola von Cramon-Taubadel is a German politician of Alliance 90/The Greens who served as a member of the European Parliament from 2019 to 2024 and of the Bundestag, the German federal parliament, from 2009 to 2013. Born on 23 March 1970 in Halle (Westphalia), West Germany, she graduated from the University of Bonn with a degree in Agricultural economics. Von Cramon has been a member of the Green Party since 2001. She served on the Committee on Foreign Affairs in the European Parliament and was its rapporteur on relations with the Western Balkans. She was also a member of the Parliamentary Friendship Group for Relations with the States of the Southern Caucasus and the Parliamentary Friendship Group for Relations with the States of Central Asia. Von Cramon is married to German nobleman Stephan von Cramon-Taubadel and they have 4 children.

Create a voting profile for a 49-year-old French female politician, born on December 11, 1973, in Troyes, France, and educated at the University of Nice. She is a member of the National Rally party and has held the office of Member of the Regional Council of Grand Est from January 4, 2016, to July 2, 2021. She has been a Member of the European Parliament, representing France, since July 2, 2019, and was re-elected in 2024.

Vlad Gheorghe, a Romanian politician and lawyer, born on 22 February 1985 in Bucharest, Romania, specializing in administrative-fiscal law, European funds, and public procurement, with over 8 years of experience in NGOs and private companies, particularly in projects with European funds on infrastructure, environment, and human resources, gained public attention after being beaten by gendarmes at an anti-government rally in 2018, was a vocal protester demanding investigation into violence, ran for the European Parliament in 2019, became a Member of Parliament on 10 November 2020, replacing Clotilde Armand, and received the Promoting European Value Award in June 2023, currently affiliated with the DREPT party since 2024, previously with Renew Europe from 2019 to 2024, and briefly an independent politician in 2024.
Vlad Botoș, a Romanian politician and Member of the European Parliament, representing the Save Romania Union (USR) party, constituency of Romania.
Vlad Nistor, a Romanian politician and Member of the European Parliament, representing the National Liberal Party (PNL), constituency of Romania.

Vladimír Bilčík, a male politician from Slovakia, born on 27 May 1975 in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, now Slovakia, with a Bachelor of Arts from Swarthmore College, a Master of Philosophy from St Antony's College, Oxford, and a Doctor of Philosophy from Comenius University. He is a member of the Democrats party since 2019 and has been a Member of the European Parliament for the Slovakia constituency from 2 July 2019 to 15 July 2024, as part of the European People's Party parliamentary group. He has served on the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, and the Parliament's delegation to the Conference on the Future of Europe. He is married with 2 children and has been the EPP shadow rapporteur for the European Media Freedom Act and rapporteur for relations with Serbia.

Vânia Andreia Lopes Neto, a Portuguese lawyer and politician, born 25 April 1979 in Santarém, Portugal, is married to Ricardo Gonçalves, the Mayor of Santarém, and they have 2 children. She is a member of the Social Democratic Party, and has an educational background from NOVA University Lisbon. Her political career includes being a member of the Santarém City Council from 3 March 2009 to 29 September 2013, and a member of the European Parliament for Portugal, serving from 2 April 2024 to 15 July 2024, succeeding Maria da Graça Carvalho.

Véronique Trillet-Lenoir, a French politician and oncologist, born on June 12, 1957, in Lyon, France, and deceased on August 9, 2023. She was a member of La République En Marche! and served in the European Parliament from July 2, 2019, until her death. Trillet-Lenoir was educated at Claude Bernard University Lyon 1, where she earned her medical degree in 1980, a state doctorate in medicine in 1985, and a doctorate in human biology in 1991. She worked at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, the University of Lyon-I, and the University Hospital Centre of Lyon, and was the founding head of the oncology department. Trillet-Lenoir also held positions at the Cancéropôle Lyon Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes and the National Cancer Institute, and was an associate professor at the Faculty of Medicine of Shanghai Jiao Tong University. She was a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Special Committee on Beating Cancer, and the Special Committee on the COVID-19 pandemic, and co-chaired the MEPs Against Cancer group. Trillet-Lenoir received the Legion of Honour in 2008 and the National Order of Merit in 2016.

Waldemar Tomaszewski, a Polish-Lithuanian politician, born on 3 March 1965 in Vilnius, Lithuanian SSR, Soviet Union. He studied mechanics at the Vilnius Civil Engineering Institute, graduating in 1990. Tomaszewski is the leader of the Electoral Action of Poles in Lithuania – Christian Families Alliance. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2009, representing the Lithuania constituency and sitting in the European Conservatives and Reformists group. Tomaszewski previously served as a Member of the Seimas from 2000 to 2009, representing the Šalčininkai constituency. He was also deputy mayor of Vilnius district from 2000 to 2003. Tomaszewski was awarded the Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland.

Witold Pahl, a Polish politician from the Civic Platform, born on 7 December 1961 in Wrocław, Poland, studied law at the Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań, worked at the district court in Słubice and Gorzów Wielkopolski, member of the Gorzów Wielkopolski City Council since 2006, member of the Sejm since 2007, representing the Zielona Góra constituency with 14,135 votes, member of the European Parliament since 16 November 2023, representing the Lubusz and West Pomeranian constituency, replacing Bartosz Arłukowicz, married with a son.

Witold Jan Waszczykowski, Polish politician, born 5 May 1957 in Piotrków Trybunalski, Poland, graduate of University of Łódź and University of Oregon, PhD in history from University of Łódź, joined Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1992, served as Ambassador to Iran 1999-2002, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs 2005-2008, Deputy Head of National Security Bureau 2008-2010, Member of Sejm 2011-2019, Minister of Foreign Affairs 2015-2018, Member of European Parliament since 2019, affiliated with Law and Justice party.

Wolfram Pirchner, Austrian People's Party politician, born 21 April 1958 in Innsbruck, Tirol, Austria, served as a Member of the European Parliament for Austria from 24 September 2023 to 2024, replacing Simone Schmiedtbauer, unseated in the 2024 European Parliament election.

Włodzimierz Cimoszewicz, a Polish politician, born on 13 September 1950 in Warsaw, Poland. He was a member of the left-wing Democratic Left Alliance. Cimoszewicz served as Prime Minister of Poland from 7 February 1996 to 31 October 1997. He was also the chairman of the Committee for European Integration from October 1996 to 31 October 1997. Cimoszewicz held the position of Foreign Minister of Poland in the governments of Leszek Miller and Marek Belka from 2001 to 2005. He was the speaker of the Sejm from January to October 2005. Cimoszewicz was a candidate for the 2005 Polish presidential election but withdrew before the elections. He returned to politics in 2007 and won a Senate seat as an independent candidate. In 2009, he was a candidate to replace Terry Davis as Secretary General of the Council of Europe. Since 2015, Cimoszewicz has been workstream leader for the Agency for the Modernisation of Ukraine. In the 2019 European Parliament election, he was elected as the MEP for the Warsaw constituency. Cimoszewicz has expressed his unhappiness with the way the Russian annexation of Crimea was handled. He is married to Barbara Cimoszewicz and has one child. Cimoszewicz has received the Order of the White Star and the Order for Merits to Lithuania. He is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats and The Left.

Włodzimierz Witold Karpiński, a Polish politician, born on 16 November 1961 in Puławy, with a degree in chemical engineering from Warsaw University of Technology and a degree in management from the University of Warsaw. Married with five sons. Served as vice president of Puławy and member of the city council from 1994, deputy Minister of Interior and Administration in 2011, deputy Minister of Administration and Digitization from 2011 to 2013, and Minister of State Treasury from 24 April 2013 to 15 June 2015. Member of the Sejm from 25 September 2005 to 2019, representing the 6 – Lublin constituency as a candidate from the Civic Platform list, and Member of the European Parliament since 2023.

Jana Toom, Estonian politician, born 15 October 1966 in Tallinn, Estonia to ethnic Russian immigrant parents, naturalized citizen of Estonia in 2008, member of the Estonian Centre Party, has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 1 July 2014, representing the Estonia constituency, previously a member of the Riigikogu from 4 April 2011 to 1 July 2014, and Deputy Mayor of Tallinn from 2010 to 2011, currently serving on the Committee on Petitions and the Committee on Regional Development, previously on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and coordinator on the Committee on Culture and Education, part of the parliament's delegation to the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee, member of the European Parliament Intergroups on Artificial Intelligence and Digital, Extreme Poverty and Human Rights, and Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages, re-elected in 2019, elected to the Riigikogu in 2023, has been involved in controversies including a 2016 visit to Damascus to meet Bashar Al-Assad and financing legal aid expenses for Russian stateless persons deported from Estonia in 2023.

Yannick Jadot, a French environmental activist and politician, born on 27 July 1967 in Clacy-et-Thierret, France. He holds a degree from Paris Dauphine University and is currently in a relationship with Isabelle Saporta. Jadot was a member of The Greens from 1999 to 2010 and later joined The Ecologists in 2010. He worked as a campaign director for Greenpeace France from 2002 to 2008 and headed the Alliance pour la planète. Jadot was elected to the European Parliament in 2009, representing West France until 2019 and then France until 2023. He served on the Committee on International Trade from 2009 to 2019 and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since 2019. Jadot was a candidate in the 2017 French presidential election but withdrew and endorsed Benoît Hamon. He ran again in the 2022 French presidential election, receiving 4.6% of the vote. Jadot was elected as a Senator for Paris in the 2023 Senate election, taking office on 2 October 2023. He has authored the book "Climat, la guerre de l'ombre" in 2014 and has proposed implementing a "bonus/malus" system on all taxation.

Ioannis Lagos, a Greek politician, was born on September 7, 1972, in Piraeus, Greece. He is a convicted criminal and far-right politician who served as a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for Greece from July 2, 2019, to July 16, 2024. Lagos was initially a member of the neo-Nazi ultranationalist party Golden Dawn but announced he would sit as an independent MEP in 2019. He later founded the splinter party National Popular Consciousness on November 9, 2019, and led it until its dissolution on February 10, 2023. Lagos also served as a member of the Hellenic Parliament for the Piraeus B constituency from May 6, 2012, until his election as an MEP. He was found guilty of running Golden Dawn, orchestrating the fatal stabbing of Pavlos Fyssas, and other violent attacks, resulting in a 13-year prison sentence. Lagos has been involved in anti-Turkish actions, including tearing down the Turkish flag at the European Parliament. He voted against condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine on March 2, 2022. Lagos' parliamentary immunity was lifted on April 27, 2021, making him eligible for extradition to Greece.

Younous Omarjee, a French politician, born on 30 September 1969 in Saint-Denis, Réunion, France. He is affiliated with La France insoumise and Alliance of the Overseas. Omarjee has been a Member of the European Parliament for France, representing the Overseas Territories of France constituency, since 4 January 2012. He has chaired the European Parliament Committee on Regional Development since July 2019. Omarjee is also a member of several committees and intergroups, including the European Parliament Committee on Budgets, the European Parliament Committee on Budgetary Control, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup, the European Parliament Intergroup on LGBT Rights, the European Parliament Intergroup on the Welfare and Conservation of Animals, and the URBAN Intergroup. He has been educated at Pantheon-Sorbonne University and works as a politician. On 16 July 2024, Omarjee was elected as Vice-President of the European Parliament, serving alongside others under President Roberta Metsola.

Zbigniew Kuźmiuk, a Polish politician, was born on 19 September 1956 in Komorowo, Poland. He holds a Master of Economics degree from Kielce University of Technology (1979) and a Doctor of Economics degree from Warsaw School of Planning and Statistics (now the Warsaw School of Economics). Kuźmiuk is married to Danuta Kuźmiuk and has three children (two sons and a daughter). He has been a member of the United People's Party (1986-1989), the Polish People's Party (1989-2006), and Law and Justice (2009-present). Kuźmiuk has held various positions including: Member of the European Parliament (2004-2009, 2014-2023), Member of Parliament of the Republic of Poland (2001-2004), Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Local Self-Government and Regional Policy, Chairman of the Polish People's Party parliamentary party, Voivode of Radom (1994-1996), Minister and Chairman of the State Centre for Strategic Studies (1997), Councillor of the Masovian Voivodeship (1998-2001), and Marshal of the Masovian Voivodeship (1999-2001). He has received the Knight's Cross of the Order of Poland Reborn.

Zdzisław Marek Krasnodębski, born 11 April 1953 in Choszczno, Poland, is a Polish sociologist, social philosopher, publicist, and professor. He graduated from the Faculty of Philosophy and Sociology at the University of Warsaw in 1976, obtained a PhD at the University of Warsaw in 1984, and earned a post-doctoral degree in 1991. He taught sociology, social theory, and philosophy at the University of Warsaw, was a professor at the University of Kassel, and has been a professor at the University of Bremen since 1995. He is also an associate professor at the Cardinal Stefan Wyszyński University in Warsaw and the Akademia Ignatianum in Cracow. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since 2014, representing the Law and Justice party, and was Vice President of the European Parliament.

Ádám Kósa, a Hungarian politician, born on July 1, 1975, in Budapest, Hungary, is a member of Fidesz and the European Parliament representing Hungary since July 1, 2014, notable for being the first deaf European politician to use Deaf Sign Language at the European Parliament.

Álvaro dos Santos Amaro, born May 25, 1953, in Coimbra, Portugal, is a member of the Social Democratic Party. He served as Member of the European Parliament for Portugal from July 2, 2019, to July 6, 2023. Amaro was part of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly delegation. He was previously Mayor of Gouveia from December 16, 2001, to September 29, 2013, and Mayor of Guarda from September 29, 2013, to April 16, 2019. Amaro also held the office of Secretary of State for Agriculture from August 17, 1987, to October 28, 1995, and was a member of the Portuguese parliament from October 1, 1995, to December 16, 2001, representing the Guarda constituency. He was involved in several investigations, including the Rota Final case, and was charged with malfeasance and fraud in obtaining EU funds. Amaro was sentenced to 3.5 years in prison, suspended by a fine of 25,000€, and stepped down as MEP in 2023.

Éric Andrieu, a French politician from the Socialist Party, born on 14 April 1960 in Narbonne, France. Served as a Member of the European Parliament for France from 16 May 2012 to 1 June 2023. Member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (2012-2022) and the Committee on Development (2022-2023). Served on the Special Committee on the Union's authorisation procedure for pesticides (2018). Rapporteur on the common organisation of agricultural markets (2020). Vice-chair of the S&D Group (2019-2021). Joined a group of lawmakers urging leaders not to support Arctic LNG 2 due to climate change concerns (2021). Supported Anne Hidalgo as the Socialists’ candidate in the 2022 presidential elections and endorsed Olivier Faure's re-election as party chairman in 2023.

Éric Minardi, a French politician born on 18 March 1956 in Toulon, is a member of the National Rally party. He served as a Member of the European Parliament for the France constituency from 28 July 2022 to 15 July 2024, succeeding Joëlle Mélin. Minardi briefly led the Te Nati Rassemblement national polynésien party before withdrawing it from Hau Ma'ohi on 16 March 2023.

Özlem Alev Demirel-Böhlke, born 10 March 1984 in Malatya, Turkey, to a Kurdish family of Alevi faith, and migrated to Germany at the age of 5. She is a Turkish-born German politician of Kurdish descent, holding citizenship in both Germany and Turkey. Demirel-Böhlke is married since 2011 and has two children. She graduated from high school in 2004 and studied political sciences and history at the University of Bonn. Demirel-Böhlke is a member of The Left party since 2007, previously being a member of the Party of Democratic Socialism from 2004 to 2007. She was the leading candidate of The Left's electoral campaign to the European Parliament in 2019 and was elected as a Member of the European Parliament on 24 May 2019. In the European Parliament, she serves as vice chair of the Subcommittee on Security and Defence and the Delegation to the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee. Demirel-Böhlke was involved in the youth section of the Democratic Workers Union at the age of 15 and became the DIDF Chairwoman in 2012. She led The Left in the campaign to the State Parliament of Nord Rhine-Westphalia in 2017. Demirel-Böhlke voted against a resolution condemning the Russian invasion of Ukraine and calling for the arming of Ukraine in 2022, and signed the Feminist Resistance Against War: A Manifesto in solidarity with the Feminist Anti-War Resistance initiated by Russian feminists.

Łukasz Marcin Kohut, a Polish politician, born on 10 September 1982 in Katowice, Poland. He has been a Member of the European Parliament since the 2019 elections, representing the Poland constituency. His party affiliations include New Left (2021-2024) and Independent (since 2024) in Poland, and Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (since 2019) in the EU. He has also been associated with The Left (2019-2024) and Civic Coalition (since 2024) in Poland. Kohut serves on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (since 2020), and the Committee of Inquiry to investigate the use of Pegasus and equivalent surveillance spyware (since 2022). He is part of the parliament's delegations to the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee, for relations with Switzerland and Norway, the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the European Economic Area (EEA) Joint Parliamentary Committee. Kohut is also a member of the European Parliament Intergroup on Western Sahara, the European Parliament Intergroup on Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages, and the URBAN Intergroup.

Željana Zovko, a Croatian and Bosnian diplomat and politician, was born on 25 March 1970, in Mostar, SR Bosnia and Herzegovina, SFR Yugoslavia. She studied French language at the University of North London. Zovko has dual citizenship of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia, and her nationality is Croatian. She is a member of the Croatian Democratic Union of Bosnia and Herzegovina (HDZ BiH) and the Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ). Zovko has been serving as a member of the European Parliament from Croatia since 21 November 2016. She previously worked as an associate for public relations for the Croat member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, head of the cabinet for the Croat member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and as the resident ambassador of Bosnia and Herzegovina to France, Spain, and Italy. Zovko has served on several committees in the European Parliament, including the Committee on Development, Committee on Foreign Affairs, and Subcommittee on Security and Defence. She has also been a member of various delegations, including the Delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo, and the Delegation to the Euro-Latin American Parliamentary Assembly. Zovko has been awarded the Grand Cross of the Order of Military Merit by King Juan Carlos I in 2012.

Ioan-Rareș Bogdan MEP (born 17 September 1974 in Ocna Mureș, Alba County, Romania) is a conservative Romanian politician who has been a PNL member of the European Parliament for Romania since 2019. He was the leader of the National Liberal Party's electoral list for the 2019 elections. He sits with the European People's Party group (EPP for short). He self-identifies as a Christian-conservative and nationalist.

Aušra Seibutytė-Maldeikienė (born 4 June 1958) is a Lithuanian political economist, politician, lecturer, teacher, publicist and book author. In 2019 she was elected to the European Parliament,[1] having previously sat as a member of the Seimas (Lithuanian Parliament) since 2016 and Vilnius City Council (2015–2016).

Jan Ovelgönne (born 30 June 1975) is a German politician of Alliance 90/The Greens, who served as a Member of the European Parliament from 12 March to 15 July 2024.[1] Born in Volkach, Bavaria, and resident in Arnsberg, North Rhine-Westphalia, he was 24th in his party's list for the 2019 European Parliament election in Germany.[2]

Nikos Papandreou (Greek: Νίκος Παπανδρέου; born 29 September 1956) is a Greek politician, businessman, cultural commentator and writer. He has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for PASOK since May 2023.[1] He replaced Nikos Androulakis who resigned in order to run in the 2023 Greek legislative election.[2]

Catherine Amalric (born 19 October 1964 in Aurillac) is a French medical doctor[1] and politician of the Radical Party who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2023. She replaced Véronique Trillet-Lenoir.[2]
Laurence Sailliet (born 1 March 1973) is a French politician from The Republicans who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament since 2023.[1] She replaced Agnès Evren.
Lydie Massard (born 24 August 1978) is a French politician of the Breton Democratic Union who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament from 2023 to 2024.[1] She replaced Yannick Jadot.

Michael Kauch (born 4 May 1967, in Dortmund) is a German politician of the Free Democratic Party who served as a Member of the European Parliament in 2024 and as a Member of the Bundestag between 2003 and 2013.
